content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												Overall, I had to say that I enjoyed playing this game. When I first started it, I was encountering some crashes but someone's suggestion on the forum quickly cleared up anything and I never saw a crash since. Regarding the gameplay, I enjoyed it. The combat did feel grittier than a Souls game, and I like how the magic in this game was much more 'supportive' rather than primary, as it can be in a Souls game (as an aside, I feel like magic ruined Dark Souls 2, but that's just an aside). The boss designs were decent--they could use improvement, but I did enjoy some of them. I also did enjoy all of the little details they put in the game, like different ways to defeat bosses, different ending paths based on choices (which did seem a little hardboiled at times but was still a nice effort none the less). The only thing that frustrated me from time to time was the level design, which seemed labyrinthine.There's lots of weapons in this game, and plenty of loot. The armor and weapon design were all decent.All in all, is it "Souls-like"? Yes, it is. Do I care? No. It's not like Dark Souls was the first Action RPG. Is it a fun game? Yes, yes it is. Do I hope they make another one and improve upon the first? Yes.I think what sometimes people forget, especially with original titles is that to criticize it needlessly and blast it with negative reviews, and to make statements such as "don't support this publisher", will ultimately lead to less variety, innovation, and entertainment. This is not a defense of bad games, but it is a defense of "improvement". If they make another, and I hope they do, I hope they can improve the formula, add some additional features that make it interesting and continue to innovate on this extremely fun genre. The more the merrier, I say.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												Lords of the Fallen gets a lot of things right, but is also blasted by many people for not being as polished as Dark Souls, or for even trying to be like Dark Souls.  Wherever you stand on that issue, I personally think the expansion of that sort of gameplay into a proper genre is good for business overall.  I want more games like Dark/Demons Souls, not less.If you can get over the fact that yes, the game is very similar to the Souls titles, I think you'll find it to be quite a good game.  It lacks some of the bells and whistles of the Souls titles, such as the persistent and interesting multiplayer found in those games, but I believe it totally nails the combat, and is absolutely packed with secrets, both of which are some of the top reasons I enjoy the Souls games.The story is a lot more straightforward than those titles (Sorry for all the comparisons, but the genre is still in its infancy and there isn't much else to compare it to, and this game wears its inspirations on its shoulders.) which can be both good and bad.  Good because you have a fairly clear motivation, bad because, well, let's face it, the voice acting is pretty mediocre and the talking animations and lip synching are actually kind of embarassingly bad.  Characters gesticulate wildly when saying the simplest things, all while retaining their stiff, wooden, doll-like faces and flapping mouths.The stilted facial expressions clash furiously with the rest of the visuals, which have a distinct Warhammer (read: big shoulder pads, intricate armor, you know whether you enjoy that style or not.  I do, but you may not.) feel that is very consistent.  Having a very solid art style and beautiful technical work and then seeing Playstation 2-level facial animations is jarring to say the least.  It's not too big of a deal, but they put it in there, so I figured I'd give my two cents.  Also I feel it prudent to remind people that while the Souls games had decent voice acting, the characters rarely ever moved at all while talking and mouths never seemed to move at all, so, uhh, just throwing that out there.So, let's talk about gameplay.  This game is said to be easier than the Souls games.  I never found those games to be particularly difficult so much as games that forced you to be patient.  Few fights ever required a high degree of dexterity, just that you observe and wait for an opening.  I think this game handles that just right.  But I warn you: If you're looking for a challenge, choose something besides the Warrior play style.  That class is a lot like the spell-casting class (Noble, was it?) in Demons Souls, where it was basically an easy mode for new players.  Try weird weapons, if you feel too tanky, wear super light armor.  I say these things because if you want the game to be difficult, then the default selections are not for you.The game has fairly lengthy attack animations, longer than the Souls games in many cases, but it also has a bigger impact.  With my great hammer during a well-placed attack I can physically knock enemies across the room, and when it strikes the ground the sound design and visual effects really sell that I'm swinging a huge, deadly weapon and that it is not to be trifled with, but it also takes timing and understanding of each type of swing at my disposal.  I can out-poise some enemies if I wear heavy armor and just swing through it, or to challenge myself I can wear very light armor and rely on timing above all else.Enemies do have a bit of cheapness to them occasionally.  Not all hitboxes are perfect, you can get hit by attacks that appear to miss you by several inches, and sometimes enemies do a very familiar Dark Souls move of "sliding" forward at the end of an attack to force it to connect, which feels just as cheap here as it did in the Souls games.  Luckily, both of these problems are fairly rare and tend to be limited to just a few enemy types -- and thankfully after encountering them a few times I didn't seem to notice it happening anymore.  Shouldn't be there to begin with, but not as big of a deal as I thought it would be after the first few times it happened.I want to take a moment to warn you that I don't play these types of games quite the same way I think most people do.  I played a ton of Monster Hunter before I first played a Souls game, so I tend to rarely ever use the lock-on here.  I don't really circle-strafe enemies to fish for backstabs and I don't have many issues with the camera that allegedly appear due to what I assume is locking on in such tight quarters.  If you use lock-on for extended periods, you'll have to get that info elsewhere, as I can't provide you relevant critique on it.Of course, while it borrows from the Souls series, it also has its own little twists that I think are genuinely interesting that may help push the genre forward.  The ideas themselves aren't mind-blowing, but stuff like the experience multiplier for going longer without banking your experience is fantastic, as well as the experience degrading the longer you take to retrieve it after death.  To me, these are pure upgrades to the soul retrieval system in the Souls games, hands-down.  I hope this inspires future games in the genre to think of cool additions as well.I had quite a bit more to say, but this is getting very long for a Steam review.  So I'll wrap it up and give my conclusion:  Is this game as polished or as in-depth as the Souls series?  No.  Is it some blasphemy to the genre that you should be offended by?  Absolutely not.  It's a great game, marred right now by some technical problems (I knew I forgot something!  The game is crash-prone at the time of this review and while performance on my Titan Black is fine, on plenty of other rigs it's all over the place.  Check the updates to see if they fix that stuff in a timely fashion.) but once everything is ironed out I absolutely recommend it to any fan of the Souls series if they want more of that style of gameplay, or people intimidated by the Souls games' obtuseness.  This is a good gateway game to those titles.  Don't be an elitist, games like this will push the genre forward, not destroy or harm it!  That's my take on it, at least.  I heartily recommend this!

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												Rating - 81/100Recommendation - Worth looking at, just don't expect Dark SoulsDisclaimer 1: Lots of people talk about crashing, but I had literally zero problems. I don't know if I'm super lucky or if issues have been patched, but I can't deduct points for problems I didn't have. Just be warned.Disclaimer 2: This game is not Dark Souls. If you're expecting Dark Souls, you'll be disappointed. If you're hoping for Dark Souls, you'll be disappointed. THAT BEING SAID, I will be doing comparisons to how Dark Souls works since it's probably the frame of reference most people will be coming from.I liked this game a LOT more than I was expecting to. Reviews for it were pretty terrible at first, and are only mediocre now, but the only thing I can think of to cause that is people coming in here with a mentality of "let's see how different it is from Dark Souls." It's clear from the get-go that the developers were trying to capitalize on a formula made prominent by the Souls games, but please try to judge this game of its own accord rather than compared to the genre juggernauts.Right off the bat, Souls players should feel comfortable. Combat is mostly focused on patience and energy (stamina) conservation, knowing when to block/dodge/strike, etc. Jumping in and flailing will get you ripped to shreds, and studying your enemies attack patterns = success. Killing enemies gives you experience, which you can use to level up attributes or spells at shards (save points). However, unlike the Souls games, using a shard doesn't respawn enemies in the world (that only happens when you die or leave the zone), but rather resets your experience multiplier. As you kill enemies, your experience multiplier increases, giving you a reward for taking risks and saving less often. When you die, you drop all your experience, and unlike the Souls games, you have a limited amount of time to pick it back up again before it vanishes. I liked the system a lot. It's a mild evolution on a formula, but it introduced just enough to keep things interesting.There's some frustration with combat, though. It's inconsistent and unreliable what attacks will break an enemy's guard, and even when you do, their shields are back up before you're even mid-swing. Harkyn (you), on the other hand, seems to get stunned for 8 seconds. It's frustrating. Fights with shield enemies are either shoot-from-afar-with-my-gauntlet or block-their-hit-and-hit-back-until-death. Plus, hit detection is not perfect. I had a not-insignificant number of sword swings and gauntlet shots that simply passed right through enemies. It wasn't a rampant problem, but it should NEVER happen.Story-wise, I actually liked this game a lot more than Dark Souls (I welcome your knee-jerk reaction downvotes). A huge part of Dark Souls' mystique and whatnot comes from a complete lack of communication with the player. Lords of the Fallen is not that game. You have objectives (story quests only), the world is laid out more linearly, and while your hand is never held, the difficulty in the game is in achieving objectives rather than figuring out what to do AND THEN doing it. The story is serviceable, and moves around enough to be interesting, but it's nothing groundbreaking.I think this game actually serves as a good halfway step between standard RPGs and Dark Souls. The difficulty is more approachable, as is the game world itself. You have a mission objective, but no map or direction markers, and side quests are never tracked at all, so it's up to you to remember where people/things are. I loved it. It still left some of the questing burden on me, but I never got that "oooookay, what do I do now?" feeling. You're told to "fight to the top of the citadel" but then left to your own devices.Hardcore Souls players might be turned off by that type of gameplay, but I welcomed it. No getting your intestines ripped out through your nostrils right away in the catacombs here. Don't get me wrong, this game is still difficult, but I had an easier time here than in the Souls games. I can't say for sure that it's because Lords of the Fallen is easier, since it's just as likely that playing through Dark Souls, Demon's Souls, Dark Souls 2, and then Dark Souls again prepared me for this one. New players be warned, this is not an easy game. You can't really wander into an area you're not supposed to be yet, though, so there is that.The world itself is not all that large (maybe half the size of Dark Souls), and there's a bit of backtracking, but it never feels all that repetitive. Enemies in certain areas will change and grow stronger as you play through the main story, so the parts where you do have to backtrack are at least interesting again. To be honest, most of the backtracking was due to side quests, which can be completely ignored. Fair warning, too, I did grind a bit (probably 4 or 5 hours' worth), but that's just because I wanted to try higher gear. I can't say for sure that it's necessary, although it did help.Speaking of gear, this is one of the game's weak points. The armor sets and weapons look beautiful, and they're almost all beefy and chunky, but all of the classes end up being built the same way. I picked the Cleric class (the healing spell is FANTASTIC) and built my character for speed, but could have doubled as a tank. By the end of the game, my regular sword (there's shortswords, swords, then greatswords) did more damage than all but 2 of my great-weapons, and swung faster. I had all but one spell level unlocked (there's 4 spells per class, each with 3 levels), and enough strength/stamina/poise to withstand direct hits from the final boss with no damage. I honestly can't see how building solely as a warrior would have been that much stronger.I suppose that's another thing I liked about this game, though. In Dark Souls, even though I played as a tanky build, I always felt extremely weak, even right up to the end. In Lords of the Fallen, however, I really got a sense of how strong I became. Maybe it's because it's easier and quicker to backtrack and fight early enemies, but it felt quite a bit more apparent what effect all that leveling up had.Overall, I legitimately enjoyed my time here. The graphics are fantastic, the game world is beautifully-designed (even if you are in gothic castles 98% of the time), combat is satisfyingly meaty, the enemies are varied and interesting, the bosses are a decent challenge (they all have hidden bonus objectives too), and aside from a few small glitches, the gameplay was rock-solid.If you come in to this game not expecting it to perfectly fill a Souls-shaped hole in your heart (and you have no crashing issues), you should enjoy it too. I thoroughly did, and I could easily see myself coming back to this game for another playthrough later.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												Short Version: Is it worth playing? YES. Is it worth the full price? HELL NO!Long Version:(WARNING: I will compare this game to Darksouls games a lot since it's obvious that it tries to mimic it's mechanisms and gameplay style.)PROS: 1. Semi-Darksouls action combat - If you like the way Darksouls I & II handles combat chances are, you'll probably like the way this game handles it as well. The difference is that the combat in Darksouls is faster and more flashy.           2. Beautiful Graphics - Although the graphics are brilliant and beautiful (scenery, armor, weapons, you name it...) some of them are a bit "samey". (More on that in CONS)           3. The story - Unlike Darksouls where you have to scrape the story from item descriptions and where most of it you decide and invent for yourself, the story here is way more accessible. You are a convicted criminal whose crimes are tattooed on your face and your mission is to redeem yourself by destroying a fallen god. Sounds fun! There are more hidden lore bits found out from the few NPCs and much more numerous log files.            4. Performance - I only played the game after the latest patch and can confirm that on my system (i5 3,5 GHz, Nvidia 770GTX, 16GB ram, SSD disk, every graphics setting maxed out) the game held a stable 60fps 99% of the time with maybe 2-3 times dropping to 45-50 FPS and only on specific places.            5. Bugs - with the recent patches most have been squashed. Haven't really noticed any during my gameplay.            6. Game Mechanics - There is a risk-reward system implemented in the game that works really well. The more enemies you slay before resting at a checkpoint the more it increases your exp. multiplier which in turn increases the exp. gain from other enemies. But if you are killed, that exp. will slowly drain away until you either collect it back or it drains completely. The only real big difference from the darksouls games.MEH: 1. Difficulty - Harder than most games, way easier then Darksouls II. To be honest I was expecting a more challenging game, but I guess this decision makes the game appeal to a broader audience.          2. Enemy variations - too little variations. Same enemy models reused through the game. Most of the bosses resemble ordinary units only bigger in size.          3. Customization - Oh my GOD. Everyone is overusing steroids in this game. From the main character to the lowliest mob. Want to role-play a squishy mage? Nope, here's a mage that bench presses 200 kg. Want to play as a sleek and agile rogue? Nope, here's a rogue with 140 kg of muscle. I prefer the big warrior class but to have the option to at least customize the face and a few sliders wouldn't hurt the game one bit.CONS:  1. Lack of NPCs - There are maybe 3 worthwhile NPCs in the whole game.             2. Dialogue - The dialogue with the said 3 NPCs is sometimes strange and somewhat out of place.             3. Replay value - Whereas I've played Darksouls I and II with multiple characters for months, After I finished this game, I'll probably finish it once more from the beginning this time trying to get all the collectables and the special weapons from the bosses. After that I'll probably delete the game never to play it again.            4. Game duration - It's too short. It took me probably 15 hours to finish.            5. "Samey" world design - Remember how in Darksouls you have very distinct and different environments? Well there's no such thing in Lords. The whole game is one big dungeon and castle interiors mixed with a bit of snowy exterior. It looks great but it's the same most of the game. And since it's all interconnected (something I like very much, reminds me of how Darksouls I handled it's world and shortcuts to bonefires) it results in being lost quite often, trying to find how to progress further into the game (something I hate very much).Overall Score: 6.5/10Verdict: Buy the game if you are a darksouls fan, but get it when it's on discount.

Posted: November 23, 2014
												Took me 20 hours.In the 20 hours, I have:- never had a single crash- never seen a single bug- never had a single framedropWhat I did have was a great fun. It is an easier game than Dark Souls (I finished both DS games), I finished most bosses pretty quickly. And yeah bosses are not as memorable as in DS games, mostly consisting of humanoid knights. But they were fun to fight anyway.The level design is pretty good. I enjoyed exploring it and the graphics is amazing (played maxed, but without nvidia turbulence stuff since I have AMD 280X).Considering the likely low budget and zero experience of the developers with this kind of game, I am super impressed with what they achieved and I hope they will keep this quality and improve upon in for the future games.If there are some nitpicks..I did not like many invisible walls, and I am still not fan of the art style. I do not hate it, but I do prefer more realistic style of Witcher / DS games. This is subjective though.As for the Denuovo anti-tamper, I had zero issues with it. Would never know it is there if it wasn't for the internet making a huge fuss of everything.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Lords of the Fallen is a third person action-role-playing game with heavy emphasis on melee combat mechanics and tactics.The Great:- Melee combat is exceptional and some of the best in the industry- Significant weapon variety that leads to numerous differing yet satisfying playstyles- Each weapon's unique playstyle feels great and is fun to experiment with- Combat is timing and pattern based making each encounter important and fulfilling to complete- Game is gorgeous to look at even with details turned downThe Good:- Environments are beautiful and intricately crafted (if a little small)- Enemy and boss designs are interesting and show creativityThe Bad:- The story is forgettable, confusing at times and makes little sense given the scope of the game- The side characters feel tacked on, tropish, and overall of little value or consequence- The main character is meant to be a jerk, and there are few options to choose not to be a jerk- I experienced several game-crashing bugs over 25+ hoursConclusion:The game is buggy, and the writing of the characters and story leaves much to be desired, but the combat in both its precision and variety is able to save this game from the trash pile and ultimately make it one of the best RPGs of the year.9.0 / 10.0

												I played this game with low expectations since there are so many negative reviews. But you know what, I had a lot of fun and the game is surprisingly good.It's not as good as DS2. Lords of the Fallen is much shorter, easier (specially towards the end), cliche story, a few problems in its battle mechanics, but definitely not as bad as some people have been writting.I have to say I bought this game in a 75% off steam sales, but I'd say it is worth even at 50%.Give it a go if you enjoyed Dark Souls and Dark Souls2, just don't expect the same level of game!

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												TLDR: Overall, moments of entertainment locked behind odd design choices and unresolved glitches that makes it impossible to recommend.EDIT: And I feel bad for not being able to recommend it because I did have some good fun and effort was clearly made.First the good: -The character/monster/environment designs are well done, it's all massive muscles, massive armour and massive weapons but if you don't mind that it's nicely done.-When the combat works, it can be fun.The mixed (subjective):-The armour sets are well designed, as mentioned above, but the standard as you go through set progression is inconsistent. For light armour for example, you get the best designed armour about half way through then get sets that seem much more 'vanilla' or are (I believe) reskins of previous sets.-The story isn't terrible, but I'm still unsure about the premise. Why exactly is Adyr the god considered a 'villain'? I may have missed an audio log that explains this, but then it is still missable.-There is a universal cooldown on spells, use one and they all go on cd (at least the ones from the same school do, can't verify whether it applies to other schools). On some combinations this may make sense, on others it seems overly restrictive. Keep in mind that without massive xp investment into faith (magic), the mana cost of each spell is likely prohibitive of chain casting anyway. Not impossible mind you, but when you factor in the cast time of each spell and the likelihood of interruption by enemy hits, a gcd seems superfluous.-Combat staggering seemed unpredictable across the board, both on you and the enemies. There seemed no way of knowing ahead of time whether Harkyn would get staggered by any given enemy's attacks or whether they would be staggered by his.-Certain classes may seem underpowered, mileage may vary. Rogue class definitely could have used some life steal baked in to a spell.-Majority of voice work is bland, not all but a lot of it.-The rune/crafting system seemed inconsistent. The game features a system where you can invest xp into locked runes  to increase the likelihood of better quality buffs but the return on this seemed very disappointing. Possibly rectified with better 'Luck' character stats but that's uncertain.The bad:-The hit detection is suspect. Weapon strikes simply may decide not to land, spell hits may just not register.-Enemy projectiles may not hit you when they should and may seek you out through walls.-Equipment stats are confusing. You are given numbers without context. Conversely some items have only 'fluff' descriptions.-The camera may decide to snap to a completely obscured perspective during 'backstabs'.-Spell effects may also overwhelm your vision.-The gauntlet is intrusive and frequently redundant. It seemed underpowered no matter which class or loadout was used, an enemy could always be reached to melee them anyway, using it costs mana that would 9 times out of 10 be better used on spell casting and it is unalterably bound to the stance swapping button which gets in the way during combat.-The physics are unbelievable in a bad way. Enemies may do a U-turn mid leap, defying momentum. The enemy also has a bad habit of tracking your motion during weapon swings that would likely snap their bones, also rendering combat maneuvering futile. This becomes more of a problem with the more fragile classes.-Pathing is incompetent. Enemies may get stuck on corners or non existent obstacles, may reset and speed off to their original point (no, not that one demon dog who is scripted to do something similar).-Harkyn's magic is wildly unreliable. Magic may simply not do what it is supposed to. Direct damage spells may just not land despite hitting the mark. Buffs may drop off before their proper duration or not do as described. Bad pathing also applies here.-Even after hours of play time, the cumbersome nature of the spell casting can still be infuriating. Enemy AI is unreliable as to attacking during casting, they may knock you out of it or stand there and wait. A hit the wrong side of a millisecond may interrupt a 'complete' cast.-Controls are unreliable, Harkyn may simply ignore commands. The most frequent suspect for me was the running shield bash attack, it simply didn't happen about 40% of the time and would land Harkyn in hot water each time. Dodges may simply not occur either.-Saves may not be complete, by which I mean you can save your progress at a checkpoint or even move to a new area and quit and when you reload, the game may simply not have saved to that point. On a whim.-Desktop crashes. Frequent and exacerbated by the above problem.

content:
Posted: February 3
												I decided to write a review of this game because most of the recent reviews are from people who have barely played the game (some haven't even completed the game) with very little achievement progress. I have spent almost 200 hours playing this game, and have earned every achievement. This may go without "saying", but I'll "say" it anyway: I'm going to attempt to chronicle my way through this game and the process I used to learn about the mechanics and what I found frustrating. I used an XBox 1 controller, so button references will be made accordingly.Firstly, the game crashes. A lot. I did some research and the general consensus seems to be that one must disable "NVIDIA Turbulence". That didn't work for me, so I also disabled "Volumetric Lighting" and "Postprocessing" and that seemed to have worked.My first playthrough was with the rogue class, whose weapons are governed by the agility trait, which, in my opinion, is disgustingly OP. Part of a rogue's special ability is having a weapon in each hand, which can be strung together into a combo. I used LB, RB, LB, RT, LT a lot. By the end of the game (level 67) I was doing around 1k damage with "claw" weapons, at 28 agility, per combo. The other ability, which the rogue can do from the start, and which other classes can do later, is parry.There are 3 shield types, Tower, Kite, and Buckler. Bucklers are used to parry, Kite shields can stun enemies, and Tower shields can reinforce blocking. I've come to the conclusion that tower shields are useless. I began by spending the first few hours learning to parry, which can be overwhelming because I was getting hit. A lot. Which became frustrating. I stuck with it and realized the timing window for parrying is quite large. Gauging an enemy's attack is quite intuitive, which made parrying a lot easier. Definitely a plus for this game. If you decide to get this game, parrying is worth investing the time to learn. Be aware, however, that while every class can use the starting buckler, you have to invest in the agility trait to use the other bucklers, which are much better, found later in the game. The trade-off for a large parry window, at least as far as game mechanics are concerned, is a very small and awkward back-stab activation hit-box. Every enemy has a different hit-box zone and keeping track can become tedious. The other issue with backstabbing is, if you miss the back-stab and are using larger, heavier weapon, you won't recover in-time to block or evade the enemy's attack. This, by itself, isn't a problem, as the rewards with backstabbing is great, and so too must be the risk, but because of the awkward back-stab hit-box, the risk is artificially inflated.My second playthrough was with the cleric class, whose weapons are governed by the faith trait. I had a lot of fun with this class because most of the weapons available to this class are "hammers" and they're so fun to use in this game because of the move list. Two-handed power moves and rolling away was the strategy I employed for most of the end-game, especially the final boss. I didn't use the kite shield that often because I spent so much time learning to parry, so as soon I found the buckler, I switched to that. I found that fighting most enemies without the ability to parry their attacks became tedious; it was really difficult to fight around their shields or deal with their attacks. One of the major downsides of this game is that enemy attacks track you through the full attack animation, so the only option with rolling is to roll backward. If you try to roll to either side, the camera glitches out and you end up rolling around the enemy, directly into the attack. Another "interesting" mechanic is that enemies, especially bosses, will teleport in the direction of their attack, giving them added range, which, to me, is sloppy programming.My third playthrough was with the warrior class, whose weapons are governed by the strength trait. This was the most difficult playthrough for me. The warrior class uses heavy armor and sits at about 95% of his encumbrance which means your character will be "fat rolling". Of course, rolling isn't necessary, because, with heavy armor, your character will just poise through attacks without interruption. This didn't happen as often as I would have liked, since most attacks will interrupt your attacks, even from weaker enemies. The weapons were the most frustrating, as the start-up and recovery frames from attacks are extremely long. I found myself unable to recovery in-time to avoid enemy attacks, so I had to use smaller weapons to keep from depleting my potions (you can refill your potions at anytime at checkpoint crystals and you can add to the total amount of potions you have, but this resets your experience multiplier, which caps at x2), which, to me, defeated the purpose of the warrior class entirely. I couldn't "roll" out of the way or block because, with these heavier weapons, the majority of your energy (stamina) is used, especially if you do a power move (RT).The story is quite vapid. Without spoiling anything, the player isn't told why the protagonist is doing what he is doing. The protagonist doesn't seem to buy into the story and we're left wondering if we ought to ourselves. Dialogue choices are also frustrating as some options will advance the story but we don't know which. My first playthrough was riddled with accidental story advancement when I wanted to learn more about what was going on around me and why. No take backs in this game.There isn't a quest selection option either. All secondary quests are done when you remember to do them. You won't know when or how to trigger each side quest either. For this, I highly recommend browsing the wiki: http://lordsofthefallen.wiki.fextralife.com/QuestsSome enemy's attacks, I would argue all enemies, don't have recovery frames, something I've noticed with western studios. This means that there isn't a buffer between the end of one attack and the beginning of another. An enemy can go right into another attack as soon as the previous attack frames end. Your character, on the other hand, has recovery frames. Which means there will be a pause between attack animations. This is a personal pet-peeve. I had fun with this game, but I recommend purchasing it during a steam sale. Like most games, it was released before the game was complete and the game won't be updated beyond 1.6 even though there are obvious issues with it. $28 for the base game and the DLC is way too much for a game in this state.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Updated with more structure.Why I wrote this rant:It sucks to know so many people are being turned away from this game due to the top review (which isn't the top review now, but it was at the time of writing this) being so negative. I read through the entire review, and came to the conclusion that the guy didn't like the game, felt like he wasted $50 bucks, and decided to write his first review on a good game that he couldn't grasp around what it actually is, in oppose to what he wanted it to be, and it's turning away many people from it. I was almost one of them, but all I could read was someone complaining about everything that this game is suppose to be. So, I picked it up, I have logged 8 hours into it, and I think, personally, he was wrong, but those are his opinions.Combat & controls rant:This game is great, and it has very fluid tight gameplay that beats that of the Souls series. And if you played the Souls games you'll feel at home with the controls for Lords. I'm currently playing as a brawler. So I'm heavily focused on heavy CQC. You got a heavy attack, light attack, parry, block, barrel roll, and all the cool stuff like catching the little♥♥♥♥♥♥in an epic attack animation by catching him from behind. Attacking is damn near perfect, and every weapon I have used so far holds its own weight, and requires you to change up your strategy because one heavy weapon might be heavier than the other, and that might prolong the hit giving the enemy more time to counter. The lighter the weapon, the faster the hit, but the cost is of course dealing less damage, but giving you more reaction time is always a positive. Blocking actually feels like blocking, and to my surprise blocking while two-handing a weapon isn't going to screw you over. The hitboxes are on point, and you aren't left questioning how you're caught on a hit even though you are not in the line of attack.Magic rant:This game of course uses its share of magic, but I feel like it is a bit limited depending on the class you initialing picked. I am a brawler so I have four magic spells: Prayer: You bring out a clone to divert the enemies attention while restoring some health over time.Rage: Gives you more attack power, and removes energy restrictions. Ram: Unleash a strong charging force that damages, staggers, and can knock down enemies.Quake: Giant hammer that comes down and wrecks face.Each spell is very useful depending on the situation, and can really save your♥♥♥♥♥ I don't really have much input on the spells really because I'm still on my first playthrough of the game, and this is as much as I currently know.Customizing rant:The customization in this game is great because it gives you an assorted list of good weapons and armors that you can actually use due to interest instead of picking up a bunch of useless gear to toss out later. It features armoring feet, hands, chest, and legs. Weapons are of course in variety such as swords, axes, fist weapons, polearms, hammers, etc. One thing to note is the equipping runes in your gear slots. Runes help in terms of boosting defenses against elements, or adding elements to weapon properties. It's pretty good when you add fire to your projectiles. Nothing beats some nice damage over time on ranged enemies. Leveling system rant:The leveling system is the same as any Souls game, but with a twist. Gather experience to level up attribute points, or gain spell points, and if you die with the experience on you, you'll lose it all, but you can get it back by going back to where you died. The twist here is that the more experience you carry on you the better and more frequent the drops become in game from enemies. You also get on a killing streak experience multiplier if you hold on to your experience. The more enemies you kill, the more experience you get. When you die you have a matter of time to get to your experience to get the full value since it has a percentage timer that goes down the longer it takes you back to where you died. Really makes you question if you should use the experience before a boss fight.Graphics rant:The graphics are great, and can be taxing on your computer, but so far I have everything set on high, and haven't run into much issues. I've gotten some framerate issues in areas heavy with particle effects like snowy areas, and encounter issues in tight corridor places as well, but they aren't game breaking, but they can be annoying. I turn down my settings to low when I stream on twitch, and the game still looks gorgeous. I love the PhsyX usage in the game. Some particle effects just make me cream everywhere. I currently run two Nvidia 680 4GB in SLI, i7-2700K, and 16GB RAM. Soundtrack rant:I've had some issues with character dialog cutting out here 'n there, and in some places the music gets super loud for no reason, and it'll go back to normal randomly. Aside from that the soundtrack is great, and it draws you into this gritty world. For some odd reason it reminds me of Diablo 2. I really can't break down soundtracks and music, so yeah. That's that.Story, characters, and enemies rant:The story is lackluster so far. You play as Harkyn, a criminal who did a lot of bad♥♥♥♥♥♥ and is looked down upon by everyone, but is freed by a monk who saw in him the ability to fight off the evil gods and their demons. That's as much as I know since I have yet to beat the game, but it's your typical story with a badass over-powered protagonist. But! I do love the characters in this game since they are so entertaining, and have their own unique humor, characteristic traits, and what not. The voice acting is pretty good though the lip-syncing is off. Enemy design is great and unique, the enemies all have their own characteristics that make them different from one 'n another, so it keeps it fun & challenging. One enemy will run at you with a constant barrage of attacks making you shield up, and go for the perfect backstap. Other enemies are a fortress of defense waiting for you to attack so they can parry, and wreck your♥♥♥♥♥♥ The bosses are kinda repetitive in design, but hold their own challenge. I won't go far into depth on bosses because spoilers. If you are a master at these kind of games you will own them no problem, but with me I died a couple times trying to get down the right strategy.Outcome rant:The game isn't punishing like Dark Souls which can be a good or a bad thing depending on who you are asking, but I think it is refreshing, and gives the new IP good ground to expand to something wonderful, and make this into a great series of games. I have fully enjoyed everything I have played of this game so far. I have played both Dark Souls, and Demon's Souls, and awaiting for Bloodborne. Huge fan of these kind of games, and this game fits in its genre as a little more casual, but definitely a lot of fun. I'd say give it a go. A solid 8/10 for me. I'm not much of a reviewer, but this game does justice. I just felt the need to say it.TL:DR~Pros:+ Great fluid combat, and spot on hitboxes.+ Plenty of customizing and armory to fit your play style.+ Leveling is easy to learn and use, and holds its weight in deciding how your going to progress through the game.+ Graphics are splendid, and the world is gorgeous.+ Soundtrack is empowering.+ Majority of the enemies hold their own challenges, making you switch up your style of gameplay to put 'em down faster.+ Most of the characters I have met in the game are pretty funny. Humor is always nice in anything.Cons: - The story is your typical save the world of mankind with a super strong buff dude who has to make up for his crimes.- Magic spells in this game can be useful, but overall they are pretty boring and can be forgotten.- Framerate issues here 'n there, but I'm sure this can be patched.- Character lip-syncing is way off, and it just looks silly.- Bosses are pretty repetitive.8/10

content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
												In Lords of the Fallen, you play as Gruff McGrufferson, the gruffest, toughest dude around. But under that gruff exterior, he is actually a wobbling mound of jelly. Our pal Gruff the jelly man must wobble his way around a castle and a demonic realm, fighting a bunch of angry demons and their sickly looking pals.Unfortunately for our chum Gruff McJellyman, his wibbly legs make him less manouverable than an asthmatic sloth, and his wobbly arms mean that swinging anything bigger than a toothpick is a real struggle for our intrepid hero. Even more unfortunate for our dashing dispatcher of ne'er do wells, the villainous villains he encounters have some deviously diabolical tricks up their muscular sleeves.Every one of these no good rascals comes equipped with an invisible record player, which they stand upon. What this means for mighty Jellyman is that all these cads he encounters can swivel on the spot... without moving their feet! The KNAVES! The SCOUNDRELS! The UTTER CHEEK! Our poor hero must face large, brutish enemies, who hide behind mighty shields, have vast qauntities of health, and who only give miniscule openings in their defence. These dastardly fiends laugh at our delicious Jelly hero, for they know that further down the corridor, two more of their identical brethren lie in wait - and our gruff protagonist must face them all, lest he be overwhelmed! Oh the horror...Although, it's not all bad news for our gelatinous champion.On his quest, he is accompanied by his best pal, Jam, the friendly invisible cameraman! Jam eagerly follows Jelly Goat Gruff on his delectable adventures. Unfortunately, Jam gets a little giddy whenever his pal Jellyman charges into battle, and can't keep a firm grip on his camera.Also accompanying our damn tasty chum is Karlo...Kaslo?...Carlos? Whatever. Our ABSOLUTELY memorable pal Karlos freed the magnificent Jellygruff from his horrible jelly prison, where our hero was placed after attempting a coup against the Ice Cream king, to supplant him from the delicious dessert throne. Mage-o Kazooie brings Gruff McJellyjelly to Keystone to fight the nasty demons, because only he, with his superior reflexes, nimble footwork, and masterful weapon-handling, can save the day from EVIL!Our gastronomical hero also gains assistance from an amiable demon blacksmith!"I can inscribe your weapons with runes to make them worthy of Gods!", he proudly claims.Lo and behold!, Jellyman was overjoyed to find that his now godly weapon turned a monster that previously took 12 hits to kill, into a monster that now takes a measly 11 hits to vanquish.Oh yeah, there's also this woman, Yetka or something. She definitely wasn't as memorable as Kazoozle, the COMPLETELY memorable wizard dude. Also, there was some bad dude who's name began with A. But who cares, he was just a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.Dare you join the mighty Jellyman on his quest?Dare you battle these fearsome record player equipped demons? Dare you slog through dozens and dozens of said demons, over and over again?Dare you wrestle with the dreadful beast known as the inventory? Dare you attempt to make sense of cryptic item descriptions that tell you nothing of an item's purpose?Dare you listen to grim and chilling audio logs?Dare you battle visually identical, yet stastically superior versions of foes you have already fought?Dare you behold Jam's shaky camera-work, while keeping your dinner intact?Dare you become... THE JELLYGRUFF?In all seriousness, I had way more fun writing this review than I did playing the game.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												LotF is a game I won’t be revisiting in the long term, but I definitely enjoyed it enough for the time I have spent with it up to now. I’d love to recommend it, but it falls short of expectations.LotF is a game that (predictably) uses a combat system similar to that in the Souls games. You control Harkyn from the 3rd person perspective and probe enemies for patterns & weaknesses before moving in to finish them off using a weapon of your choice. There's a relatively large selection of weapons & armour to choose from, with the game slowly allowing you access to more powerful items as you continue with the linear narrative. The combat is functional and usually fun, but can be a little clunky at times, and the spells are often completely underwhelming and are more useful for tactical purposes. If you like to play RPGs as a mage then honestly you should probably avoid this game. You have access to one long range weapon which you can use in a variety of ways, but I found it most useful for pulling single enemies out of larger groups.The game looks pretty good with a very consistent art-style, and the two major areas had very distinctive visual themes. The enemies were well designed and the environments were pretty, even if you could tell how constrictive they were. The armour designs were not to my taste (far too large and “showy”) and were a bit reminiscent of the kind of over-sized armour you see on space marines from 40k. The enemy animation was good enough for me to easily distinguish between what attacks they were winding up which allowed the combat to flow. The sound was not up to the same standard as the visuals: the scripting and voice acting in LotF are simply atrocious. Conversations often have sentences that don’t really follow on from the last, being said in tones that don’t follow the mood, on subjects you couldn’t care less about. The poor voice acting really impacts on the narrative too, as it is delivered in a very obvious and linear manner through conversations and cutscenes. The story simply plods along from A to B with few surprises. The audiobooks add meat to the narrative and are delivered with far more convincing speech than that from actual characters in the game, without them the story would have been paper-thin and completely forgettable (which is why so little of this review is dedicated to the story).I have a few more gripes about LotF as well. The biggest issue is that after finishing, not much changes in NG+ except that enemies have far more health, which really kills the replayability. My second largest issue is the scaling/levelling seems very oddly balanced: even when not using checkpoints for long periods of time to get extra XP, I rarely built up enough experience to increase Harkyn's capabilities in a noticeable manner; sometimes adding a point into Strength actually reduced the damage of my equipped Strength-scaling weapon and I have literally no idea why. Thirdly there are some technical problems: occasionally the game would outright crash, resulting in complete loss of everything you’ve done since last touching a checkpoint; the frame-rate would often bomb to unplayable levels; and sometimes the load times between areas would take unusually long.It probably sounds like I’ve panned LotF, but I did manage to enjoy my time with it despite its failings. If you like 3rd person fantasy RPGs then this is worth the price of admission in a sale.

Posted: November 2, 2014
												The game is great but the product is defective. I haven't completed my first play through of Lords of the Fallen because I simply haven't been able to.  Not because the game is too difficult or too long but rather because of endless crashes.  My first save file was ruined by a death loop bug that rendered the file completely unusable.  I looked to see if there was a solution or if others had experienced it.  A few had and some even were able to get out of it by rolling their character immediately upon loading.  "OK" I thought, "It was only 10 hours on that file, no big deal."  Now on my second play through (after having twiddled with the settings per all the common temporary fix threads out there) I just can't play for more than 10 minutes without a crash.  This is particularly problematic in a game in which one of the core mechanics is gambling for bigger rewards by not saving your game.  This, in itself, is a fun mechanic- I like the idea of having to risk your progress in the game for incremental rewards.  It's clever and potentially fun.  This is undermined entirely by the reality that bugs and crashes incentivize me to save as often as possible.  There are good things about this game, a lot of them.  The art is amazing, the game feel is heavy in a visceral way that connects you to what you're doing.  I can't recommend it until it's been fixed, however.  I can't even play it.  With a GTX780 and similarly big specs throughout the rest of my rig, there's no excuse why these glitches, crashes, and bugs should exist.  This game was simply not tested thoroughly enough. I hope the developers will 1- fix the bugs asap and 2- learn their lesson so that their talents aren't overshadowed by sloppy mistakes.Update 1: I have pushed through to NG+ perhaps due to a desire to harm myself.Update 2: I'm looking forward to the new patch which promises to fix stability issues; I will expand my thoughts.  Update 3: So far, so good.  Played for several hours without any stability issues.  Will get through NG+ before I decide to turn the frown upside down.  Clearly I'm enjoying the game a great deal or else I wouldn't be playing it.  It's still not for everyone.

												Originally the 'mixed' rating had put me off, but I decided to try this during a sale.  In a way that was a good thing, going in with low expectations and being pleasantly surprised.  The things that made me happy about it:   Good graphics  Gorgeous environments  Framerate not capped at 30 (ahem)  Difficult mobs/bosses  An actual storyline I had a read through many of the negative reviews and a lot of it is down to personal frustrations.  While in some places the game is actually quite unforgiving, I didn't think it warranted such negativity - difficulty spikes and overcoming them are part of the excitement of playing games like these.  The lesson I learned here was to take these Steam ratings with a pinch of salt.But to each their own, I will say - if you like fantasy-setting style games with difficult yet rewarding fights, try this out.I would advise you to have a look at a class guide first - I went in as a Solace Rogue and had a very tough time at some places but did manage to complete.

												Lords of the Fallen is the first true attempt from a Western developer to imitate and improve upon the formula established by From Software, and it's a mighty successful one. Though not without its shortcomings, the game fully delivers on its basic premise and it lays the groundwork for more games in the IP; with excellent graphics and solid action/RPG gameplay, fans of the genre should be pleased.A disclaimer from someone who could never fully get into Dark Souls to others like me: don't dismiss this game just because of that. Lords of the Fallen does a better job to help newcomers; you'll die and hate it at first, indeed, but eventually you will grow to love it. content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, and the developers of Lords of the Fallen have made it no secret that they aim to recreate the magic of the Souls franchise. A series defined by brutal difficulty, ambient storytelling and a constant sense of despair, fear, and loneliness; Lords of the Fallen set quite a high goal, and it’s sad that it seems they weren’t able to make it all the way there.The story of Lords of the Fallen follows Harkyn, a gruff no-nonsense criminal released to defeat an invading enemy known as the Rhogar. Most of the game takes place in the Keystone Citadel, a vast castle set upon a snowy mountain at the peak of the world. The story seems ambiguous at first, with only mere mentions of Harkyn’s crimes and little backstory given other than the Rhogar seek to destroy humanity.There are developments, a few twists and turns, but they ultimately amount to nothing. The world is fairly uninteresting, and little inspiration was taken from the Souls series in creating a world that makes you wonder why everything has fallen to ruin. I cared little for Harkyn, and even less for the characters in the game. There are a few NPCs scattered about and a couple sidequests to complete, but really, this is a game focused on combat first, story second.As for the combat, it’s solid enough. You have a typical Souls control scheme, with light and heavy attacks, a dodge roll, a magic projectile-firing gauntlet, and the ability to two-hand or sword-and-board. Backstabbing is still the name of the game here, although the equipment and armor allow for a more tank-oriented player to hunker down instead of dodging and utilizing invincibility frames. Magic is also a tool at the player’s disposal, though the variety is rather interesting.There are three trees of magic you select from at the start of the game, focusing on certain strengths. All three trees receive Prayer, which spawns a decoy that any enemy, bosses included, will blindly attack instead of Harkyn. I only ever found use in the Brawler tree, where the abilities seemed extremely overpowered. Ram is essentially a fireball that goes through enemy shields, Rage allows unfettered use of an unending pool of stamina, and Quake is just straight-up a lightning bolt that wrecks everything in eyesight. There’s really no room for subtlety or complexity in this magic system, a plus for some and a minus for others.To be honest, most of the game’s combat feels much like the magic system: there is a sense of mind-numbing difficulty, but streamlined in order to not deter players who aren’t used to this sort of punishment. You’ll be challenged, but rarely punished. There’s a variety of approaches, whether you choose to strip off your armor and go fast and quick against the mightiest of bosses, or want to spam Ram on every minion in sight, and every strategy is viable.The trade-off is that there is little of the depth or complexity that enraptured Souls fans in the past. There is little variety in weapons, outside of the addition of gauntlets. Gameplay is interesting, but you won’t see as many gimmick builds or min-maxing as you would in a Souls game. This is furthered by the fact there is no multiplayer in any form; the lack of invasion gameplay and one-on-one duels means that your primary means of perfecting combat is against minions and bosses.Bosses are a major factor in any character action game, and even more-so in Lords of the Fallen. After facing encounter after encounter, your prowess and mettle is tested to the fullest by these monstrosities. The bosses are definitely special encounters, and stand out compared to the common fold of enemies. They’re difficult, and you’ll bang your head against the wall a few times trying to pass them.To be frank, the bosses of Lords of the Fallen are just not memorable in the slightest. It doesn’t help that they’re given little to no backstory, and labeled simply as “Commander” or “Worshipper” or “Infiltrator.” Souls games often had memorable encounters, heightened by the lore leading up to them and given meaning by the events of the game; battles against titans like Sif, Gwyn and Artorias have meaning behind them, and are a culmination of the player’s actions. The Rhogar bosses feel arbitrary, as do the rest of the bosses in Lords of the Fallen. They act as an end goal, a finish line, but signify little more than that.Lords of the Fallen can’t be painted over as simply a Souls copy, however. It does a few things to expand upon and innovate the mechanics of the pseudo-genre, and it does these well. The experience system of Lords is similar to the soul-collecting mechanic, where experience is earned from enemy kills and completing objectives, and dropped on the ground upon death.You not only have to recover these after your respawn, but you only have a certain time-frame to do so. The experience will gradually decay after some time, and eventually disappear. You also gain experience multipliers and extra loot the longer you hold onto your experience, at the cost of potentially losing it. You can “bank” you experience at checkpoints, but even this has it’s own set of risks. You can apply experience towards either a point for your stats or a point for your magic. These mechanics create a constant risk-reward balancing act, and is very fulfilling. I often found myself questioning whether to bank my XP into that spell point I was aiming for, or potentially lose it all in an upcoming boss fight where I wouldn’t have a good opportunity to reclaim my points.Graphically, the game is beautiful on high-end PCs. Console versions suffer from framerate issues, but on the standard gaming computer, this game will run at a clean 1080p at 60 FPS. The kicker for PC users is that they should prepare to deal with a wealth of bugs and glitches. I had several game-breaking bugs, which lost me massive amounts of progress and several chunks of hair. Also, camera control is abysmal in most hallways and corridors. While you have control of the camera, the automatic pans and swings around for backstabs or dodges are really annoying to deal with while you’re managing a million other things on-screen.Overall, Lords of the Fallen captures the Souls essence in a base sense, and provides a nice entry point for those intimidated by the series’ infamous difficulty. Where it failed to capture its inspiration’s essence was in the lore and storytelling, both of which fall flat in Lords. This is an enjoyable romp through a series of difficult bosses, and it does a nice job of making you feel like you’ve grown from a measly warrior to unstoppable force by the end of the game. Just don’t expect the same depth that inspired the fanatical cult following of the Souls games.

Posted: October 28, 2014
												Praise the  sun  \0/Review in Progress : will add on more Lord of Fallen is a beautiful third person hack and slash game that  is grim, challenging and reminds me of a of  Dark souls  with different hit mechanics, better graphics,  enemies with more abilities and a more articulate  plot.StoryThe game plets player assume the role of Harkyn as the words a different time and war pop up after the cinematic. Apparently, he is on a journey with another man traveling to a  monastery and has lost many men on the way. Only on arrival and opening the doors did they see that the monastery is completely empty and bodies' litter the entire room and demonlike enemies starts attacking....ClassesThree discipline  type for magic: Deception, Brawling, and Solace of magic to choose from and three equipments type to start off, Cleric, Warrior, and a rogue type class.Brawling is focused on offensive magic. Solace is focused on more protective and healing while deception is focused more on more of a mix of imparing and debuffing enemies.Variety of spells seems limited in this game for all 3 tree has similar spells.ControlsThe various attacks that can be performed are  weak and strong attack, rolling, running, jumping, back stepping, parry, frontal kicks, and dodging. The invincibility frames, however, are completely different and more precise when evading. There is a Magic and a Stamina bar so running, attacking, or evading use stamina while magic of any sort from spells to the gauntlet uses the magic bar.The initial layout for the controls is almost exactly the same as DS, if you know the controls, you'll understand this game right away. The only difference is the use of items and cycling it since it has to be favorite set or used from the inventory screen.When attacking you can chain combos with your weak and strong attacks, How hard you hold down an attack will cause it to use up more stamina so technically both your  strong attack have additional stronger attack. Included in attacks is also dual wielding or single weapons with both hands wields depending upon the weapon type. Later in the game players will discover a gauntlet weapon that will allow different type of attacks with spells such as range, aoes etc that uses magic. Runeslotting begins later on changing up items.The keyboard controls are bindable and the default is really decently bound through for this. The gamepad layout is similar to DS.EnemiesEnemies in the game starting off are a bit unpredictable due to having various attack patterns and having the ability to swing in various radius and also turning around. Some enemies such as bosses will have numerous fighting patterns that switched up depending on how much you damaged them. Stealth dispatching of enemies exist if you walk up to them slowly. Don't always depend too  much on trying to attack or evading from behind because you can still get hit from enemies when they swing their weapons near your character and they respond really fastSome of the AI is really stupid. I have seen my character stealth past them right in the front just by walking and not a single reaction from their line of sight at all and being able to do a stealth attack to kill them.Gameplay:After defeating  the first boss It seems that the points can be stored towards attributes or spells, Not storing can cause perma loss, but if you don't save or use your points  you can gain more experience and earn with higher kill streaks by playing on. Saving requires save shards nearby and going across the character development screen and where exp points can be banked. Upon dying players will have a limited time to gather their lost experience floating around that looks like a wisp which will need to be grabbed or you'll lose it. Most of the areas  of the game and map are open or enclosed  where enemies are plenty an ambush you along with  certain unique monsters hidden throughout that can cause your downfall so thread carefully, when enemies are encountered  lock on, swing and chain combos or your choice on bypassing them if you want. if you die or use a  save shard they will respawn most of the time. There are plenty of areas and chambers to explore.Combos are important for the play if one wants to master more damage and mastering them can be quite tough. Using your experience to upgrade your stats is also as important in order to do more combos, take more hits and gain more stats in surviving this world.During the story there will be certain choices players can take which are either evil or good. There are also dialogue options to help players better understand the story and situation at hand.Stats in the game fall under strength, vit, faith, endurance, agility and luckStrength for str weapons and to carry heavier gear, vit for health and potion effects, faith for mp pool and weapon magic damage, endurance for carrying more and stamina, agility for damage with fast weapons and energy, and luck for better items from enemies along with crafting material finds.There are also three types of armor in the game, Light medium and heavy, which affects your character in variety of ways with your stamina and movemen and def. Most equips found are part of set until next playthroughThe maps are dark but extremely detailed with destructible about such as barrels, book cases, benches, etc. with  decent physics. There are potions,chests, portals and  items hidden throughout and audio scrolls that tells the story of the game.  Graphics Looks amazing and well done, graphics are gorgeous and really detailed, many destructible all over the environment. Game runs at 30 fps for me for some reason. Trying to push or uncap for more. The interface is completely different in the inventory though and seems more sleek and clean. The game lighting is great, and the effects are top notch. The art reminds me of warhammer and the enemies   bodyparts/armor chips away as you fight them. The animations are seriously well done though sometimes I notice my rogue doing some really weird glitch through on attacks and hopefully that's a bug that can be fixed. Opinion?Game is awsome so far and borrows from DS well and DS borrows from Monster hunter well, Ds didn't invent the manual camera control style combat folks I've got games predating before DS. I also like the precision of hit boxes though it can be wonky at times, the challenges and boss fight  to this game along with the immersive  graphics, Movement feel so fluid with the character, though more work needs to be done to iron out the bugs. Many are going to compare this to dark souls because it's very similar with the camera style and controls, but yet it's different in mechanics  especailly enemy targetting. The game is ok overall and difficulty starting off seems really hard as a rogue class as in omg i am getting my face ripped.Pros so far+ Graphics looks amazing and really detailed. The Physics looks great when chipping at enemies.+ Dark soul's layout on controllers, the keyboard and mouse are really well bound and plays a bit differently+ Destructibles and physics DX 11 effects.+ Interesting classes to mix up, though spells are limited+ Great Voice acting and music scores that remind me of lord of the ring.+ Immersive environment, Blowing winds, snowfall, Shadows, Lighting etc.+ Enemy armors and weapons break as you attack themCons- No multiplayer- Optimization on this game right now currently is. Completely WHACK and first game for me to have frame drops at the wierdest places had to turn off some options to get it to run well.-The lip synching animation is horrible- Spells lack variety- starting  Bosses could be a bit challenging for some people.Yt video - Working on it, too busy playing the game.

Posted: March 17, 2015
												Having played it back-to-back with Dark Souls I have to say it borrows a lot of elements but feels different overall - and that is a good thing. PROs: It's hard, to me personally even harder than Dark Souls was in the beginning. Maybe because of my non-standard starting combo (Hunter, cleric magic + rogue), maybe because I keep pressing B to dodge-roll instead of A. Combat is amazing, the controls are smooth and very responsive.  "The more enemies you beat without using a savepoint/spending xp, the more XP multiplier you get" feature. Loadscreen hints explaining stuff that I just had to google for Dark Souls. You might prefer it otherwise, I like when I can find all basic info inside the game. It looks absolutely friggin fantastic... CONs: ... if only Nvidia Turbulence wouldn't cause very frequent crashes (on a GTX 970 mind you, 0 crashes when disabled) it would be even prettier. Story feels kinda "Yeah guys, we really should add some story". A rather easily ignorable con for this game tho. A weirdly massive difficulty spike for the area between the 3rd and 4th boss really frustrated me :D

Posted: November 22, 2014
												I am a huge fan of melee combat. The type you see in Dark Souls and orignal Age of Chivalry.Where your attacks matter and it's not just a spam fest with lol one button guaranteed counter (Think Shadow of Mordor, Assassin's Creed. Disclaimer: I dont think those are bad games, i just prefer a challenge and not my "hero" overpowered)So, it really just boils down to that, honestly. Do you love melee combat, slow tactical play, heavy weapons that feel heavy, armor that feels like it is heavy?Challenging enemies (each can end you if you get reckless), the sound of steel clashing with steel, being bruised and beaten, waiting for that perfect moment when the enemy makes a mistake? When the the time finally slows and your greatsword smashes him down? That adrenaline you get when you actually win a very hard boss fight?You do? Well get this, you won't regret it. Do you want to just mash buttons, get a combo streak, get one button multiple executions, fight 50 enemies at once? A nice map, waypoints, shortcuts, fast travel, road paved for you? Don't get this then.That's all you need to know about this game.Disclaimer: In my 26 hours of play, game crashed twice. Please, stop saying game crashes all the time because it doesn't.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												First of all, I really wanted to like that game, but it made it more and more impossible the more I played.From the beginning to the second boss, I enjoyed the game and thought it is a nice souls clone. But after that I started to notice issues that annoyed me the more I played.First, the enemies. While they are not really hard, there are enemies that take minutes to beat just because they are behind a tower shield. That would be no big problem, if your shield break and/or kick could shove the shield aside to make it possible for you to hit them. That won't work. Only thing that works is running shield bash, and even with that it takes way too long to kill them. The most stupid thing is that the enemies with the big shields have an shield bash + sword slash attack that is faster than anything you could do, even the light class + dagger doesn't offer that. Also, hitting enemies with big weapons doesn't seem to stagger them. There are unarmored crossbow wielding enemies that keep firing arrows at you while you hit them with a freakin'  hammer that has an attack animation of a train... The enemies are all very similar. The mutant knights you fought at the start keep appearing through the game with just more health and damage. That is true for all enemies.Next, the boss fights. I haven't finished the game yet, but what i have seen already makes me sad. The bosses are really easy, because they have 3-5 types of attack they repeat. A LotF boss battle follows always the same pattern. Get away when they do attack a, b or c. Roll away from attack d and attack for 1/1000 damage to their health bar. Repeat 10-20 minutes, you win. :(The area is relatively small and feels uninspired. At first sight, the game looks awesome and it does really have nice graphics. But later it is just repetitive and uninspired somehow. Also, after the second boss you don't know where to go. I went everywhere, beat the big shield guys near the back entrance and gone through the graveyard to the "catacombs". The NPC weren't at the place he supposed to be to let me into the other dimension/world. After I got out there i where supposed to go through the catacombs again. Also, catacombs is no area name but is the quest location. Confusing. Levers and that kind of stuff is hard to make out from the background of rubbish and debris.The checkpoint system makes the game unnecessarily easy. The enemies only respawn after you die, so you can replenish your health and vials infinitely while progressing through the area. While the bonus exp system is there to balance that, it doesn't work. The bonus is just not enough to make it worth to "gamble" for it with less healing.The character development and crafting is very disappointing. You choose one of three classes and then stay with 4 more or less useful spells. Crafting is not existent. There are runes you can put in some of your weapons and armor, but they are only a few and not really interesting or game changing in any meaning. Also, you do get the ability to put runes into your stuff only after the second boss. ... if you found the right way directly. A little bit late for my taste. The story and NPCs are not overwhelming but also not bad. Standard mediocre medieval monster stuff. Nothing impressing or interesting.The whole game feels slow. Really slow. Take Dark souls and make it 3 times slower. I don't see any gain from that. I want slow attack speed with ultra greatswords but not with small axes. Also, fast roll feels slow. Moving is slow, magic and shooting is slow. Not really fun to play like that. Souls gave you options, LotF gives you nearly nothing. Of course there are differences between light and heavy armor, but it's just too little in my opinion.The controls are badly programmed. Locked on an enemy, rolling/stepping backwards just seems to be a lucky occurrence. If you press back and are just one millimeter of to one side your character roles left or right not backwards. While the enemies even turn 360` with their hardest attack, you get hit all the time. It felt for me that there is nor invincible frame with rolling, too. The lock-on is clumsy and sometimes just annoys the ♥♥♥♥ out of you.Conclusion*First impression is nice, later gets boring/repetitive*Bad enemy and boss design, not hard but time consuming boring battles*Too easy checkpoint system*Character/Skill development nearly not existent*No crafting, only runes with small impact*Area small/repetitive design, way not clear/confusing*Story nothing special*Everything is slow, turtle on dope in gelatinous mass slow*Controls sometimes not direct/on the point*Nice graphics and sound design*If you liked souls series, do not expect something similar good from this game. Only buy at high discount!I give it 65 out of 100Side note: I played the game with maximum graphics fluidly and with a controller.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
Overview: Borrowing gameplay and design elements from Dark Souls, Lords of the Fallen is a deep, gorgeous looking third-person action RPG. Sadly, it also made some crutial sacrifices in the name of accesibility that went a bit too far, and ultimately spoiled much of the potential that the game had. In the same year that's given us the brilliant Dark Souls 2, I can't recommend Lords of the Fallen.Pros: Beautiful graphics, fluid animations, runs smoothly without many bugs (the developers have released a few patches that have seemed to cure many of the launch issues).Fun, satisfying gear. Weapons feel different, armor weight affects mobility.Semi-randomized loot drops makes collecting gear a lot of fun. Some of the best looking armor I've seen in gaming.Interesting risk-reward system where your xp and loot find modifiers increase with each kill, and reset to zero when you rest.Cons: Too easy! This is by no means an easy game, but starting with light armor my character soaked up a ton of hits, even from bosses. It only gets worse as your gear easily overpowers enemies later the game. The challenge just isn't there (see below for more).Most enemies (bosses included) can only really be fought one way. Wait for them to attack, dodge/block, hit, repeat. There aren't multiple ways to approach each battle, so the gameplay feels quite stale after just a couple hours.Character development is very limited. You're a warrior whether you like it or not. The game tries to mix it up with a 4 skill tree (either healing/defense, sneaky backstabbing, or more warrior stuff), but none of it really changes the combat up much. Also there's a projectile gun-type weapon, for some reason.No multiplayer. None. No co-op, no PvP.Conclusion: I really wanted to like Lords of the Fallen. I really did, and I really tried. CI Games deserves some credit for bringing it's own style to the Dark Souls type of hard core action RPG. Despite its many short-comings, we can be optimistic that they will keep working and deliver us a fun and challenging sequel. I'll sum it up with this, in my own words: Dark Souls scares me. That's why I keep playing it. I feel like Dark Souls is one step ahead of me at all times, that I'm never fully equipped for what the game is throwing at me. That's what makes it so special, it's David and Goliath and if I keep trying, I can bring down the giant. But that's the fundamental problem with Lords of the Fallen. In this game, I'm the Goliath and there are a bunch of Davids running around poking at my feet. It doesn't scare me, and it just doesn't have that satisfaction that I want from this type of game.
