content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												Deserves better reviews than it has. Apparently was riddled with bugs when released (lots of crashing, poorly optimised), but I had no problems running it on high settings with a modest mid-range rig (i5 3570k, AMD 7870, 8GB RAM). It also gets compared to Dark Souls a lot, and rightly so, but I don't think any game should be negatively reviewed for being 'not as good as Dark Souls', as that's a pretty high bar. So without further ado, lets dive right in and compare it directly to Dark Souls!Similar to Souls: Checkpoint system, red floating crystals instead of bonfires. Replenish HP / MP / potions, enemies respawn. Melee combat mechanics - parry (only with subset of shields), backstabs, stamina management, dodgerolls, staggering, light attack, heavy attack, running attack etc. Similar range of weapons. % Equipment load determines movement and dodgeroll speed. 'Weighty' feel to larger weapons. Weapons (but not armour) have stat requirements. Some weapons scale with their relevant stat. Loot - set loot gained through chests, enemies have a chance of dropping 'runes' (for upgrades) or equipment (rare). No duplicate armour / weapons. Level design - sprawling areas that loop back into each other by unlocking shortcuts. Lots of secret items and areas. Leveling - bank experience at checkpoints to level up attributes / spells, each subsequent level requires more. Upon death your exp is left as a 'ghost' with a timer on it, or until your next death. NG+ and NG++ for multiple playthroughs. Decimate furniture by rolling into itDifferent from Souls No fast travel from checkpoint to checkpoint, not a massive problem because; Smaller world, fast traveling would have been nice at times, but overall not a big problem. Shorter game, could be finished in maybe 8 hours if you don't explore much. Personally it took me around 15 hours. No invincibility during dodgeroll that I am aware of. Causes some moments of anger if you're used to Dark Souls, but you get used to it. Magic - each class (warrior, thief, cleric) has a set of 4 spells that can be unlocked and leveled up at checkpoints, separately from attribute points. There is also a gauntlet that has 3 modes of fire (basically different ranges), which gains power with more Faith (cleric / magic build). Both share an MP pool. Much more straightforward story, quite typical dark fantasy stuff, not too abstract or anything. Equipment upgrading is done through a 'rune' system - you gain sealed runes from defeating enemies, and unlock them to reveal type (eg power / fire / luck), runes range from 'lesser' to 'flawless' and can be attached and detached at will from equipment that has slots. No multiplayer aspectOther notes: The game looks great - dark atmosphere, good enemy/boss design, weapons / armour look suitably fantasy, so you get that extra bit of satisfaction from new gear. The melee combat is heavily emphasised, ranged combat is minimal (pretty much limited to gauntlet). Many weapon types have very slow attack speed, which can take a bit of getting used to, but there are claws and daggers for faster attacks (this is how I played) which are perfectly viable. It is not as big or complex as Dark Souls, but still holds it's own as a solid Action-RPG with dark fantasy flavour, good melee combat, and some side quests and extra exploration encouraged to flesh out the experience.All in all I really enjoyed my time playing Lords of the Fallen, and seeing as you can get it for disgustingly cheap when it's on sale these days, I don't see why you shouldn't pick it up.

number of helpful: 157 of 237 people (66%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												(TL;DR? This review is also available in video format for your convenience below.)With the recent success of the Souls franchise and its emphasis on precision timed combat and high difficulty it was only a matter of time before imitators would listen to the herald of success.  Lords of the Fallen brings its own take on the punishing hack n slash genre.  While there's no hiding its influence from Dark Souls, it doesn't manage to improve the formula enough to justify its own existence.The differences between the two titles will be immediately apparent.  You'll be moved throughout the game through a much more direct plot than the subtle nuanced on-goings of the Souls games.  You play as Harkyn, a prisoner released by Kaslo, to hold off an invasion from the imposing forces of Rhogar who are subverting the natural order of things in his world.  The story is rather empty and predictable for the most part and is told through clumsy character animations with flat voice acting.  It manages to do little else other than keep things moving along through the 12-20 hour campaign.  The visuals are solid for the most part and offer well lit, moody environments to explore.  Initially, the world feels large and expansive with a host of optional areas to explore but you'll soon come to realize most of these areas will require you to delve into them at one point or another throughout the story, making the interconnected albeit small castle that you spend the majority of the game in feel limited.  There isn't a huge variety in locations either as you'll generally be exploring the snowy exterior of the citadel or its gloomy interior.  The whole thing feels pretty underwhelming by the time you finish it all.Game play is very similar to the sword and board melee combat of Dark Souls but with a much more limited assortment of spells available to its three classes.  You'll also be welcomed with a large pool of life, a recharging mana bar, and a steady supply of healing potions that make the encounters considerably easier than its counterpart.  Bosses are intended to offer unique fights but by the end of the game you can overcome some of the more difficult bosses by simply buffing yourself with magic and pulverizing the boss to death before they can inflict enough damage back to offset your relentless assault.  The camera can also be a bit irritating as your battles can be hidden by hanging banners and other furniture with dips in the frame rate being commonplace. Enemies also tend to offer little variety with only around a dozen types with the shielded ones being the most annoying to fight since they rely on blocking a little too much causing conflicts with them to become prolonged and irritating.  All of that being said though, while not meeting the standard that Dark Souls met and being a little slower, it still manages to be competent enough to enjoy the game's short duration.The items that you acquire are all well designed and offer a much flashier aesthetic than what you'll find with most of the armor and weapons in the Souls games.  While you can upgrade gear and items with its rune system, you'll be frequently re-socketing pieces as replacements since upgrades will come frequently.  The soundtrack holds its own but doesn't manage to leave any lasting impression as is a common theme with the game.  One of the cooler aspects of Lords is the risk/reward mechanic behind its gameplay that rewards you for holding onto a larger amount of experience that can be cashed in with a multiplier that rises with each enemy killed, although it unfortunately only caps at 2.  You'll also be urged to return to your body quickly as the amount of experience you regain is based on the speed at which you reclaim your corpse.  Although the lack of overall difficulty in this compared to Dark Souls trivialized this aspect a bit as I was always able to run by enemies and regain my corpse quickly on the few occasions that I died.  Upon completing this game you'll be rewarded with a New Game + option that raises the difficulty and unlocks more spell trees but that's if you're able to get to the end which leads to Lords of the Fallen's biggest problem, game breaking bugs.While clearing out the missed collectables and locked doors throughout the world that I hadn't gone back yet to open just before the final boss I fell down a hole which killed my character.  Instead of respawning at my last visited checkpoint, the game quick saved and spawned me at the bottom of the hole which I was unable to escape from, or reload a previous save.  So with that, I had gone as far as I could without restarting the game on a new save file and playing through the entire game again to finish the final act.  Glitches like this are inexcusable in a finished product and should've been tested out before release.  Luckily, I wasn't too wrapped up in the story to care that much of whether or not I saw the end.Lords of the Fallen manages to feel like Dark Souls Lite, it offers similar but simpler, slower combat.  An interconnected but small world when compared to vistas like Lordran, and a risk/reward system with little actual risk.  In addition to all this it lacks any of the creative multiplayer features found in the Souls games.  If you're looking for something to hold you over until Bloodborne, Lords of the Fallen offers a strong initial impression that can scratch that itch for a very brief period of time.  Just be sure to watch your step and go into it with much lower expectations.This review is also available in video format:


YouTube™ Video: Analog Reviews: Lords Of The Fallen 

			Views: 3,559		

			With the recent success of the Souls franchise and its emphasis on precision timed combat and high difficulty it was only a matter of time before imitators would listen to the herald of success.		

Pros+ Solid yet borrowed combat+ Makes a strong first impression but loses momentum quickly+ Good soundtrackCons- Game Breaking Bugs- Short length compared to Dark Souls- Linear with the 'optional areas' not being optional.- Does nothing originalIf you enjoyed this review, feel free to follow me as a Steam Curator: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/4886473/

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												TL;DR: Buy Lords of the Fallen if you have a decent PC to run it onA lot of people bash this game, as you can probably see up there under the user reviews percentages.Most of those people are folks that live, breathe, eat and sleep Dark Souls or one of the other souls games in general (or bought it on launch day, more on that in a minute ) and as a result they spew bad reviews at it simply because its a similar game/competition, not harcore enough or simply "Not the same!", Its rather unfortunate really.Lords of the Fallen was really buggy on launch, like game destroying buggy, but now all of those bugs have been fixed and now the game works flawlessly. Having put 20+ hours into it I havent encountered a single bug or issue since it was patched up, like this "animation lag" or "crash" people falsely throw at this game nowadays ( once again, to make it less appealing than a Souls game because of blatant bias )Having a high end of average rig, I get a super stable 60fps when playing, and not only does it run smoothly the game looks amazing, so amazing on ultra, especially with its later armour designs  that frankly Im disapointed that Dark Souls 3 didnt end up looking this good. Animation quality with the exception of one or two characters is great and frankly its one of the few games wearing a cape actually looks cool as opposed to it looking like a sack of buggy Gmod crap.Gameplay and combat are pretty much what you expect, its a souls style game, a big open-ish area to area world. Combat consists of the usual light attack, heavy attack, block and then a parry/special shield move, also with a block-breaker, spriting, rolling and jump/lunge attacks. Dodging works just fine but heavier armour makes your dodge less viable etc etc, less emphasis on range, though you do get a ranged weapon eventually. Kill bad guys and fight a boss, if you die you lose all your experience until you can go visit the spot where you died to get said experience back, die again and its all gone. Stats n' the like work a little differently, but the idea behind them is the same, use gained EXP to level up, but if you hold onto your experience without visiting and saving your progress at a checkpoint you gain a multiplier to your EXP, which is good when you need to farm for levels and cuts out on some that needless busy-work time.While Lords doesnt have any multiplayer components, it places more emphasis on the story, and while the narrative is 'okay' thats where it all falls short. The main characters themselves with the exception of your main guy Harken, are sort've shoddily done. But there is dialogue choices and lil' sidequests where you have to make a decision that affects the reward you gain at the end. If you dont care so much about narrative as you do gameplay, you wont mind how bad the story is that much.Bosses are fun, each one with a little secret 'extra' way to beat them to gain a boss-item/weapon from them, the secrets can be fun to find even if some of them are somewhat missable or hard to figure out. Quest-lines, hidden secret weapons and armour, runes to upgrade you weapons and armours with, its all just filled with really good stuff.If you have a decent rig/desktop PC to run it on, and you want something new and fresh from the Dark Souls monotony, then just buy Lords of the Fallen,

												Love this game. at almost 80 hours I have:  Randomly Crashed to desktop - 0 times.  Crashed from Loading game - 0 times.  Triggered a Crash by using Hvy ClawFinger Attack in "Main" World - 4 times (And, learned to stop doing it.)  Lost 51K+ Stored XP when while in "Bonus Pocket Dimension*"  I was Double-Killed by just respawning. - 1 times.  Was so Buthurt I tried to force game to Crash by using Hvy ClawFinger Attack in BPD* leading me to find out that it wouldn't Crash in BPD* (And, proceeded to Spam the total hell out of it, and it refused to crash my game!) - Many, Many, Times. Triggered a Crash by using Hvy ClawFinger Attack in BPD* World - 0 times. Put a Band-Aid on my hurt for losing 51K+ Xp - 1 times Angry that the "Red" Chest that caused the Death, that lead to the Buthurt, That I eventually won and opened, and only had 1 small magic regen shard in it! - times  ∞   Category Personal Score   Graphics 90   Sound 70   Music 85   Story 80   Boss Fights 95   Weapon Variety 70   Weapon Graphics 65   Armor Variety 60   Armor Graphics 95   Mob Variety 30   Mob Graphics 65   Boss Variety 90   Boss Graphics 90   Combat System 95   Magic Gauntlet System 75   Recommend to Others 90   Hopeful for a Part II 90   Think it Needs Co-Op 99   Hopeful Everyone will get to play -bugs 100 Special Note:I am very sorry for those that have been unable to play yet or are still waiting, or trying to play but are stalled in progressing. But as someone who has watched days of dev's coding and understands barely a smidge of the complexity games as simple as Minecraft™ encompass, I personally can rest assured that those that are pationate about what they have created are not out to Troll but actively pursuing corrections to allow everyone to enjoy thier project. And, Hope for a resolve of each issue that might be giving you problems. Hang in There <3

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												It's pretty hard to launch an all-new triple-A game nowadays due to the huge risk, the adversity towards it by the current video games industry, as well as the pretty finicky nature of actual players, who might judge things a bit too harsh.Even so, Polish studio CI Games, formerly known for the Sniper: Ghost Warrior titles, together with German developer Deck13 Interactive, decided to bite the bullet and roll out Lords of the Fallen, a brand new role-playing game that features big characters, huge monsters, and tough combat, not to mention some pretty impressive visuals.Lords of the Fallen follows the adventures of Harkyn, a prisoner whose crimes are written on his face. While the world is busy finding ways to vanquish all evil, an ancient god awakens and sends his Rhogar Lords to destroy it. As you can imagine, Harkyn is apparently the only man fit to go up against those demonic legions so he, together with mentor Kaslo, go on an epic quest to stop them from crushing the world. They get to explore a fair amount of environments and interact with different characters. Unfortunately, while you can make quite a few choices along the way, many don't have consequences and quite a few of the supporting cast members either use stereotype attitudes or are undeveloped. Plot moments are kept to a minimum and cut scenes do a decent job making things clear, without wasting time on things that don't immediately matter to the player. The world of the game gets fleshed out a bit more thanks to the audio diaries, but not many players will actually pay attention, which is a shame, as Deck13 and CI have done a great job in terms of world building.Lords of the Fallen tries to combine the traditional role-playing mechanics with those seen in hack and slash titles, delivering a result that works pretty well. Harkyn isn't remotely as agile as Devil May Cry's Dante, but his moves are pretty swift and his blows pack quite a punch, depending on the equipped weapon type. You can pick between three classes – Warrior, Cleric, and Rogue. Each has its own magic category, relying on spells to buff survivability and damage for the warrior, healing and enemy manipulation for the cleric, or stealth and critical hits for the rogue. Leveling allows you to spend points in either the stats category, thereby boosting your health pool, your damage, and other such things, or the magic one, where you can unlock new spells to unleash, depending on your available Faith level. The combat relies on regular and heavy attacks, with the beefier ones requiring a few moments of build up before they're ready to go. Without a doubt, fans of the Souls games made by From Software will feel right at home, but there are quite a few more elements added on top to draw in more people.Among them is the XP multiplier system. Each kill results in Harkyn getting more experience. When you reach the bonfire-like checkpoint, you can opt to use those points, thereby losing your multiplier, or you can keep going and see it increase exponentially. This high-risk, high-reward system is quite good, and if you die, you have a set amount of time to get back to your XP pile before it vanishes forever. The loot system is quite well done, and besides offering better and better armor or weapons, it also allows players to collect runes that can be used to provide great bonuses to your existing gear. These can often make or break a tough battle, so spending some time to analyze their pros and cons is essential. Unfortunately, you need to wait until you get to an NPC that can unlock the runes, so at least in the beginning you can only open certain chests with them.The environments look quite impressive, but they don't vary all that much, as you'll often be fighting through ruined castles or snowy areas. The world of Lords of the Fallen certainly looks amazing but it's not explored all that much. What's more, the lack of a map or at least a semblance of a waypoint system means that you might end up going down wrong paths filled with enemies only to encounter closed doors and other such things. Thankfully, the enemy variety is quite solid, with a decent amount of monsters wielding different weapons, spells, and attacks going up against Harkyn during the campaign. Some of the Rhogar Lords require quite a bit of out-of-the-box thinking, but sufficiently leveling up certain skills, especially on the warrior, make a few of them die rather easily.Of course, like in Dark Souls, the difficulty, at least in the beginning, is grueling, so expect plenty of deaths and other such things. Unfortunately, until you start leveling up your attributes and spells, you'll have a really tough time, especially when you go up against enemies that know when to use their shields. Some of their attack patterns are also erratic, so don't be fooled into thinking you've memorized their moves. Enemies are also quite agile, and in some cases, this exposes a few problems with hit and collision detection. Speaking of problems, you'll also find that there are no difficulty options. This means that experienced RPG fans might soon feel like their version of Harkyn becomes a bit too powerful towards the end stages of the game. There is a New Game + option that buffs difficulty but also allows your character to unlock a second type of magic spells from another class, so things get even easier if you make smart choices.It's also worth noting that, at least right now, the game is quite unstable on the PC platform. It crashes in all sorts of moments and the framerate spikes when transitioning from inside areas to exterior ones. Enemies will sometimes freeze in place, and if you attack them, they'll immediately fight back in a flurry of frenzied blows.Lords of the Fallen is a gorgeous experience in terms of visuals, delivering realistic graphics but with plenty of rich colors. Provided your computer can run it, turning on all the different effects makes the whole experience look even better. Character models are sharp and textures look amazing in quite a few situations, although in some things get blurry. Animations, unfortunately, are a bit erratic, especially when characters talk to one another, as they flinch and gesticulate even when they deliver regular sentences. Also, expect a lot of clipping when it comes to your character's cloak and shield.Lords of the Fallen is a decent role-playing experience with some innovative features but it's weighed down by the balancing problems and the technical issues. After a few updates, it might become a good and challenging RPG, but for now, it falls short. It is still very much worth playing, so don't hesitate to pick this up on a sale.Recommended

content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
A Very Good Game UnderratedAfter completing the game just now, I cannot refrain from writing anything but a positive review when there are so many negative ones here bringing the rating of this game down which is real injustice and a shame. Sure the game lacks Dark souls level of polish and there is the issue of crashes when the fighting gets a little too intense during certain boss fights and especially when magic spells are used too often in such scenarios but this in my opinion does not take away all the goodness this game offers overall. Being a carbon copy of Dark Souls in most aspects, Lords of the Fallen starts feeling like an entirely different game after a few hours. With a decent story, great graphics with spectacular lighting and particle effects, clever use of magic, tricky side-quests, hidden secrets and npc interactions, it creates an experience which is different from the Souls series which actually is a good thing in my opinion. LOTF is an easier version of Dark Souls with a merrier environment - much for the pleasure of a casual gamer though still only a Souls fan would connect to. First timers with no prior induction to Dark Souls kind of gameplay might find this game tough enough for few bouts of frustration.The graphics and lighting are really good and almost all armors are intricate in design. The music is satisying, voice acting good but the animations that support it look stiff most of the time. Combat feels strikingly similar to Dark Souls with identical button mapping on the gamepad which is a good thing for a Souls player. The loot is diverse and a few of the weapons and shields are awesome. For example, a shield called 'Twisted Ways' (DLC content) has a rotating map on it. How cool is that? Talking about map, the overall size of the game world known as Keystone is quite big and most of the time would leave you scratching your head as to how to get to a particular spot which had a locked chest that you now found a key to. With twisted dungeons hiding secrets, a castle holding plenty of hidden areas and a portal to a whole new dimension, the whole process of exploring every nook and corner can be daunting. Enemies and Bosses aren't that tough compared to Dark Souls and what I like most about them in LOTF is there is a knack in taking them down. Ofcourse, Dark Souls has it written all over it but in some areas in LOTF, especially in one or two boss fights you might want to think out-of-the box to avoid taking damage which is something spectacular when you discover it yourself. However, some boss fights are crash-riddled if you do not own a beefy PC and the DLC boss is such a pain to beat. End of the day, bad optimization is where the game loses at and If it weren't for this it would've received rave reviews for sure.Simply put, this game might fall short on optimizations but it is a very good game if your PC can power it. Following the footsteps of Dark Souls and yet bringing a whole new feel within is purely refreshing. LOTF is best played with keeping Dark Souls' gameplay in mind and might do enough to frustrate newcomers. But to those who are well acquainted with the Souls series, LOTF is yet another epic journey.To sum it up:   + Good Graphics - Needs a beefy PC   + Varied Loot - Some areas require polish   + Interesting Secrets/ Replayability - Can be frustrating to the uninitiated  MY SCORE: 80/100

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Ok, ok, this review has gone through a few iterations so bear with me people.When I first played LOTF, I absolutely despised it.  Being a big fan of the Souls games, I was looking forward to some Souls-esque but-without-getting-stomped-by-overpowerd-invasions fun.  But dang, Harken was slow and seemed to spend about 10 seconds winding up his attacks before actually throwing them, and I quickly grew bored of this game and its unresponsive controls.  So, my first review was rather scathing, and lo many a fan boy/girl posted some rather immature and insulting comments, most of which have been deleted.  I’m a stoopid noob and I should go back to candy crush saga, apparently.  I also need to 'git gud' even though the difficulty of this game (which isn't much) was never an issue...Being a cheapskate and wanting to get my money’s worth out of the game, I forced myself to complete.  And you know what?  LOTF is not a bad game.  I might even have enjoyed it a wee bit.  But I would not recommend this game unless it is on sale – because there are much better games (i.e. Dark Souls) which do everything LOTF does only much better.Still, LOTF is bloody gorgeous, looking like Todd Macfarlane and Warhammer Fantasy got together to make a Cannibal Corpse album cover.  The armour and weapon designs are so ludicrously spikey and evil that I want to break out my old Slayer albums.  Sound is also great, with satisfying clunks and crashes giving combat a satisfying feel.  The bosses are super cool too.  I also particularly liked the system up upgrading weapons and armour with runes, which is very simple but kinda nice anyway.However, I found the controls to feel really unresponsive.  No matter what class you play as, there’s a significant lag between actually hitting the attack button and Harken swinging whatever oversized spike metal thingy he is carrying.  It lead me to a lot of frustration, as I signed in vain while the enemy would rush off for a cup of tea, do the washing, then come back and put their shield up in the time it takes Harken to wind up his attack.  Second, the game is not really challenging, and it doesn’t have difficulty settings.  Most enemies can be overpowered just by circling endlessly and button mashing, and many of the bosses can be easily beaten on first try once their attack pattern has been seen a few times.  I understand that NG+ is more of a challenge, but I’d already lost interest by then.In summary, my opinion, which you don’t have to agree with, is that LOTF is an ok Dark Souls-lite game, but I wouldn’t recommend it because Dark Souls, even Dark Souls 2, does EVERYTHING infinitely better aside from graphics.  Furthermore, if I’m in the mood for some fantasy hack and slash and I’m not in the mood for Dark Souls, I’d play Devil May Cry, Darksiders 2, Dragons Dogma, Revengence or something long before I’d go for LOTF.  but hey there seems to be a lot of ppl who really loved this...what does a stoopid noob like me know anyway? git gud or go home...Edit - Now that Dark Souls 3 is out there is no need to even contemplate this game.  Or go with Salt and Sanctuary if your a 2d indie hispter - that said, if they make a sequel i'd give it a look as, if they got the gameplay right, this could easily be the Slayer album cover made flesh the never-dying 12 year old inside me is always looking for.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												FINAL UPDATE; Removed Original Review to make room;Well, I made it to NG++. IIRC, the First Warden on NG+ hit me for like 8 damage in full heavy armor. On NG++ he hit me for 12. I played a bit further and noticed a very sharp increase in damage from certain monsters in the first area of the game; so yeah, the difficulty technically increases.The shame is that it took so long to get this way. The gameworld is quite small once you run through it once and that "newness" feeling wears off. Its cramped, short and leaves me wanting. Lords of the Fallen is a decent games with Dark Souls mechanics, but after the first playthrough the game loses its drive very quickly. 7/10 is the best I could rate this game, especially with this crashes that I have also fallen victim too.Bottom line;+Great graphics+Dark Souls mechanics...ish+decent story and voice acting+has a feeling of drawing you in; presentation and atmosphere is well-done.+music is fantastic++catacombs area is perhaps the best area in the game.+cloth/cape mechanics are the best I have EVER seen in a game. I totally wish DS has this type of technology as well as other RPGS-relatively short. I finished the first run in 11-12 hours. NG+ was perhaps the same if not quicker because I was very powerful.-Feels cramped and the world is not nearly as large as the impression gives you. In ratio size, the game world is probably 1/3 of the DS series; that includes anyone of the games.-difficulty feels like its wildly overtuned on certain mobs while rediculously undertuned on certain bosses-less variety of monsters as one would expect-magic itself is remarkably similar to itself; all spells utilize a flaming avatar to accomplish what the spell would give you. Feels too generic and similar and "Mimic" was downright frustrating.-underwhelming crafting system. +/- defense in an element and/or attribute scaling and one would have hoped that putting a "Fire Rune" onto my weapon would make it burst into flames and set enemies on fire; nope. Only truly useful rune was the the attribute scaling one which doubled my 2h output to be able to put out enough DPS to kill the final boss on NG+ after over 12 attempts.-NG+ = shards for loot or you pick up any armor from the chests that you missed on your first playthrough. Incredibly boring-I genuinely expect to continue to progress my character throughout ALL playthroughs and leveling up my character in NG+ was a damn grind and chore beyond what I would have expected.I expected more. I bought into the hype and the game failed to meet my expectations. Im an experienced gamer. Ive been playing games through my days ever since NES. Im no stranger to game mechanics and progression. Get it if you want it, but dont expect to be floored unless you have low expectations and standards. I wish I would have waited for sale.UPDATE-2(Slight Spoilerish);;From what I have read playing as a warrior is generally considered to be the easiest form of play. This is using a shield and possibly a 2-handed weapon. I use this setup. I decided to jump back in and play a bit more on NG+. I have reached the Citadel and have noticed a large jump in damage to my character. I am using the heaviest set of armor with the best defense stats and a tyrant in the graveyard nearly one-shotted me with his overhead swing. It was a genuine "WTF" moment.Needless to say that I was quite suprised. I continued playing a bit more and noticed sharp rises of damage intake during set points. The catacombs boss proved an interesting challenge as he hit quite a bit harder which is something I was not used to. I actually died on the giant boss that you eventually meet in the area of the three statutes. He hit quite hard.I am not picking up anymore armor on NG+ which leads me to believe that because my defense stats will generally not improve except whenever I mod them fully with runes that I have picked up throughout the game and because the damage intake is steadily and sometimes sharping increasing as I get towards end-game sections; I do feel that perhaps NG++ will truly be where the actual difficulty lies that people most want concerning this game.Its a matter of deduction based on the information available. This is with the best defense AND without using spells. As such, I am now actually looking forward to NG++ to see just how punishing this game truly is.Also, because of the high defense given by heavy armor...this means that medium and light armor wearers will face significantly more damage and possibly one-shots on several abilities given by several mobs. This is not considering any defensive advantages given by the magic system in this game. It is purely utilizing armor and weapons.I have currently 13 potion slots and I find myself using them more and more. That is a good sign. I will update when I finally experience NG++UPDATE;After playing through NG+ to the halfway to 75% point I must say that I have to change my review to being recommended only if your dead set on getting a game that is similar to the DS series or waiting for a sale or unless your out-right starved for something new and exciting.Unless you enjoy the story and are set on keeping the same playthrough running as much as you can then you will not find hardly anything at all to keep you engaged with the game after beating it the first time...unless you want to make different choices to affect the ending slides; but you could just watch youtube, right?I saw the vids on youtube and even the tips during the loading screen. They said you will get new loot and stuff on subsequent playthroughs. The only thing that I have noticed are new lore drops specifically in the regions on normal that were not there but were then there on NG+As with regards to armor/weapons? I did pick up a light armor set which seems to be the rogue counterpart to the last heavy armor set I picked up for warriors. I could have missed it on my first playthrough, however, so this isnt saying much. I went through this entire experience of NG picking up shards 95-99% of the time. Very underwhelming.My thoughts are that what was promoted is not what was essentially delivered to a satisfying context.Im disappointed. The combat is good, but I feel that long-lasting value is lacking to this game and that is a damn shame.For the first playthrough, however, it was a blast.

number of helpful: 806 of 1,355 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												UPDATE: beaten the game and all opinions below still apply, honestly (I was about 8 hours in when i wrote this impression). I can say that if you don't like Demons/Dark Souls, you will more than likely doubly-dislike this game. So just to get that right out in front, don't look for this game to change your opinion on the Souls-style gaming, because it wont. Now to people who are looking for a Souls-like experience, in my honest opinion, you should NOT get your hopes up. While the game has an overall Souls feel when it comes to combat, as Lords of the Fallen (LotF from this point on) seems to borrow VERY heavily from the game, it's about as far from Souls-FEELING as it could be given how closely the mechanics work. The game- is SLOW. Like, "snail trudging through molasses in winter-time" slow. In every aspect that a game can be considered slow, LotF is. Player movement is slow, attack animations are slow, roll speed is slow, gauntlet attacks are slow, spell startups are slow- hell even the story is slow, but I'll talk about that later.If you go into this game thinking you're going to play it like anything other than that fat-rolliest heavy armored monster-weapon-wielding tank in Dark Souls, then you're going in with expectations far exceeding what the game allows. Unfortunately, it seems that many of the enemies and a few of SOME enemies attacks seem to be designed entirely around blocking the hit and then countering after their animation is done- which is fine for the most part, but when LotF advertises dual-wielding fast weapons and light armor with the option to dodge roll away from enemies, it's NOT fine. The level of reaction time a person would need to dodge some enemies moves borders on precognition, and this is coming from a Darks Souls 1 and 2 vet (nearly 800 hours combined with both games across PC and Xbox 360). Not only that, but many enemies have RIDICULOUSLY GOOD tracking on their moves. Which is GREAT for THEM, but sucks  for the player. Take all of the complaints of Dark Souls 2 humanoid enemies having auto-tracking overheads and you can apply that to almost every enemy in the game with nearly every attack. Granted you can still dodge them, just like in Dark 2, but it's still difficult, and if you're anything but fast rolling, the chances of you rolling far enough to be out of range of their next auto-tracking attack is slim. Take one of the later bosses for example- The Infiltrator. VERY MINOR SPOILERS  I dodge the first attack of her hit string, by rolling UNDER her, only to have her INSTANTLY turn around and hit me with her second swing because I could not roll far enough away from her. Very, very poor design. I wont get into the fight itself until later. The enemies in this game so far (as I said, about 8 hours in) are almost all humanoid. So circle-strafing almost completely nullifies the lesser enemies as a threat, which is fine. However, some of the enemies later on end up having such good tracking that it's nearly impossible to get around their shield. This wouldn't be a problem if after guard-breaking them with a kick my attack animation was fast enough to hit them before they recovered but sadly with just about anything other than claws or daggers, it was not fast enough, and I was left fighting a frustrating battle of "wait until they attack and try to move in before they recover" which also proved incredibly difficult. Okay, so how about blocking with my shield and allowing them to suffer recoil from their blow and sticking them then? Nope. They recovered before my hit landed and blocked it. OKAY. HOW ABOUT I JUST SIT HERE AND HOLD MY SHIELD UP UNTIL AN OPENING PRESENTS ITSELF. ahahahaha- no. He guard breaks me with a shield slam that is almost faster than my brain can even register and then follows up immediately with a slash that takes down 3/4's of my health bar. Mind you- this is all ONE ENEMY- but it's the perfect example to what I feel is just bad enemy design in general. You want to make your enemies hard, cool give it some of the counters above, but not ALL of them. I literally had to just run away from the damn things until my mana filled up enough to allow me to burst him with my gauntlet- which took 4 hits (and if you've played the game, just after you get the gauntlet, getting in 4 gauntlet blasts can take a long freakin' time with the slow mana recharge and how much it costs early game). Not only that- there were 3 of these enemies in the area, sort of following the same corridor. Hurrayyyy. I beat them but I was not at all happy with what I had to resort to in order to do so- for the gauntlet to be the ONLY reliable way to deal with them at that point just was not fun- at all. As for the monster designs, they're fairly simple. They don't do much poise damage, they mostly stagger off your shield, and some do fire or poison damage but it's all pretty standard stuff. Nothing to complain about, nothing to praise. Boss designs- SPOILERS AHEAD So many of you probably know that the first two bosses are tower-shield users. Basically you wait for them to attack and either dodge or block and retaliate. Standard stuff, nothing to talk about with the first one... The SECOND tower shield boss- summons adds. Which, if you're a Souls fan, you are probably of the same opinion as I am, that adding adds to your boss fight is basically admitting that 'yeah, we didn't know how to make the fight hard or interesting, so worry about these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s screwing with you while you're fighting this brainless boss". Now I make an exception for this one, because the boss does not stay active while the adds are out, so you fight the adds and then go back to the boss- fine, whatever. Pointless? Sure. Harmful? Not really, it's fine. Now beyond that is where it starts getting irritating. The next boss I fought killed me a few times by doing an AOE attack that covers the whole entire arena. He has a startup and once you know what comes after the start up, you know what's on it's way- but the first time, you're screwed. Cheap death, cheap gimmick and utterly pointless once you figure out WHERE you're supposed to stand, which is not exactly made apparent when your first instinct is just to avoid the blue bulbs and hide somewhere they're not near. On top of that- he summons adds. Same with the next boss, Infiltrator. Adds, heals itself, mana is being sapped.. otherwise a boring fight with only a few actual attacks.The level design is-  okay. The game does take the open world aspect of Dark Souls 1 with areas looping back and creating shortcuts from other areas- but the problem is going THROUGH the areas is pretty linear. It's much more akin to something like Dark Siders 1 level design where you go the way they want you to go and then loop back around when you acquire a thing that you needed to get into an area you couldn't before- which is really just to create the ILLUSION of an open world game. On top of that, in my first few hours of the game, I saw just blatant copies of previous areas with just a few minor furnishing adjustments and enemy placements. Pretty lazy. However, the ART style is really nice, if you're into that Diablo-esque "hardcore metal hellspawn" style- which I am, aha. If all that wasn't enough to spook you, the game has performance issues. My PC runs  Shadows of Mordor on max settings without a stutter, this game drops inexplicably below 30 FPS constantly, and sometimes lower- and that's with settings set down on what are described as, or would be considered "medium." Very disappointing. Story is the most barebones "i'm a tough guy" story you could have. Don't come to LotF looking for anything more.Sorry. Can't recommend this game so far...

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												Game is underrated because of somer players experiencing crashes. Those negative experiences are greatly overshadowing the people who are in game enjoying themselves. To people who are experiencing crashing: I was one of those people. An AMD Catalyst update fixed the issue for me. I'm running HD Radeon 7xxx series in crossfire and Windows 8.1.Please stop giving a negative review of the entire game because it's crashing for you. Every game release has issues. If the developers were ignoring our experience that would be one thing. But the developers are constantly replying in the discussions and releasing patches in order to solve the issue as best they can. It's too early to determine whether we've wasted our money. If you're still crashing then enjoy something else in life and check back later. You can't review a game you haven't played. Yes, you've spent your hard earned money. But. You. Have. Not. Played. The. Game. There's proof the developers are working and some people's crashes (mine included) have been resolved.EDIT [03/03/2015]:Interesting. I happened to check back at this review and saw all of the negative comments, which I can only assume are the same people having issues.Should the product have been a better quality upon release? YES. But the reviews people left gave a horribly false impression that the developers were not responding AT ALL, which was FALSE.This is where I had a problem and felt the need to write a positive review. My review offered what I thought was important to tell people that was lacking in other reviews (i.e., nothing explaining for the umpteenth time that it's a Dark Souls clone. Seriously, how many reviews do you need explaining that?). People were focused on negative experience of the game crashing; therefore, my review focused on the opposite side of that. My patience with the developers, WHO HAD RESPONDED to the crashes with attempted bugfixes, is not apologetic. I saw complaints. I saw responses attempting to address those complaints. That's progress in the right direction. And realistically, that's the best that can be done because magic doesn't exist. NO EXCUSE for a faulty product, but at the same time, leave a fair review noting that developers are responding.TL;DR (for the lazy ones): You have a right to do what you want with your money. Leaving a negative review because a game doesn't meet your expectations (e.g. doesn't work) within a certain timeframe is COMPLETELY FAIR. Just make sure you say THAT in your negative review. It is UNFAIR for EVERYONE to a write negative review suggesting development just isn't responding to problems. This is what my original review was targetting: the people writing negative reviews because they were crashing and claiming development was unresponsive. Some of us have been on both sides and would take a responsive development team fixing a faulty product over a decent product but unresponsive development team any day. I hope everyone is now in a position to enjoy the game. I won't be reading any further comments.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												UPDATE: After approximately 10 hours of play, I have to say that Lords is surprisingly well put together, fun to play, and perhaps most importantly (at least it was for me), LOTF FEELS like Dark Souls!-Blocking, movement, rolling, armor weight plays a role in your roll... Familiar and comfortable - which is good, because LOTF's combat is (dare I say it) deeper than DS!-The classes dictate your gameplay - the rogue is VERY different from the warrior, who is also very different from the mage. -Ph4t l3wtz r ph4t. A great RPG inventory, which leads me to...-Stats page! I don't want to spoil the game or the story for anyone, but everything here is a lot of fun. I've got 3 of the big bosses down and the game is still mysterious but scattered with "lore" drops that unlock more of the story. There have been a couple of side quests, and a Dark Souls-eque decision I had to make regarding an NPC (help him or harm him). I look forward to NG+, which I haven't said about a game in a long time. 8.5/10Buy it for sure, watch it for a sale if you have to, if you liked Dark Souls you will enjoy LOTF!====Update: After 3 hours of gameplay, I've re-rolled my character and beat the first boss twice. Dark Souls fans, praise the sun! This game is awesome!====A polished, working and serviceable Dark Souls clone. And I say that with the utmost respect, because it's fun, challenging and feels like a mix of Darksiders, Diablo and Dark Souls. If you enjoyed DS, you will enjoy this..... If it runs. As of this review the game is poorly optimized and requires tweaking to make it run properly. AMD users have no love at launch and many have issues, Nvidia users should change their Physx settings to GPU through the Nvidia control panel. If it is patched, this game is an outstanding achievement for CI Games, because it's well built and fun to play.

number of helpful: 28 of 35 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												Thank you to Deck13 and CI games for development and publishing Lords of The Fallen. I enjoyed the world and charcters you provided for me to escape.As i end my run of LOTF during new game + and reflect my on experience it reminds me of a successful turn-based game(Aarklash Legacy) that stripped away a lot of "trending" RPG systems to the bone while focusing more on gameplay. I think thats exactly what LOTF also has done though with mixed results but it has more me excited for a sequel rather than another Dark Souls.LOTF is a 3rd person action game in which you play as Harken(no charcter custimization) a criminal that has been sprung from jail from a mysterious monk named Kaslo. Kaslo insist you are the one to defeat the evil rhogar and the revived God Adyr as it takes evil to slay evil. Though Harken wears his crimes on his face with markings(very cool)it is only mentioned briefly from a run in with a guard and we never know what crimes he committed. A big opportunity missed in that regard. Along this story quest you will face a few decisions that will decide one of three possible endings. Its a good video game story with good voice acting but none of it was memorable. Its all pretty standard by now, but more effort is here than expected and its actually a story rather than pieces and speculation.Once you start the game you are only given 3 classes to choose the cleric, warrior, and rouge which for story reasons makes sense. All charcters have pre made stats so custimization is minimal. I chose the rouge class which from my understanding is considered hard mode and at the start it is very diffcult as a slight breeze seemed to kill me. Fortunantley you are able to level quickly but it took a good 10 hrs before i felt powerful. Leveling your character is pretty normal as you slay enemies and complete quests you are rewarded with XP which you will distribute through either upgrading your magic(4 spells x 3 upgrades) or physical (6 options STR/VIT/END/FAITH/AGI/LUCK). Again comapared to a lot of RPGs these upgrades while minimal i think actually made it easier to maintain the specific charcter you envisioned at the start. Gaining experience does come with its caveat of risk and reward. In LOTF the longer you stay alive and kill enemies a multiplier for XP will continue to increase(x2.0 max) and If you die your 'ghost' will be waiting for you to return. However, your ghost will dissolve based on the stregnth of the multiplier. The larger the multiplier the longer it will be visible and at 100%. I like this idea but it is basically null becasue of checkpoints are located everywhere. I can only think of one instance where i was not able to retrieve my ghost and it was just a dumb mistake on my part. LOTF also does not follow todays trend with a massive open world but a more confined semi linear castle exploration design. This made for walking around slow and steady and some of the levels are good but late near the end game i was totally lost and could not recall where to go. Dont be mistaken there are some levels that are outdoors but for the most part action is in tight hallways. The level and quest design also plays into LOTF no hand holding policiy which i love but if you want to make it easier on your self keep notepad and pen close. Not suprising as with any title today i recall LOTF did have some launch issues with some bugs and graphical glitches but other than a crash or 2 the game played and looks amazing. The envorments, weapons, enemies and charcters all have a heavy metal vibe and the sound design maybe some of the best for this type of genre i have heard. The thud of weapons against shields, echoes in the caverns and just the wind blowing all make for a very immersive experience.  As a rouge i moved fast and with the spells available i was pretty powerful late in game but getting in close against enemies was high risk. However a majority of fighting is always one on one so encounters are not too difficult. I pretty much used either daggars or these awesome wolverine like claws  as weapons and late in the game i found out somthing i did not know. Without spoilers it basically changed everything about my charcter and i suddenly became a real bad♥♥♥♥♥  If LOTF has its 'thing' its these hidden secrets about weapons, bosses and quests. After i completed the game and found out some of the secrets i was suprised how deep and how many there actually are becasue in In game you would never know. After my initial playthrough i started up new game + which a rarely do but becasue i wanted to see if any higher gear would drop and i was really dissapointed. Enemies and loot did not scale and i basically walked through the first 4 bosses without a scartch. If it did scale who knows i proabably would still be playing.LOTF is a good new action RPG that compliments other titles in the genre but seperating itself in some new and exciting ways.  It doesnt follow todays RPG trends of needing a huge open world, 100hr campaign, and deep crafting system it relys on good ol' game and gameplay and that is always welcome in my librbary. PositivesA solid 3rd person action RPG game that doesnt take 100 hrs to completeEnviroments, weapons, charcters and enemies look greatSound design is incredibleNice clean UINo hand holdingLevel design is ok, but i would like to have seen the world more interconnectedSome bosses are great A lot of 'hidden' content for quests, bosses and equip You can break the game making it easyNegativesToo many Checkpoints decrease the tension, maybe an option to decrease for difficulty?Enemy variety Some bosses were very basic in design patternNo scaling for enemeis or loot in new game +the balance of enemies and spells  fells off- you are OPNot a lot of difference in spells from each type of charcter choiceCrafting is quite shallowInventory UI could be better-cant drop itemsNotes:I played on my desktop PC with an R9 390 video cardI have about 30+ hrs in one full playthough and upto the 4th boss on new game +I played the game at 1080P/ 60 running smooth with 1-2 crashesI used an Xbox controller

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Genre - Dark Fantasy Action RPGSo this game is like Dark Souls, not as good, but in the same league. Dark Souls fastly became one of my favourite game series after a bit of trial and error. This game follows a similar format, fight monsters in third person with melee and a few spells (no ranged in this one I'm afraid). The combat flows quite well, although it could be a bit more accurate on registering a hit sometimes. The mobs are quite varied and will need different tactics to defeat. The same can be said of the bigger bosses. You also might need to grind a bit (not too much so far though) to beat some enemies, but this doesn't feel like a chore. You grab armour and weapons and can customise them with different level gems. The story is standard fayre but it seems to keep the game flowing. You only get the one male character model to use but with three different classes, sorry girls and girl wannabes. I have basically used this game after finishing Dark Souls 2 to give me a break before I jump into the next New Game +, and this game does the job nicely.

number of helpful: 108 of 174 people (62%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												Don't. The game looks pretty. It sounds pretty. The character development feels like it could be pretty.The combat though... isn't good. It's slightly clunky but managable at first, but then you run into an enemy with a tower shield and the fun just jumps out the window and the tedium sets in.It's a game that needs other options on how to deal with enemies, and pigeon-holes you into doing only one thing, regardless of what your spec happens to be. The fact that the rogue, for instance, needs FAITH to cast his spells (and be a rogue) should be a clue. The fact that a tank/warrior needs the same stat to cast HIS spells should also be a clue.The classes don't really work the way they need to.That's not even getting into how the combat feels, which is awkward.Weapons and characters do not interact as if they are in the same world. I feel like the animation happens, then damage somehow happens. I don't feel like the weapon is connecting with anything. The weapons certainly don't connect with the terrain, which is a shame.Weapon animations themsevles are largely dissapointing not just in visual appeal but also in practical use in combat. One of the first weapons you get is a greatsword from a boss, and it is arguably the best in damage for a strength based character but it is also almost useless due to it's slow animation speed and the fact that the move set is awkward in a fight.Dodges are completely useless. They are too short, the invulnerablity is too short, and enemies will follow you through a dodge and hit you anyway if they are charging.Sprinting is a pain in the butt on a controller. Holding down the same joystick you use to move is not a good idea for a sprint function. It's especially awkward since you need sprint to fight and you need sprint to JUMP. And jumping is required to get to certain areas.Leveling up takes too long and the rewards for leveling up aren't that interesting.Spells are limited and mostly boring at the start.Some enemies (especially those with shields) are tedious to the point of frustration because their guard can't be easily broken, dodging around them doesn't work (they stick to you and rotate very fast), the kick attack is erratic and unreliable, and they don't seem to lose stamina when you hit the shield. They certainly don't lose more stamina than you do, and you stagger yourself if you hit a shield anyway.The enemies animations always seem faster than yours, even when they are using a great weapon and you are using a 1h sword. For whatever reason, enemies always seem to interrupt your animation while it is very rare to interrupt theirs. This means you can be spammed to death by enemy attacks, while you cannot spam them to death. This is especially frustrating when dealing with multiple enemies at once. Gods help you if more than one of them has a shield, because using a strong sweeping attack certainly won't.There are more things to complain about, but they all center around the combat system and controls. The thing is, 99% of the game is the fighting, and the fighting itself is tedious and frustrating. Unlike in Dark Souls where if you beat a monster that has been giving you issues and you feel elation, in this game I feel nothing. Ultimately, it feels like I didn't win. I feel like the game just randomly allowed me to win. Skill doesn't appear to play a part in how the game goes, which is exactly the opposite of what I wanted out of this game.In short, don't buy it unless it is heavily discounted. I'm glad I waited and didn't get it at premium new release price ($50+) but I still feel that at $30 I could have spent my money elsewhere and been happier. The game looks really nice, but it doesn't play like a play-tested game. I feel like it was such a missed shot. They had everything they needed to give From a run for their money, but the one thing they didn't perfect bit them in the rear.

number of helpful: 19 of 20 people (95%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 6
IntroductionIf you are that person thinking you might actually enjoy this game but hesitating because of the negative comment ratio, I suggest you not to. Just go out and get it, the content and quality this game offers is well worth its low price even without a sale. Now that being said, let's explain why;Artwork (9/10)The game has an amazing art style and very good graphics to display it. Environments, armors and weapons are of very high quality. Character animations are also well done.  Both movement and attack animations look very natural and feels right.Combat (8/10)Adapted from Dark Souls, the heavily punishing combat system is nothing original but works just fine with a large variety of weapon choices. Story (5/10) Altough we have an intresting main character, a not so bad universe and a few great dialogues, LOTF is not a story driven game. It does introduce us with some details of its universe with the collectible audio notes every now and then but since the game progress is slow due to its difficulty you never get caught in the flow of the story. Also the ending was rushed and looked cheap compared to the rest of the plot.Stability (10/10)I guess the game had some issues at the beginning hence it got a lot of negative comments about crashes and bugs but as for my 20 hour walkthrough I haven't experienced any crashes or glitches.SummaryLOTF is great choice whether you already like Dark Souls-like combat & atmosphere or you want to try it but don't really want to invest a big sum of money just to see if you would like that. It certainly is a very cost-efficient purchase and a fine game that I'd recommend.

												Ok, First of all: I had fun with this game. 13 hours of fun. It should have been 15 hours of fun. After "The Annihilator" Boss, he bugged, and I couldn't progress in the game anymore. This bug has been acknowledged by the devs since nov '14, and in april 15 there's still no patch to fix this. Ok. I hate when I can't finish games after 13 hours. I had to watch the lets play to at least know the ending, because I didn't want to invest another 13 hours for this bug to eventually happen again.So what's great about this game? + It's a Dark Souls clone, but it's a bit easier (if you like it to be a bit more casual)+ Great graphics and ambience+ way more simplified classes than in Dark Souls (things can get confusing in DS)+ not as "Dark" as Dark Souls, so maybe appealing to larger audiences+ it just feels more epicWhat's bad?- lip sync and dialogues. Wow they suck. Also the characters are moving like 1990 half life characters when they talk- Could have done without characters at all. You're not invested into them the least- Bugs. Game breaking bugs. And crashes.- Rather easy (more casual than DS)All in all, I would have loved to play this some more, or at least finish it myself. But as it is, for me right now, I can't recommend it - because not being able to play the game to the end SUCKS. This doesn't mean that this may happen to you, and as I said, the 13 hours i DID spend on this game were fun.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2016
												Lords of the Fallen is actually pretty great. I had held off picking up the game for a while because I'd seen a lot of "Meh" comments about it, but I actually really enjoyed it.Is it Dark Souls? No. Does it scratch that same itch? Absolutely.GraphicsThe game's gorgeous. From an artistic (design) perspective it's not on the same level as Dark Souls but they do a lot of great things with lighting, physics (except for some hilariously bad rag-dolls), and particle effects. There's also a lot of great texture work here. Cranked up, it's a very pretty game. It also has some of the most badass armor designs I've ever seen in a game, and none of them look bad, from the earliest ones to the stuff you pick up late game.CombatThe combat is quite fun if you're a fan of Dark Souls/Monster Hunter's style of deliberate pacing. It's got some pretty challenging bosses too - most of which I'd say are fair but tough. I think there are a few too many variantions on "Dude In Armor" enemy types but it's not too egregious. One thing I'll say is that it clearly has a primary focus on melee combat. You get a gauntlet which can be used for projectiles, and there's magic in the game, but the problem is that the magic skills are on timers and both it and the gauntlet share your magic resource, which regenerates fairly slowly. Both the magic and gauntlet aren't bad in terms of being effective, they just seem to be mostly supplemental and are designed to accompany your melee attacks, not to replace them.StoryThe story's kinda bleh to be honest - it's not exactly bad but it's a bit on the generic side. I think part of the problem is that they kindof drop you into the middle of things with very little context and I often felt like there were missing pieces - there's very little character development to speak of (there's really only a handful of speaking characters, for that matter), things just kindof happen as you progress. Most of the backstory comes from collectible audio logs (which are oddly represented by pieces of paper, but are literally referred to as "audio notes" while they're playing haha).ConclusionOverall I definitely think it got a bad/unfair rap primarily because it's a whole lot like Dark Souls but not quite as good. Outside of that comparison though, I actually think it's a really fun game. The combat is good. The graphics are good. It's challenging and scratches the old Dark Souls itch even if it's not quite on the same level. Recommended!

number of helpful: 84 of 137 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Length of Game: 10 HoursOptimization: Awful, worst port I've ever played,Difficulty: Difficult at first, far too easy 3 hours in.Design Choices; BadDon't buy this game.  Don't support the developers and don't think twice about it.  To detail why I don't think this is a good puchase, I'll start with the enemy variation.  This game does a good job initially at giving a wide variety of enemies to fight.  They all have unique ways to kill them and they stick out pretty well.  A few hours in, you will not only be fighting these same monsters, but you will get a few more that are anti-fun to deal with.  It's not that they're difficult, it's that you either have to wait forever for an opening or they have mechanics to bore you to death.Allow me to explain, using 2 enemies as examples.  There are very large soldier looking characters with a big shield that will block all your attacks.  You can't kick their shield out of their hand so you're left with two options.  Wait 14 years for them to lowe the shield to attack them or sprint at them and bash them with a tower shield.  Once you do option 2, you realize EVERY enemy is weak to that.  How very exciting, eh?  Second horrible mention is the mages that not only explode when they die, but pretty much have a kill move if you attack them during a certain period where they put white sparkles around them.  They do a TON of damage as well, which isn't necessarly horrible, but it's very cheap when you're beginning the game and when you kill them, they explode and kill you, forciing you to keep doing it until you figure it out it.  And while this wears its novelty off fast, you will encounter these things when you have plenty of health and they don't hurt you, but they still knock you down every time they explode, making it increasingly annoying.Let's move to bosses.  4 of them will most likely be somewhat difficult for you, probably.  I killed them in one go, and those first four bosses is the hardest this game will ever be.  The rest of them you either have too much equipment, or they just don't have interesting enough mechanics to worry about avoiding.  It becomes a mess, where your character is so Godly unstoppable that you juts completely wreck everything on screen.  It might be fun for some people, but given the way the combat system works in this game...it feels very cheap and hollow.  The reason for this is, you have a stamina bar, so you're not just going to wrack up tons of kills altogether, you STILL have to wait constantly for that to recharge, but without any challenge or thought as you progress in the game.  Rather than having to deal with difficult situations or enemies, you're dealing with boring enemies that you meet in the first 3 hours of the game, and bosses that die in a few hits.  It's very flat and not fun.Graphics are great, they look nice and have an art style that anyone who plays World of Warcraft would most likely enjoy.  They are not, however, optimized, and you will crash more than a blind person in a food store.  You will find enemies later will explode, which is a boring as♥♥♥♥♥♥mechanic by itself, but will often cause the game to crash to desktop.  This happens REGULARLY on the most annoying ♥♥♥♥ing stage in the game.  There's a maze like area later in the game in which you have to pull 3 switches and these fire dogs are EVERYWHERE in it, and ONE of them will crash your game.  This is ridiculous beyond belief, there's not way this should have gotten through Quality Assurance.While the game has just released for almost a week now, the developers are trying to show care and fix their game up, but I feel the damage has been done and hurts their credibility.  If they cared to fix the game up, there's no way they should have had so many game breaking bugs, bad balancing and generally boring gameplay.  If you're looking to scratch that Dark Souls itch, I highly recommend playing Dark Souls 2 on NG+. as they add completely new monsters to areas, and add more boss mechanics.  Or whatever your favorite game is, don't let me tell ya how to think.Thanks for reading!

number of helpful: 53 of 83 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												This is a mere first look review, as a dad and a gamer my time is very limited (sad face).  However I put a good almost solid 7hrs or so in it so I can at least give you all an idea of what to expect and how it plays.First of all, do I recommend this game?  Sometimes this can be a tough question, however Lords of the Fallen is very well built fundamently enough to give an absolute yes.  If you love the Souls series you will get a more refined experience of risk and reward.  Is is better than Souls?  I feel the two have their own place and one does not outshine the other.  However Lords of the Fallen has a loot based gameplay which does drive you to go onward to see what else you can find and being able to switch gear and adapt to what you want to play as for that specific boss or sceniro is greatly appreciated.  I'll break down things in categories to give a better understanding of things.The StoryRun of the mill and not very interesting in the least.  The characters you meet you will not give two ♥♥♥♥♥ about as they don't even seem to have a personality.  They are nothing more than virtual mannikins.  However the lore (audio logs you can find around the world) and atomsphere is something to behold.The CombatThis is where I feel the game shines.  The combat is very fun and engaging, there is no animation waitout so if you are mid-swing and need to dodge you can do just that.  You can react to your situations with near instant input reaction.  You can also play to your style and not be punished for it, sometimes on the Souls series there were bosses and encounters that pretty much required a shield build to stay alive (or praise the sun for some god damn luck), this game allows you to play to your strengths with the build you want.  You have stamina which will affect the amount of swings you can do before you have to take a breather, which adds some strategy in the way you will be attacking your enemy.  You have mana which allows you to use your abilities and guantlet to shoot enemies from afar.The Bosses (Lords)The absolute best part of this game is the boss fights.  Not only are they scripted to do different things for each phase but the complete strategy you had planned out will change drastically.  This gets more and more apparent as you progress throughout the game.  You will feel as you are fighing epic bosses and feel accomplished after defeating them, much like the Souls series you will die and die alot.  Each boss plays on the area that they are in, what I mean by this is they sort of interact with their surroundings and you need to use it to your advantage.The Loot/EquipmentThere is chests to find and loot off of enemies and Lords.  There is legendary versions of items as well which normally has to do with defeating a Lord with a certain condition or challenge.  The loot seems to be varied and happens enough to where you want to keep going into your inventory screen and seeing if what you got is better.  The equipment comes in 3 classes (light, medium, heavy) and has a weight value which will help you determine if it is right for your build or not.  Obviously if you want to be a rogue you would want light armor to help you roll and dodge with no restrictions.  However you can mix between light and medium to find a perfect middle ground, much like how you would avoid "fat rolling" in Souls.The "Level Up"So the unique thing about this game is that there is a risk vs reward, one that capatilizes on what the Souls series did but takes it one step furthur and makes it attractive to hold on to your xp.  The system is designed where you accumulate xp by defeating enemies, that xp is not safe, if you die you lose your soul and you have to go back and get it to get your xp back much like Souls.  However the cool thing here is, the more xp you carry with you the better the loot drops and the better the xp bonus.  For once a system that rewards the risk.  If you care not for the risk, you can bank your xp at a crystal in which you can transfer it to spell points for your abilities or stat points which allows you to ramp up your base stats.  This system is by far what makes this game interesting and questions "Is it worth trying to beat this boss with my 10k xp?"The ControlsI feel these are refined and really excellently laid out.  There are toggle keys to switch your weapon types, spells, and consumables on the fly.  This is the first game in a long time where I felt the keyboard setup was actually more usable than a controller.  That is normally a huge flaw when it comes to action games, this however just works and works well.  After trying a boss with the controller just to see if it was an easier experience, I quickly switched back to the keyboard.  I'm a keyboard and mouse guy, with Souls I had to use the controller since the input lag was horrid, but with this game I am happy to say, awesome keyboard and mouse controls.  The GraphicsVery well made textures and models.  It is a very beautiful looking game.  There is interesting set pieces and things out in the distance to catch your eye.  The snow falling, the wind blowing, all great stuff.  However the game does seem to randomly slowdown in certain areas for little to no reason other than unoptimize graphical elements.  The snow falling and looking in certain directions can cause your frames to drop quite a bit.  Hopefully they fix this soon, a smoother experience is always a plus.OverallLords of the Fallen is a satisfying experience overall and I highly recommend it to any Souls fan.  It has its kinks and issues, mostly random slow downs, but I have heard of issues where characters popped in and out of cutscenes or graphical elements missing.  I've glitched a few bosses to the point they were unbeatable but resetting the fight will fix the issue and it seems to happen if you disrupt their phase change somehow.  It is a rare occurance was only able to do it once.  Have fun killing the Lords!

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												After all the technical glitches and bugs seem to be (mostly) fixed, the game is now playable, but beware: Bugs weren't the only issue plaguing this beautiful game:First off, let me say I have played and beaten both Dark Souls, soul level one challenges, Ng+7 and etc.. Now.. to Lords of the Fallen.      Pros:- You start in a beautiful looking world that truly does remind one of "next gen" with partical and lighting effects only adding to this goregous game. - Combat takes some getting used to, however is not terrible once you seperate Darksouls and lords, as they are two different games. - You feel very weighty, weapons are slow and powerful feeling, sending a mob flying across the room from a well timed hammer strike is always a good feeling.      Cons:- After playing through the game, I honestly must say the biggest fault is enemy design, the devs wanted a difficult game, they got one -- For the wrong reasons. - Confusing levels, and no map! While some might like this, I again found it merely to be a time sink -- Confuse the player on where to go and they'll play longer and like the game more! Thank goodness enemies only respawn if you die.- Many enemies have one weakness and only one for the accurately leveled player; ranging only taking damage from spells, to having a shield that is practically unbreakable. ("Just shield break!" any seasoned dark souls player would say -- One issue, you cant in Lords of the Fallen, making turtling NPC's one of the biggest time sinks and inflating the time you'll spend in an otherwise short game.)- Boss design: Easily the biggest con for me, bosses weren't difficult in a dark souls fashion, they were tedious and annoying. Sure, dodge the big hits, deal with the adds they summon, run away from the big one shot mechanic, and the boss has full healed again! Time to widdle away at his HP for the 15th time in a row. The last boss especially being unkillable unless your character is built for damage and damage alone, tanky characters or slow hitters -- Enjoy never killing this boss due to its "difficulty". - Story. Well, it was lacking, and kinda there. Almost felt like the writers watched Elder scrolls: oblivion being played on mute and wrote their own story to go along with it.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												EDIT 2:  End-game, some bugsEDITED: Read bottom for help against stutter and potential decrease in crashes!After an hour of gameplay there ain't much to say. But the game is awesome so far, controls are a bit different than Dark Souls but there actually is alternative controls which makes it EXACTLTY the same. The game itself is amazing, love the graphics and the combat is brutal and realistic, get caught in a combo and you're dead. Much like souls, exp drop on death and is reclaimable, but there's some other things too that is different and maybe a bit more... Creative?For souls fans, I really would recommend. There's no customization (sadly) other than new armor/weapons (looks amazing though).Edit 2: End-game, some bugsAlright, so I have reached the end of the game and I'd like to share my complete opinion.The game is still really good, I freakin love the various, enemies, bosses, armors and weapons throughout the game. Having said that, there's still some bugs and the game is... Resource heavy. My rig (GTX 780, 16GB RAM, i7-4790K CPU @ 4.00GHz) crashes after a while of playing and I get a message about my graphics card crashing, probably overheating. I'm no expert, but I'd say the game needs some tweaking, because there's obviously something wrong.Some bugs I've discovered: http://fextralife.com/forums/p686398/bug-report-various-bugs-big-or-small/#p686398Edit: Stutter and potential decrease in crashes!Got some more time in now, the game is really good and the bosses, storyline, creatures and equipment are really interesting. The only problem that seems to bother people are lots of crashing and I experience them too. Hopefully this will be fixed ASAP as announced by the developers.Things that might decrease the crashes and stuttering:-Turn off Nvidia Turbulence and/or Vsync in the Advanced Display Settings in-game (Announced by dev, might help).-Optimize the game with Gforce Experience!- Might help to configure the PhysX settings in the Nvidia control panel: Changing processor from auto to CPU helped for some (in my case it got worse, I use my GTX 780)
