content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												Hello all, first off, i haven't played dark soul so this review will be for the standalone game and no comparison between it and DS.The game remind me a bit of bound by flame, or even darksiders 2. The sad thing about is that most of the game, the stamina bar only feel like it is there to slow the action down. I can understand the wish for realism, but getting winded in 3 swings to instantly recover 2 seconds later.., i am not a fan of the mechanic as a whole. The game rpg roots are solid, using xp for ability and spells investments rather than actual level up (each investment count as a level up and require more to increase as you do it). Along with that you have a gamble mechanic where you can lose XP. Being defeated drop a xp ghost that you have to gather back or recover using items, otherwise the xp is lost. The more enemy you kill in a row without stopping increase the reward gained which is enticing, as some players may want to challenge themselves and end up with 40 levels worth of upgrades sooner than expected.  The bosses tend to be challenging and require patience or varied approach as your game play style can greatly vary depending if you're the heavy armor self healing type or the nimble rogue-style stabber.The game visually remind me of dark fantasy settings and is passable. At launch the game had a few stability issues, but they have since been fixed, for me at least. most of the few bugs i have seen weren't game breaking.The rest of the game is a rpg experience that focus on action and combat rather than storytelling, which may be something some players are looking for these days. It is not my best rpg of the year but, with the replayability, i am still glad i bought it.Have a nice day all!-Lost

number of helpful: 38 of 58 people (66%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Interesting combat, beautiful locations and character designs, although buggy and a poor story.I really enjoyed Lords of the Fallen. I've never played Dark Souls, although I have heard there are many similarities to those games, so if you've played those I suspect you know what you're in for. Fans of the Dark Souls games have criticised Lords of the Fallen for being too easy. This could be true, I certainly didn't struggle for any amount of time on any boss fights, although there is a level of challenge to learning how to fight effectively and to levelling your character up. Plentiful health potions and several of your spells can make the process feel easier than it may have been without them, and the dodging system is generally fairly generous in what counts as a hit or a dodge.The story is fairly standard fare, with no surprises and some terrible dialogue. It hits a few tired cliches along the way too, such as 'man is the real monster' and characters that are clearly going to betray you 'shockingly' betray you at the opportune moments. Having said that, the story worked enough that I wanted to continue playing and see it through to the end. The environments are beautiful, and a real draw. Set in a mountain monastary, I enjoyed unlocking the various areas and whilst there's a lot of back-tracking, it didn't take too long to reach anywhere else, with some areas feeling like hubs that you can branch off from. I've heard complaints of the areas not being distinct enough, I'm not sure I agree personally; there's some real variety, and the alternate 'rhogar' world you visit is quite striking, I feel there's enough variety without feeling like the game goes through a cartoony 'theme' for each zone.The game is relatively short (I completed it in about 15 hours), although it offers New Game + and New Game ++ modes for those looking for more, apparently offering a little more story and new treasures to discover. The game does have quite a few bugs, notably the game crashed completely on me three times in my 15 hours. Some enemies would bug out and stop moving, and I died for no apparrent reason a couple of times too. All that aside, I still really enjoyed the game, and if you're looking for something fun and not too shallow but not too deep, I'd recommend giving this a try.

												Game isn't perfect, but it received a patch (that cleared most/all issues i had) within 24 hours of release. some might argue that it should have released like that... smarter people might realize the sheer scope of different hardware, etc. and how most other developers don't respond that quickly. On to the game itself. the difficulty is that of Dark Souls (duh) but not in a bad way. each enemy is different, requires different movement/weapon choices. the character voice animations are pretty bad, but the textures are beautiful, and the combat feels fluid and dynamic. story seems interesting, albeit short and to the point in delivery. Would give 8/10 and shall recommend. (if you liked souls, then try this. it is a lot of fun, and refreshing to see a positive take on said gametype)

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												To preface this review, I beat lords of the fallen in 7.5 hours. on my first and only character.As a massive fan of dark and demon souls(well over 200 hours combined) I was very excited to bite my teeth into something even resembling dark souls. the beginning of the game is a blast, difficulty is on the low end and you are just murdering everything. first 2 bosses are a joke and took very little thinking to kill. about 1/3 way into the game, for no apparent reason their is a difficulty spike. the same brain dead enemies you were killing now have 4X health and damage. this♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off more than anything some enemies are much more stronger count parts of them self. yet the game doesn't give you a visual queue or even a different enemy model / weapons to show this difference. you will go into a room with 1 strong and 1 weak version of the same enemy, this can offset your play style and often can result poorly from you thinking 1 of the enemies is a weak version instead of a strong version. once you are past the difficulty spike which isn't terrible it just really came out of no where, its a complete breeze again. HEAVY ARMOR RULES EVERYTHINGall I used was heavy armor in this game while 2 handing my weapon. beat the game using the codex. 3 enemies coming at you? who cars just face tank right through them and you'll win.about the 5th or 6th boss? is the one with 3 legs and my god that boss was a joke. I literally just stood in front of it casting rage and destroyed the boss only drinking a single healing potion. it had mechanics I could see but why play around mechanics when you can just face tank something and win?RAGE IS OPwarrior spell rage allows you to use your weapon with 0 energy cost, holy♥♥♥♥♥♥is that powerful and super OPif you're in heavy armor have a relatively heavy weapon and use RAGE you will kill anythingshield bros? no problem use rage break their guard and kill with your infinite stun lock you have on thembosses? no problem slap on rage and get an easy 1,500 damage at the cost of taking a few hitsyou literally don't need to worry about enemies as long as you keep up a constant assault on them, since heavy weapons often do mini stuns you can combo and enemy or boss to death by just using combos with infinite energy.BOSSESbosses are for the most part a joke in this game.the only boss that I died to was the one where you travel dimensions and you have the option of fighting him in the open area and he uses 2 swords. forgot his name, but thankfully you had to do a little bit of thinking to kill him and it took me 2 tries to kill himevery other boss I downed in the first tryNow this all may seem like a lot of negatives, or positives if dark souls was to hard for you. But, somehow I had a reasonable amount of fun playing this game. graphics are superb if running on max settings. (ignoring the frame rate issues, crashes etc.) it was a decent hack and slash game. I enjoyed breezing through all of the late game content face taking and murdering everything. difficulty wise the game is not there but its a good amount of fun to load up and kill some stuff in. I plan on beating it on NG+ and NG++, to see if there are any interesting armors/weapons. lords of the fallen is the toddler version of dark souls, yet I still managed to have a good bit of fun being a dark souls vet.is it worth the 50 dollars? - probably not but I plan on speed running this game seeing how broken I can make itis it fun? - despite its issues and shortcoming I had a good deal of fun with the gamerecommend? - can't beat dark souls - start with this.dark souls vet? - pick it up and see how fast you can wreck everything in the gameit's a good bit of fun, id advise everyone just to try it out.

number of helpful: 44 of 69 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												Edit: Just when I said it wasn't quite as hard as Souls....Holy S**t!! After the 2nd boss the game cranks the difficulty up quite a bit it seems. There's an enemy I would compare to the Black Knight that uses a tower shield, that dare I say it is harder than the Black Knight. I figured out that if I timed it just right that I could stagger him with the RT power attack with the Persistance greatsword. I died countless times, and finally was able to take him down an get some nice XP and a "Codex" sword. As I said, it seems to be improving as I go along. One of the strongest similarities to Souls with LotF is how movesets, tactics and timing matter more than just sheer damage and speed. LotF REALLY punishes you for being careless with your armor and weapon loadouts. If you think you can just plow through everything with the same weapon and armor loadout you're sorely mistaken. Also, a BRILLIANT mechanic that I've been BEGGING for in the Souls franchise, shield charging bashes that can stun/knock down enemies. It is so much fun to use this mechanic. Also, one of my favorite mechanics from Dark Souls that was taken out in Dark Souls 2 has returned in Lords of the Fallen, KICKING!! I LOVE this mechanic, so much fun to use and does more for combat than you would expect.Terrific game so far, it's being way underrated. And this is coming from a major Souls fan here. It's gotten better and better as I go along. Despite strong similarities to Souls, it manages to really capture it's own feeling. It has a very unique feeling to it, and it's combat is unlike anything i've ever seen in a good way. Takes some time getting used to cause it's a bit weighty even compared to Souls, but it's very fun, challenging and satisfying. Not QUITE as hard as Souls, but I struggled a decent bit with only the 2nd boss. Great weapon/armor variety as well. Beautiful weapon/armor design, as well as great enemy and level design. I plan to update my review as I go along, but if anything it seems to be improving as I go along which is great. So far i'd say it's easily an 8/10. Kevin VanOrd from Gamespot and GameInformer were right on the money with their reviews. Not really seeing what the other reviews have an issue with that scored it lower. Take the game on as it's own ARPG experience like you SHOULD, and you'll have no issues seeing how good it really is. Something I think a lot of reviewers have failed miserably at doing. I LOVE Souls, and while I still would say it PROBABLY is overall better, that still does NOT make it the be all and end all of ARPG's, something apparently a lot of people need to come to terms with. Lords of The Fallen is a success in my humble opinion, and I recommend it 100%.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												Alright so this game has recieved a lot of bad reviews for being derivitive of the DS series, however I believe firmly that this game is very much on par with the souls games for a number of reasons. If  you don't want to read the whole review let me sum it up for you: if you enjoyed the souls games and were looking for something similarly difficult and fun then you will most likely enjoy this game. Here are the reasons why you will enjoy this:1. Visuals. This game has stunning visuals, much better than DS 1 & 2. The bosses, the textures, the armors and weapons all look ♥♥♥♥ing sweet. Very ambient lighting as well also sets a great mood for the game.2. Difficulty. Similar to the souls series, this game is extremely difficult and is paced much the same as the souls series (ie. kill enemies to gain something similar to souls, which you use to level up and if you die you lose your souls and can retrieve them on your next life and if you die again before getting them they are lost).3. Bosses. The bosses in this game look awesome and are extremely hard. If you beat one on the first try then kudos to you, but it's taken me at least 2 or 3 for most bosses and sometimes more. This difficulty leaves you with an extremely satisfying feeling when you finally understand the patterns of the boss, and their attacks and kick their asses and take their loot.4. Story. So in the souls games, the story is very vague. You hardly ever understand what you're killing and for what purpose, as well as your character because it is created by you, has no back story that you know of. Sure you get a general idea at the beginning as to what you're doing, but no real explaination or plot thickening occurs and you basically walk around killing♥♥♥♥♥♥ LotF however has a nice little back story to the game, as well as much more interactable NPC's within the game that really give it a better, more complete RPG feel. So basically that's it. This game is thoroughly enjoyable and I would highly recommend buying it ESPECIALLY if it is on sale as it is well worth  you time. This is an criminely underrated title and if you have any love for the format of DS's games then you should give this a shot.

												If not for near release day crashes, performance issues and negativity for copying Dark Souls.  It's a pretty decent game. (Patch 1.2 improved the game greatly, just completed first playthrough.  Highly recommended as of now)Supposedly the companies first big budget title (can't confirm or deny).  I for one, welcome our new western dark souls overlord.Pros:-Plays like a slower version of Dark Souls (Combat wise) (Huge perk imo)-Neat moveset variety (Per weapon, One handed, two-handed/duel wielded and a magical gauntlet)-Everything feels like they have weight to it (Heavier weapons will feel heavy, large shields will be near impenetratable)-Amazing graphics and breathe-taking views.-Replayability due to different playstyles, magic selection and NG+ (up to 3 times)-Decent upgrade system via runes (Discovered some weapons can change if you use the proper runes on them)-Lore is available if you want to look for it-Very fluid combat (Any attack into any attack)-High risk, high reward style of play is rewarded (Obviously, by name itself)-Intense moments where it's either kill or be killed-You can spec heavily into your playstyle (be it heavy weapons, a flurry of lighter blows, turtling-Enemies all have a niche, although sometimes shared (Immortality until you obtain their heart, two lives, tanky/high threat)-60FPS/1080P or potentially beyond ( I can now run max settings with almost no fps problems )-Most cons can be easily fixed with a patch (They have just done so)Cons:-Randomly crashes, one known to me with the fire-fiend explosive enemy(ies) (FIXED)-Major performance issues outdoors (FIXED / IMPROVED GREATLY)-Upgrade system is small and could be expanded upon (four choices with different rarity/power)-Once you know an enemies' weakness you can easily exploit it for a quick win-Heavy armor is easy mode and basically required unless you drag a fight out (Rephrase- more forgiving than relying on dodges alone which can be difficult)-Sidequests can be cut off by progressing too far into the main story-Most of the lore is hidden within discriptions and items you randomly pick up and not get a prompt to delve into.-You can't tell if you're going the wrong way until an enemy wrecks your♥♥♥♥♥♥br>-Reused areas and replaced mobs when you defeat a lord (Game always has you returning to places you've been (zzz same environment)-Borrows heavily from Dark Souls (Combat, some boss moves (I.E. Worshipper's ground spike move reminds me of Gravelord Nito's blade dance/scream)-DON'T LOOK AT THE BLOODY SUN, OH GOD MY EYES, LENSFLARE EFFECTS-Blotchy "snow sticking to camera" effect, bland hexgon like shapes.Protip: This is an opinion, please don't argue it.Edit: As of a couple hours ago patch 1.2 rolled out, I can now highly recommend this game as the crashes I have encountered have been fixed and outdoor FPS and other performance issues are a lot better.  A week from release and they fixed their game pretty damn well.

Posted: May 20, 2016
												Not sure what graphics engine they used, but this game was pretty.  I really enjoyed my play though with this game.  Some frustration with slow attack animations, but nothing game breaking.  I had read sites saying that this game considered easy mode Dark Souls, and I would have to agree.  Although it was still challenging at times, I did find as you got new gear the difficulty went way down.  Like most games, you will get a feel for a certain way of attacking, certain combos, and spells to use.  Once you master your technique this game is not very challenging but still wickedly fun.  This title may not have the depth, challenge, and longevity of the souls games, but for someone looking for a moderately challenging and beautiful ARPG this is a worthy pickup.  I would suggest anyone who is not familiar with action RPG titles play this one before attempting Dark Souls to understand some of the battle mechanics and frustrations that come with ARPG games.  Most definitely recommended.

												Not a bad game, not a great game. If you haven't played Dark souls, play Dark souls. if you have played Dark souls, play this and grow more appreciation for the master pieces that we have. But seriously, the games alright but it could have been so much better if the combat was better, there weren't only like 5 variations of enemies, the storyline was interesting, the lore was more interesting, the environment was more dynamic, the bosses had better mechanics, magic was better, the voice acting was better, the questing was better. I can go on. But despite all this, the graphics are really nice, the weapons and armor are designed nicely, the game in its entirety is so heavily influenced by Dark souls that it could never really be a bad game, it's still worth playing if it comes into your possession somehow.

												If you've played and enjoyed anything similar to the Dark Souls series, this game is right up your ally! After reading all of the negative "clunky" reviews, I had to investigate further - this is simply just players not familiar with an action RPG, and managing stamina/energy during combat and actions, or taking into consideration the weight management of equipment you're carrying. I haven't played a lot of the game, but can hardly wait to play more! This is seriously an under rated gem. Which is unfortunate that many will most likely not experience as a result of the reviews. The git-gud or git punished style game play is pertty similar to Dark Souls, but definitely has it's own flair/twist, and is quite enjoyable. I would say it's even more forgiving than a DS game, and is a great into into this style of game.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
Lords Of The Fallen ReviewI personally really like this title. Now, before I dive deep into this review I just want to clarify a few things. I had originally played this around November of 2014 on Xbox One. I think it ran at about 15 - 30 FPS. So I didn't see it worth it on Console. I never made it past the second boss a.k.a "Commander" while playing this on console because there was no difficulty option. I have waited until 2016 to pick it up because I bought a GTX 970 paired with my AMD FX-6300 so I can play it on PC. I haven't completed the game, because I am taking my time with it and exploring everywhere I can.Pros: Beautiful graphics. Good level designs. Sounds! The sounds are amazing in the game. From the footsteps of your plated boots hitting the ground to opening a demon chest and hearing it "roar" until completely opened. Options menu. I would have liked to see more, but what they have now is fine The "Feel" of the game. I love how heavy you can feel when wearing heavy armor and how light and agile you are when wearing cloth "rouge" armor. Weapons. There are plenty of weapons to choose from and having certain runes slotted into them makes the weapons more deadly! Looting. Oh man, looting in this game is so much fun! From looting armor, weapons and runes I can't get enough!Mixed: Combat. While the combat is somewhat balanced, it just feels "okay". We do have some special moves you can pull of depending on your orientation to the enemy and/or type of attack, I think is kinda boring. I've spent most my time with the following on every enemy. 2 Heavy attacks + 1 Regular + 1 Heavy.  AI. The AI in this game gives me a mixed feeling. The AI scales with your characters level so it makes sense to make them hard or challenging. Well, with the different types of enemies you encounter (Excluding bosses) I feel like some of them "cheat" or are more difficult than they should be. Music. (The Pros about sound were specifically on the in-game sound design, not the music) The music is okay, while it's nothing great, it does provide a certain feeling. I just wish they had a little more variety. While playing through the game you'll find yourself listening to the same audio tracks over and over again.Cons: Boss fights. I am a few bosses in and had the weapon "My Axe" and the "Symmetry" armor set. While wearing this armor you get a 15% (I think) Damage increased when two-handing a weapon. So, I had two runes added to "My Axe" one High Poison Rune and one Low Fire Rune. I literally hit the "Annihilator" Boss about 6 times and killed it. Certain bosses are hard and certain ones are too easy and predictable. Characters. I really dislike how all the character are introduced. Harkyn, a criminal we know that, but what for? Why was he chosen by Kaslo just to help "save" the world? Kalso, No idea who he is, besides a wizard/mage that was travelling with Harkyn and broke him out of prison. Anntanas, the guards look up to him as if he is a god. No real back story to him. (Keep in mind this is based off of not finding every single audio note and a general play-through of the game)_____________________________________________________________________________________________________Overall is a nice game. It's solid and is worth picking it up. I personally waited until it was on sale from $39.99 to $9.99 USD. I would spend $9.99 again on it in a heart beat. So, if you want to play dark souls or have tried and it seems too difficult for you then just pick this up. It's a much more relaxed casual look on a "Hardcore" Action RPG.Rating 8/10.

												At the time of writing this review I have still not played very far into the game, but I feel like I need to add a positive review among all the negative ones.First, I have played both Dark Souls and Dark Souls II, and I enjoyed them a lot. The second game wasn't the same blast as the first game, and that's why Lords of the Fallen has felt like a very refreshing change for me.The game is beautiful and modern in a way the Dark Souls games aren't, if you care for that kind of thing. The combat is in many ways very similar, but still has it's own feel with weapons, animations, movement and so on.So far I have beaten three bosses, and I got to say the game feels very cinematic in a way the Souls games aren't. The battles are dramatic and hard, and while I beat almost every boss in Dark Souls II on the first try, it felt good to get my♥♥♥♥♥kicked for once. The same thing as in Dark Souls apply though, that when you learn how the game works and the pattern of the enemies it becomes a lot easier.I have had a few crashes, and the game could be better optimized but I haven't had any big issues that most people have. Then again I have a GTX 980 and i7 4790K, so keep that in mind. I will probably update this review later, but I personally really enjoy this game so far and encourage you to watch some streams on twitch and make up your own mind. I can't understand why there are so many negative reviews, really.If you like hard games with a fantasy setting this is for you.

Posted: October 30, 2014
												If you like dark souls then you will probably like this game.  There are several problems with it though.  First off there are definetely performance issue which I suscpect are present because this game was written mostly as a console game which both consoles use radeon, and I use a nvidia card.  Also in regards to the gameplay I have found it to be much slower combat than dark souls.  In dark souls I often found myself going without a shield, carrying a big damage weapon and rolling to avoid most damage.  I do not really find that strategy to be all that effective in this as the enemies have more health and also seem to hide behide shields.  This isn't nessesarily a bad thing, I view it as kind of the opposite direction of where bloodbourne is headed as they are going for a more offensive playstyle.  The weapons in this game I think really need balancing.  The weapons you expect to deal high damage (clubs, greatswords, ext.) do far less damage than the staff weapon which attack much faster and consume less stamina.  Maybe I am missing a gameplay mechanic here but I really think axes and the like should do more damage than staves.  Something that I think is a huge streagth for the game is the magic.  The spell are so different from the ones in dark souls and it is something new.  I hope this is the first in a number of games that follow this dark souls like formula, a genre of fantasy rpgs with combat that doesnt suck.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												(Early impression of what I have played so far.  I will edit this to a review soon!)If you are a fan of the third-person action game genre with light RPG elements, I would highly consider this. The visual presentation is excellent. A stunning game. The combat and overall gameplay is FUN. The game isn't arcadey easy, but it does present you with a good amount of challenge. I hate to bring up the name here, but it is not Dark Souls hard. But that's the thing, it is not suppose to be Dark Souls hard.The premise of the story isn't all that bad, and reviews have clearly exaggerated this aspect of Lords of the Fallen.  I would say it is pretty in line with other third-person action, adventure games.  But one could argue that it is a loss when a game lacks a good story and plot.  Voice acting in LotF is also another element in the game that isn't awful.  It is average, but not to the point where you would want to cover your ears, singing "La, la, la, la, la, laaaa."  It did not make me cringe either.  I love the art style, the presentation, and the combat. There's weight to every attack and the weapons and armor that you cling onto for dear life as you battle hell and its minions. Despite this positive note, often times movement feels sluggish, and swinging a weapon feels too slow.With that said, you can really tell that the developers put a huge amount of work into this game. There is no doubt about it. This game took WORK. It's beautiful and stunning. It plays great. Runs great, even with the short-changed framerate lock (with vsync enabled). The lack of proper Steam overlay support and fix does bug me because I want to take those amazing screenshots.Speaking from the heart, because we all should, this is not a poor man's third-person knock-off of another game.  And I am not referring to "that" game.  I am speaking in general.  Have you ever played a third-person action Viking or Templar video game lately that was great to excellent, let alone good?  Yeah, I dream of those games for those time periods.  While this doesn't exactly fit those fantasy bills, this game is not a Mickey Mouse job from the repair shop.  It is a well developed game, that could use a few more weeks being polished because of the few technical issues that I may be just knit-picking here.I was going in with really low expectations, and I was pleasantly surprised.  Yes, I have played Dark Souls 1 and a bit of Dark Souls 2 on the PS3.  Well, if you are slighly interested and curious about Lords of the Fallen, you will need to treat this game uniquely as its own, and nothing else.  I have friends that played Dark Souls religiously that play this game and they agree that it is a good to great game.  Give it a chance, or better yet, give it a try.My rating: 8.0 out of 10(highly recommended)

number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 17
												For a video review, go here: 


YouTube™ Video: Res Reviews Lords Of The Fallen 

			Views: 161		

			Lords of the fallen review. For more Res Reviews check out our playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLIKsf2nlMdD_KDb6YzF7Lhza0vgfsfFpU Follow us on social media to make sure you see all of...		

A text review is provided below-Lords Of The Fallen is a third person action RPG bearing many similarities to the Souls series. The main differences lie in the persistence and reuse of the world, the loading screens between certain areas, and the fact that this game does not support multiplayer of any kind.So right off the bat the gameplay is golden. This is the only game of this type in which I was capable of using a keyboard and mouse to play. The movement of the camera (which seems meant for a controller) is a little off-putting every time I start up the game, but as I actually begin playing I get used to it very quickly so it’s not that big of a con. The actual action and fighting of this game is very fluid and very fun. The lock on mechanic for me sometimes seemed to mess up and I couldn’t scroll between enemies. I don’t know if that was my fault or if the game had some sort of issue with that.What story there is in Lords of the fallen is sparse but refreshing. This game allows for far more story than any of the Souls games have. This helps to give you motivation to keep trudging onwards against the increasing difficulty the game throws at you. It allows you to make some choices as well and gives you dialogue options in a very RPG like manner that I did not expect, coming from the Souls series. Definitely a plus. And this game can be difficult when you’re first learning the enemies. There were a few regular enemies I found that kept killing me, and finally being able to kill them was a huge turning point and always gave me a sense of accomplishment. This game is also packed full with lore you can find spread throughout the world in the form of audio recordings which is always a nice touch.The boss fights in this game are intense, difficult, and long-lasting depending on your playstyle and whether or not you research the bosses beforehand online, which I did not do. Some of the bosses have some pretty nasty tricks that you will not be prepared for in this case though. Either way, I haven’t played a game with such engaging boss fights in quite a while. This game can really surprise you too. You can be walking through an area where you already killed one boss and then BOOM, another one jumps out at you. And this game has a LOT of bosses in it. In fact it even reuses the first boss as a regular enemy. The first time I saw that I was completely not expecting it and got my♥♥♥♥♥handed to me. Of course once you realize what you’re up against you can face it again and win, but that’s part of the fun of this game is learning and adapting. Getting better with every attempt.This game also has a very intricate level design that I really enjoyed too. Everything is connected. My favorite part was how in the first fifteen minutes you get to watch someone go flying through a door just before a boss fight, and then 7 hours later you unknowingly walk through the same doors from the other side to face a mini boss.The graphics of this game are absolutely gorgeous for 2014 and still damn good for today. My only complaint in this department is in the animations. Some of the ways characters move around as they talk to you is extremely silly and when you pair it with the extreme fail that is lip syncing, then watching someone talk can be the most entertaining part of the first 10 minutes of the game.Unfortunately this game has a lot of glaring issues that stop it from being game of the year material in my opinion. The biggest issue? Bugs. Visual bugs. Skills not doing what they say they’re supposed to. For example, this one rogue skill that lets you go invisible, but unless you use it before combat starts the enemies still know where you are. Hitbox bugs which cause your attacks or your skill attacks to miss. Strange unexplainable bugs. And finally the worst of them all...crashes. All of this may have at most made me rage for a bit and refuse to play for the rest of the day, but the game was just so damn good I had to come back the following day.Then there’s the fact that just like the Souls game this one refuses to even slightly guide you. Just got 5 new side quests after fighting a boss? All you have to go on is the very vague directions the npcs gave you. I had to search on google how to solve most of these quests. The game also doesn’t let you keep track of side quests so make sure you are paying attention to the dialogue. But then again there are some sidequests that are as simple as finding a flint and using it to light a fire, no dialogue included. Seriously. That’s a side quest. I don’t know where I got the flint, but I got like 1000xp for completing a side quest once I lit a fire with it. And then I got attacked.The lack of any form of competitive or cooperative play in Lords of the fallen kind of fits with the design of the levels which can sometimes be very narrow, but combined with the lack of any friendly npc companions to help you in fights? This game’s world can feel very lonely. This does help to put you in a very survivalist mindset though; knowing that everything you find is against you. I wish that they gave you something to make the world feel less empty. Even the generic NPCs you find standing around that are supposed to be friendly REFUSE to fight enemies that are right next to them!Overall though I really did like Lords of the fallen despite the issues it did have. But to have so many bugs rampant in your game 2 and a half years after your release is laughable. Lords of the fallen gets a 7/10. It’s a good game, but far from perfect. It is buggy, it requires many google searches to make sure you don’t miss anything, but it is still fun and new game+ and the following mode add plenty of new things to the game to give it two more playthroughs of replayability. I definitely recommend this game at full price if you enjoy these kinds of games and enjoy doing new game plus. A half price sale is good enough if you just want it for one playthrough. But do make sure you can be tolerant of this game’s flaws.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												BEWARE: The game is currently optimized pretty poorly and has a lot of technical issues for some people. Be sure to check the forums to see if they have been fixed!Lords of the Fallen is a western take on Souls franchise. It borrows a lot of things from Souls and tries to explore the possible developments of the genre with a couple of new features.The game immediately feels like Souls game, yet there are enough differences to justify its existence.The biggest thing about LotF is that if you are looking for the complexity and difficulty of Souls - you won't find it here.This game is much simpler and easier. But if you always wanted to play more of that fantastic Souls combat without suffering horrible through each encounter - this game is for you.Combat is extremely close to Souls and quite enjoyable to play.Well, may be aside from ranged combat and magic spells that are pretty basic in comparison to Souls games.The world is as well much smaller than those offered in Souls. And since game is quite simpler, you can beat it in ~20h or so. Which in my book is pretty much good for a $60 game.The game does have some issues with balance: spells are overpowered, there's no way to use spell points once you'd level all your spells up to max, UI could be a bit better, world could've been a bit bigger, targeting autounlocks from time to time which is annoying.But most of those are pretty minor and don't stop you from enjoying a good combat, fantastically looking world and cheesy storyline.More detailed look and gameplay in the video:

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												I hereby crown this October 2014, Broketober, because the must-buy releases just keep coming (Alien Isolation, The Evil Within (if you can run it), Wasteland 2 (I know, that was September) and now this beauty!**After 5hrs+:Still continues to deliver, a bit of long loading at times during travel transitions (40-60secs) occasionally and sometimes the locking system (like other games of its type) will get you killed but the game continues to be interesting, challenging and rewarding as these games should be. Go with a 8-8.5 out of 10 thus far.**Early days but I like to give a first impressions when I hit the 2hr+ mark and will update as I go along:Great game for me so far. It is without doubt heavily inspired by 'that' game series (you know which one) right down to the control system with only the primary buttons differing slightly (and you can actually pause the game).Everything controls really nice, the combat animation is smooth and varied (you seem to be able to use different weapon types earlier the DS), the risk / reward system of the xp drop is interesting as you have the risk of losing it all but keeping it going while killing nasties means more xp faster via a multiplier and better loot drops (I think I was at 1.40x when I first hit the outside and got a 27 damage butcher knife (most start stuff was 16 I believe and DLC stuff 19-26) which was a pretty damn sweet payoff, I think that's how / why I got it, I could be wrong though).Difficulty (using the rogue with 2nd / green tier magic option) is nicely balanced thus far for me (with the first boss taking me 4 attempts due to my 'one more hit' greed) but the game does a great job at giving you the base game dynamics info in-game rather than leaving you to have to potentially go online or work it all out cryptically.So, so far, so great.**Technical issues / notes:-Playing on everything maxed except textures with is on 2nd highest (high as opposed to very high). I had about 40mins fluffing around with settings because the options menu contains no info on settings so it's pure trial and error for the most part.-Anisotropic filtering seems to stay on 4x when I change the setup to custom. I also had one crash but haven't had any issue since (did set the game exe to Admin rights just in case so that may have cured it). -I'm assuming setting Texture setting to Very High requires graphics card ram of 3GB or more since it goes really, really slow in places with it 'on' on my 2GB NVidia gt750 ti.-Camera can be a bit whiley-fox / hyper sensitive at times but not a major issue, just worth mentioning-Also it seems a lot of the negative reviews for this game are stemming from technical issues so I will update if I experience anything game breaking / stopping and give my full spec as to help those that are unsure their system will be ok with it or are having trouble:GeForce GTX 750 Ti 2GB, 8GB Ram, AMD FX 4100 Quad-Core 3.6 GHz, Windows 7 (64Bit) @ 1920x1080p

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Great looking game.  I personally haven't had any crashes, only some occasional lags (e.g.: outside around the towers - but nothing major or game-breaking) on my i7 4770 16GB, GTX 670 2GB (344.60), on Very High Settings.  I'm a fairly casual player and haven't played DS like everyone compares it to, but for just grabbing the game and playing, it has been a lot of fun.  While it isn't an open world or anything, the maps seem fairly decent in size.  They were a lot larger than the impression I got when I first started playing.  Like I mentioned, I'm not a hardcore player...so for someone like myself, some sort of map system would have helped out.  I spent my share of time running around in circles.Not a ton of character customization, but a lot of cool weapons and armor to be found.I've seen a few people talk about the voice acting, but from my end I found it (the voices themselves) pretty good.I can understand people's frustrations if the game is crashing, but I can't really comment on it as it has actually ran well on my system since the launch.  As a "non-crashing" game, I would definitely recommended it.EDIT: I started off playing with Mouse/Keyboard, but fairly early on switched over to using my X360 controller and it made a world of difference in fighting.  It's probably just because I'm not as coordinated as I use to be, but the game became a lot more enjoyable after using the gamepad.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												An above average action RPG with a weighty, satisfying combat system. Comparisons to the Souls games are inevitable given that it borrows quite heavily from the mechanics of the series, and whilst it lacks the excellent pacing that makes those games so memorable it has enough of its own ideas to remain enjoyable throughout.The vast majority of the bugs the game had at release have been worked out, but it still requires a reasonably high-end GPU to play.

												I'ts Hard to do a proper review on this game.First of, this game doesn't have any major flaw on tha game itself.Gameplay is great overall and the story match the game pace quite well. (not anything spectacular, but worth a generic A-RPG)Mostly of the issues of this game are related to game optimization.I had my own crashes and issues back when I played. But I've played the game normal.At the same time I know people that had to literally re install their windows to remove it from the computer (shenanigans).I recommend this game for:- Fans of Dark Souls that are looking for the same gameplay experience.- People looking for a less flashy eye candy A-RPG with more serious-looking PvEI do not recommend this game for:- Players chasing the same difficulty levels as DkS. This game is far from being hard. Something around medium difficulty depending on your build choices. Still it's the hardest ARPG released at Q3-Q4 of 2014.- A story worth of Square in the 90's. Seriously guys, stop chasing ghosts of the past.Some Tips for starters:- The gameplay is NOT sluggish. Every weapon has at least one attack thatss faster than the moveset that works as a opener. Make sure to study the whole moveset of your weapon instead of just spamming R1 like DKS.- Heavy Armor = easier game. Playing on Light armor may surprise even experience gamers. It's your choice.So far, assuming that the game loads on your computer without any let downs, I don't see how you wouldn't like this game.

number of helpful: 23 of 36 people (64%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Lords of the Fallen is, at it's core, a Dark Souls knock off. For those who think Dark Souls is a little more challenging than it's worth but love the idea, Lords of the Fallen is here for you. Mechanics:You start off by picking a generic class type: Brawling, Deception, and Solace (Warrior, Rogue, Mage). Each class type gets a unique set of 4 spells, with 3 levels within each spell type. Within these classes, there are sub class choices made up primarily by beginning stat variations. You level up your attributes by killing mobs, and gaining experience. You get an experience modifier that scales up the more enemies you kill without saving. Dying loses all experience, and you have to run back to your ghost and claim your ghost to regain lost experience.All class types can wear all types of armor, with a burden rate that slows down your character as it becomes more burdened. They can also use all types of weapons, but weapons have stat requirements that make most weapons outside of your class unlikely to be used. Occasionally mobs will drop runes that can be "unsealed" by a mystical ghost armorsmith to varying levels of usefulness (i.e. common luck rune vs. flawless luck rune). These can be slotted into armor and weapons for bonuses. There are a handful of trinkets that can also be equipped that are seeded throughout the world and add additional bonuses (more weight carrying, health regen, additional magic regen, etc.).Magic and Energy is used to cast spells and swing weapons respectively, with spells and weapons draining set amounts on casts. Once the bars are drained, the respective ability can no longer be used until it's regenerated.Armor and weapons never break, and can't be sold. They are collected, and stored and swapped out at any time (including mid battle). You also have a set number of potions that grows as you find more empty potion bottles, which can be refilled (partially) at save points (eerily similar to Dark Souls flasks and fires). In addition to potions, you are given consumables which grant fire resistance, energy points, etc. Energy and Magic regenerates but health does not.If all of that sounds pretty standard, that's because it is. Lords of the Fallen does not provide anything new, and instead provides a healthy dose of mediocre. It's like watching an action movie that you know wont be great, but you've watched all the good action movies already. You'll settle for that movie. It'll hit that craving, but you wont go out and tell your friends to go and watch it. That's Lords of the Fallen.Story **SPOILERS**:Where Dark Souls makes you curious about the world you're wandering around in, Lords of the Fallen teases it ever so slightly just enough for you to realize you (and likely the story writers) don't care at all about it. But you don't play Lords of the Fallen for the storyline. You play it to kill monsters.The game immediately throws you into the middle of a storyline, requiring you to suspend your belief and understand that a lot of things happened before you started this game, and you don't need to know about them, nor will you ever learn.Facts:1) You're a criminal (Harkyn)2) You're following a monk (Kaslo) who has apparently let you out of jail.3) They tattooed your face so others can recognize you as a criminal.Why did they let you out. You don't need to know. Why are you following this monk instead of just killing him and running off? You don't need to know. What did you do to land you in jail? You don't need to know.You start off right in the action, in Keystone Monastary, where Antanas the king of everything is holed up. You fight the Rhogar, a demonic race that is invading the human plane, and killing humans. You find out that Anatanas has found a way of seperating the evil of man from the good, leaving only the good, and it is hinted that this might be want has spawned the Rhogar.Kaslo lets you know that it is your duty to fight the Rhogar Lords. Throughout your journey you run into Yetka, another warrior in the area who is looking for ways to translate a book left to her by her parents in a different language.You fight your way through a number of bosses including the First Warden, Commander, and Worshipper (in the graveyard). The first two are fairly simply knight type bosses, with the Worshipper summoning demons that you can kill before they hatch. Once you kill this Demon, you enter... THE RHOGAR REALM. It's here you meet the Crafter, a floaty blackish ghost being whose evolved in the Rhogar Realm to travel dimensions. Who was he before he evolved? You don't need to know. You find out very little else about him In the Rhogar Realm you kill some of the Rhogar Lords in order to stop the Rhogar invasion, so you do, and come back to planet.... not Rhogar. Here, you meet back up with Kaslo and fight your way back through the Rhogar's invading the Monastery to get to Antanas. Through audio clips picked up by floating scrolls you find out that Antanas is obsessed with evil after losing his wife, driving him mad. Kaslo seems to sense that something is wrong, telling you he will stay behind to investigate, while Antanas sends you back to the Rhogar Realm to kill the remaining Rhogar Lords, and draw out Adyr the god who controls them.So you go and kill the Rhogar lords back in the same map you used. You meet Yetka once again who is still deciphering her family text. Turns out it's written in Rhogar! You come upon a beast, and she implores you not to to kill it, because it can take her to her family. So for once, you show mercy, and let her take the time traveling beast back to her family.... and that's the end of her storyline. Why was she trying to find her family? You don't need to know.Finally you make it to Adyr, who shows you the ghosts of all the bosses you've defeated (with stats on how many times you died and how long it took you to kill them. Thanks Adyr!) and he tells you... (PLOT TWIST!!!) Antanas is the bad guy all along *dun dun dun*. He never shows up, and gives you a magical rune to use against Antanas to kill him, and let the Rhogar win once and for all. And so you... BUT WAIT! Kaslo shows up in ghost form, and reveals that he is in fact also a god, but a watcher, sent to restore balance.And then he sends you back to the Monastarey where you run into Ghost Crafter, the being you know  almost literally nothing about? He mentions offhandedly how pretty your new rune is, speaks a riddle, and presents you with a choice.  Do you forge the rune into your armor, your weapon, or just let him have it. Apparently this choice alone determines whether you let the humans win, the Rhogar win, or balance the world. Why does he need the rune to balance the world? Why him? You don't need to know.So you give him the pretty rune given to you by a god literally not twenty seconds earlier, and fight your way through soldiers to reach Antanas only to find out he's turned into a Rhogar himself! (dun dun.... dun.....). So you kill him, and the game is over.Congratulations.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Just finished a playthrough and started new game + on my cleric. The game fairly long, standing at 15 hours with almost everything explored. As many have said, it connects dark souls-combat (albeit heavier) to a diabloish universe. The monster and item design was cool, and the numerous hidden secrets make for an interesting experience.  Many of the boss fights were lovely, although the damage I inflicted upon them felt neglible and the overall length of the fight was very long, boss kills ranging from 3-10 minutes. However, seeing that the game itself focuses even more on windows of opportunity and the rare occasions of being able to load a combo (which many weapons have, interesting mix-ups of light and heavy attacks) on an enemy. The level design is also solid, feeling threatening, seeing closed portculli and doors right and left, only for you to find that it was a shortcut to the section or activated by a pressure plate. The entire scenario is very much a mix-up of the Painted World of Ariamis and the third act of Diablo 3. I will be honest in my opinion that there was room for improvement at times, regarding the story, characters, overall itemization  and ranged combat. Most of the times when I hit a brick wall in terms of multiple monsters or a strong individual one, I resorted to spam projectiles with my gauntlet (which uses mana as a resource and allows you to deal dmg from afar, and through a shield in most cases) killing them as easily as a ranged fighter in Souls games in general. The game left me asking for more, even though the ending itself was quite weird and basically left a chance for a season pass to come, and there still are several things I want to see regarding hidden gems like alternate boss kill challenges and what happens if I choose otherwise at sidequests.  The game was very stable on me, and I only experienced minor lag during a session of multiple hours, although the loading screens and transitions were quite long.  I will be on lookout for the announced puzzle-oriented Library DLC, and wish the best for those who have poor experiences with the game regarding performance issues.Overall, I rate graphics(played on high with a stable 30-40 fps) 9/10Story and characters 6,5/10 Gameplay 8/10 Souls feels 8/10 would bangbringing the total score to 8/10

Posted: March 19
												Soulborne player will dislike this game, i can understand this due to the sluggish and slow movement of the character, especially on heavier weapons like polesword or greataxe...But this game does not as bad as people claimed. I will give my short review based on my personal experiences with the game:Pros:-Decent graphics for the time-Interconnected world-Weapons and armor look detailed and beautiful-Runes and shards system-Similar gameplay to Soul series (i'll take anything that similar to souls game)Cons:-Too little variation on enemies (mostly humanoid creatures)-Movement seem sluggish (as mentioned above)-Bosses are uninspired (a boss named Beast, wut???), very predictable and their attacks are easily telegraphed-Late game is a piece of cake, especially with Luck based runeThe core gameplay mechanic of the game is not bad, but it's unpolished. The story is kinda cliche with forgetable NPC. For example Kaslo just appear a couple of time in the game, say something then disappear. Most of the dialogues are badly written, except one ( you'll know what i meant if you manage to get that far). The world is small and required backtracking. The multiply exp system is a good idea but most of the time it's not worth the risk due to the small increase interval. Pick this up on sale if you like souls game, dont buy it at full price, not really worth it

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												One of the absolute best ARPG's I've ever played in my life. I'm a major fan of the souls series and any ARPG's in general. However even with the release of the wonderful Dark Souls III that I had been hyped about all year, and I sunk hours and hours into... Lords of the Fallen still remains the best ARPG I've ever played. The story may not be the best, and in comparison to the souls series and it's deep, rich lore... this game has got nothing.  However I didn't go into this game expecting a great story. I wanted a fresh, polished, unique ARPG... with memorable boss fights. That's exactly what I got. A unique and refreshing take on the ARPG genre, absolutely breathtaking visuals, an amazing soundtrack, extremely memorable boss fights with solid and challenging mechanics, and a satisfying ending. There is even the added bonus of massive replayability. When I really love a game, I try to go all out and get all the achievements and that usually means replaying the game a few times. In Lords of the Fallen I had to replay the game 4 times to get all the achievements, and yet it didn't stop there... I replayed the game 3 more times after that simply because I loved the experience that much. Lords of the Fallen will always hold a special place in my heart, and I will always cherish the experience I had with it. I sincerely wish the developers would consider making a sequel in the future.Side Notes:- I didn't buy the game immediately at launch so I never experienced any of the bugs or preformance issues that earlier players might have.- The DLC "expansion" was absolute garbage and a rip off. They added one small boss in an annoying and gimmicky maze and it took me around 30 minutes to beat. AT A $10 price tag. There are hundreds of other games you could buy for that $10 that are way more worth the money. I was very disappointed in the DLC.Synopsis: One of the most refreshing, unique, memorable ARPG'S I've ever played and probably ever will play. Great for fans of the souls series, and players new to the genre alike. Massive replayability. Breathtaking visuals. Incredible soundtrack. The DLC however is a total rip off at $10 as it takes around 30 minutes to beat and has a rather annoying maze. I wouldn't recommend buying the DLC unless it's on sale and you really want all the achievements.

Posted: April 15
												This is masterpiece! Absolutely great game, hard, challenging but also very satisfying. Visuals are simply stunning, everything from environment to armors, weapons and characters. Love how levels are designed at first it seems linear but it connect in many places you just have to open blocked doors, pull lever, remove magic seal etc, this help a lot with backtracking, looking for secrets, moving faster to mission objectives etc. There are tons of weapons and armor to find, almost every weapon feel different, have different attacks and you have to learn how to use it to stand a chance again your enemies, this alone give you huge amount of replay value and opportunity to test different weapons and play styles. You can really feel how heavy your weapons and armor are, the heavier it is the slower you move and loosing more energy to swing your sword or hammer, it can even make to the point that you don't have enough strength to swing some super heavy weapons even once :) Overall really great game, very well crafted, lots of content and hours of playing, definitely thumbs up from me! :)

												Lords Of The Fallen is a solid and fun game. It's no Dark Souls, we've all heard it. But in it's current state, with a price tag going super low in sales, it's quite a bang for the bug.Nice graphics and style, while performance never really sucked on my older system. Most of the time, it ran very well. Especially the armor and weapon design is great, everything feels quite heavy. Combat speed depends on your character build, but I opted for an axe swinging warrior and it felt and looked like leading a tank against tanks. Some animation-locks are bummers, but most of the time combat felt fluid.Story is okay-ish, a bit shallow, characters a bit chlichée.But still, give it a chance: It's a rewarding dark fantasy action rpg, and something I'd most def go back to. Solid 7.5/10

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Very Early Review, only a few hours in so far with the first 'Boss' down, and I have to say I'm loving it so far. As a huge fan of the Soul Series and From Software ingeneral, I feel this game is going to fill 'Dark Souls void' until Bloodbourne comes out. The game engine is very smooth, attack animations are very fluid and the sounds to go with are amazing and very immersive. If you're a fan of Dark Souls  PVE   than you will not regret this buy! Will post more as I play through.Playing through abit more one of my complaints would have to be the camera control or positioning at times, it can feel kind of buggy at times and lead to a few irritable deaths. You'll also notice how heavy of an influence the weight of your armour makes on the speed of your dodges, again like in dark souls. But I feel you're more penalized for using heavy armor in this game, atleast early game.Pros so far:Immersive EnviromentDestructable EnviromentsSoundtrack & Voice ActingFluid Gameplay MechanicsIntense and long lasting Boss Fights with some awesome mechanics and attack animationsGauntlets (A Shield/ Magical Projectile item)Lots of lore filled items and audio logsOptimized very well for PC, no crashes and consistant high frame ratesReplayability with new game+ and different classesAttacks feel 'real' a 2handed power attack takes a decent ammount of time to follow through giving the attacks a very real feeling with a tactical approachCons so far:No Character CustomizationCamera controls/anglesGame pace is very slow No mini map or quest markers which can lead to getting lost quite oftenNo Co-opNo multiplayer / PVP3 Classes (Warrior/Cleric/Rogue)My PC Specs and Settings:Intel Core i3 3220 3.3ghz16 GB RAMGeForce GTX 750 Ti SC (Overclocked quite abit)Running on High settings with x16 Anistropic Filtering

content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
												I have like 800 hours of play between Dark Souls 1, 2 and 3. I have never played Demon Souls or Bloodborne as I have never had a console and will never own one. Period.I have just installed Lords of The Fallen as I finished DS3 three times and got enough of it.And…So far so good...It is not Dark Souls game. In some aspects it is familiar to DS, but it is more fantasih with a touch of D&D. The plot/story feels more significant and clear than in DS with a touch of mystery.I also do not understand all the hate towards this game. I do feel it is hugely underrated on Steam.Pros:-	Beautiful graphics – I find the graphics way better than in Dark Souls 3. The game is simply gorgeous.-	Performance/Optimization – again better than in DS3 – On full QHD and everything maxed out (all details on very high and antis on x16) I can run it 50-60 fps on my laptop. Whereas DS is only 40-45 on just full HD with occasional drops to as low as 30.-	Apart from occasional Memory leaks I have not encountered any bugs yet-	Lore – I like the logs you find throughout the game-	Atmosphere – proper Dark Fantasy Game with more stress on Fantasy than in Dark Souls-	NPCs  - so far I encountered like 5 of them and I found every one convincing and interesting-	Plot – so far so good – mysterious and stimulating -	Character development – very intuitive -	Equipment – armours and weapons – well developed – imo better than in DS-	Portals to the other worlds – I like the ideaHard to say-	Fighting system – it is okay but comparing to DS it feels much slower and clunky; I can still enjoy it though. Especially with some final hits that feel so powerful-	Levels design – I am still in two minds about it; levels seemed well connected but in the same time felt too small and shorts; I need to play more.-	Voiced Protagonist  – he feels like a really badass criminal – maybe not my type but I am able to impersonate while playing so its good and he has a good voice… but still I prefer the solution like in DS where you can shape your protagonist the way you like. Cons:-	You can’t hit a wall with your weapon like it is always too far. That feels really unreal-	Enemies – so far I have not seen anything special, just humanoids with shield, few assasins with daggers or crossbows and mutes – I will change this if I encounter more interesting enemies-	Bosses – so far I beat two and they were very easy + very similar – I will change this if I encounter more interesting bosses-	Rolling – it just does not feel right, even when not almost overcumbered it is slow and has short range. I barely use it-	Enemies that are covered behind their shields at all time – I find them really frustrating especially when using heavy slower weapon-	Memory leaks – it kicked me out like 2 times during 3 hours of play to the desktop with a message to close apps in order to free some RAM. I have 16GB of RAM and it is just not right; I am not sure if that is the game’s problem or Windows 10. Same thing happened to me with Fallout 4, but not in DS3-	Move set – only light and heavy attack + roll attack – is that right or am I missing something-	No multiplayer – that is too bad; I like the DS multiplayer and I think same thing could have been implemented here My Ratings:DS 1: 9/10DS 2: 8/10DS 3: 9/10Lords of the Fallen: 7/10UPDATE:+ I really like this game for it immense and hard to find secrets:)UPDATE 2: Finished it after 24 hours (I know it is long for this game but it’s just me I like to take my time a lot while playing focusing on all the closed doors and secrets) and my final feelings made me to decrease my rating from 7/10 to 6/10 and here is why (some spoilers ahead)-	After finishing it I realised I do not have the desire to go into NG+. Why? It is hard to say but I have got a feeling this game has nothing more to offer and I kinda do not want to go through this story again. I have had like half an hour on NG+ as an assassin and I felt fed up (2 out of 4 assassin’s skills are almost exactly the same as warrior’s) + the only thing NG+ changes is the enemies health what means you just need to hit them more like in Fallout 4, sponges-	(All the) Bosses are like super-easy; no challenge there at all; The most it took me to take down a boss was 2 tries and I had to do it only with 3 bosses. The biggest let-down was the last boss. I entered a room for the first time with just 4 potions (out of 12) and I won... It took me like 15 minutes, being careful with my life but it was just… too easy-	The story climax and the ending was disappointing; [SPOILERS WARNING]  first off why did I have to betray humans and Antannas? Why couldn’t I fight the god and help Antannas? No choice there and I was expecting more. Ending itself was poor as well.-	Monsters variety – not enough and too boringBut despite all the above I would still recommend this game to anyone to try it out. It was fun for me for one play through and the game has a lot of nice touches to offer (like graphics, atomosphere, secrets and lore). For me it is strong 6/10. After finishing it I can say (no remorse) it is in different league than Dark Souls; it is a different game but in the same time feels a bit short and lacking in some aspects where Dark Souls shines.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												11h played - not a single crash. Sometimes I have fps drop down on highest settings but nothing that makes game unplayable. Im playing on Phenom II x6 1090T 3.2Ghz, GTX650, 8GB RAM so my rig isn't high end. Overall game is very good, Playing heavy armored tank it's kinda easy mode but medium/light armor is another story. Maybe on NG+ you will need more dodge and monsters attacks will crush you. Bosses are fine, nothing "epic" but compared to boring ones from DaS2 they have more interesting mechanics. There are some things that annoys me a lot like "invisible walls", a bit too much of backtracking or minor bugs. Controls and combat are same as DaS games (with same terrible run-jump mechanic) with some addition like shield charge (run+shield button) or fluid combo chain light+heavy attacks. I find LoTF more responsive than DaS2, kinda same good as DaS1. Graphic is beautiful, art style, locations, armor and weapon models, everything is top notch, especially compared to DaS2 terrible graphics. Animations are also great, "feel" of heavy weapon swing is one of a kind. There is no map, no objective mark or other easy-mode features so if you don't like exploring locations on your own and being lost (dmn those catacombs) think twice. There are also features like other dimension trials - some sort of side missions. Story? Really? This game is about combat and nothing else if you want good story go buy a good book for yourself. Overall it's very solid title and if CI Games will patch it and fix performence issues (for other ppl?) and minor bugs it would be even better. In general DaS1>LoTF>DaS2 (in terms of gameplay cause LoTF it's very short compared to DaS games)

number of helpful: 24 of 39 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												Lords Of The Fallen is a soulslike game set in a dark fantasy universe very similar to the one seen in Warhammer. Sounds good on paper, however I can't really recommend this game. Let's start with what's good.PROS: - Beautiful art style, lots of interesting details in the environment and in the gear. - Decent graphics with volumetric lighting. Sometimes the picture on the screen gets borderline gorgeous with all the ashes and sparks from hits flying around. Breathtaking. - Good combat system. Similar to the one seen in Dark Souls, yet with it's own twist (the addition of the Gauntlet is a nice touch). I love the timing-based combos — no more angry button smashing, you have to be careful with when you attack. - The Sound in this game is fantastic. Love the clenching of metal and heavy footsteps of the character.CONS: - Good God, camera gets atrocious sometimes. You're supposed to fight mobs, instead you're fighting game's camera. - Some mobs and bosses auto-aim on you. Meaning that while you're dodging their attack - they will follow you. - Speaking of Bosses. What was that? They all look the same! And why are they so easy? Beating the final boss in my second try is not good. - Story? What story? That plot-twist was borderline ludacris. - Mundane voice acting - Game's world navigation is frustrating. I've been cycling some areas over and over again, just because a narrow path was hidden between two bigger objects. Not really a good design decision. I personally think this happened because the image lacks depth. - Speaking of Game's World. It's really small. Loading screens between some areas are extremely frustrating and why are they there anyway? Damn. - There's only, like, 10 variations of enemies. - Game finale doesn't feel satisfying at all. - While Risk-Rewarding Check Point system is a great idea, there's really no risk to it. You can put all of your experience points into stats straight away without saving.All and all, this game is not hopelesly bad. It has lots of potential, yet somehow, at this moment, the developer didn't seem to push it hard enough. I can't recommend this game, however, I'll keep my ear to the ground for The Surge, see if Deck 13 will work on their mistakes.

												DO NOT BUY THIS GAME ON PC JUST YET! The game crashes every time I play it and I have a new £3000 PC, so thats not the issue. I have only used the main menu to exit the game twice since I didnt need to every other time I have stopped playing it. The game is ok and the graphics are really good. The trash mobs are too easy once you know what to do and most bosses I have killed on my first or second attempt, so its not really in the same league as Dark Souls when it comes to boss fights. I did pick up a legendary weapon early on that scaled with my main stat, so that has made a lot of the game trivial. If you are thinking of buying this game, just buy Dark Souls 2, yeah the graphics are good but its pretty short and you can only go to new game++. At the moment the best I can give this game is 2/5 which is a shame.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 13
 A Good Buy For  Open-Minded Admirers of Action RPGs I think the main problem people have with this game is they compare it a little too much to and hold it up to the standards of multimillion masterpieces like those that From Software makes. Sure, this game has similar systems to Dark Souls and may remind you of it from time to time, but this is its own game and should be reviewed as such, not how it holds up to the game of another developer. On its own, the game is moderately entertaining in how it approaches the combat system (which does feel very different than that of a Souls game), but in the end suffers to its lack of enemy variety and formulaic liniarity. After all, I was a little dissapointed to see that the first 2 bosses were guys with shields and swords, a standard knight archetype, and how you will see the same 5-6 enemy variants most of the time in the opening hours. This may or may not improve in the late game, and ill push through to the end to find out, but the goal of a game should be to grab the player's attention early on and maintain that interest, building on its systems and mechanics. Lords of the Fallen fails in this aspect. Some commendable early-game attractions would be the combat and loot systems. The combat feels much more Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning esque than Dark Souls, be that good or bad is up to you. It feels slightly more fast paced and less methodical than Dark Souls too, giving the impression that this game is a little less about careful life or death combat choices than its counterpart. Though don't take this the wrong way, Lords of the Fallen is still a difficult game and at times, especially during boss fights, you will feel closer to the Dark Souls style of calculated blows and dodges. The loot early on feels a little like a Diablo game. There is plenty of loot (armor, weapons, such) in the first couple levels allowing great customizability in playstyle, especially when it comes to the weapon variants and the variety they give to your approach to combat.Over all, do I reccommend this game? For the price of $19.99, I think any open-minded admirers of Dark Souls or other difficulty based Action RPGs will enjoy this game. Idealy, find it for a deal, but the asking price is fair. At the very least, it's a good play so that you may have an example of how Action-RPGs can have shortcomings and how to avoid them. I respect From Software so so much more now and appreciate their arts now that I see how much work it had to be for them. I look forward to a sequel, where maybe they can iron out any flaws in the design and generally improve on the core aspects of the game they have made.

												If you miss dark souls 1 style gameplay and want your dark souls 1 fix without going back, then this game is perfect for you. Im going to make this review short as my last review was rather longThe gameplay is reminiscent of dark souls 1, you can't walk around in full heavy armor light rolling with a great shield and heavy weapon unless you fully invest into weight carrying. Enemies know how to get around shields and they know how to use shields, you have to learn their weaknesses. Boss design is well done, i'll admit after the first two bosses being guys with tower shields i was worried, but the bosses get better from that point on. One thing i personally liked about the bosses is that they each seem to excel versus certain types of characters while being weak to others. As a rogue i had issues that i saw knights just breeze past and vise versa.Gameplay is heavier than dark souls 1 and it is fulfilling, armor designs are a little more stylized but in a good way. While the general enemies are not exemplary, they never felt out of place and they were spaced out logically, i was never swarmed by one enemy type.Anyways this review feels incomplete but i said it would be short so all i have to say is this game is very much like dark souls 1 except with new story and visuals, gameplay is fun and i will probably be playing alot of it until bloodborne, if you like DS1 you will most likely enjoy this game, and if you want to get started into games like the souls series this game is a friendlier version for new players.

number of helpful: 12 of 17 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												Lords of The Fallen is an action RPG with gorgeous graphics, superb sound design, and great music. As a lover of Demon Souls, Dark Souls and Dark Souls II, I can only recommend this game as its gameplay is just the same as the Souls series only more fluid movements and animations. You can basically choose between 3 different play styles, though you are free to mix and match as you desire:Heavy armor with slow powerful weaponsMedium armor with magic and mid-weight weaponsLight armor with fast weaponsEach has their own style of gameplay, with weapons that feel and play differently. Just like in the Souls series you have to earn experience (souls) from slaying monsters. You use them to level up your character and learn new spells. There are 4 for “class” chosen at the start, and you can unlock a second and third set on your second and third playthroughs respectively. If you die, you respawn at the last save point, dropping your experience. Just like souls, in order to retrieve it, you have to make it back to the point you died without dying. The longer it takes you, the less experience you recover, and once you’re there, you can choose to leave it on the ground temporarily in exchange for a few buffs that might help you defeat a difficult enemy. This game is as hard as the Souls series and Bosses even drop different bonus loot depending on how you killed them and what weapons you used, or didnt use during the fight.It’s safe to say that this is just Dark Souls with a more linear level design, though not by much. The story is very clearly told, though it isn’t very compelling. But really in a game like this, who really cares?

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												A Dark Souls clone?Thats definitely not it, its far from similar to DS in terms of atmosphere and the overall experience. Its just the mechanics that have been 'borrowed' from the souls games. After playing the game for ~2 hours i can tell you that its definitely a game worth giving a try, although dont expect a literal Dark Souls clone, its a game of its own. The one thing i can praise the devs for is the combat system which feels waaaay better than the one in Dark Souls, im not really a fan of the armor and weapon design, if someone digs 100% fantasy design which would more than likely never work in real life then thats the game to look out for.Onto the graphics, the game looks aesthetically pleasing with well designed locations and great attention to detail, the places ive been to actually feel like they have been abandoned just a few moments ago. Positives:+Satisfying combat+Great atmosphere although could've been better+Their XP system is a nice addition (the more you kill the more XP you get, untill you go back to a checkpoint which works like a bonfire, then the multiplier resets)+Pleasing graphics+Really well designed locations+Soundtrack, although might sound a bit generic, works great.Negatives: -Overdesigned weapons and armor-Interface could've been improved in many ways.-Pretty linear-Voice acting is rather poor-So is lipsync and the gestures-Inventory window looks all nice and dandy, but id prefer it being more useful than looking 'nice'.-Not impressed by the boss fights so far-Not really challenging, at least in the 4 hours of playtime i have.Summary: If Dark Souls was a genre of its own, then this would be just another game in that genre, its not necessarily a clone but at least a 'heavily' inspired game, its trying to be a Souls game without being one, if that makes any sense.Graphics: 9/10Sound: 7/10Gameplay: 8/10If you can get it for less than 30€, give it a try.
