content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												What can I say about Lords of the Fallen. It's a solid game for a Dark Souls clone or inspired game if you want to call it that way. It's obvious for anyone who played LotF that this game has a lot of similarities with Souls series. The similar combat style, the similar experience loss on death, health and stamina management is also here. But it doesn't mean the game is a blatant rip-off. The developers took some interesting ideas and mechanics from Souls series and created this game. But unfortunately taking something good doesn't mean the final product is going to be good. The story is here and they are trying to tell it to you but after all I'm stil not sure what happened during the game. Combat system is slow and in most situations forces you to play defensively. And to be honest it's way to easier to play with huge sword and tower shield than trying to roll and dodge. At least for me. The game is also pretty short. 11 hours to complete NG seems just not enough for a game like this. I know there are NG+ and NG++ but I don't see the reason to complete them unless you're aiming for achievements to unlock. I heard right after the release people had some technical issues and crashes with this game. But it seems the game works fine now after they patched it a couple of times. Well at least I didn't have any problem with it.As the final verdict I'd say Lords of the Fallen doesn't worth the full price unfortunately but if you managed to get it during the sale you can have some fun with it. 7 out of 10.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												Considering that i'm a little more than halfway through the game now, I guess it's about time I wrote a review for it. And I have to admit: it's one of the finest RPG's I have ever played. I stayed away from it for a while because I got involved in Dark Souls, but I think that this game is better than Dark Souls And Dark Souls 2. This game definitely does not deserve the negative attention that it is getting because of performance issues. Well, if anybody had taken the time to look into the settings, having the shadows set to low will fix many of these problems. And you can't say it works fine for me because I have a fancy computer; All i've got right now is a GTX 760 and an AMD Phenom ii x4 820, and on high settings (aside form shadows) I get 60 frames/second consistantly without experiencing game crashes. Enough said about my computer, here's what I think of the game itself: Never once have I felt bored with this game so far. Many people would compare this game to the Souls games, saying that this game is terrible. In reality, as I mentioned before, it's better than the first 2 Souls games. Nothing can beat Dark Souls 3, but did it really have to take them Demon's Souls and 2 more games to figure out how these games are supposed to work? I'm not saying that the souls games are bad, it's just that this is better. Realistically, there could be a larger variatey of enemies and more classes to chose from, but it's the gameplay itself that got me hooked. How there are multiple NPC'S for you to interact with and actually respond to is what makes the story engaging. And these NPC"S have their own emotions and personalities as well. And as for the combat- there couldn't be anything better. The control is smoother than it is in any other RPG I have played (other people say that the controls are clunky because they are probably not familiar with this type of game). The hit detection is precice, and every battle you come across has life to it- even if it is just 1 enemy you are facing.As a final note, if you have played and BEAT a Dark Souls game or Bloodborne, then you sould only get this game if you want a more relaxed experience, as this is easier than those games. It still has it's difficulties, but overall it is less stressful playing this game. If you have NEVER played a souls game, then this is the place to start. Overall, it's easier and more enjoyable, and it has more story involved in it.And my final thought is that this game has one thing that I have always wanted to see in a souls game: YOU CAN SAVE YOUR PROGRESS WITHOUT SPAWNING ENEMIES!!!

												Short version: Yes I recommend this game, 7/10As someone who has not played a Dark Souls title, I really enjoyed playing Lords of the Fallen. I have heard that this game keeps crashing for most players which is a let down although I played it in high settings (can check my screenshots) and did not crash once...I completed the game within 12-13 hours as a rogue and spent 6-7 hours messing around on other classes at the beginning of the game, so an average of 30 hours played which nowadays is pretty good for a £30 single player game. As someone new to this genre I was disappointed that there is no way to view/keep track of active missions/quests and I got turned around and confused on where I was meant to be going and doing. The graphics for this game are amazing the voice acting on the other hand... could use work in places, the combat felt very well polished with a decent control layout and the NPCs behaviour felt really well done. The inventory menu is easy to use although something where I could store gear I am not using would have been nice instead of it always being in my inventory an having to scroll through like 20 different weapon to find the new set of daggers I got.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												Graphics are beautiful. I like the third person view distance, just right. It has elements of say Diablo 3, in that you can build your character with armor sets & weapons of various types, that look amazing & have their own unique approach. You can even socket some of your gear with runes. The movement of my character is smooth/fluid with perfect combat mechanics. Is this game hard? You better believe it. Each monster has its own style of killing you & you must figure out how & when to execute your weapon on each monster. Is it frustrating? Yep! But that is part of the style & fun of this game. My character has been murdered A LOT! I've even had to turn off the game & walk away for a bit, then come back & try again. It can be brutal. But the sun shines & the birds sing when you figure out how to kill these ♥♥♥♥♥♥. So far the game runs very smooth with no crashes & no glitches whatsoever. At the moment, my character is doing pretty well overall. I am still being murdered at times, but with only a few wrong moves rather than just one wrong move. How to deal back some of the punishment? Gain experience points, use a bit of magic & find better weapons via chests. Will quitters enjoy this game? Nope!

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												What can I say about this game. The best way to surmise it is, it's like being in a relationship with an abusive partner, that requires you to abide by very strict rules but doesn't abide by the same ones. Did I finish the game? Yes.Did I have fun at points? Definitely.Did I continue to play after that? Yes. Mostly out of spite.Here is an example of what I am talking about:Me: Enemy, why didin't you die? I have fought you many times before and you have always died with one hit?Enemy: *shrug* Suck it nerd.Me: Why the hell did I just die? I jumped and landed on the platform!Platform: Your pinky toe was kind of hanging off a little bit, @sshole.Me: I AM HITTING THE ROLL BUTTON! ROLL FOR THE LOVE OF ALL THAT IS GOOD!Game: Meh. I didn't feel like it.Me: I swung my weapon but it didn't cause any damage? What is going on, this doesn't make any sense.Enemy: Oh we're supposed to make sense now? LULZMe: OH MY GOD I AM GOING TO BREAK MY KEYBOARD INTO LITTLE PIECES AND BURN THOSE PIECES! I WAS DOING A COMBO, WHERE IS MY COMBO?!?!?!?!Game: Hahaha. Go ♥♥♥♥ yourself.Now, these things wouldn't normally be a big issue, as no game works 100% perfectly. The problem is this game expects you to play absolutely perfectly but doesn't offer a perfect platform to do it on. Ultimately, this game does have a lot of cool things to offer, great graphics, somewhat interesting story (very short though) and actually pretty good replayability with the Game+ feature. I just cannot bring myself to recommend it as it will probably cause you many hours of suffering and possibly a broken keyboard or gamepad.

number of helpful: 36 of 64 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												From what i have played so far the game is brilliant, the combat system is very much like Dark Souls. If you did not enjoy that kind of combat then do not buy the game. There are a few key features that i like about the game and a couple that i anoy me a little.To start with the game has a brilliant combat system that has improved on the dark souls style. there are a few little things that just make it a bit more skill based and less luck/bruit force. there is a much better stagger effect that requires the player to time blocks on bigger enemies, this is not as hard as parrying and you have a much bigger window to do so. i feel that it just adds an extra mechanic to the game, your now thinking if its not worth trying to parry a super fast enemy at lwast i can try to stagger them.Another aspect that seriously made the game for me and i love it to death is that you now have a gamble when you gain XP. basically, you kill a monster and get xp, at these shine things you can Bank the XP and save it up to level up so that when you die you don't lose it. HOWEVER if you keep the XP on you, you get a higher chance of better item drops. I love this mechanic in the game and it seriouly makes you think.there is not much about the game that annoys me besides one thing that i think is worth mentioning. Tutorial. the game is quite heavy in the menues and can be a little confusing to start with. i feel that the game doesnt explain the menues well enough but this is nothing that time cant heal as you will learn as time goes on.If you are using a game pad (you should be) navigating the menues can be a ♥♥♥♥♥, i dont know if this is just me but having one of those circle menues that you rotate the analouge stick to get around is very annoying when you want one of the diaginals AAAAAHHH, i waist so much time on it.Other than the few very minor bad aspects of LOTF the game shines through brilliantly, graphics are amazing and the game runs so smooth for me, besides the loading screens but who cares.There is one last thing but if no one else is having this problem it must be my computer. the game has crashed a few times for me and im recieving graphics error reports. im running a pretty good GPU so i need to do some reaserch to see if others are suffering.8.7/10 Love this game, feels like a new take on Dark Souls combat that does not fail to impress

content:
Posted: January 1
												First of all I have not played any of the Dark Souls games, so the closest game I played that I can compare LOTF with is Blade of Darkness, which I played way back in the day.That being said, the game was a mixed bag for me.The gameplay for starters is not for everyone. You either love it or hate it. So you cannot judge the game by it. I personally enjoyed it. It requires a certain degree of patience that many simply do not possess. For the good parts:The graphics are nice, the level design, artwork, animations, all very good.I finished the game in about 26 hours, which in my opinion is pretty balanced. It's not short enough to consider it a bad investment, but it's not long enough to get you annoyed along the way and not finish it.Now for the less then good parts:The voice and lip-sync animations are less then mediocre. The soundtrack is fine I guess, but it did not impress or remain in memory.The story is pretty simple. You do not get enough information about any character in order to have any sort of emotion invested.For me personally, at least 75% of the weapons i found were just collectibles. I never once used them. even those that were specific for my class. They do not seem to be properly balanced for the moment that you find them. I think i used a total of 4 weapons the entire game. I mean i used the same staff for 4 bosses in a row. The armor pieces are much better balanced however.The game allows you to ignore the class selection and use any equipment, as long as you have the stats. That is how i got to be a Rogue that uses heavy armor. The side effect of this is that you will naturally gravitate towards certain weapon classes and others you will never ever touch. The game has a design choice evident from the start, specifically if you want to uncover certain loot, you have to backtrack a lot. This, coupled with the fact that all enemies respawn if you either die or switch zones, has two effects, neither which I am a fan of. It's either a chore to go run around to open that one door/chest that you couldn't before, which makes the game feel empty, either you have to kill every single monster all over again, which in some cases was annoying as all hell because of the positioning of the monsters.The game crashed a few times for me. 4 times during boss fights, which was really annoying, and once during normal play. I however did not lose more that 10-15 minutes of playtime. In the end for me that whole experience sums it up to a high 6/10.The good features outweigh the bad ones for me, but not enough for a second playthrough anytime soon.The price for me is more than fair (15-20 euro). I do not consider it a waste and for what it's worth, I would recommend it to friends. If a sequel would improve on some of the bad points, it could become a decent franchise.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23
												To start off, since I've seen people mostly complaining about constant crashes, I've not experienced any problems with that. I don't know what I've done right, but I'm happy I didn't have to put up with it.Secondly, a lot of people are comparing this game to Dark Souls and the game really is inspired by the Dark Souls series. The thing is, if you played through Dark Souls series first, Lords of the Fallen will be incredibly dull, mostly easy, empty and boring to you. But if you're playing Lords of the Fallen first it probably would be pretty hard, but it would be just a tutorial for Dark Souls and you would simply be amazed by Dark Souls.Story:To be honest, I didn't really follow the story through, so I can't say much. But if you visit LotF wiki you'll see everything. I'm sure the devs tried to make the story interesting, but I just didn't want to keep track of what's going on. Probably because the game doesn't explain from where Harkyn (protagonist) comes from, what he's done, you only know he's a convicted criminal who now has a chance for redemption to kill some gods or whatever. I don't think wiki's got more than that.Combat:In the beginning you get to choose between 3 Magic types and 3 starting equipment. Rogue (light), Warrior (heavy), Cleric (medium). There are stats: Strenght, Agility, Faith which scale with weapons (meaning you have more damage with an agility weapon the more agility you have) and other stats like Vitality, Endurance, etc. In the game, it doesn't really matter with what you start with because you can build your character differently later. I usually play with light armor and fast weapons so when I did go as Warrior on my second playthrough I just ended up with agility weapons because I don't like being slow.The 3 Magic types give you different magic abilities which you have to unlock with experience and they sometime do appear useful, but I didn't use them that much because I wasn't going for Magic stat.And also you get The Gauntlet, which is a big gun, basically. It uses Magic to shoot.Most effective fighting technique is to do combos. With combos Energy (read "stamina") depletes less with each attack. Agility weapons like fists, daggers and shortswords have a special combo move on the 3rd and 4th attack, which can stagger opponents and deal fair amount of damage.Weapons:As I said, weapons scale with stats. Hammers are the only weapons scaling with Faith, so there's no point in going for too much Faith for damage because I find hammers awfully slow, but Faith also gives you Magic.The problem is, weapons, for example swords, all have the same animation and same attack speed. Meaning when you get a new weapon, you don't care what kind of animation it has, you just look at the damage you output. Again, if you look at Dark Souls, almost every weapon has it's own move set. And that's what the game is missing.There are also different damage types, like physical, magic, fire, lightning to be extra spicy and you acquire those from runes. When you find a blacksmith he can put runes in to your equipment.Armor:Nothing much to say about this. There are light, medium and heavy armor, depends on your playstyle. There is a weight load so if you put too much armor you'll move and roll slower.Armors are nicely designed, I really liked that.Enemies:There are not a lot of enemies, around 15-20 coming at you throughout the whole game. Enemies with shields are really annoying because they don't do anything besides sitting behind a shield and maybe attacking you one or twice before you manage to somehow kill them.Generally, they are all easy and... Basic.Locations you have to go through get recycled.Bosses:Every boss is nothing special, they all have some basic attacks and they are all extremely boring, because they have too much health and the fight doesn't progress at all. So it's just the same moves for 5-10 minutes straight.Music:Not bad when there is something in the background. It's quiet mostly.Love the theme song though.Overall, it's a good game to play, but I didn't find much worth in it. The devs tried at least.Just go play Dark Souls.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												I'm not huge on Dark Souls, and I've heard that Lords of the Fallen is supposedly much easier and more forgiving than Dark Soul, so keep that in mind if you're a super veteran who can complete Dark Souls 2 without dying once. But for people like me, it's a decently challenging game where you'll die a few times here and there until you recognize the pattern and master the control, and beat your enemy down with a small portion of your own health remaining. Then you kick open some chests and find some more badass loot, you move on and get your teeth kicked in by the next big bad monster. It's satisfying all the way through.The game looks great and sounds great, though the voice acting leaves much to be desired. The running, dodging and weapon wielding animations look fantastic, making you feel just how heavy each swing of your massive hammer is. There are some minor issues with some of the animations, and the game tends to have serious issues with cloth and armor pieces clipping through your shield and other parts of your armor. It's not a big deal gameplay-wise, but for a game that otherwise looks this good, it does put a dent in the overall presentation.Overall, it's a fun game. And I think it's the perfect gateway game for people who want to get into challenging action RPGs, but are intimidated by Dark Souls' notorious difficulty. Lords of the Fallen isn't a perfect game, but it's quite a bit of fun and well worth the money.

												Yeah, we get it. It's not Dark Souls, but Lords of the Fallen is a relatively decent game with a few differentiating characteristics: chief among them include traditional storytelling elements, unlike the ambiguity found in Dark Souls, and a far more forgiving playthrough. content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Taken on it's own merits, LotF is great fun so far. I'm enjoying the combat system quite a bit, and the sound and animation do a great job of lending a visceral feeling to the game. Heavy weapons especially have a great sense of impact and power. I enjoy the art direction quite a bit (armor and weapon models are particularly impressive). There's a good use of color and contrast, and the game is vibrant without being cartoony or sacrificing a gritty feel. Overall it's gorgeous and runs smoothly on my mid-level system. No crashes yet (running the newest nvidia drivers).It's hard to avoid comparisons to Dark Souls. The mechanics are so similar. Personally I prefer the combat system here, as it feels more fluid. That being said, the game is a little less challenging and combat so far hasn't provoked that same rush of anxiety that I get when playing DS. I'm still having a great time with it, and I really enjoy the way they've tweaked some of the other systems like magic, leveling, and reincarnation.Bottom Line: Fun combat, great weapons/armor, well done sound and art direction. If you can play it without wishing it were Dark Souls 3, you'll have a great time.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Screw the haters.Okay, here's the deal: the game is a Souls ripoff. It's also nowhere near as good as the Souls games. Does that mean it's bad? No.Lords of the Fallen takes the Dark Souls formula and twists it a bit. You got interconnected areas to explore, you got respawn points to find, you got deaths to do, it's all there, but it's got its own additions to the system. It does magic really well - even the gimmicky-looking but fun spells like Mimic have use - and it has a really cool attitude to subquests: yeah, they're there, but forget tracking and a journal - you remember to do them, or you don't. This may sound annoying and backwards but given the rather small size and huge interconnection fo the game's world, it opens a lot of rewards for exploration: you get this mysterious item, wonder if that guy who alluded to it has something to say about it, better go talk to him - on the way, oh look, secret switches I missed and a whole new area filled with giant ♥♥♥♥ing spiders.Completionists won't like it - or the fact that there's a bunch of choices with very definite consequences that can lock you out of rewards - but it encourages thorough approach and constantly being on lookout for secrets, and the game is chock-full of those.Okay, the elephant in the room and what most people hate: combat. It's slow. In addition to good old souls' stamina, attacks just come out slowly even with fast weapons. It's not very stylish or action-packed and emphasises strategy over reflexes. I can't really speak for the people who hated it but here's a tip: try out the biggest ♥♥♥♥ing stick you have in your inventory. Wielding slow and powerful weapons has rarely been so satisfying and I maintain this game has the best-feeling warhammers I ever cracked goblin skulls with.What else is there? The setting is obviously nowhere near Souls stuff and you will get tired of the endless snow, the story is really predictable (although the novelty of medieval audiologs helps with that a fair bit) and most of the bosses are variations on Big Guy In Armor. Mechanically they are mostly handed well (two exceptions aside) but could use a bit more creativity in visual department.What it really comes down to is this: it tries to be Souls. It's not. But it's a solid tribute and definitely a good game for at least the one playthrough when you get all the magic of exploring harsh, unforgiving and content-packed environments. The real "failure" of Lords of the Fallen is that it doesn't live up to the source material - but when the source material is brilliant, being just good is nothing to be ashamed of. I wouldn't by it at full price but this game is a very solid sale pick.Oh, and don't buy the DLC. It blows - about an hour long and ending with a boss that's just piling one idiotic design decision over another.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												Game was extremely frustrating at first, only because I'm not used to playing this type of combat style. This game actually got me to play Dark Souls just to see the connection everyone was talking about, and I'll agree it definitely was inspired, but its so different from DS that honestly the only relevant link I can make between them is the combat style. A few key things to note about this game would be:- Every action you take animation locks you. Light weapons like daggers/fists are very short locks if you don't get snagged in a combo attack, and larger weapons like greatswords and maces have a longer lock (approx. 3-4 seconds per special attack swing). This is also effected by the type of armor you're wearing. Wielding Heirloom (elemental hammer) and wearing all light armor I was able to swing and dodge attacks significantly faster.- Know your enemies! This game is 90% about knowing your enemies and how to handle them. This isn't the type of game where you get in and steam roll through trash mobs to the boss. You need to wait for your enemies to give you an opening and move in for the attack. The more you play this game & the more you die, the more you'll get better at noting openings in your enemies. Once you get the timing down to make hits in the sweet spots, the enemies drop like flies.- Leveling. I found it insanely helpful to level grind for a while in order to progress to the area past the 3rd boss easier. The good news is that there's an experience modifier you gain from killing multiple enemies in a zone without going back to the crystal and healing. This modifier makes it insanely easy to level up and I recommend taking full advantage of it. (side note: bank your experience when you get the chance, it won't reset the modifier and you'll be thankful you didn't have it on you when that 1 mob decided to eat your face off in an area way far off from your last crystal touch).Things I would like to see them improve on with this game:- Combat system: swing/hit lag. There's been numerous times in a fight where I got hit by a swing that was actually 4 feet away from my face, as if the weapon has an invisible hit box on it that extends past the actual model of the weapon. There's also the enemies that swivel around to cornhole you when they should be stuck in an animation lock.- Combat system: heaviness. I enjoy how heavy combat feels here, but to an extent. I've fought quite a few enemies wielding a huge great axe with a heavy shield on that come at you swinging a mile a minute AND have time to swivel on a heel turn and block your attack with that big shield that begs you to question why this is kosher when it takes you 3-4 seconds to make that swing and sticks you in a deadly animation lock. If combat is going to be this heavy I would highly recommend making sure all the monsters suffer the same penalty.- Expansion to multiplayer/co-op. I really, really hope to see this game develop further into a state of being where other players can come in as other characters and assist. I realize at the moment everyone plays as Harkyn, so it's a bit unlikely, but this game has a ton going for it in all the right places and I would love to get the opportunity to play it with friends instead of having them watch me play. This game starts out a little raw in the beginning, so it'd be nice to have the ability to walk through it with a friend that's new to it and encourage them to keep going/show them the ropes.- Map. This game would have benefitted GREATLY from a map or at least a compass that points you towards lost experience points like the loot compass if you're really against maps for forcing exploration (I'd argue there's no reason you can't just have people unlock the map by exploration as they go though). I had no problem memorizing where to go and how to get there after a few runs of zones, but whenever I died I wasn't particularly paying attention to the exact location I was in and I'd have to run around for a while to figure out where I dropped exp. There was also a time where I died at the entrance and dropped 6k, but when I respawned the experience wasn't there, even though I still had 100% (6,438) on the screen waiting for me to pick it up. I had to just take a dive because I had no clue where it put it.Comments:- I would have loved to see the story developed a little further. We know very little about Harkyn, but are continuously reminded of his reputation. This may be intentional, leaving the player to their own imagination, but it makes it feel a bit impersonal. Also, the ending was....disappointing. I just wasn't really ever sold on this game story-wise. I played it for the challenge and the audio clips were intriguing to say the least, but that was about it. It could have benefitted from a little more world immersion, cutscenes, and an ending that's better than just a re-cap of what you accomplished and a snippet of story about Adyr.The ending feels rushed honestly, or like someone got burnt out and just needed to meet a deadline. It bums me out because of how awesome the game was otherwise -- but perhaps we'll see more great titles that improve upon this? :)I would love to see some worthy content addition that adds more areas to play in so we're not stuck in just this one castle. While there is one other area you gain access too, most of the game is played just in a single area with multiple zones you're entering into. It's huge, don't get me wrong, but I would love to see more.TLDR: I highly recommend this game and will be continuing to play with ng+ and ng++. It frustrates the crap out of me when I die but, I'm constantly challenging myself to beat bosses without taking any damage at all or meeting legendary requirements to make it harder on myself and taking advantage of every slow-mo death blow I deal while adding a "BAM" vocally for enhanced enjoyment, as is mandatory. Game takes a while to warm into if you'r'e new to it's kind, but stick with it and you'll get your monies worth.

												The whole experience is kinda strange. The mechanics are pretty good mostly because they almost directly copied from Souls series, which is actually pretty nice for I like Souls series. However, things that were taken from other games or made by the developer are not polished and kinda look like the game demands bigger budget than it actually had. The animation is pretty bad, the plot is scarce to the point of nonexistence. And it is not like in Souls where there is a nice setting and you can actually explore it, here the game is pretty linear despite the player being able to go back and forth throught the locations, and actually seems like it was supposed to be story-driven. But the player ends up hacking and slashing the enemies mostly just for the sake of hacking and slashing. The whole game seems like a start, a pretty good start, but that is just it. Even though i recommend the game. i cannot say that it is worth 60 bucks. And I would not have bought it for these money.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												First off, this is a good game. Everything is very well polished, it looks good, the story is decent enough, most of the combat is fair if not easy. There is a decent amount of mix and match with armor to stay at your desired weight level.Unfortunately it is pretty short. I've got 14.3 hours on it and I have beaten it. My actual play time is only 12h59m because - and this is the worst part by far - crashing. It's ridiculous how often this game crashes. There is some optimization issues present when booting up and every once in a while when loading between worlds/zones there will be some framerate drops.Lastly I just want to point out that this is not Dark Souls; it is much easier. As long as you do not go exploring areas that you are not ready for (Catacombs before closing the Portal) you will not experience any difficulty at all. I've heard and read that playing the rogue (as a rogue) makes the game a decent challenge but I feel that each class should present their own challenges which they do not. Overall though I think it is a decent start for the studio and hopefully a long line of Dark Souls hopefulls. If you come in expecting a 10/10 Dark Souls clone you are going to be severely disappointed. If you come in with the mind set that this could be an enjoyable experience that takes many elements from a game the devs love then I think you'll be satisfied.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												Solid combat on par with its obvious inspiration Dark Souls / Demon's SoulsFeels uniquely heavy and arguably more realistic. Reccommend a first playthrough is done with heavier armor until you get used to it however. Light armor results in getting hit being brutally punishing.Highly reccommend learning how to use the sprinting shield bash well to help with handling the more tanky shield-toating enemies most people have loved to complain about. I found after some practice I was able to make quick work of them when at first they were genuinely difficult to handle.Also a huuuuuge note to those who might have crashing issues and feel they can't properly challange themselves due to being unable to use checkpoints to save the game and risk losing their exp multiplier: The multiplier is not based on how long it has been since you have use a checkpoint. It simply gives you more exp based on how much you are carrying on you. The only thing that will reduce this is if you use a checkpoint and actually BANK your exp into your AP or SP pools. So long as you are holding XP that you would drop on your ghost if you died, you will continue to build up your multiplier. The story is forgetable but enough to give some context to your actions. I'm more in it for the gameplay personally so this doesn't really affect me too much. The in game areas and vistas are incredibly beautiful and graphically this game is very much a looker. You will need a fairly beefy rig to get the best out of it, but after the latest update allowing you to disable the nvidia specific effects, it seems to run a lot more reliably and much more steady framerates.With Vsync turned off my rig runs this at around 60 - 70 fps, usually around a steady 70 fps in most areas. This falls a fair bit when first loading into new areas via a portal, but quickly evens out after just a few moments. Overall I highly reccommend this game to any veteran of the Souls series who is in it just for the extremely satisfying gameplay. You will feel some real accomplishment as you go from struggling to kill most foes to finding ways to easily dispatch them, and conquering some genuinely interesting boss fights. You won't find your intriguing and wonderfully subtle story line, but you'll find a generic fantasy plot decent enough to give you an excuse to slay more demons.

												Il start by saying that i enjoyed playing LotF until the end without any issues and 2 crashes only, mostly bc of problem i have on my graphic card (Sometimes stop responding), its a very entertaining game with interesting story with 2 key points that change the outcome of the ending you get.Im not going to make Dark Souls comparations, first bc DS didnt invented the wheel, only shapped to better what other games like Darksiders or Fable The Lost Chapter for instance, had already tried to achieve.Its very easy to fall into making new games rip off of others, but i think most have their own identidy, for instance i find the combat in LotF more polished that DS, but being more easy in term of challenge and specially bosses fights.The graphics and sound are very good and the story is interesting enough to keep you playing, the voice actors do decent job but sometimes lack ability to create link with the player but nothing special.The gameplay is fun and requires a little understanding on how to use things, and the game does a good job on that if you read the hints carefully at tutorial.Overall i find LotF good enough to make me wait for a sequel that is already confirmed by the Dev, there is still a DLC coming for this game with the last PC patch, but even without it i already made my purchase worth while with 30h of gameplay and half way out of the second playthrough, wich show that the game have some replay value, something that most games miss out now days unfortunatly.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												I'm going to do some comparison between this game and the Souls series because of how similiar their core gameplay is. So, brace yourself.Lords of the Fallen is a short but fun game. Its core gameplay mechanics are highly similiar to the mechanics found in the Souls series. The difficulty and depth, however, aren't on the same level. I would describe it as a dumbed down version of the Souls series, but that would imply that it's a clone of that series. Which it is not. Story:The story is about an outlaw called Harkyn, who is freed from prison to help fight the invading rhogar. Not everyone is happy about this and you will notice it when you talk to certain npcs. As the story progresses, you will fight the leaders of the rhogar, the rhogar lords. The story is presnted clearly, with cutscenes and as background lore which is found in audio logs that you find as you explore. The audio logs are played in the background and they aren't intrusive.Gameplay:Gameplay is, as stated before, very similiar to what you find in the Souls series. There are backstabs, parries and ripostes as well as light and strong attacks. The overall pace of the fights feels somewhat slower than in the Souls series though.The control scheme on a controller is super similiar to the control scheme of the Souls series.You will start the game by choosing a magic school out of three different options. One provides stealth themed spells, while another provides defensive magics while the last provides offensive magics.Then you proceed to pick a character type out of three different options. There is the warrior, that starts with heavy armor and is strength oriented. Then there is the rogue, that starts with light armor and is agility oriented. And last but not least there is the cleric, that starts with medium armor and is faith oriented.Note: Nothing is bound to your starting character type. Any type can use any type of equipement, provided that they meet the neccesary requirements. However, you are not able to get any magics from other spell schools than the one you picked at the start.Your character has a variety of different attributes which you can improve with experience(exp) gained from killing enemies. This exp will be lost upon death if it hasn't been banked at a checkpoint. When you die, you leave behind a ghost that contains all the exp you had on you, and it can be retrieved by getting to it and activating it. This exp on your ghost will start to deplete over time so getting to it as fast as possible is essential if you wish to gain the most of your exp back. The ghost will provide you with a slight health regen when you are near it, possibly aiding you in a place where you previously died in a tough battle. This bonus is lost when you pick up the ghost.Your character is able to wield a shield and a weapon, dual wield small weapons such as daggers and shortswords and two-hand bigger weapons like greatswords and greataxes. You will also gain a gauntlet which is your primary source for magical or elemental damage. The gauntlet has three modes: Projectile, which shoots a long distance projectile. Blast, which is a short range blast that knocks most enemies to the ground while dealing minor damage. Explosive, which basically throws a magical grenade.Graphics, Visuals, Art:The graphics are nothing especially amazing, but they are good enough. The art style wasn't to my liking, but I didn't really dislike it either. Come to think of it, I found the monster desing and the overall art style to be somewhat reminiscent of Diablo 3. Anywho, in my eyes, the game looks good enough.Music & SoundsI haven't really got anything to say about the BGM. I think the BGM is nice and quiet by default, since I can't remember hearing it too much. Heh. As normally I have to tone down the music volume so that the BGM doesn't get intrusive. No such problems here. The voice acting is decent. Could be better, yes. But it gets the job done, with a static decent quality.Afterword:It took me around 15 hours to finish my first playtrough, but that's not that bad since the game has the New Game Plus (NG+) option. I haven't tried the NG+ yet, since I decided to make a different type of character to find out my favorite playing style, but I'm hoping that the difficulty will spike up in the NG+. Overall I would recommend this game, but not at full price. Especially fans of the Souls series should wait for a price drop, imo. And those who never touched a Souls game or found them too hard or difficult to grasp, this game might serve as a good introduction to the gameplay mecahincs, as it's less in depth and thus easier to grasp.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												A game inspired in mechanics by the Souls-series, a couple of nice features and a more mainstream approach to story and exposition.LotF mostly plays like Dark Souls.You've got classes of melee weapons that you can either one-hand with a shield or two-hand for more damage. You can parry enemy attacks, block them or dodge out of the way. It also has a couple of features that ended up in DS3, like paired weapons, where you wield one in each hand when two-handing, and charged heavy attacks.You explore dark fantasy locations like castles, tombs and hellish realms, mowing down enemies, looting treasure and killing bosses. Although progression is mostly linear you'll soon find that most environments interconnect and you'll end up reaching blocked out areas of the early game and opening shortcuts.The story is somewhat short, taking around ~20 hours if you go about it at your leisure. Once you beat the game you can start new game plus which offers harder enemies and better loot.There is no multiplayer like in the Souls-series.It has an intersting spin on "currency". Like DS you earn XP that you can either use to level up and upgrade weapons or you can keep on yourself to boost your item find, with the risk of losing it upon death.Overall the game is a good attempt at a Souls-like. It wears its inspiration at its sleeve.You may feel it is easier than the Souls-games. Combat-wise it's not, though I personally don't find DS hard either, both games require patience to progress but you never feel lost in LotF, you always have a sense of direction and there are almost no points where you need to wiki it. As I said at the start of the review, it's has a mainstream approach to story telling, exposition and pacing, done through dialogs with NPCs and recovered audio logs, with Souls-like combat and exploring in between.On the other hand said story is cookie-cutter dark phantasy writing, men fighting against demons, sent by a vengeful god and the expected twist near the end. You won't cringe but won't be search Youtube for lore videos either.Surely worth the asking price on a sale. I got it for ~12.5€ and don't regret it.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												I don't know how far I'm into Lords of the Fallen yet, but I feel like I should write a review because it's still fairly new and there's probably a lot of people thinking about getting it. I'm a big fan of the 'Souls' series by From Software, as many of the reviewers on here are. However, as Lords of the Fallen's story hasn't really caught my interest, I'm just going to review the combat mostly.CombatThe combat, at first, feels slow and clunky. -Armor makes or breaks how combat, for you, will flow. I fell into heavy armor very quickly, finding that the increased defence and poise made it so I could tank many hits while swinging around a big weapon. Once I got the basic understanding of how they wanted someone in heavy armor to approach fights, it stopped feeling slow and clunky and started to just feel meaty. In comparison to any of the Souls games, heavier armor makes a significant amount of difference in whether or not you can take a hit and how much damage you'll take. I like this, personally, as it means that armor is as big a decision for you as your weapon choices.-Weapons are fairly varied, but rather than directly upgrading any weapon with a moveset you like, you have to find better weapons that do the same thing. It's more of a traditional RPG setup, where finding better gear is important. The weapons, however have fairly limited movesets based on type and some weapons are very ineffective against certain bosses. Overall, I'm fairly unhappy with the weapon options, with the faster weapons feeling weak and having very little advantage against the heavy hard hitting great weapons. There is one advantage Lords of the Fallen has, most weapons have a very satisfying weight to them that is missing in other games. Few things are as satisfying as crushing something's head with a big hammer after you've died to it a few times, and the weapons allow this.-Stamina and Power Attacks are very interesting. Stamina recharges quickly, and only when you really invest in attacking or block a lot of attacks that you perhaps should not be do you feel like you are running out of stamina. Speaking of investing in attacks, your Strong Attacks can be charged up in Lords of the Fallen, making them more powerful. I like this a lot, as it adds a big dynamic to how much time you're going to invest in a swing which makes a world of difference in the combat in Lords of the Fallen. Another great system is Perfect Hits, which are performed when you hit the attack button just as your last hit finishes, conserving more stamina on the next swing allowing for longer (or improved, in the case of dual wielding) combos. The changes to how you can use your stamina are really interesting, and add a new layer of depth to a system that I feel like I knew well.-Magic is fairly uninteresting. The spells are mostly buffs or light AoE attacks, and although these buffs have very powerful  effects and can be used in combat I found myself forgetting about them more often than not. The cast time for spells is long, meaning you have to find openings to cast effectively. Even when I did cast, I found myself more often than not focusing on using a single spell before a fight or when a boss was doing an action that allowed me a few moments respite. Magic adds to the meaty combat, making you feel more powerful when you use it, but it lacks in variety. The Gauntlet is very cool, however it is difficult for me to find it's place in the meaty melee combat of Lords of the Fallen.One other thing I would like to note before I wrap this up is that the game itself is very pretty. I'm not a big fan of the design choices for how the enemies and the main character look in armor (shoulderpads bigger than your head and spikes!), but the rest of the game looks beautiful. My computer can normally run games on max settings, but I find Lords of the Fallen on even mid-low settings is fairly clunky in terms of FPS and whatnot. Overall, I would recommend Lords of the Fallen. It's fun, meaty, and so far a great time sink. As a Souls player it took a bit of getting used too, but the ability to take hits from enemies and not worry means a lot after playing the Souls series, where I used to try to dodge everything. I feel like it doesn't have the same challenge as say Demon's Souls or Dark Souls, but it is overall fair and it doesn't need to be that difficult. Both seperate and compared to it's spiritual predecessors, it stands as a overall decent game.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												I definitely enjoyed Lords of the Fallen.  It took just under 15 hours to complete on my first playthrough, having missed some sidequests.  If you've never played a game like this, it may be difficult and it may frustrate you.  Even if you have played a game like this it may frustrate you. I got lost mulitple times, not sure where to go to progress, but always eventually found the way.  If you're a Dark Souls fan, you might be annoyed at some of the less polished enemy and boss patterns, but the game controls just like Dark Souls...only slower.  At least with a strength build.  Using daggers or staves make you attack very quickly.The weapons feel heavy and satifying, making combat addictive and fun, once you get the hang of it.  Audiologs, weapons, runes, and armor are hidden throughout the world to find.  You can mix and match the armor and most of it is pretty awesome looking.This game is not as fun as Dark Souls.  But it is a fun action RPG with enjoyable combat (most of the time) and high replayability.  There are faults, but I found it easy enough to push past them and have a great time.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												I've only just started this, so this review will probably change, and I could be wrong about points that I make, so I'm going to apologize in advance, sorry. Also, I might spoil some enemy types that aren't integral to the story, but if you would rather figure out your own strategy against them, don't read the last few linesAnyways, so far this game is satisfying, it's truly a souls clone in combat controls and exploration design but the game does not share similar character movement, progression, speed, or difficulty. Let me explain: I feel that the game's designers decided at a very early stage in development that the souls style of studying enemy attack patterns and figuring out where to go through trial and error was what Lords Of The Fallen was going to use. But instead of completely copying the formula, as there was a good chance that it would bring more criticism than it would praise, the game's difficulty is only in learning the enemies patterns. Most enemies do not instantly kill you, and very many don't actually hit you for a third or half of your health bar. Instead they usually deal a lot less damage. Also, the game gives you the freedom of using magic in any character class a lot quicker than the souls games. The tough part, the portion of the game that I feel people will either love or hate, is that the game feels considerably slower than the souls games. Your character doesn't quite roll as fast backwards or forwards and the enemies really need to telegraph their heavy attack for you to be hinted at a safe side roll. Still, I was able to use it effectively on multiple enemies and it felt good to get my character to a green weight and feel how much quicker he was after getting used to the heft of dodging. As far as dual wielding and the long range guantlet, they are severely limited in my opinion. They have such a high risk of not stunning the enemy or taking such a long time to complete the animation that I feel that the easiest course of action is still sword and shield. I was surprised that the shotgun style blast spell of the guantlet took so long to shoot and since it recommends close range to be effective, in it's current state I have never sucessfully used it.I have unlocked 4 spells for the warrior class and while I have benefited from using them in certain situations, since they share from the same mana pool as the guantlet, take a while to cast, and have a considerably longer cooldown, I rarely use them outside 1v1 encounters with tougher enemies. They really haven't helped me with crowd control. I can say that the guantlet's piercing spell has saved me a couple of times, though. As for the crowd control, areas stay clear of enemies that you have killed until either you are away from them a significant amount of time (could possibly also be distance from the area), or when you die. Enemies will then respawn and you can kill them all over again. The trade off with healing and hoarding XP is explained pretty early on. You can heal and refill potions at red rocks scattered through the map. They have floating stones around them that represent the amount of potions they can fill and those have a cooldown, so the game promotes your progression forward and finding the next checkpoint rock. Also, you can choose to fill xp into either spell or ability points, with the trade off being the more xp you carry, the more rare the loot drops are. There is also a smith that will let you enchant items with gems if they have sockets. It will also let you bet xp into the smithing process to coax out more valuable gems. The story itself did sort of a poor job explaining why you are doing what you're doing at the start. It really just throws you into fighting tutorials as Harkyn, and doesn't explain for a few hours why you're just killing a bunch of monsters. When it is explained by Kaslo, a monk you're following, it really is as simple as kill the monsters or we die. There is a lore tab in the menus that explains more in detail what you are doing, and pieces of that lore are picked up as scrolls during the game. I can't say much of the story right now outside of the obvious, you fight lords, you die, they die, it's fun. That's all I can really type for where I'm at in the game but here's a tip for minimizing damage with most of the dudes with shields, the doggies, fatty sniper, and the circle-strafing rogue: The sprinting shield bash has stunned 99% of the humanoid enemies, and it almost always leaves room for a follow up attack. Use it on the dog like creatures, it knocks them like 10ft from where it connects. The fat sniper recovers pretty quick so after the follow up I make some space with the backwards roll and shoot him with the piercing guantlet, with the right timing, that's like a third of his health.

Posted: November 5, 2016
												Allegedly a Soulslike, Lords shares more of its pedigree with Darksiders, and not especially in a good way. The narrative is heavy-handed and intrusive, controlling your progress through the game rather than contributing to it. There's very little in the way of discovery and nearly everything looks dark, stoneworked, and samey. There *are* a lot of convenience options, which is nice, but not enough to overcome the fundamental lack of interest I felt while playing this.It's a rare sin when a game bores the player not just during a particular section, but the whole way through.Finishing Lords of the Fallen was like finishing a whitebread and boiled potatoes sandwich; you just sit there and wonder why you kept going.You just sit there and wonder if perhaps you have a problem.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Don't expect it to be exactly like dark souls, just because it uses similar gameplay ideas. It admirably tries to make a game that isn't a straight up clone, but turns the souls games into a genre that this also sits in. It provides interesting new twists of familiar mechanics. For instance attacks can be timed with perfect intervals for lower stamina usage and performing combos that otherwise don't get triggered. As you kill enemies, you build up a multiplier for xp and loot and using a bonfire-equivalent resets it. That makes for an interesting choice where even for a new area, you might not want to refresh yourself but keep your multiplier instead.The fighting style of this game is slower than souls games and it's not as widely varied in how many different types of playstyles are fully supported. You'll find some options that are offered to be inconvenient and not totally viable, but plenty are, and all the common options like big-sword-guy or shield-guy or daggers-guy are all perfectly doable, with the game being easier or harder by player choice by wearing heavy armor or light gear.For full price I can see how it could have disappointed some people in the obvious comparison against dark souls. But especially at it's current price point, it's worth the time and money investment for sure.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												I did not like this game at all in the begining, but i kept playing for the gorgeous graphics and slowly i began to like it more and more until i was hooked.The difficulty will seem a bit off and overdone in the first part of the game.The "trick" to overcome most difficult situations is to observe carefully and look for patterns, openings in enemy defenses and such.The rest is putting a modicum of effort into carefully reading and understanding the stats and what they do, then experiment a bit.....and die a lot without getting frustrated (arguably the biggest challenge of this game).Im not a big fan of challenging games that are challenging for the sake of it, and this is not such a game.In this game i managed to build my character in a way that suited my playstyle and bring it to my difficulty comfort zone towards mid-game, after that it was almost too easy even for a casual like me.People complain that fights against shielded enemies are long....very wrong, all fights are short, even the boss fights, if they take too long, you need to experiment some more.If you are willing to invest a bit of effort, the rewards are great: superb graphics rich in detail and effects (needs a strong pc), a decent story, exciting boss fights, great variety of weapons and armors, decent amount of secrets to discover and last but not least an impressive variety of fight styles and strategies.I usually dont care much about how the character looks but the weapons and armors in this game are jaw dropping, and the heavy weapons and armors look and feel really heavy. Ive never had such an enjoyable experience playing a heavy fighter, ever.The game crashed about 10 times in 50 hrs of play (much more often after the last patch) but updating to the newly released beta drivers fixed this issue for me.All in all i highly recommend this game, its a real gem both visually and gameplay-wise.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Just wanted to give a review on this to help people who are unsure about it. Overall the game is very good. The presentation and gameplay are top notch. It all feels hand crafted and it looks as though a lot of love has gone into it all. The difficulty curve is very good. If you're struggling with a particular enemy type early on then change your tactics. This is all you realise as you play through. Some guys have huge shields so using your sword might not be the best approach. Try some long spear pikey thing to piece the shield and all of a sudden your doing damage again. Same with armour. You can totally change the way you fight from moment to moment. So...Dark Souls. Yes it's similar but so are most video games in general. compare Battlefield and COD...compare Silent Hill with Resident Evil....compare Ridge Racer to Mario Kart (maybe not that one... :)) All i can say is that LOTF is it's own game despite the similarities. After an hour or two it's clear this is no copycat. they have taken some of the greatest bits of Dark Souls and used them to craft their own world. You can feel the strong influences from the guy who worked on The Witcher. The enemies, armour/weapons, environment do really have a great look to them. And then there's the lighting...WOW!! Only complaint so far: Random crashes happen every hour or so. Also...could do with a torch in places...If you love Dark Souls that much then stick to that. This isn't Dark Souls, nor does it try to copy it. This is a game for gamers who can appreciatte good games...simple. :)

number of helpful: 14 of 25 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
TL;DR: Dont expect Dark Souls, but if you like Dark Souls you might like this game, too. It has a more traditional approarch to storytelling and a different, slower combat system. These things arent better or worse, but some people might be upset about that. In the first part of this review I will list the differences to Dark Souls, after that I will tell you what I think the game does good and bad.Differences to Dark Souls:- combat is slower and less responsive, which isnt a bad thing. In Dark Souls when you press attack, your character immediately attacks, even with heavy weapons. The heavier your weapon the attack costs more energy and also your character needs longer to recover after an attack before you can dodge or attack again. In Lords every attack, even with light weapons, has a wind-up kinda. So when you press attack, your character starts swinging his sword so the attack hits the enemy very late in the animation and after the animation your character has a long recovery time before you can block again, but you can attack very quickly after the first attack. Because of this making combos is much more effective in Lords than in Dark Souls. Another difference is that you can dodge ANY time while you are attacking, which means you can also cancel your attack animation.- dodging is different. In Dark Souls when you dodge your character "jumps" away very fast (depending on your gear). While you are dodging you are invulnerable for very short time even if the enemy attack hits you. In my experience with Lords there were 2 situations were dodging behaves different. When you are in a defensive position and the enemy attacks and you dodge, chances are he will hit you 90% of the time unless his attack is really slow, especially because your character rolls much slower than in Dark Souls, even with light armor.But when you roll after an attack or while you are in an attack animation, your character will start rolling immediately and chances are you character will dodge the enemy counter-attack easily.The best way to play (this is just my experience) you should block when you are defending, and dodge when you are attacking. - loot is different. In Dark Souls every weapon is useful, because they are balanced against each other. There are boss weapons and rare weapons, but those are harder to upgrade and can only be upgraded 5 times, whereas the normal weapons can be upgraded 15 times or 10 times. So you could complete the game even with the starting weapons.In Lords however you find weapons which are simply better than your previous weapons. Its like Diablo or Borderlands.This isnt necessarily a bad thing, however it decreases the amount of variety of the game, because every play will use the best gear he finds and fits to his character stats, but in Dark Souls every player uses a different weapon, a weapon he likes because of its moveset or look. The bad thing about this is that despite this there is much less weapons and armor in the game, so there is EVEN LESS variety. This isnt a huge problem though, but its important.- the checkpoint system is different. When you save at a checkpoint, enemys wont respawn and not all of your potions will be replenished. Every checkpoint can only give you a maximum of 4 potions back and you have to wait for the checkpoint to recharge. Enemys only respawn when you die or when you go to a different region (basicly every loading screen). This is worse game design than Dark Souls imo, but that doesnt mean its bad. An advantage of this is that the game is less frustrating (if you are someone who gets frustrated) and also they compensate for this by not replenshing all your potions at checkpoints as I explained.The Good:-  good level design . Dark Souls-esque level design with focus on exploration, shortcuts to previous regions and sometimes alternative ways. However the leves arent that big and mostly you are walking along corridors.-  good art-style . Unique art style which is really nice to look at and even if they dont have THAT much variety in the design of weapons and armor, its never boring to look at this game.-  great graphics . Looks great and has okay system requirements. Last patch fixed most crashes and game runs even better.-  good bosses . Mostly humanoid bosses, but interesting nonetheless with different attack patterns and unqiue ways to kill each boss for unique loot.-  good combat system.  I explained this at the first section of this review.-  good next game + mode  when you start next game plus you can select an additional spell tree, so you still make progress on your second playthrough (unlike Dark Souls where you have almost everything after your first playthrough), however there arent new enemys like in Dark Souls, old enemys just become stronger.The Bad:-  small amount of variety. The art-design of the game is great, but it doesnt change that much. most weapons look similar, most armors look similar and most locations look similar.-  a little bit back tracking might annoy you.  Sometimes you have to go through locations you already visited. I personaly had no problems with this, because it doesnt happen too much and sometimes they change things up a bit. But some people might be annoyed by this.-  too easy.  The game was challenging, which is good, but it wasnt hard. The more you continue through the game, the better you get and the game gets easier and easier. I killed the last 3 bosses on my first try. Normally the fact that the player gets better is a good thing, but the game has to offer NEW challenges and harder challenges so the player is always challenged. Maybe this isnt a big problem, especially if you consider that I am a Dark Souls veteran, so for non-Dark Souls players this might be hard game.-  forgettable and unnecessary story.  Because of the more traditional approach I expected a good story, but the story is so forgettable, the game would benefit if they just cut out the story entirely and only keep audilogs and side quests and dialouges. At least then you would have less interruptions and could decide yourself how much you want to learn about the world. Conclusion: Lords of the Fallen is a GREAT game with minor flaws. This is especially impressive if you consider that this game is made by a small german developer studio and still has great production value. I wouldnt pay 50€ for this game, but I dont pay 50€ for any game anyway. For me its worth 30€, I do not recommend this game to people who have to button mash and need simple controls to enjoy a game. Button mashing will be punished in this game, which is great. Also you have to be patient.

content:

												It's basically Dark Souls with much better graphics and toned-down difficulty. Still, Lords Of The Fallen is a great game.It took me about 17h to complete and the game crashed only once, so I guess I was lucky :)+ Stunning graphics.+ Runs smoothly, 60fps@1080p all the time, all maxed.+ The combat is simple, yet stellar, with a feeling of weight. + Decent length.+ Armor design is superb, they look seriously badass!- Too easy. The bosses in particular.- The boss design is boring, practically every boss is a dude with a sword etc...- Clunky animations, especially the characters.- Not much to explore, the game is much more linear than f.ex. Dark Souls.All and all, Lords of the Fallen was a good game and I can recommend it to anyone who likes the whole Dark Souls - style of gameplay and genre.8/10

Product received for free
												If you enjoyed Dark Souls, there is some chance that you will enjoy Lords of the Fallen as well, although you might find them too easy and shallow when compared to any part of DS.If you like the concept of Dark Souls but are also a casual scrub and cannot make it past the asylum demon, Lords of the Fallen is the game for you.In short, it is much easier, much less demanding, much less complex version of Dark Souls. These games share similarities such as storyline which makes absolutely no sense, or the combat system, which is actually very good in LotF, although when compared to DS it might seem a bit more clumsy - you will often fight enemies in small rooms or narrow corridors, your character is a bit less mobile than in DS, the animations are usually longer and there are less enemies that you will have to face simultaneously, which in my opinion is the exact thing that makes thsis game easier than Souls. The bosses are also well developed and varied - some of them are just a challenge for your combat skills, while the others require you to use some special mechanics in order to defeat them.So, if you read it all and made it this far, it probably means that you are really interested in getting that game. Just do it. You're not going to regret.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												I greatly enjoyed this game - but I struggled with it in the beginning due to comparing it too much to Dark Souls.For example - there are enemies that have their shield up nearly constantly. In Dark Souls you would kick, here the kick was nearly useless. However in Lords of the Fallen you shield rush your way through which is actually more awesome than the Dark Souls kick.The game has many similarities that's true - but did introduce new ideas and concepts, however it seems that the gaming community might have expected more Dark Souls (an excellent game) but got Lords of the Fallen (a great game) and thus saw Lords in a negative light.Things I loved:Running through enemies with your shield up.Jumping attacks - all the time.Using giant weapons nearly constantly (something I didn't tend to do in Dark Souls)The art style.Some of the more unique looking enemies.Most of the boss fights.Being balanced for a single player game - thus allowing you to feel very powerful.I haven't tried to play as a rogue or cleric - I might try these for the next play throughts - but I feel that I got a great deal with the warrior play through.

number of helpful: 16 of 29 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Great game in it's own right. Combat is very well done. Each weapon has weight and works out exactly like you would expect it to. Graphics are really nice but needs a patch to fix the memory leak. Story is decent, voices are well acted. The best is the combat by far though. It really has the "OOMPH" that the Dark Souls game severly lacked.I want to add a few things. There are quite a few bugs in this game that are downright game killing. A couple of the weapons have added procs that when they go off will crash the game about 80% of the time. The small "dogs" that are on fire and roll towards you will cause the game to crash at times. Enemies can and will disappear through walls, there's no hit detection on anything except enemies. The game is NOT optimized well to run on PC. While running the game with 4gb of Vram my memory will shoot up upwards of about 80-85%. My cpu will skyrocket as well. Anywhere from 20% all the way to about 70% depending on the area. While this game was supposedly made separately from consoles it's hard to tell as you get hints telling you to use triggers or bumper buttons.    While I enjoy the game a lot, there's quite a bit going on in the background that is killing this game outright. At times when fighting enemies you'll even hear an "error" sound but nothing happens. Almost like there's a window behind the game alerting to something going wrong.   All in all, a good game that needs a couple of patches to iron out the wrinkles. If you're on the fence about this one I'd give it til at least the Steam Winter Sale to see if it drops in price and has been fixed appropriately.

												I wanted something challenging, but not as frustrating as the Dark Souls series.  This is a great balance of challenge and fun that I think most people would enjoy.  It also seems that most of the issues that people were having problems with at launch have been resolved with patches.  It has a tight, clean interface and the combat is a blast.  You'll die plenty, but the game gives you ways to wager risk/reward.  I'm really enjoying this game as I hoped I would.  It deserves more than mixed reviews imo.  I'd give it a solid 4.5/5 stars.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015



YouTube™ Video: Lords of the Fallen Review 

			Views: 322		

			Is Lords of the Fallen just a Dark Souls clone or is there more lurking beneath the surface? This is my first attempt at a 1080p/60 fps video. Let me know how it looks in the comments below.		

In the past year I’ve become a big fan of the Dark Souls series. After several unsuccessful attempts starting the first Dark Souls, both on Xbox 360 and PC, I finally dug my heels in and found an entry point into the infamously difficult action RPG. I moved on to Dark Souls 2 after finishing the original and spent many hours exploring the world and leveling my characters. Eventually my interest waned and I moved on to other games. Even though there was new Dark Souls 2 DLC, I’d become burned out and needed a break.Cut to a few months later and I started to see footage of a new Souls-like game called Lords of the Fallen. The game looked beautiful and was an unapologetic Dark Souls clone, an action RPG with tight combat mechanics, high difficulty, and punishing bosses. Lords was positioned as a western version of the Japanese Souls series and looked to move into the specific niche carved out by Demon’s Souls, Dark Souls, and Dark Souls 2. As a fan of these games I was immediately intrigued. How does Lords of the Fallen compare? Is it a true successor to Souls series or is it just a pale pretender?Developers Deck13 Interactive and CI Games have delivered a game built from the ground up to appeal to fans of Dark Souls. If you’ve played any of the Souls games you’ll be able to pick up and play immediately; there’s even a control scheme that matches that found in Dark Souls, save for a few minor differences. Rather than going through all the ways Lords of the Fallen is similar to Dark Souls, I’ll highlight some of the most interesting ways they differ.The first major difference you’ll notice relates to the character you play. In the Souls series, there are no set characters. You’re responsible for choosing the way your character looks and there are no clear backstories. In fact, the story in the Souls series is largely opaque, with a few hints here and there. In Lords of the Fallen you play as Harkyn, a former prisoner with a troubled past. Although you can still customise your playstyle with creation choices, everyone experiences Harkyn’s story. This streamlines the story but also serves to limit your role-playing possibilities.When starting a new game you choose class and magic type. Class determines starting skills, armour, and weapons. Magic type is a little misleading, as your magical powers are closer to special combat abilities rather than specific types of spells. Every magic type enhances combat, whether by weakening your enemies or strengthening your attacks. There’s no option for a pure magic user, for instance, as the game is specifically tuned for melee combat. What magic there is supplements hand to hand combat rather than replacing it.This focus on hand to hand combat means that fights are slower and more deliberate. Even fights with low level enemies can take a minute or two to win. Shield-bearing enemies are everywhere in the world and they take up the most time; unlike Dark Souls, where you’re able to break their guard and attack during the opening, the shielded enemies in Lords of the Fallen recover quickly and don’t offer many attack opportunities. Thankfully you’re given a gauntlet that can fire magic projectiles and this soon became my go-to method for dealing with frustrating shields.Lords of the Fallen streamlines the gameplay formula set in Dark Souls. This makes for a generally easier, friendlier experience. One of the most tedious aspects of Dark Souls relates to running back after dying during a boss fight. Bonfires are normally not right next to the boss. This means you have to struggle your way through groups of enemies in order to have another go. Lords does away with this frustration and typically places checkpoints right next to boss areas. You can also bank experience at checkpoints and then spend it later.In general, Lords of the Fallen is a much more linear game, and that’s both a strength and a weakness. I prefer the open world of Dark Souls and the nebulous character motivations. I like having the option to try a different route or move to a whole new area if I’m stuck. The bosses in Lords of the Fallen, the titular Lords, are also pretty unoriginal. Mostly heavily armoured knights with shields, there are no bosses on the massive scale seen in the first Dark Souls. While there are different patterns and stages to their attacks, most boss fights are grindy and tedious.Some of the game’s mechanics are poorly communicated. I was halfway through the game when I realised some walls could be broken by dashing into them while holding up your shield. The health potion replenishment system could be clearer as well; sometimes I’d have them all refilled when saving at a checkpoint and sometimes not. I later discovered this was regulated by how many enemies you killed between checkpoints; there might’ve been a tip explaining this, but if there was I missed it.The story in Lords of the Fallen is much more transparent than those in the Souls series. There are dialogue trees and clear quest objectives. I had a much better idea of what my character was doing and where the story was going. That said, I didn’t necessarily know where I needed to go. I lost track of how many hours I spent backtracking, looking for that one door I hadn’t opened yet or struggling to find an obscure corridor. There aren’t that many different areas and some of them are ridiculous mazes with similar paths that blur together.On a more positive note, Lords of the Fallen looks beautiful, with great lighting and animations; it’s definitely got Dark Souls 2 beat. However, my biggest gripe with the visuals is the inconsistent camera. Several times I found myself losing my character into first person mode by getting too close to a wall in combat.Ultimately I enjoyed Lords of the Fallen; however, there isn’t as much replayability for me when compared to Dark Souls. You’re limited in character creation choices and there’s not that much difference between a cleric, a warrior, and a rogue. There are extra boss challenges that’ll reward you with a special weapon if you complete them but some of these are exceptionally difficult and don’t interest me that much.I beat the game once in about 20 hours and then again in New Game+ in another 10 hours or so; I had a lot of fun playing through the first time but NG+ wasn’t that different. The combat kept me coming back but at a certain point the enemy scaling outpaced my own and I stopped having as much fun. The interminable backtracking also wore me down; there’s only so much time I want to spend running around a circular room.Playing Lords of Fallen made me appreciate the Souls series even more; it’s been enough to whet my appetite for another Dark Souls 2 playthrough, and an attempt at the new DLC. I’m looking forward to Lords of the Fallen 2; hopefully Deck13 Interactive and CI Games will deliver a game with wider scope and more interesting bosses. Until then, there’s always the endless appeal of Dark Souls.
