												EDIT2: About 2 hours after I made that edit I walked through a door to a new area and I immediately fell through the floor and died. I then repeatedly respawned at the start of this area constantly dying unable to do anything so basically now my save is completely ♥♥♥♥ed until the fix this.EDIT: Now that I've gave the game some more time I have to say I think it's actually not as bad as I first thought. If I'm playing a character in the heaviest armour using the heaviest weapon then of course my attacks are going to take half an hour to wind up. The game is actually quite satisfying once you get used to the combat and appreciate how it isn't exactly the same as Dark Souls. There appears to be a lot to do and there are many different new mechanics that do build upon the Dark Souls Genre. I don't think the game is perfect but I do think it's a good start in what hopefully is a long line of good Dark Souls like games.OLD REVIEW ( If you like Dark Souls I wouldn't automatically assume that you'll like this game. While the combat is similar it's not exactly the same as Dark Souls. Dark Souls combat is quick. This combat feels like you're playing as a sloth that is covered in treacle who's just woken up from a year long slumber. A sloth that has to wait for the enemy to use that one move that has a long enough recovery time to actually get a good attack in without being staggered.It's okay but I wouldn't really recommend it.)

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												Lords of the FallenFirst off i wanna say that i went into this without any real expectations. The game was gifted too me by my brother who is a huge dark souls fan. After spending a dozen hours with the game i have too say I am quite impressed. I am basing this review on my own experiences and not those of other people. I can recommend this game due too the fact i have had none of the crashes and hardships that everyone else has been having. I will list some pros and cons for the game and then a final verdict. Pros:-Gorgeous graphics, some of the best ive ever seen in an adventure game. -Combat is fluid and takes timing, gives you a sense of accomplishment-Loot and more loot-Replay value, if you love collecting everything and wanna get 100% complete there is lots too do here-Soundtrack is spot onCons-Enemy types become repetitive-Some framerate issues -Camera can get a little in the way sometimes due too linear corridors-Voice acting is mediocre at best and lip synching is terribleSo overall I found the game too be engaging and fun. Not the best action rpg i have ever played but surely not the worst. A great battle system and sense of urgency keeps you on your toes as you traverse this world in search of a new peice of gear and formiddable foes. 7/10

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												i am big fan of 3rd person action adventures (fantasy or modern), and liked LotF a lot+great viduals+awesome art and level design+solid combat, that requires timing and patience (its not combo-heavy, but button mashing doesnt work either)+crashed 2 times in 50hrs, path 1.4 (1 crash was due to low VRAM when i tried ultra textures)+had no FPS drops on i3 4.5Ghz and GTX760, all maxed except tetures and turbulence+nice bosses, but battles with them are fairly short, and are mostly about dodging the bad stuff and wait for oportunity to strike+NG+ and NG++ with new items, lore and much more challenging (you can free roam after NG++)+you loose all gathered EXP and EXP multiplier when you die (but you can save the game without loosing it)-if you are not "explorer" type, fairly short (8-10hrs maybe)-story was there, but wasnt anything memorable or thrilling (all the little twists were kinda obvious)-no quest log of journal (or i missed it?)-some kind of teleporting between locations would be cool, at least the major ones-many ppl are reporting crashes, not sure if this was prior to 1.4 issue, but i did not have problem+- singleplayer only (what i dont really mind, but some "hardcore" Dark Souls fans might miss MP (but seems that most of those hate on any other similar game anyway)Dont expect Dark Souls game, this is easier, simplier but on the other hand more immersive and beatiful looking game (that wont make you eat your pad out of frustration)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												So, despite the rumors and vids that i heard and saw, i still bought that game. I have to say that i don't regret it. Yes, the game has its flaws, but which game hasn't? The bugs and the major performance issues didn't show up in my playthrough. (could be because of all the patches the developers released). In fact, i never had any FPS drop down below 55 on ultra settings and didn't had any gamebreaking bug or CTD.There are only some problems i have with the game. First, the overall length of the story. It is waaay too short for that kind of game. I didin't rush through the campaign nor did i miss any side quest. I did everything i could and explored every dungeon. For that 16 hrs are too few. The second problem is the Lore. Yes you can read a bit about the Lore in the codex and you find audio notes here and there, but the explanation is way too vague and you are just thrown into a world you have no idea of. You get way too few infos about any character not even your own. A shame actually, because the world seems pretty interesting. Thrid and final problem i had is the lack of quest informations and the vague explanations of quest locations. I guess it is a bit like Dark Souls in that regard, but it wouldn't have hurt to actually have a list of all open quests. I can live with the lack of map or questmarkers, but a chance to reread what the open quests are about would be helpful.As you can see i recommend the game so there has to be something positiv about it right? :) There is. The fact that they shamelessly copied from Dark Souls pays off. The combat is breathtaking and you really have to be strategic to defeat the various types of enemies and bosses. The boss battles are hard, but still fair. The different weapon types all feel completely different. Every weapon has its own story and unique look. Armor as well. The weight and energy system is as good as in Dark Souls. Do you want to be the fast dodging skilled fighter with two blades or more the heavy armored Tank who wields a huge axe and tower shield? It's up to you. You can even be both or a mix in between ;) Oh well and the graphics look badass. So overall, I can say that i quite enjoyed the game and might start a NG+ sooner or later. If you didn't buy the game till yet and you really want a game that is a little easier than Dark Souls then buy it :)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												I can only reccomend this game!Sure, it is no Dark Souls 1 in terms of the world, the difficulty, the atmosphere and the sheer amount of complexity and content. BUT, when you look at this game by itself, its very good. Some points that are worth mentioning:- The combat is amazing. All weapon types handle very differently and you have a lot of choices on how to engage and deal with enemies trough combos, leap attacks, rollattacks, parries, counters etc.- The itemsystem and rpg element of the game is very solid. The different types of armor and shields offer a nice variety and whilst the character leveling is rather straight forward, you can still develop a unique playstyle.- The leveldesign is top notch, the world feels like a maze where you always find new paths, secrets and shortcuts.- Although the artstyle feels somewhat generic, I really enjoyed the atmosphere of a rough nordic world mixed a world, that reminds you of diablo1.- The story was decent. The dialouges sometimes felt a bit cheesy, but I liked the plot and the audio logs.In the end I would say the overall quality of this game is a bit worse than dks1, but better than dks2! Regarding technical issues: I had several problems with crashes and freezes that were really annoying, but the game is completely stable with patch 1.2 for me now.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												It was a really fun game and was my first experience at challenging ARPGs. I must say though for a $60 title it was very short in terms of content. I got 13 hours out of a single playthrough and was left wanting more. One thing I also disliked was the fact that you could tell the game was progressing very quickly because it seemed that in no time at all you were onto the next boss fight with no kind of down time or build up between them. I know what I said is very negative so far but wait. The combat which has to be the highlight of this game is EXTREMELY satisfying. That fact that I started out a pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ player and slowly progressed and got better and better really made me feel good and helped me feel like my character was actually getting stronger. The story in this game wasn't too bad but wasn't really fully explained in my opinion. It felt very open ended when I finished the game but the audio logs that are left around the world that help you discover the story are a very nice touch. I absoloutley love the art style in this game but maybe a few less spikes on all the armour would be nice. :p Overall though I'd give this game a 7.5/10 and anyone who is looking for a game similar to dark souls but a bit easier and more of an entry into tough ARPGs, this is the game for you.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												Lords of the Fallen has a somewhat dented learning curve: unless you're a veteran of the Dark Souls franchise—which I'm told LotF emulates—you'll probably find the combat pretty challenging in the beginning, to say nothing of taking down the first boss or two. But once you develop certain magical skills, the difficulty drops almost to the point of tedium (for me, the skill that did it was "Stab" on a rogue, and to a certain extent, "Shift"). Most common opponents suddenly pop like soap bubbles, and as soon as you learn to evade the most damaging boss attacks, the big guys no longer pose nearly as much of a threat as they're probably meant to do. And since the story is dark fantasy boilerplate with ciphers for characters, even the admittedly gorgeous visuals can no longer make up for the fact that your sole incentive for plodding through the game is the prospect of finding shinier toys in the next chest. That ain't much. I'm by no means saying LotF is a bad game, especially if you can get it during a sale, which is why I'm still recommending it. You may well get a few hours worth of fun out of this title. Just not enough fun—or challenge—to last to the very end of it.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												A few technical problems with this one. If you are using an AMD graphics card, this game will likely slow down or run at sub optimum. The specs required are higher than suggested. It isn't super stable.That said, this game is a solid experience. Like many people, I will compare it to Dark Souls since they fit in the same niche. This game is an odd blend of Diablo style leveling & loot collection (everything is randomized), and Dark Souls combat.  You can technically pick a class, but very quickly these have little to no difference, beyond the cleric having a heal. Weapon stats, damage, and speed are all random so a pair of shortswords can do more damage than a two hander, and be slower. You have a stamina bar, health, a limited number of health potions that refill at rest points, a block, parry, heavy attack, light attack, and roll. The art personally reminds me of the chunky comic book style from Darksiders, so a big plus. It does repeat the Dark Souls 2 problem of most enemies being some variation of "guy in armor", but they all look impressive, and the rarer non-human enemies are quite cool. The story is pretty standard fantasy fluff, and isn't going to under or overwhelm anyone. For 20$ or less, you are getting 10+ hours of solid game to slake that thirst that -for me- only the Souls series really fills.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												So, despite the rumors and vids that i heard and saw, i still bought that game. I have to say that i don't regret it. Yes, the game has its flaws, but which game hasn't? The bugs and the major performance issues didn't show up in my playthrough. (could be because of all the patches the developers released). In fact, i never had any FPS drop down below 55 on ultra settings and didn't had any gamebreaking bug or CTD.There are only some problems i have with the game. First, the overall length of the story. It is waaay too short for that kind of game. I didin't rush through the campaign nor did i miss any side quest. I did everything i could and explored every dungeon. For that 16 hrs are too few. The second problem is the Lore. Yes you can read a bit about the Lore in the codex and you find audio notes here and there, but the explanation is way too vague and you are just thrown into a world you have no idea of. You get way too few infos about any character not even your own. A shame actually, because the world seems pretty interesting. Thrid and final problem i had is the lack of quest informations and the vague explanations of quest locations. I guess it is a bit like Dark Souls in that regard, but it wouldn't have hurt to actually have a list of all open quests. I can live with the lack of map or questmarkers, but a chance to reread what the open quests are about would be helpful.As you can see i recommend the game so there has to be something positiv about it right? :) There is. The fact that they shamelessly copied from Dark Souls pays off. The combat is breathtaking and you really have to be strategic to defeat the various types of enemies and bosses. The boss battles are hard, but still fair. The different weapon types all feel completely different. Every weapon has its own story and unique look. Armor as well. The weight and energy system is as good as in Dark Souls. Do you want to be the fast dodging skilled fighter with two blades or more the heavy armored Tank who wields a huge axe and tower shield? It's up to you. You can even be both or a mix in between ;) Oh well and the graphics look badass. So overall, I can say that i quite enjoyed the game and might start a NG+ sooner or later. If you didn't buy the game till yet and you really want a game that is a little easier than Dark Souls then buy it :)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												Lords Of The Fallen is obviously inspired by the souls series. Really obvious,but the fact is that it does a very good job in creating a world and using the souls gameplay in a very good way. It is to be expected then, that you will be drawing parallels between the two. First of all is it worth the money? I would say even though there is no pvp as far as my knowledge goes (it might change latter) that it is worth the money and time to play this game. It really has been a long time since I spend 30 hours in a few days not even a week in a game such as this, the combat system is fun and challenging (not as much as the souls series) and there are enemies that will require you to really figth hard to beat them (or use magic but we'll get to that) the leveling system is also nice, one small critisism I have is that faith weapons become really weak later on, but over all it's a really well made game polished with fun staged and bosses. At this point I have to say that it is rather easier that what dark souls, demos souls or bloodborne are to the point that an experienced souls player can beat bosses on a first run without a guide (which is wild fantasy in a souls game) and thats because of what I refered to previously as "magic". Magic in this game or spells are really overpowered, to the point that you 3 shot a boss with a fully upgraded quake, now that doesn't hold true for the NG+ but you have to remember that unless you want a specific item for the aestherics of it and a few achivements, there is absolutely no reason to replay the game in NG+, NG++ and so on. Unless you really love the game. But appart from the no PVP problem other than that this game packs a really nice storyline with some plot twists some nice secrets, interesting gameplay especially stealthy gameplay at some points since there are enemies who can not hear you and has a few choices that matter in terms of story and gameplay (not too many and no where near as much as they do in the souls games but your choices matter non the less). So in all honesty if you really like the souls series but you are not an easily buthurt fan boy, in which case you should avoid the game and the review all together, then I can not recomment this game enough, it has really been a long time since a game had such nice aestherics in regards to the enemies the weapons the armours the effects in pretty much everything it incorporates, the gameplay is polished and works very nice the bosses have specific patters which if you don't want to abuse with spells then they make for a really nice challenge, also a thing I really like is the fact that you can use any weapon you happen to come by and by that I mean there are no useless weapons, you still need the appropriate skill to use them (dex stg etc) but I haven't found a single weapon that was legitimately useless. So over all it's an awesome under rated game that has been hated a lot mostly for the lack of PVP and really deserves your time if you are into this kind of games like I am.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												Gametime: 15 hoursNumber of playthroughs: 1The Good:- Beautiful, grim, dark art. Gothic in a sense with other inspirations for the more fantasy stuff.- Decent keyboard controls, only remapped 2 keys- Combat is good; forgiving for new players and hard to master for hardcore players. Parrying is difficult and optimizing stats is rewarding (but not really difficult in any way).- Sound design is nice but not awesome- Lots of items to customize with progression and unique art.- UI and interface is decent- FIghting enemies is fun but takes patienceThe Bad:- Crashes, most of which have been fixed for me with patches but some random ones here and there still exist.- World feels small and cramped most of the time. Needs more areas and side quests.- Side quests are hard to track and remember- A lot of items in the game have cryptic effects that you won't know until you read about them or really experiment and pay attention- Last boss fight was lame- New Game+ doesn't have much to offerThe Ugly:- Not much really, this game is a stone's throw away from being amazing.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												So it took me about 22 hours to finish the game on my first playthrough where developers were saying approximately 30 hours, which to me is fair but I am very familiar with this style of game and BECAUSE of my souls experience this game posed very little challenge. Once I was in a comfortable set of armor and found a weapon I liked, the game was a breeze and again little to nothing posed any real threat, I mean I one shot every boss in the game as I went through and the bosses were easily harder than any of the trash that was encountered. Now, I will mention this, this game is HEAVILY inspired by the Souls series, and rightfully so, the Souls game were so unique and so unforgiving that when I had finished them both with about 200 hours invested into each I was craving more of that Souls style combat and I found it here in spades, just not really as punishing as souls. All the people who said that this game was bad because combat was slow a clunky and the developers tried to make it hard by making enemies dodge hit and block faster than you clearly has no patience at all, they were obviously spoiled by games like Darksiders where you can litterally button mash your way to victory. Combat in Lotf is precise and deiliberate. Swinging a heavy weapon means looking for that window, taking advantage of it, and reducing yourself to the fact that you may only get the one swing in unless you use a weapon which a much faster attack speed, it's all up to the player. What I did like was that they allowed magic to be a viable option even when building a melee character without being punished for it. This is a solid game and if you are the type that enjoys weighty realistic combat, visceral environments kick a$$ looking bosses, this game will not let you down. 8/10 for me.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												I can recommend the game without a single doubt to anyone who liked Dark Souls series, and to everyone who wanted to like Dark Souls (a format of a game) but just couldn't since it was too much♥♥♥♥♥rape.Lords of the Fallen is a bit easier than DS in fact. Specifically it is a bit more forgiving with more frequent Save Points and more responsive combat. Moreover, you will not rage over a death because of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t mechanic. The controls are as tight and responsive as they could be. The "feel" of the weapons and armours and that feedback is just so incredible. You can almost feel the pain when you smash someone with that great-two-handed-hammer. I think no one has done it better before.Graphics are great with amazing views and very climatic landscapes, dungeons, monsters, weapons and armour sets.The storyline is OK and interesting, the only problem would be occasional silly/stupid NPC lines.Also, this game has a lot of secrets and finding/figuring them out is very rewarding. Wandering of the main-story route sometimes takes you away for well more than an hour.Sure, it is not an open world by any chance, but it is definitely NOT a single route single corridor gaming as some major reviews claim it to be.I personally do not like the Gauntlet as an substitute to magic and I feel the game is lacking a proper mage class. Playing a cleric/warrior I as felt the cleric spells to be a bit weird looking but that's personal preference.I have not experienced ANY crashes whatsoever, the game is probably fixed by now.Check this game out! It's seriously worth it. 9-/10

content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												Wanted this game for a long time because I always wanted some "Dark Souls" game which wouldn't be so surreal in visuals and atmosphere. I like dark atmosphere games but Dark Souls seems too much sucked from a finger for me and has too much unnecessary surrealism.Anyways, bought it (LotF) and, I can say, I am satisfied overall. This game is a strong 8/10: not a masterpiece but once you enter it you can't exit until you've played for at least 2 hours session (was playing it for 8-10 hours sessions couple of times and still there were moments when I needed to go for a sleep/food but I couldn't because the game is actually really good and addictive), and that happens with every session till you complete the game.Story is not 10/10 but has a strong foundation and moral. Boss fights are pretty cheap and easy, even for me, who played Dark Souls for 30-60 minutes overall. Some random situations against common enemies can be 100 times harder than any boss fight in the entire game.Another great, and significant, point of this game is gothic fantasy-scandinavian atmosphere in visuals, music, architecture and battle equipment.Next one is a spoiler so take it on your own risk.The thing I can't get over with is: you (playing as ex-prisoner and highly dangerous man, kill the entire hell of demons and dark lords) are coming back to your realm closer to the end of the game. You literally save the world from hell whilst others couldn't do a♥♥♥♥♥♥and it turns out that the main enemy was by your side all the time, which is ok. But which is not ok is that the main antagonist is guarded by regular human warriors who were suffering demon invasion the entire game and were introducted to us as a bunch of suffering people who can't stand it and all gonna die soon if you do not hurry and save the world. The plot shows us that people can't do much and you are the only hope.So, closer to the end of the game, you are forced to fight them as your enemies (plot twist) and it turns out that they are such a pain in your♥♥♥♥♥as opponents. You suddenly realise that all those lords of hell and demons were NOTHING comparing to these regular human warriors because all of them are just disgusting (talking about their fight styles and fight behaviour overall) and really hard to kill.So, automatically, the question is rising: why the hell they needed some lone ex-prisoner to save their asses whilst they are more powerful than any demon in the game? Seriously, most restarts during the entire game I had at this particular part - fighting regular human warriors.This thing just makes the entire plot look like some bad joke or awful anekdote, at least for me.But, if you close your eyes on this (because, I hope, this thing is just a necessary plot twist which automatically transfered into game balance, but still I can't get why they (developers) couldn't just kill those warriors (in storyline) and replace them with new demon types or just make those people corrupted - would make a complete logic) the game is strong in its perfomance and you will like it.

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Lords of the Fallen is among the first entries of what I hope to be the beginning of the "souls-like" dark fantasy action RPG.  Like many early games in a new subgenre, it excels in some areas and falls flat on its face in others.  It ends up being a decent game that falls just short of expectations.The graphics of Lords of the Fallen is gorgeous, with fantastic and consistent art style throughout the game.  Unfortunately, the game is not well optimized, and does not run well for many players.  Some are unable to play the game at all due to constant crashing.  The developer has been hard at work releasing stability patches, so this may not be a problem in the future.  Just keep in mind that you may not get a smooth experience if you don't have powerful setup.The game offers some interesting lore, given to you mostly by audio logs found throughout the world, and a little more through dialogue.  Conversations have an awkward, jilted flow, leaving most characters dull and one-dimensional.The meat and potatoes of games of this type is the gameplay, specifically combat.  Fighting in this game is broken in both senses of the word.  The biggest problem is the fact that you lose stamina at the beginning of your attack animation, instead of the end.  Weapons in this game have great, weighty attack animations that lose all momentum the moment you get hit, regardless of how close you were to completing the attack.  This makes fighting with slow, powerful weapons infuriating.  All too many times I've attacked with a long windup for an attack, only to get hit with a piddly 2 damage from a quick enemy swipe, losing the attack and the stamina invested.    Never spam the attack button, as you will most often get hit every time, losing all stamina leaving you unable to block or dodge, all the while dealing 0 damage to the enemy.  While there is a poise stat, I have never seen Harkyn tank a hit and strike through, even in the heaviest of armors against the lightest of enemy attacks.The game gives you a variety of spells, most of which have very little use.  While a few spells offer utility, the casting animation of spells leaves you vulnerable for too long, making it difficult to justify casting spells in combat apart from a select few.  You are given a magic "attack" through the gauntlet item, but it is awkward to switch to mid-combat and  does little damage per point of magic usage unless you have invested heavily into it.  Because of this, combat is nearly always through melee combat.  Of note are ghosts and anything with a shield, which are difficult to manage without magic.On the other hand, combat can be broken in your favor by the inexplicably strong effect stat scaling has.  You have no reason to put anything other than a Luck rune in your weapon, since the increase of damage outclasses anything else.  Because of this, any weapon without a rune slot or without any scaling (as in, most weapons) will be overlooked.One thing the Lords excels in is boss combat.  Bosses are all unique and have segmented health bars.  With each segment you reach, the boss changes tactics or adds new attacks.  This leaves boss encounters fresh and interesting throughout the fight.  In addition, you pick up a weapon from each boss you kill.  By fulfilling certain criteria, such as taking no damage or ending the fight quickly, you will get an upgraded version of the boss weapon.  This is a welcome addition to add extra challenge if you are up to the task.All in all, Lords of the Fallen is a bittersweet game.  It ends up being a mixed experience that may be worth it if you can work past its many flaws.  Expect around 15 to 20 hours of gameplay.  Consider giving it a look if it is on heavy discount, but you won't miss much by passing it by.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
 Warning: If you do not enjoy games like the Souls series, do not buy this game. Lords Of The Fallen has been compared to the Souls series, containing a slow tactical approach to close-quarters combat gameplay, with difficult enemies and locations to overcome.In this game, you will control a hero called Harkyn. He is a warrior with a mysterious past ready to confront an army of demons. He was release from jail by a mysterious man called Kaslo. Kaslo gives Harkyn an opportunity for him to redeem for his crimes in a mission to save the realm dominated by demons.The gameplay is really good and easy to learn. I strongly recommend to play it with a controller, otherwise, the game can be harder to play. The game uses a "risk and reward" system. The amount of experience the player can gain for use can be increased through a multiplier that builds up the longer the player mixes up combo attacks or avoids using checkpoints and spending their experiences.The cons that I have about this game are about the cutscenes and the camera. They could have putted more effort in the cutscenes to be more natural. Sometimes the dialog and the movements of the characters do not match, and the scenes are very robotic.The camera during the gameplay can be tricky sometimes. As an example, in a small room during a fight, the camera goes into an angle that you cannot see your character or the enemy, and this can become deadly sometimes. This event happens in rare times, but when it happens it is very annoying.If you enjoyed the serie of Souls and like new challenges, this game is a good choice for you!9.5/1O

												What a shame.. I for one really do think the game is lovely, but in its current state I can't recommend it. I wouldn't say its unplayable, but it does have some very annoying bugs (very odd fps drops, which seem completely unrelated to what goes on screen, wrong enemy hitboxes, wierd AI glitches, and so on). As I said this truly is a pity as the game is actually quite good in itself. The combat is addictive and it does have a nice, dark tone to it although the voice acting and lip-sync leaves a lot to be desired. So yeah, If it wasn't for so many technical issues I would definitely recommend it, though in its current state there is simply too much microstuttering and various stability issues going on for a game a la dark souls, where stability should be kind of a priority. FYI I didn't see many CTDs (just one in 6 hours), its just the other problems that are very annoying. Ethically I can't recommend a buggy game.. But if they fix it, this could become a hidden gem!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
NOT RECOMMENDED - YETThis feels like Dark Souls made right (for PC), game is hard but rewarding.Plus it's prettyHoweverIt runs like crap. So far i only had a chance to test it out on a PC which meets "recommended" specifications, however the performance was-sub par.Framerate is not only lower than it should be but also tends to drop to even lower values every now and then.Many blame this occurences on Denuvo which is a DRM system, or rather "anti tampering system" as it is described by its creators.Generally Denuvo is a very controversial topic and if you don't know what it is - i strongly recommend getting acquainted with the topic before making the purchase.Personally i don't appreciate developers punishing those who bought their game with an overload of DRMs, however that is my personal feeling.The good-Proper PC version of Dark Souls(Graphics, controls, etc.)-Hard as hell, but rewarding-Has a lot potentialThe bad-Performance issues-Controversial DRM or just the fact that it's double DRM-Within the time i played so far, plot is not explained very well, you don't know who you are, why you are where you are. Basically nothing is explained (i sure hope that changes later on)-Poor voice acting and lip sync.-Some people encounter stability issues(crashing), besides performance problems.That is all.//Followup:Now i had a chance to "play" the game on my own PC. The game will crash the entire system with BSOD under a minute after i start the actual game.This only proves that performance/stability of this game is a total hit/miss roulette depending on your setup.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												In short:It's not worth the £30 I paid for it, bear in mind though, that's not to say it's a bad game, because it ain't.Graphics:Beautiful environments (most of the time you get to see dungeons), weather effects (not that many of them, but still a joy to look at them). Absolutely great design of a dark world at the edge of destruction, same goes for the enemies.Story:From what I've noticed there's quite a lot of people complaining that it was dull and uninteresting which I'd like to disagree with. It's not among the best ones though, so don't get your hopes too high either.Gameplay & DifficultyWhile I did not continue playing after finishing the game once, I'm pretty sure I have the right to say that this game is nowhere close to being as hard and unforgiving as Dark Souls. Boss battles... some bosses I actually didn't have to dodge or block at all, I entered enraged mode (Warrior Ability - *Rage*) and bashed the b**** to death.The game got (for me, obviously...) a bit too easy after a few hours of playing, jumping onto my enemies, killing them with one blow.It took me about (don't look at hours on record, I'm always pausing for long periods of time) 10 to 12 hours to finish the game.There's quite a lot of equipment which kind of ruins the nice feeling of finding something real powerful. First you find a set of armor, newer, better, so you put runes into it and then boom... you find something better after (not exaggerating) 10 minutes and you redo the whole armor-runing process.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												Okay. In order to truly get a good idea on what Lords of the Fallen is like, we need to look to a game called "Dark Souls" to explain it's gameplay. LotF sets out to be difficult from the get go, forcing the player into positions where patience is rewarded over arrogance. This would be decent enough, if not for the severe lack of content, or seeming lack of it. The game seems to suffer from a major pacing issue, and atmosphere issue, that Dark Souls does not. While Lords takes a lot of it's inspiration from the Souls series, from it's combat, to it's attempt (but ultimate failure) at recreating the frustratingly hard difficulty level of Souls, to it's story; it doesn't bring the atmosphere of severe hopelessness, and the feeling of just barely being able to trudge along into the next area of the game. The Warrior is capable of tanking so many blows it's just way too easy, the Cleric does way too much damage right out of the gate, and the Rogue is way too quick for his own good.That being said, the game is fun, it's just not what you've probably heard. It's easier than Dark Souls, way more forgiving, in a world that is attempting to recreate a hopeless environment and ultimately fails, making you feel like a total ♥♥♥♥ing badass instead of a total ♥♥♥♥ing pushover, but it's fun. I'll recommend it to anyone who enjoys their time with RPGs.For a number? How about 7/10. Solid, but could easily improve.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												In Short:Game is fun for the most part. The combat takes some getting used to because it is far more sluggish/slow than those who are used to the souls series. It's a pretty neat looking ascetic overall in my opinion, but the high fantasy style that seems similar to World of Warcraft, Diablo 3, or Darksiders series is getting a bit over used. The story is nothing special, but not bad either. There's a lot of lore to find, but it's told to you in scrolls and cutscenes and such, not like the Souls series where you find items and piece the lore together yourself. There are some nit picking problems like I don't find the jump mechanic and various areas to get some loot and require a jump any fun, just frustrating, but those small issues don't detract enough from the game's over all joy. The only big problem are the crashes. As of October 30th, the game crashes way too easily and often. For those who don't have an Nvidia to do that "fix" (which doesn't work for everyone) you're pretty much screwed until they patch it. The other issue is the frame drops which are fairly frequent (doesn't seem optimized). I'd wholly recommend it immediately if not for the crashes and frame drops. For now, I'd say get it if you're REALLY looking for a mixture of Diablo 3/Darksiders style world and Souls style combat, but I'd hold off until they finally fix these technical problems with the game.Steam seriously needs a third option for "Do you recommend this game" imo, basically "Yes, with warnings" or something.A Bit More Depth:Bosses (far as I can tell so far after playing as long as I have) aren't anything special. They're about on par with Dark Souls 2 in terms of design (which means it falls short, imo, to Demons's and Dark Souls bosses), but they are fun fights. A bit too many humanoid enemies which is disappointing, but the different humanoid types are vastly different in attack styles and require different ways to deal with which is fun. The settings for most bosses also are pretty Dark Souls 2 from my experience, plenty of room to maneuver (nothing so far that feels like Capra demon in DkS1 where you're cramped for room to move). I'd say the only real gripe here is that some bosses have some one shot killing abilities that you won't know how to deal with immediately and that can be frustrating, but I personally don't mind it too much if there are some good cues (without being blatantly told) of how to deal with it and most do have that, some are just more subtle than others.Another really cool thing about bosses is that they have the ability to get special loot from them when you beat them in a certain way. The only downside here is that there's NOTHING to indicate what that special way would be leaving you to have to look it up online or just stumble upon the solution by dumb luck (which means you might not know exactly what caused you to get the special loot).The level design is pretty straightforward as you go through the game (not much in terms of choice of path), but when you get through the game you open up more and more paths that show how there's some interconnectivity to the overall world design. For those who loved that aspect in Dark Souls, they'll enjoy it here as they get through toward later parts of the game. It's just a bit of a pity there's no real choice in path from the start in which way to go, but it's not bad from a story telling perspective and the levels look nice enough and have a good amount of interconnectivity within themselves for side paths and short cuts and such that it's never a bother (at least to me, you might feel differently).It's a bit sad you can't customize a look for your character, but that's to be expected given how they tell the story, but what is nice is how much you can customize your character in terms of armor and weapons to use. And the fact you always carry them all on you at once makes it easy to switch weapons and gear and find what you really enjoy. While it doesn't get as punishing as a Souls game because there is a pause menu that allows you to change gear, even in combat (to a degree, not at all points, but if you haven't been attacked or not attacking for a bit, you can switch comfortably as the game is paused to let you do so), it does allow such experimentation with the different weapons that you'll appreciate it as every weapon is VERY different from one another in every way and some will adhere to a person's playstyle more than others.For example: I started as a warrior, I used a sword and shield from the start and found I wasn't enjoying it as I did with Dark our Demons's Souls. The attack felt a bit too sluggish to capitalize on brief moments of an enemy's vulnerability and even though the shield claimed 100% defense, some enemies still seemed to attack through it (at a lesser damage than if I wasn't blocking) at points (far as I can gather that's more due to their attacks being able to pierce shields, so it's by design). So I have currently gone to using a larger two handed weapon that can do ridiculous damage and/or stun/stagger the majority of enemies to get through the game. I'll only occasionally use the shield for some attacks or in clutch moments. It's still very enjoyable though.To go on more about weapons, they are also upgradable by various "runes" you can find in the world and from enemies and have to unlock at an NPC and place within a weapon at that NPC (who can be summoned at specific parts of the world). The weapons and armor generally have 'sockets' to place these runes. So in that case, it's very WoW/Diablo 3 in the customization of weapons and less the way Dark Souls did it. The only downside is that Runes are "unlocked' and what you get is random. You can use some Experience points to increase the chance for higher quality runes, but that randomness is still something I don't wholly like, but that's a personal opinion.Speaking of Experience points, they are very similar to Souls in the Souls games. They are your everything. You use it to unlock your magical abilities and they are used to unlock runes and they are used to gain points to be placed into specific attributes. In this way, it's a lot like the Souls games which I like. The more you spend into the points the higher the cost it is to get the point to spend for your attributes. The attributes are Strength, Vitality, Endurance, Faith, Luck, and Agility. For the most part, what each does is straight forward. Strength increases damage for larger weapons (and some small increases to equip burden), Vitality increases your HP s you can take more hits, Endurance is your energy/stamina (as well as equip burden), Faith is your magic/mp, Luck increases drop rates, and Agility is increased damage for smaller weapons and I think also equip burden, but I can't remember (haven't done anything with Agility yet). You can place points freely.You'll also need to spend experience points to get points to put into magic. Magics come in 3 types. Brawling, Deception, and Solace. You choose one at the start of the game and can't use the others at all for your first play through (I've read and heard that in NG+ you unlock a second tree and in NG++ you unlock the final tree). To go into each tree will be a bit too long with the characters I have left, but they are fairly unique from one another, but you'll never have a magic only character like in the Souls games.All in all, the game is fun and has some nice adjustments to the Souls systems (like the timing/combo system or the 'blood pools' that contains your expedience on death being able to heal you if you stay near it, but draining the experience in it, etc), but is not at all like the Souls in its overall presentation. It's a good game that's only really marred by the crippling frame rates at points and the endless crashes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												I honestly have no idea why this game has such a negative image. As you can see from my played time I have experienced this game to the fullest and I loved every seccond. PROS!-The game is beautiful on max settings, I have a very powerful rig and have played a lot of games to their highest capability and I struggle to think of many games that are better looking. This is at 100+ fps at 1440p.-Runs very smooth as well, has the odd crash to desktop but that happens once in maybe 8 hours. When its running it runs great.-The asthetic of the game is great as well, the world is a little small and you repeat a couple areas with enemies just moved around but to be fair it does fit into the story. They do a fantastic job of making a dark and gritty world. Theres bodies strewn around blood all over the place and building burning. The enemies fit in with the asthetic well, they have dark demonic armor with brutal looking weapons witrh hints of fire and brimstone. They look amazing. The first boss really is a testament to this. The charactger you played (Harken) has great character design, theres lots of little touches that make him a very good character (except his voice acting, some of that is terrible) but he dosent do much talking. -The armor and the weapons, I have been gaming for 26 years and have never seen more badass armor designs in a game, I seriously mean that. Just look at this https://i.ytimg.com/vi/SgtiRB8uvsg/maxresdefault.jpg  The capes flow and move perfectly as well. Have a quick google and look through the sets you will be impressed by most of them. Some are generic and look crap though but they are very few and far between. I love the weapon designs, they just fit the world perfectly, they have such tiny details on them that add to them so well. Nice variety as well.-The main issue I have seen from other peoples reviews is the combat system. If you expect to go into this game and roll about like you can in the Dark souls series you are going to be disapointed. If you understand that this game is methodical, you plan your blocks and your rolls. If you manage your tallents and skills along with your inventory well you will be fine. Weapons are very acurate to how you would swing them in real life. A longsword you can swing several times  so you can get away with spamming and a huge Greathammer is a long slow devastating attack. You have to take into account the enemies range, the enemies abilities and if they have a shield etc. If they do use a heavy attack and guard break them, or kick them or use a spell etc. I absolutely adore the combat system. -The leveling system is actually very robust, you gain xp and can choose to put the xp into skill points or spell points. Skill points increase your main atributes such as strength agility endurance faith etc. Spell points are invested into various abilities in the spell tree you picked at the start of the game along with your armor. Which brings me to another point, it may look like you only have 3 skill trees but the armopr you pick at the start changes things as well. For example you can have Warrior with light medium and heavy armor same with Rogue and Guardian. Theres many more pros but I dont want to bore you too much!CONS!-The voice acting, every character sounds like they are speaking the words phonetically and dont actually understand the words, it takes you out of the world a little but theres very little talking which leads me to my next point. -There is very little story, its there just not very well explained. I could probably sum it up in one sentence. So I will SPOILER Man released from prison to kill big nasty demons that threaten the last of humanity, man is good at killing thus he is asked to go to their world and kill big nasty god, he kills him good then good guy is actually bad guy and prison man must kill him. Game ends-There are a few bugs, nothing massive though. For example if you lock onto a certain bosses head during a certain phase the camera clips through the floor and you can see nothing. Theres a couple sound bugs where a sound stays stuck on and audiologs sometimes have no audio but saving and restarting the game solves these issues and if you want a bity of world building you can acess the audio logs through a menu.-New game + and ++ are very limited, in NG+ theres a few new trinkets and 1 set of armor for a light armor user but not medium and heavy. That really iritated me at first but the final armors for medium and heavy look so good I stopped caring. But this is important to a lot of people and I totally understand that so be prepared for enemies to scale, a few more audio logs but no new weapons. All you unlock is a 2nd spell tree by entering NG+ and the 3rd and final one on NG++-The DLC is pretty rubbish, the main one is unlocked later into the game and gives maybe an hour of content your first playthrough but soon as you know the puzzles thats dropped down to 20mins max. The rest are weapon and armor which all look great (especially the armor) but they are starting gear and give you a tiny edge at the begining but thats it since they are soon replaced. The heavy armor is obsolete in about 10mins for example.-This is a tiny issue but I will put it anyway. The jumping is a bit crap. Theres an element of playforming in the game to reach chests with armor or hidden places etc and when you land you always do this long exagerated roll which more often than not causes you to roll off the other side of where you were jumping. But you dont need to do it often.ConclusionThis game really is a diamond in the rough, it was plagued by bugs at the start which ruined its reputation. 99% of those have been fixed. I pre ordered this game and stuck it out for 1 playthrough and loved it. I decided to reinstall it a week ago and havent put it down since. This game is, in my eyes, a masterpiece. This is obviously my opinion but hopefully thats an indication of how good this game really is. There are a lot of people that expected this game to be something different when they picked it up, hack n slash or a standard rpg etc. They were disapointed with that and gave the game a bad review because they didnt do the research or were terrible at the combat system because they were used to a fast paced Dark souls style. This game was marketed as being very similar to Dark souls, which it isnt. The game can be hard but not as hard as higher NG+ cycles in Dark souls games. All in all this game is an incredibly rewarding experience, and for £15 its a bargin. One full playthrough of full exporation will be a solid 40 hours of enjoyment. Thanks for reading guys and I hope you decide to give this gem a try. Any questions leave a comment etc il be happy to answer them.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Ok so lets jus say this, if you like dark souls you will enjoy the mechanics in the game as they feel very much the same. And if you dislike the punishment and difficulty of dark souls then this may be a better fit fot your likes. The good: 1) It is very beutifull, from the landscapes to the design you can tell that a lot of effort was put into this. 2) The way the weapons feel are simply natural, a hammer is slugish yet you feel the power that goes with every strike yet a sword is fast and fluid. 3) There is tons of variety when it comes to the weapons. Now the bad: 1) The map is dissapointing, there is basically two distinct locations you travel to, the monastery and the Rhogar realm. 2) Some bosses are just crazy easy and boring, most are too alike and simply dont give you much satisfaction once they have been defeated (although there are some really cool ones who are rather difficult). 3) I have noticed in my computer that this game needs to "warm up" before it's ready to be played, when started the game suffers from low frames for a few minutes. Verdict: I simply loved the story (mind that a few characters are forgetable), all the hidden lore, and how this game uses dark souls mechanics to build its own world; besides a few drawbacks the game is fun and i cannot wait for the confirmed sequel, 8/10!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												I'll just say. For the first title of a new IP that is 100% a derivitive dark souls. it's great. There are some bugs and frustrations but no more than the bugs and frustrations with DS and DS2. My biggest complaint (which really is a matter of perspective) is that if you are thorough in your first playthrough there isnt any point to a second playthrough. But seriously, since when did only having 1 playthrough in a game automatically make it garbage? I honestly loved every minute of it start to finish and enjoyed it on my second playthrough as well (which i havent completed yet) because its just a lot of fun. Everything about the game feels stylish and polished. I'd recommend it and in fact have purchased it for several friends as gifts because i believe in the franchise so much!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Should you try this game? Yes. Is it like Dark Souls? Sort of. (TL;DR at the end)Before I start:Many people had problems with the performance, I started to play after patch 1.4 and everything was fine, no crashes, stable framerate.First of all the grapchics are great and the combat is pretty solid, animations look realistic but sometimes you can just stick close to an enemy and avoid getting hit. Regular enemies can get hard to kill because the window between their lowered guard is little, so if you have a greatsword you may have a hard time dealing with them.Game is also more forgiving in my opinion, if you are afraid of rolling you can go with a heavy armor that can absorb a lot of damage. The third boss got me becaus I was using Dark Souls techniques and tried rolling away but still getting hit, so I equiped the heaviest gear and tanked the boss and it actually worked.There are 10 bosses, some are hard some are easy especially if you figure out their attack pattern. But the world has a lot of hidden treasures that you can try and find.If you manage to beat all the bosses in the first attempt and not get stuck and lost for a long time you can complete the game in 10-12 hours.IN CONCLUSIONIf there is a sale on this game and you like Dark Souls type games, give it a go, I don't think you will regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Before I get into the good, I will shortly list the bad points, as there hasn't been too many. Firstly, the game lags unexpectedly in some places and has crashed a couple of times (One resulting in a pc restart, which I thought was odd), and secondly, when replaying the game, the fact that loot isn't randomized can get a little bit boring as you begin to know what is where. However, now that I have that out of the way, I can get onto the good points.This game is a great alternative if you want a game that plays like Dark Souls, but is a more western style Action-RPG. I love the armour and how bulky everything is, it reminded me, in a way, of the first fable games, with the ridiculously large hammers that you could wield! The classes are nicely varied, and the xp system (getting xp to a checkpoint and getting larger xp modifiers for surviving while holding a large amount of xp) was very satisfying, and felt rewarding when you go on a big monster massacre and actually come out of it alive.The bosses are all very varied, and if you bother to pick up some of the extra lore, such as audio-thingies, they can be interesting to learn about too! They are all challenging in their own ways and require a certain amount of tactics to beat them. The story line itself is nice, the lip syncing and voice acting was average, but I liked the fact that you have choices in conversations, some of them actually affecting the outcome of certain situations.Lords of the fallen - 9/10TL;DR - The game has some performance issues at the moment, and I feel spoilt by randomized loot in other games when I play this, but the armour it gives you is very chunky and makes your character look like a boss. Speaking of bosses, they are varied and fun to beat, the story is also pretty good so far!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I waited for this game ever since it was first announced. It looked great! Stunning visuals and it came at a time when I had just finished Dark Souls 2 and its dlc's so it was a great transition. I waited a couple of days after release before I got the game as I wanted to gauge the general feeling. I noticed that a lot of people were slagging the game off because it was "trying" to be dark souls. Being a genre defining game its understandable that any subsequent games in that genre will be compared but that doesnt give people right to slag it off just because it's not a good. Anyway, mini rant over. This game is very good. The graphics are stunning. At first I thought they were a littke blurry but I realised that it was just part of the art style. The combat is great. More aggressive than dark souls. Some of the regular enemies can be as difficult to get past as some bosses. In general, the game is relatively easy. There are a few hard spots that took a while to get that rhythm.  Nearly all the boss fights I finished on the first try with only 4 fights taking a couple more. The story was largely a mystery until halfway through and some if the characters seemed randomly placed. Quests were unmarked and there was even a point where I had managed to face the 5th boss before I had found the 4th. The magic was largely redundant. I only ever used one spell. Granted, I've only used the warrior spell tree so there could be others that would be useful. The magic gauntlet that is in the game seems just like an excuse to have something like a gun. Again, only one of the three modes seems remotely useful. The boss fights were fun, despite being easy. They did have an element of challenge to them to a small degree. They were well designed and imaginative in the play styles and methods of combat. I remember some people mentioning that they had lots of crashing, like every 15 mins. In the 17hrs or so of play at time of writing I've only ever had 3 crashes and all of them happened in the same place for the exact same reason. For some reason, the pc couldnt handle an exploding troll midget in this small area. If I lured them out it was fine. If I fought them in the area, boom, crash. Since then, no problems. Overall, I would give the game a solid 7/10.Pros;- Gorgeous graphics with a awesome setting- Well done combat with good balancing- The armour sets are badass- Bosses are inventive- Plenty of back story in the form of well done audio logsCons;- The story was good but the delivery could have been better. Often spent time wondering what was going on purely because of poor scripting. - Gaps in said story- Some boss battles too easy

												At first I was very dissapointed with this game(becouse of lags and crashes, and boring start of game), but after patches, I've managed to overcome first 1-2 hours of game and I've noticed that I really WANT to play this game(feeling that I have not experienced for long time). The disadvantages are: still quite poor optimization (few times I experienced lags and there still were 2 crashes for a single walkthrough) and shortness (the game is very short - about 6-8 hours for me).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I was waiting for this game for a long time and now that I have played it through 3 times I thought I could throw in a review. Though my computer couldn't handle it with full graphics but even on the lowest settings it surely looks good. I began as cleric brawler and loved the fighting mechanics from the start. First slow swings felt manly as they landed to the chest of an attacking rhogan breaking its will to fight me. As I proceeded from boss to another it felt great to find new weapons and at the beginning most of then were an upgrade. The weapons, shields and armors look unique and in my less humble opinion the designs of them are coolest thing I've seen in a while. Big plus for that! Level design is nice and places you go vary nicely but the need to go back to area visited before to get some items is always kinda frustrating. The boss fights were unique but way too easy. Only thing providing proper challenge was the last boss on my first run.First time it took me around 12 hours to beat the game and I missed most of the locked chest as I was brawling my butt around like an idiot. Second time I was deceptive rogue and it took about the same time as the first run but I found most of the secrets and third time I was again cleric with solace magic tree. It took me about 7 hours and found rest of the secrets. I felt that the game was way too short even though it was satisfying to play and I was left to weep for more.I enjoyed the story but most of the time I forgot to listen the lore items I found. They would have probably given me hints and told me what was going on in the monastery but I was kicking butt and taking names at the same time so I didn't listen.Aside from minor crashing (which seems to be fixed quite well after the patches) and little bugs I found this game to be solid 9/10 and the one missing point is because of the length.P.S. I haven't done Ng+ on any of my characters but I for what I have understood there is more items to be found.P.S.S. I did cleric twice because the achievement for way of the warrior/cleric/rogue seems to come more from the magic class taken and not for the choice of warrior/cleric/rogue. Odd but that's how It went.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Should you try this game? Yes. Is it like Dark Souls? Sort of. (TL;DR at the end)Before I start:Many people had problems with the performance, I started to play after patch 1.4 and everything was fine, no crashes, stable framerate.First of all the grapchics are great and the combat is pretty solid, animations look realistic but sometimes you can just stick close to an enemy and avoid getting hit. Regular enemies can get hard to kill because the window between their lowered guard is little, so if you have a greatsword you may have a hard time dealing with them.Game is also more forgiving in my opinion, if you are afraid of rolling you can go with a heavy armor that can absorb a lot of damage. The third boss got me becaus I was using Dark Souls techniques and tried rolling away but still getting hit, so I equiped the heaviest gear and tanked the boss and it actually worked.There are 10 bosses, some are hard some are easy especially if you figure out their attack pattern. But the world has a lot of hidden treasures that you can try and find.If you manage to beat all the bosses in the first attempt and not get stuck and lost for a long time you can complete the game in 10-12 hours.IN CONCLUSIONIf there is a sale on this game and you like Dark Souls type games, give it a go, I don't think you will regret it.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Lords of the Fallen is a gritty, hack n slashy rpg experience. Very polished graphics although I've encountered a few mistakes graphically as well. Make sure your graphics card drivers are updated, because there are some stabillity issues with this game.The fighting mechanics feel a tad clunky at times but the 1 hit kill moves from behind look pretty awesome and the game is quite a challenge in comparison to other games in the genre. Lot of ducking and weaving is needed. The enemies and surroundings are well designed and look overall awesome. Although snowy bush copy paste # 17489776397 also occurs overall it's fun to explore in this game. I like the surroundings a lot. You can see a lot of details went into the painting of the textures for walls and rocks.What can I say, this game has my kind of "50 shades of grey" and for the non cutesy gritty loving hack n slash rpg fans out there this is a must.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												I bought this game as a Dark Souls for beginners but I played as a rogue, later to find out this was the hardest class. Got oneshot by pretty much everything during the first half of the game, so I was not disappointed by the lack of challenge. I enjoyed this game a lot, and would recommend it. Pros:- Beautiful game- Great bosses (most of the time)- Lots of different weapons- Decent lifespan- Enjoyable contentCons: - The story is terrible. But who cares?- Level design didn't seem very clear to me, and the fact that every area adjoins each other wasn't helping. At all. - Broken power curve. Basically, I sucked big time during the first half of the game, then I got overpowered in the latter part. But I have to admit I enjoyed it. I might not have finished the game if I'd kept on being oneshot by everything during 30 hours.- Some bosses don't have any interesting movesets and end up being not much of a challenge. I spent more time figuring out a way to deal efficiently with rhogar knights than to beat bosses like Champion and Protector...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												The comparison of LOTF vs DS (Darksouls) is a fair one.There are many differences, but game control is similar.LOTF is less time consuming to play through. I made it through the game in less than 6 hours, something I couldn't have come close to doing with out many more hours of practice on DS games.LOTF is not nearly as difficult, nor is it as re-playable as DS.However, I had fun with the game and the story. I just couldn't buy into it as deep as I would have had if I played LOTF before DS. LOTF is a good alternative for people who like the melee/spell caster games with a medium-ish difficulty (at the harder settings). It has a decent story and some reasons to explore, but not a lot of reward to do the exploration.I would still say that if you have some time and the money, it wouldn't be a bad experience. Likely, you would enjoy it.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												So... It's a Dark Souls clone. There is no denying that. But... Dark Souls is a great game... and this clone of it is pretty good too! The enemies are less varied than Dark Souls and the bosses are more forgettable, but the amount of fun to be had is on par with Dark Souls.I'm sure some people will say it's a bad game just because FromSoftware didn't make it, but they're wrong. It's a fun experience, unless you don't like dying a lot and have problems timing attacks with precision.There is a lot of narrative in this game. Since there is no character creation, you just play as Harkyn. Harkyn has conversations with people. So the game doesn't feel as bleak as Dark Souls (keep in mind when I call Dark Souls bleak, that's a good thing, but it doesn't mean Lords of the Fallen is bad, it just feels different), and it's obvious what you are supposed to be doing. There's spells in  the game too, but I didn't use them so I can't really speak as to how fun it is to use them.Overall I highly recommend. It's a fun and challenging experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Lords of the Fallen is a beautiful game that feels like a mix between the gameplay of Dark Souls, the loot from Darksiders and the aestetics from a Blizzard game. The movement and the combat feels very responsive and the flow is very natural with each of your swings with your weapon. This game does a good job at showing off great animation, especially when you land your blows on the enemies and stagger them. The controls are easy to learn, though you can't re-bind your keys for either keyboard or controller. There are how ever, two control settings from which you can select; if the original controler scheme should not meet your standards. The game does a good job at delivering the story to you and it doesn't forcefully do so either. Every dialogue is skippable, should the story not meet your fancy. Unfortunately, the gameplay isn't very challenging and there are no settings to change the difficulity. The video options are also very lacking and should you not use an Nvidia Video Card (Graphic Card) you won't be very pleased that the game has a running PhysX that you can't toggle on and off; Making the game run awfully bad for those that do not have support for PhysX. The camera can be a bit off from time to time, but the game generally does a good job at making sure you know what's going on around you.I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys a third person fantasy-based RPG. If you're into Dark Souls, you might want to have a look at the game for a casual playthrough if anything.As of the time I'm writing this review, I'm 6 hours into the game and have not yet died a single time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25
												Being an somewhat of a fan of the Souls franchise, I've heard a lot of things about this game, most of them, as I've found out, untrue. Lords of The Fallen (further only as LoTF) gets a lot and I mean a LOT of flak for, copying dark souls, being way too hard/way too easy/way too clunky. Well I went into it expecting what it is, clunky souls and boy was I surprised. So let's get a few things straight.Combat - It's slow, really slow, even one handed weapons take longer than your average two-hander in dark souls, that's not even mentioning the really big stuff, this game loves its big and metal things, so much so that some weapons are so heavy in fact, you can't even use them one handed, not even with proper stats, now that's a weapon. So for you guys out there who breezed through dark souls via R1 spams, you are not going to have a lot of fun here. Certain enemies demand certain tactics, hell there is an enemy that will smash you into the ground over and over again until you learn how to parry, really loved that one. Speaking of which, yes, your usual suspects of light/heavy attacks are here with your backstabs and parries, giving the combat a nice depth, really forcing you to learn how to fight your enemies and see the openings.Theme - As mentioned above, this game goes in big, hard and metal. You can wear outrageous amounts of armour and you will be moving at the speed of snails and fat roll everywhere, BUT, you can clear the game just as well doing that as if you go for light armor and dodge everything. I've really felt powerful being able to shake off big hits as minor bother. So unlike in any other souls-like game, here, heavy armor is actually a legitimate choice and a welcome one at that, I've had unbelievable amounts of fun crushing through enemies with a 2 handed axe, effectively making some of them into a wet spot on the floor.Story - Honestly, not the strongest point, you can take it or leave it, there is plenty to know about the world and how it came to be if you choose to hunt for audio bits and bops or you can ignore them and skip through most of it, so unfortunately this one might be one of the weaknesses. It doesn't have that "I wanna know more" pull to it, but is still enjoyable enough as short as it is.Performance - Oh yeah, this one...yeah... clunky is the best I could put it, frame rate drops on a fairly powerful rig for today's standards, texture pop-in, few enemies joining the space program and rocketing off into space, oddly stiff and stood upright weapons, leading to more than a few morning wood jokes, you get the idea, it's not gamebreaking, but it's not quite what it should be.Overall, I'd say this game is definitely worth 20 bucks, it's difficult, but fun as it is meant to be. I can see myself clearing it a few more times to see all the secrets and find all the armor sets and challenges. So if you enjoy yourself a bit of challenge yourself, but not so much of it to be overwhelming and want to feel like a buldozer let loose in a cardboard box this might just be the game you might enjoy.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12
												A lot of negative reviews come from frustration of players. This is true in this game. You die a lot, more so than compared to Dark Souls. Yes the comparison is always there, but this game has its unique points to differentiate from Souls and Bloodborn series. First of, Lords of the Fallen has solid and somewhat compact storyline. Second, the map itself is not that big after you finish your first playthrough. Lastly, this is more of a story driven RPG game, you will be appreciated at the end with the choices you made throughout the game.Now on the bad points of the game, the camera system is frustrating. I don't know how many times I've died just because I cannot face to the enemy or my character somehow facing the wall while wildly swing sword. This happens mostly in narrow corridor and dungeon, so most open area fights are no problem. Next on the voice acting. For a story driven game, I would expect some form of good voice acting. But alas, the main character voice is so dry, I don't know if he is speaking just making grunts. Lastly, the game punishes you for choosing speed focus characters. If you are planning to play Rouge and sneak up enemy from behind, just forget about it. The game wants you to be heavy fat guy with shield on and walk slowly like obese person.Overall, this game is not perfect but don't expect to be like Souls series or Bloodborn. Don't expect RPG like Skyrim or Dragon Age either. This game is really for niche audiences. Most will definitely hate it coz you die in the first two fights of the game. Just like Dark Souls series, if you look past all these negative points, at the end the experience is rewarding and I, myself enjoyed it. But this is not the game that I will come back to replay from time to time.

												The first boss isnt very good, and by that i dont mean it is a bod boss, cause it is fun, it just doesnt do a good job of explaining how further bosses play out very well, and is by far the hardest boss till after the graveyard. the beginig of the game kinda sucks but that is just as you are learning how the mechanics work, like no iframes hitting a blocking enemy is basically getting hit (wich makes sense as you can do it to enemys) and turtles suck. after that its pretty good looks good and has bad characters who are only there for... reasons. pick it up if you want to frustrate yourself till you get the hang of the controlls and to look at all of the pretty scenery at the two locations of the game: snowy castles. i love snow areas but when i step through a portal to basically the demon realm i would rather not step out of a snowy castle just to end up at another snowy castle. end verdict: Its ok i guess, wait for it to be on sale, and the dlc is better.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												 will start off with several facts: I am running a the followin spec: Core i5-3470 CPU8 GB corsair vengeanceAsus GTX760 2GB Direct ♥♥ II OC The game hasn't crashed at all on High settings at 1080p on my 42" tv playing with a xbox controller. The game is really fun, I have only Dark Souls II experience in this sort of game and in my opinion DS2 was really clunky and for my taste very vague and didn't enjoy it a lot, finished it and didn't touch it again.I have clocked in 30 hours in Lords and I have enjoyed every minute - the relatively streamlined exploraion is the ONLY fault I have with the game. The combat is fine, it is really methodical and actually punishes roll and hitting from behind that every1 loved in DS. The XP system is top notch - high risk / high rewards and if you don't overjump your skill you WILL find your perfect balance.Boss fights are a bit too straight forward. Let me explain they are far from easy but anyone that applies some patience and methodical movement will beat every boss (for now haven't finished the game so can't talk 100% yet) in 2-4 tries. In my experience DS2 is "hard" mostly because of the extreme amount of damage the bosses do, the mechanics GENERALLY bored me. Here you got decent mechanics and the bosses do more damage than normal but not in the extreme. I'm thinking NG+ will be a different animal unless you outlevel it like I did without farming just exploring EVERYTHING on normal! I am exploring everything possible and every bonus stage and most deaths I account to judgement and lack of skill at that moment rather than controls or mechanics(those are SPOT on).Graphics - jaw dropping even on high, next week my GTX980 will arrive and I will add a comment about the very high setting. Sound design is really good and everything is fleshed out very well, the weapon to shield clunk is sooooooo good. All in all I am loving the game and will defo replay it, DS2 was my kind of gameplay my the japanese influence is just not my taste, also the extremely vague story was just blah. My thoughts on the two major criticisms the game is getting:Stability - I guess it is very personal because the game is stable and I am getting constant fps around the 40-60 mark which is great for the graphics, and SOME very rare 35s which disappear and I cannot replicate.Difficulty - for me the game is just as hards as DS DS players are alreay used to the combat style so it will seem easier to them.
