number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												A technically inferior, but shinier Dark Souls.I'll put it simply, the game's fun, and it looks great, but there's a few things that irritate me and not in the way that Dark Souls irritates you because it's difficult.This game is difficult because of the choices made in some game mechanics, as well as small bugs that turn into big problems. One such bug is enemies turning around to instantly face you if you manage to flank them, completely negating the tactic in the first place. I'm talking about the no-animation, teleport-y kind of turning around, allowing them to immediately attack you again without giving you an opening to attack them without being hit yourself.It's also too easy to get stunlocked to death by groups of enemies. Sure, it's more "realistic" if one knock to the ground can immediately mean your death due to multiple enemies being able to still attack/hurt you when you're in a helpless position, but it's not at all fun, or indeed fair. If you die in Dark Souls, you know it's your fault, and you know what you can do to prevent it from happening next time. Further to the point, if you get swarmed by a group, your first instinct would be to retreat and take them on in a more tactical sense, right? In LotF it only takes a nudge for you to get stunlocked enough to suddenly get surrounded, and then you're done for, as there are no i-frames when rolling.In LotF, you're forced to play tanky and take hits, as going the light route is simply a massive handicap, due to dodging not being as refined as in Dark Souls. So a lot of the time it's luck as to whether you're going to win a fight or not, or whether the enemy you're fighting is going to poise straight through your well-timed heavy and land you on your♥♥♥♥♥for a grizzly death. So a lot of the time you're relying on your health and defense in order to survive such things, and hopefully dole out more damage to them than they can to you. Despite this, I would recommend LotF, just don't expect to be able to play like you can in Dark Souls, and don't expect the kind of well-crafted mechanics or indeed interesting lore/characters that Dark Souls is known for. Play tanky, get mad when faced with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, have fun when not.

												I had never heard of this game, just bought it on impulse because it looked so good.  Best buy I've done all year, so far I've had 40+ hours of pure RPG action madness fun. The game has a very steep learning curve. and is damn hard in the start but once you master your character and understand the xp system & save system & weight system; it's fantastic.  Hope these guys make more.   I see some people complain about bugs, I haven't seen anything in 40+ hours playtime that I don't see in every other game out there.  Be prepared to die a lot the first 5-6 hours, be prepared to figure things out, nothing is explained properly and the manual is total crap so you need to try things or do research, it's just the way it is.  Take it as a challenge, don't whine about it.  Once you get proper control and figure out when to use what weapons, stances, etc you're gonna have a blast.Graphics 12/10Gameplay 9/10Sound ??/10  (spotify, find some manowar)Story -10.000.000/10 (but who gives a♥♥♥♥♥♥ really)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Don't let your decision wether to buy this game be influenced by the "Mixed" status of the user reviews. Most of the bad reviews are not actually about the game, they are rage reviews by people who experienced crashes and technical issues that have for the most part been solved in recent patches and will be addressed further in patches to come. I and many others can play this game without any problems. It's just that customers who are content with a product are much less likely to write a review about it than discontent ones. I just wanted to bring a little balance to that.The game is often accused of being a Dark Souls ripoff. That's not entirely false, but it doesn't really cover what this game is. Lords of the Fallens approach to combat is basically copied from Dark Souls with a few subtle differences you will only notice after playing for a while ... and why not? Hardly any game did combat as good as Dark Souls did. And that's where the similarities end. The level design, the approach to character progression and a few other things, like UI and so forth, all that is new in Lords of the Fallen. It's still inspired by other games, like Darksiders, but most games we love build on concepts other games have introduced in the past, don't they?Another famous argument against this game: "It is too slow". In fact, it's not that much slower than Dark Souls. People just tend to start the game in the heavy tanking warrior kind of starting gear, which is full plate armor, and they think that's the pace of the game. As a rogue you can roll and sprint and jump all over the place in absolutely sufficient speed, believe me.The most important thing to me is that Lords of the Fallen is fun to play! It's modern in all the parts, where being old school doesn't bring any benefit: presentation, controls, interface ... but it's old school wherever it's important: the challenge, telling you only the basics and letting you figure out the rest, lots of secrets! Yes, it has a few design flaws: there's one particular move in the shield + one-handed moveset that allows for exploitation so that most enemies can be beaten effortlessly. That's Something the developers definitely have to nerf in a future patch. Boss fights are not as varied as in Darksiders or Dark Souls, though still fun an challenging they feel somewhat repetitive. Also there are neither the dramatic dialogues Darksiders had nor the intriguing lore of Lordran (Dark Souls), but what people tend to forget to mention in reviews is how much fun they had playing: I had tons of it.Objectively I have to admit that this is inferior to both Dark Souls and Darksiders, but in fact I feel much more like playing Lords of the Fallen most of the time, than I feel like playing Dark Souls. Lords gives the same challenges and emotional rewards for beating them without being as overwhelming. This game is pretty good at tying you to the computer: "Gotta get back my experience points after dying", "gotta beat this boss", "gotta hunt loot Diablo-style", "gotta find the secret way to this area over there", "gotta find the key to this door/chest", "gotta grind me a new level up", "oh I heard I get a unique armor/weapon when I do this while fighting that enemy", and so forth. It does this no worse that Dark Souls or Darksiders and I got to say it looks better while doing it.Important info: Although the combat works much better with mouse and keyboard than in any Dark Souls game, you're still much better off with a gamepad. In fact you can add an XBox 360 controller to the requirement list.So TL;DR, this is my thumbs up for a great, challenging Action-RPG that is best described as a blend of Dark Souls and Darksiders, with minor flaws but lots of fun to be had.Goodbye.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Lords of the Fallen is the first "Souls game" I ever finished and I do not regret it one bit.It’s a bit more forgiving than the Souls games and perhaps the balance is not as immaculate at different stages of the game, but it makes up for by the share amount of fun it brings to the table and by the much lighter atmosphere is has.The game world has more colours in it, the story telling is more straight forward and level design I found enjoyable although there were a few moments where I briefly felt lost and missed a map.I enjoyed looking for the secret areas in the game, the crafting of weapons, the reward system for not saving. What I wold have liked to see in the game is a little more enemy variety in terms of tactics. Both for the regular baddies and for bosses as half way through the game I found myself just jump-bashing most enemies which got a little repetitive despite being quite fun. The mages provided a little variety (especially spirits) causing me to actually swap weapons but that was basically it. The bosses played out pretty much  similarly as well, just wait for the boss to pull off an attack with the longest cool down and strike him a few times and then retreat (repeat until dead). So little adjustments there would come a long way.The story as such is pretty straight forward with a few alternative endings. I did like the ending but would have liked to see some more meaningful choices in the game and reflections of those choices in the end. But for an action RPG this is fine.In total, I find the low metascores quite unjust. It’s a very fun title with enjoyable gameplay and solid mechanics. The soundtrack is excellent and the graphics are fabulous.In my book, this game is 80/100

Lords of the Fallens approach to combat is basically copied from Dark Souls with a few subtle differences you will only notice after playing for a while ... and why not? Hardly any game did combat as good as Dark Souls did. And that's where the similarities end. The level design, the approach to character progression and a few other things, like UI and so forth, all that is new in Lords of the Fallen. It's still inspired by other games, like Darksiders, but most games we love build on concepts other games have introduced in the past, don't they?Another famous argument against this game: "It is too slow". In fact, it's not that much slower than Dark Souls. People just tend to start the game in the heavy tanking warrior kind of starting gear, which is full plate armor, and they think that's the pace of the game. As a rogue you can roll and sprint and jump all over the place in absolutely sufficient speed, believe me.The most important thing to me is that Lords of the Fallen is fun to play! It's modern in all the parts, where being old school doesn't bring any benefit: presentation, controls, interface ... but it's old school wherever it's important: the challenge, telling you only the basics and letting you figure out the rest, lots of secrets! Yes, it has a few design flaws: there's one particular move in the shield + one-handed moveset that allows for exploitation so that most enemies can be beaten effortlessly. That's Something the developers definitely have to nerf in a future patch. Boss fights are not as varied as in Darksiders or Dark Souls, though still fun an challenging they feel somewhat repetitive. Also there are neither the dramatic dialogues Darksiders had nor the intriguing lore of Lordran (Dark Souls), but what people tend to forget to mention in reviews is how much fun they had playing: I had tons of it.Objectively I have to admit that this is inferior to both Dark Souls and Darksiders, but in fact I feel much more like playing Lords of the Fallen most of the time, than I feel like playing Dark Souls. Lords gives the same challenges and emotional rewards for beating them without being as overwhelming. This game is pretty good at tying you to the computer: "Gotta get back my experience points after dying", "gotta beat this boss", "gotta hunt loot Diablo-style", "gotta find the secret way to this area over there", "gotta find the key to this door/chest", "gotta grind me a new level up", "oh I heard I get a unique armor/weapon when I do this while fighting that enemy", and so forth. It does this no worse that Dark Souls or Darksiders and I got to say it looks better while doing it.Important info: Although the combat works much better with mouse and keyboard than in any Dark Souls game, you're still much better off with a gamepad. In fact you can add an XBox 360 controller to the requirement list.So TL;DR, this is my thumbs up for a great, challenging Action-RPG that is best described as a blend of Dark Souls and Darksiders, with minor flaws but lots of fun to be had.Goodbye.

content:
Posted: March 12
												A lot of negative reviews come from frustration of players. This is true in this game. You die a lot, more so than compared to Dark Souls. Yes the comparison is always there, but this game has its unique points to differentiate from Souls and Bloodborn series. First of, Lords of the Fallen has solid and somewhat compact storyline. Second, the map itself is not that big after you finish your first playthrough. Lastly, this is more of a story driven RPG game, you will be appreciated at the end with the choices you made throughout the game.Now on the bad points of the game, the camera system is frustrating. I don't know how many times I've died just because I cannot face to the enemy or my character somehow facing the wall while wildly swing sword. This happens mostly in narrow corridor and dungeon, so most open area fights are no problem. Next on the voice acting. For a story driven game, I would expect some form of good voice acting. But alas, the main character voice is so dry, I don't know if he is speaking just making grunts. Lastly, the game punishes you for choosing speed focus characters. If you are planning to play Rouge and sneak up enemy from behind, just forget about it. The game wants you to be heavy fat guy with shield on and walk slowly like obese person.Overall, this game is not perfect but don't expect to be like Souls series or Bloodborn. Don't expect RPG like Skyrim or Dragon Age either. This game is really for niche audiences. Most will definitely hate it coz you die in the first two fights of the game. Just like Dark Souls series, if you look past all these negative points, at the end the experience is rewarding and I, myself enjoyed it. But this is not the game that I will come back to replay from time to time.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												*In Progress Review*Lords of the Fallen, so far, has provided me with a more accessible version of Dark Soul's famously hard gameplay.  To be fair to each game, I will try to keep comparisons to a minimum, and to judge the game by its own merits and issues.  To be concise I will divide this review into two sections.  Let me begin with things I enjoy about it:- Lords does do one or two things that, personally, I think they did better than Dark Souls.  The enemy AI is more varied and a bit more defensive.  Their move sets tend to control your character's motions and mechanics, as opposed to just hurting you.  - I like the setting of Lords of the Fallen.  Post-apocalyptic fantasy is one of my favorites, as it's a combination of two genres I really enjoy.  - Lords also is a very pretty game, I really like the design and aesthetics of it.  Mostly since I enjoy gothic stylings in my games, and Lords delivers that much in spades.  From Harkyn's armor, to the enemy designs, to the locales; all of it just drips dark fantasy.- Lords is challenging without being too challenging, you won't die as much in Lords as you would in a Dark Souls.  If you keep getting killed generally it means you just should not be wherever you are yet.  The game is gated by "Meat Walls" as opposed to obstructions, for instance locked doors.  Though those do occur as well.- Lords has an incredible inertia to the combat.  The weapons feel hefty, the strikes of the enemies feel powerful.  At times Lords is on-point with the combat, and you feel awesome about the results of an encounter.  The timing-based nature of combat is also a welcome adition.Now to things I'm not as fond of:- Lords needs a bit of polish, especially in just fine tuning the combat.  Occasionally you'll have a strike that should have hit, but did not.  This is just a minor sort of thing, and doesn't detract too much from the overall experience.- The lore in Lords is very flimsy.  Its there, and what's there is good, it just doesn't feel like there is enough of it.  The world is more sketched out than fleshed out.  However; the story is serviceable, and is good compared to a wide berth of games.- It seems that the Strength build is the most viable one, or at least the most easily accessible.  I'm about halfway through on a Strength run, and I dipped my toes in as a Dexterity build.  It didn't seem to be as effective.  However; I will not say any absolutes on this point, since I plan on going through the game again with a different build to test it out.Overall I recommend this game if Dark Souls caught your interest, but you can't get past the difficulty.  However; after playing through this, I recommend you give Dark Souls a try as well.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Lords of the Fallen is very similar to Dark Souls.I like all of the differences to Dark Souls and Lords of the Fallen is what I hoped Dark Souls 2 to be.The combat favors blocking more than dodging, though if you're wearing the heaviest armor, fighting with 2 handed weapons and without a shield is quite viable.The character classes and stats are a manageable amount. You can pick between Warrior, Rogue and Cleric twice, once for the spells and once for the starting equipment and the combination of both determines the starting attribute points.The graphics are top notch, but it also sometimes drops down to 30fps (which max for Dark Souls btw).The art style has similarities to Darksiders, though it looks less clunky and more refined. The Warrior's heavy armor sets look bamf. The animations are very fluid.If you kill enemies and don't bank your souls, you get an XP and loot chance multiplier (capped at 2.00x).The levels are well designed so that while you traverse them the first time, you're doing loops and unlocking shortcuts and when you're done, going through a zone is very quick, so that there's no need for quicktravel. Half of the levels are very clear, but the other can be somewhat confusing, especially Catacombs etc.

												Honestly I'm really enjoying this game, I'm running on windows 10, with a 970 and I haven't had a crash or even a serious frame drop in the 14 hours I've played thus far.As far as the game play goes, at the start of the game, its rough, like seriously rough, the combat timing is different than what you would think, and not at the same fluidity as other games like it, but ones you get a feel and sense for it, realize that your actions have to be quick, but very calculated. I also think the graphics are really solid, If you get it for $6 USD (Halloween Sale), go for it, but I wouldn't be mad paying $20 for it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												Note, that this is not a glowing recommendation. Very far from it. But Lords of the Fallen is a pretty interesting attempt at creating an aRPG that follows on the formula of Dark Souls, but with a more Enclave and Blade of Darkness feel to it. Where it succeeds it does things very well, where it fails it fails pretty hard.A lot of mechanics and even controls work pretty close to how they do in Souls series, but Lords of the Fallen is a lot more restrictive in ways you develop your character and how you play. While the game differentiates three classes, in actuality they seem to work more like variations on a warrior class - one that focuses just on pure brute force, one that focuses more on quick moves and one that focuses on mixing magic and weapons. There's only one ranged weapon you get and it can get elemental damage and the "spells" work more like active skills, usual to aRPGs. Those spells are quite similar between classes and if you play the New Game+ and then ++ you will be able to get all the class-specific magic spells, if you want.What feels most off about the entire game is, probably, that the game feels much more script/premade animations heavy, than Souls games and the classic Blade of Darkness. Enemies track you with absolutely perfect precision, even when they run around like crazy, unless they are in the attack animation, they can get into block or attack animations (that hit/block) even sometimes right after standing with their back turned to you (I once got hit by a projectile of an enemy that was looking in the opposite direction and lots of ranged enemies will turn and shoot without missing a beat and always hit) and most projectiles track you insanely well. All of those CAN be avoided in most cases, but they still look and feel like player input reading AI perfect creations, rather than creatures who exist in the game's virtual world. Which is very unlike Souls games, where enemies feel much more "flawed" in a natural way - like fighting another player, not a computer. Another huge issue of the enemies in the game is that lots of them sit in full defense mode most of the time, requiring you to wait till you can backstab or parry/riposte them, with enemies 100% controlling the rhythm of the fight. Which, more often than not, actually feels boring, because enemies rarely feel unpredictable.And the predictability even goes with the bosses. You don't learn to counter their different moves that they can mix in various ways. With most bosses, you learn one, yes ONE, pattern they will always follow, slowly but surely chipping at their health and doing the same thing over and over until they finally die. There are exceptions, but usually bosses are more frustrating and boring than any fun.What about the world and the story? The design of the levels (and there are distinct "levels" in the game with loading in-between, but you can go back and forth) looks good, as does the art design of most of the game, but they are actually rather boring. Especially when you realise, that even if you do explore them early and completely you will still need to redo that again and again after, because some things will just appear or change, sometimes without rhyme or reason, in them. You found a locked door behind which is just one square room with a chest and can't open the door? You will be able to get the key to it only by the end of the game. Even if you don't even need to go back there, even if the item you get isn't really worth it, there's no story reasons behind it - it's just that. And story itself is, actually, pretty dreadful and told via voice acting that ranges from passable to pretty bad. Which is sad - game actually has some potential to tell some interesting and variable stories and the NG mechanic even seems to hint that maybe something similar to Eternal Darkness replayability. But nothing like this is here and even those variables that can change the ending sometimes glitch out.Lords of the Fallen has some good ideas, it's actually rather fun to play, but it's questionable decisions keep annoying you and by the end part of the game, they can build up so you might want to drop it. Sadly, there might not be a sequel that actually improves on the game's ideas, because this was a pretty good first try.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												Lords of the fallen is a great game if you like harder arpgs where your attacks are a commitment, and timing is important. Lords of the fallen is trying to make an entry into the same genre as Dark Souls, with a lot of similarities, but also some cool differences.I have more than 600 hours in Dark souls 1 and 2. Lords of the Fallen has fun bosses, weapons, armor, and the labyrinth DLC adds a fun puzzle. As a dark souls 1 and 2 onebro, I actually think doing a level 10 LOTF run would be harder, if you are worried it will be too easy of a game, Please support this game when it is on sale, and allow for the rest of the world to enter the HCARPG market without a unwarranted fear of failure. EDIT: I did a lvl 10 run, and it was challenging, but not as much as I thought, but still very fun.Pros+ Great graphics+ Different builds play and feel different, add replayability+ You feel like a badass, but a mortal badass+ Combat is always fair, you should only die to an enemy once if you can learn.+ Bosses have interesting mechanics (not all but most)Cons- lots of people complain of crashes (not me)- World is large, and well made, but only consists of a few kinds of environments- Some combat is forced in small corridors and the camera makes this hard to see what you are doing (only a couple spots)- No multiplayer at all (Dark souls multiplayer is wierd, someone make a co-op game like this please)- Story has a canned ending with a narrator telling very similar stories. (Still better than ME3 ending)- Magic is basically a cannon with only a few good moves you can use to cheese the gameTLDR;  Dark Soulslike. Good game, but not for everyone.  Give it a chance if you like that kind of combat.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												I have this game a while and am only getting to play it now. I got it on bundlestars I think pretty cheap. A game having so many negative reviews usually pushes it down the list a bit. I gave it a go and it was okay but not great, but sometimes you have to stick at it and not get frustrated and by the time I got to the first boss I was really getting into it.What I've learnt is that the standard warrior tank class sucks because it's slow and boring to play. For my second game I rolled a rogue and the game was suddenly so much better. It's a much faster and slicker way to play the game. Also you need to get as much xp as possible gathered up early on as it makes things a little easier especially as a rogue. You are going to need play it for a while to settle in then start again when you know what you're doing so you have less chance of dying so you can build xp up.Some say this game is like Dark Souls and some say not. After completing Dark Souls 3 I think they are the same type of game and I would make comparisons between the two. I didnt really play Dark Souls 1 & 2 so much though.I feel a bit for the devs of this game with all negativity surrounding it because it's actually very good and very well done.Anyway, in my opinion this game is definitely worth playing. The graphics are great, the fights are satisfying, the enimies have a great look and design, there is plenty to do and the boss fights are good. To improve things I'd like to see things explained a bit better like a training mode or something that goes a bit deeper than the tutorial at the very start. Also, another couple of classes to choose from would be great as I honestly think the fun drops drastically playing anything other than the rogue.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												first and foremost if you want to play the genre but arnt ready for dark souls this is a good starting place. It has all the elements of the dark souls series except ranged weapons, which in my opinion was good as range often made dark souls much easier, so this is kind of forced melee learning if you arnt used to it. this game is as advertised, its an easier dark souls game. This game also simplifies a lot of the dark souls non-combat mechanics such as weapons and armors dont get upgrades, but instead they have runes that can be unsocketed and resocketed as many times as you want. experience is also simplified as  you can dump all your xp at save points so that you dont drop it on death. now for my negatives about it... the game itself crashed on me 5 times, causing me to redo things (such as bosses). almost all of the bosses had some gimmick that you needed to learn in order to beat them making bosses and the occasional ledge the only ways i died. after i finished the game i looked at how other people beat some of those bosses, and apparently i missed 75% of the health potions in the game(and i still beat the game without dying more than twice to the same boss). due to gimmicks there were a few bosses that didnt feel like bosses, but instead just enemies with extra health. this game is short, if i didnt have to redo parts due to crashes my playthrough would have been about 10 hours, however if you are new the the genre this could be much longer. i also have a few issues with the combat, mainly about shields. In the souls series you can attack immediately after a block, and enemies follow the same rules as the player. In this game however there is a lag between blocking and attacking, but the enemies dont follow this rule leading to shield enemies blocking your attacks then immediately attacking you back. In dark souls 2 they addressed this problem by replacing the kick with a shield break attack, however even though this game is mechanically similar to dark souls they didnt add it in. Due to all the sheild enemies and the sheild mechanics not working the same for the player i ended up just 2 handing  weapons with lots of poise. This poise allowed me to take a hit or two while i bashed on their shield a few times causing them to recoil which allowed me to actually hit them. I didnt do any backtracking or farming, nor did i look anything up, and i say this because early on i felt like my weapons were way too weak. finding a good weapon really made a huge difference. i complain about this because you are supposed to have a choice with weapons. In dark souls weapons are a preference based on your attributes, but two weapons of the same type will do similar damage, however in this game i got a sword off the first boss and compared to the sword i ended with it dealt five times less damage. the weapons dont appear to be balanced off stats, but rather where you are in the game which allows enemies to scale poorly. the enemies in one area might die in one hit, while the enemies in another area might die in ten hits. the armors in the game also scaled weirdly as large jumps in poise and armor wernt matched with large jumps in weight. there were some medium armors that after being socketed were just better than heavy armor found in the same area. the game give you a gauntet to cast ranged shots at the cost of mana, but i found that after i got a ranged class spell i pretty much stopped using it as the class spell was just hands down better. lastly there were times that enemies attacked or shot through walls leading to taking extra that i wasnt expecting. i might play through this game again, but im going to wait a while and see if they fix the crashing bugs and some of the attacking through walls bugs. so if you havent bought this game yet, but want to eventually, wait for it to go on sale at a later time, minimally after the crashing bugs have been fixed.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												I'm torn between recommending this game, or not.  Pros: - Incredibly gorgeous graphics.-Optimized amazingly.  I don't have the BEST graphics card, but I had it maxed out and stayed at 60fps all the time.-The armor and art style in this game are incredible.  Absolutely beautiful backdrops and awesome armor.-Pretty solid gameplay, Definitely provides one hell of a challenge.Cons:-The combat is annoying ONLY because you get animation locked during attacks.  Literally everytime I died or got hit is because once you click attack it literally takes like 3 seconds to swing a big axe.  In that time as you're winding up (unable to cancel and dodge) you will get WRECKED by npcs.- Difficulty.  Yes, this is a baby to Dark Souls and a lot of people REALLY enjoy the challenge, but dang... I got stuck on the fourth boss and just COULD NOT beat it because of the animation locks, inability to dodge etc and it just got to the point where it went from a great challenge, to screw it i don't care anymore.-LAUGHABLE voice acting/mouth animations.  Holy cow.  So cliche and it's like the game was made for the korean language or something because the mouth movements don't really match what's being said.In the end, if you want a really beautiful game and a dark souls type experience, this is a great game, but sometimes the animation locks alone made me rage quit.  Once you get to a certain level however, the game DOES get a bit easier, both due to better gear and finally learning attack patterns etc.  I definitely had fun even if the story and voice acting is a little funky.Bit of advice:  Cast your prayer where they attack your double and just kill things from behind them if you're stuck!

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												No, it's not as good as dark souls... But the reason you are here is because you like Dark Souls combat and progression. This implements something similar to Dark Souls 1's combat and progression system, but personally, I think they've actually done a better job with it. Also, I think the bosses I've encountered so far have been brilliantly designed.  They don't look interesting at first glance, but actually fighting each one takes a completely unique stratagy that you have to figure out as you go, which is really quite satisfying. So, if that is all you want, get it. HOWEVER, if you want the rish story and varied vistas of darksouls... well you're not going to get it. IMPORTANT NOTE: While you may be able to run this game at max settings using your current CPU and GPU, I'd take a look at your RAM.  This game eats up a lot of it.  I recommend 16GB for max settings and 8GB for min to avoid thrashing.  At 8GB on max graphics, it was clear my CPU and GPU were fine, but every now and then It would freeze for a bit.  which indicated that something was being transfered to/from the disk.  After checking the the tsk manager, I found that I was using nearly 7GB of the 8 on my computer.  Since then I have upgraded my RAM to 16GB, and it runs at a smooth 60fps now. The level design is pretty good, and IMO is better than Dark Souls 2's level design. However, level design is not the same as the visual design.  Some people don't like the visual design since there isn't a ton of definition, but I think it's fine that way.  It just means you can't play with your eye's closed. Overall, that is pretty much the theme of the game.  Stay alert.

content:
Posted: March 9
												 Lords of the Fallen is a weird one. It’s obvious that devs ware targeting fans of Souls games as their main demographic. While in reality the only people who could possibly fully enjoy this game are those who have played none of the Dark Souls games(yes, even DS2).I think this because, LotF copies almost every single gameplay mechanic from Souls games, which in itself isn’t bad, but unfortunately whenever a new mechanic was introduced all I was able to think about was “Hmmm, Dark Souls did this much better”. The only positive thing I can say about this game is that it made me appreciate how well designed the original Souls games actually are.For the first half of the game combat felt very clunky and slow. Some of it is because every weapon is slower than its equivalent in Dark Souls, probably because devs wanted every attack feel heavier and meatier, but I think that they overshot their goal and made it too slow. It just feels bad. Later on I adapted to LotF speed, but it still wasn’t a great gaming experience. LotF is also a perfect example that graphics aren’t everything. On the technical side this game has top notch visuals. All the effects are there - lighting, physics etc. The only place where it fails is the esthetic. It’s just soooooooooooo generic. Every piece of armor is covered spikes and random fantasy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Same goes for weapons. Devs probably just wanted every piece of gear look crazy and “cool”, but if there is no progression “boring” regular weapons to fantasy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t(and I don’t mean that in a negative way), then the “cool” stuff doesn't feel special. If everything is special nothing is. All enemies are forgettable as ♥♥♥♥, both visually and how they interact with you. So are the bosses. I will forget each and every one of them really quick.There’s no nuance to anything. There is also a story and music. Nothing much to say about those. Both are forgettable and uninteresting.LotF has a much more conventional story telling structure with a lot of dialogue and long cutscenes. But it’s just so generic and boring.If plan on playing this, but haven’t played any of the Dark Souls games, just play those.If you have played all of the Souls games and are desperate for more of the same... I don’t know. Maybe get this if it’s really cheap.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												Look, here's the long and short of it. I wanted to like it a lot, and I ended up dissapointed. It runs like bootybuns. It plays like Dark Souls but somehow, even more slow and grindy and tedious, and with none of the caveats or nuances that make games like that tough but fair and overall satisfying experiences. On top of this, in the beginning it's a semilinear sort of game, so if you wanna just grind the everloving crap out of your dude to make him awesome enough to not die as much, you gotta backtrack the same claustrophobic environments over and over for the handful of♥♥♥♥♥♥tier enemies to respawn.Are there fun moments? Yes.Is the game pretty? Sure, if you got the rig to run it.Story's acceptable, voice acting is pretty nice, and the overall quality of the presentation cannot be ignored, but under that thin veil of gold is the very definition of artificial difficulty- your reflexes here mean nothing as your character lethargically winds up- to late, your target swivels and wrecks your♥♥♥♥♥♥ Rinse and repeat. Boss battles are not a matter of skill. They're a matter of gear, strategy, and sheer dumb luck, and if that's your cup of tea by all means drink it- I myself tend to play games more often than not with this silly, antiquated idea of enjoying them while I do it.So if you like playing frustrating, tedious games that waste your time being the opposite of fun or entertaining, have at it. Not my thing, and if it's not your thing either, I can't reccomend this title to you in good faith.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												I'm always surprised when a solid game gets really awful reviews on steam, but I think in this case, it's mostly souls fans who aren't too pleased with this game taking elements from souls wholeheartedly without shame. Is it as good as Souls? No, but that doesn't mean I didn't have fun with it.+Great visuals+Good music+Combat is a watered down souls experience. Diluted souls is still excellent. If you're going to steal, steal from the best.+I actually liked the story, but I have a thing for janky euro stuff. The detailed ending was really cool, either way.-Game doesn't explain stats well at all. Took me a while to realize items I don't meet the requirements for? Yeah, it shows them as being trash. Then suddenly they're better. Bad system. It doesn't explain poise, it's hard to compare items, the rune system is awful, etc... A lot of the stat scaling is off, too.-Magic isn't explained well either. Prayer is actually "decoy". I'm still not sure what the point of stab is.-Enemies aren't explained well - By this I mean, enemies can be higher or lower level, or have totally different skills, but all use the same model. Wut? Seriously, you can think 'oh this combo will take this guy down' and it takes off 25% of his health instead. Because it's actually an elite.-Game world is very small and poorly laid out.Basically: It's a decent game direly missing a better translation and more polish.As an aside, the first boss is so poorly done in this game. He has a long combat string that you don't have enough stamina to handle if you're at all off balance, and you're supposed to wait for an opening - an opening that can be 30 seconds apart, and one shots you if you're too close to it. Derp. It's pretty miserable, but all the other bosses feel way more fair and less tedious. Also, if you do buy it, don't get the DLC unless it's in a good bundle.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Alright, granted, there are some issues with the game at the moment. Mine also presented itself with a nice "has stopped working" intro, but... After I had managed to fix that and actually start up the game, I fell in love with it. The dark fantasy setting, armor and weapon designs, everything fits in nicely, and the combat is something I hadn't even dared to hope for. You see, I tried to play Dark Souls and would have probably loved the game, if only the developers weren't so damn lazy and Dark Souls' PC port wasn't one of the worst I've had the "pleasure" of attempting to play.For all of you who would be scared that Lords of the Fallen is unplayable without a controller, take heart. It's working just great with a mouse and a keyboard, something Dark Souls hasn't come close to even with the "mouse and keyboard fix/mod" whatever. I can certainly see some inspiration and there's a strong similarity here, sure, but Lords of the Fallen wins it all for me. I won't budge when a developer forces me to use a method of control that isn't readily available nor preferable for most PC gamers.Alright, enough comparing the two games, let's get to what you can expect when you pick up Lords of the Fallen. Well, I'm not that far in myself yet, so I can't really divulge too much. But I can tell you I was fighting the first boss for an hour last night (refused to use potions) and I was having a great fun. There's just one attack that seemed to be dodgeable more based on luck that anything else, which kinda infuriated me, but other than that, the game seems fair when it comes to difficulty.The melee combat is what I personally enjoy most about the game, and it's one of the main reasons for which I bought it. Another being its grittiness and somewhat beautiful art design and dark fantasy setting. Every strike you make with your weapon carries weight. It doesn't reach further than the length of your weapon, if you swing a huge two-handed axe with one hand, it puts you off balance and leaves you open for a counter attack for a while, it's really all amazing. Especially it's a hell of a change for veterans of games like Darksiders, like myself. Controls get in your blood very quickly, plus they're all rebindable and there are even many possible presets.Complaints about the game? Well... the initial "has stopped working" aside, I haven't had a single crash so far in over 3 hours playtime (I do tend to get quite frequent crashes on Dragon Age: Inquisition and still I think it's a great game!). I agree it is a serious problem and the developers should work their butts off to fix it asap, but it doesn't diminish qualities of the game objectively. I didn't experience performance problems either, I'm running the game in 1920x1080 resolution (my wide screen's native), with pretty much everything set on high, anisotropic filtering at 8x I think, with V-Sync on, on my gaming rig with Intel i5-4430 CPU, 8 GB RAM, and nVidia GTX 760. The game might not be the best looking game ever, but I personally enjoy the graphics and animations very much. I really miss a map though, that's a bit of a nuisance.So the conclusion, knowing what I do now, I wouldn't have minded paying full price for the game to support the developer, because they've done some excellent work on this title, finally making this type of games available to die hard mouse/keyboard users to enjoy. If you have doubts, pick it up during a sale and give it a go.Rating:Graphics - 8Sounds - 9Music - 7Gameplay - 10Overall appeal - 10Final score - 8.8

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Very entertaining, yet hard rpg in the veign of the souls series. You take the role of 3 classes, and then 3 subclasses fighting challenging enemies either up close, or from afar with various spells. This is mostly a melee game though with very limited ranged fighting abilities. The bosses are not much harder than the regular mobs, meaning the regular mobs are challenging in their own right. I recommend this game if you are a fan of challenging action rpgs. Its also a must-get if you're a Souls Fan.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Not worth the time. The game, 2 months after launch still crashes and has obnoxious camera angles and sway. The performance is still all over the place. The game additionally is flawed, since you can charge and charge ANY enemy over and over and never take hits while doing almost significant damage. Ever. (Shield)*EVER*This is a dumbed down, buggy unpolished sloppy attempt at recreating a souls esque game. It is not a challenge for a souls player (beat ALL bosses first try, if it didn't crash getting there, and like Souls 2 the bosses were pretty repetitive.) The crashing wouldn't be such an issue if it saved in near realtime like souls, but NO. It is checkpoint based. You killed all those enemies and your game crashes? Oh, well do it. Again. And again. And..I had 1 crash per hour and PhysX was off. The performance, HOLY♥♥♥♥♥the performance. This game is running on 30-70fps ON A GTX 970 OCd at 1080p. Do you see a problem there? Top tier card, bottom tier performance. Hmmm. Combat is satisfying when the camera isn't jerking all around the place artificially. There is additionally a lot of routes you can take when deciding what weapons you will use.If the issues were gone, I would say the game is enjoyable if you are looking for a short (10 hour short) RPG with very little mechanics and decisions (completely linear besides exploring) easier souls like game. MEH quality game, AAA hype.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												Not a bad game, anyone who has played dark souls or demon souls will get a bit of fun from it, but may find it below what you would expect in terms of difficulty. For example I found myself killing a boss I was supposivbly meant to leave till later on.The gameplay is solid, giving you an idea of some of the things dark souls could have done, the perfect timing system with swings to reward not button mashing, the magic isnt intrusive on combat and isnt a automatic win and enemies are both fun and can be unpredicatble.The problems being no enemies are really memorable including bosses, a lot just involve either jus the dodge-hit strategy with little deviation from their 2-3 moves, or out cheaping them, for example on boss who will spam a fire attack you wont be able to dodge really all that well, so you have to spam fire resistance items to really win just in case you get hit once.The Rune system is interesting, but could use more work, its really hardly worth your time exept for the gauntlet.The characters are really needing work, I came out of dark souls and really felt terrible for some chars, even my enemies fates. In this I really couldnt care less about any of the supporting cast or the main character, there is really nothing worth noting about them, you have: "obvious villain", "The girl" and "The exposition spewer" Thats abut it from a few side quests and one knight who hates you for... some reason?Altogether, I like the gameplay, the fighting works and how armour and stats really do play into your game, if just for that its worth trying it out.However the lack of good characters, enemies and overall story is a little offputting, I would reccomend you get it on deal if anything as it is still fun, albeit not worth its full price if you are looking for a challenge or a story to lose yourself in.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												Now, let me start off with the good. This game is fairly fun to play (which is a HUGE plus and the only thing that kept this game worthwhile to me)  and has solid combat (albeit some weird hitboxed in some places). The levels are rather well designed, with everything being interconntected by cool shortcuts.Now onto the bad, which there is a LOT of. FIrst of all, this game runs like absolute crap. On NVIDIA GTX 760, I was barely about to keep it at 40ish fps on all lowest settings. Second, this game crashes. A LOT. And this is especially frustrating because unlike the Souls games, this game only saves at checkpoints (bonfires). So, it is quite easily possible to lose 20+ minutes of gameplay after a crash. Some enemies (I am looking at you, exploding fire beasts) seem to almost always crash the game without question if you get hit by the explosion.Besides running badly, this game has some poor design decisions. Certain attacks feel faaar too fast and unpredictable to dodge with any sort of human reflexes, so you are basically forced to eat them on the chin.The difficulty feels really inconsistent. Unlike the Souls series, it really suffers from overleveling if you explore everything similar to many other RPGs. So, while the game starts off fun and challenging, if you are like me and explore everything, starting about half way through the game you will get so tanky you can just wear heavy armor and take almost everything on the chin without dodging or blocking.Addidionally, the inventory system is HORRENDOUS in this game. It uses the same inventory as dark souls, where all items are put into one huge list based on the slot they go in. And while this wasn't horrible for dark souls, it is really bad for this game as it is based on the Western style of RPGs where you are constantly getting new armor/weapons which are straight up better than the ones you had before. As far as I could find, there is absolutely no way to trash, sell, or drop old items. And while you can favorite ones you want to use, you cannot automatically favorite new ones. So whenever you get a new weapon, you have to often scroll through 30+ other ones before you can find it.The last downside of this game, is how insanely short it is. While my skill from a LOT of experience with the souls series probably made me beat this game a lot faster than the average person, the shortness still cannot be overlooked. Trying to explore and find EVERYTHING, this game took me 17 hours to beat. If I was just doing the main story, I probably would have done it in 10 or less. And with this game being relatively linear and lack of multiplayer, the replay value certainly feels lacking. CONCLUSION/ TD:DRDespite these huge issues, I have to say that I still enjoyed this. But the only reason for it is my absolutely ADORATION of the Souls style of combat (Dark Souls 1 is easily my favorite game ever made, with me putting 500+ hours into it). So if you are like me and absolutely adore this style of combat, you might find this a fun distraction despite the plethora of issues. For most people though, this game is not worth the $50, at least not until the bugs/crashes get fixed.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												I really wish I could recommend Lords of the Fallen, the game carries a great deal of potential and by somewhat replicating the souls series combat mechanics they have assured that at least some of the combat is satisfying and enjoyable but the truth is that for all my hopes that souls style gameplay can become a genre in and of itself Lords of the fallen is sadly not the game to do it.The most glaring issue for this game is it's shoddy release state. For a start the game is very poorly optimised, on release PhysX and Vsync options did not even appear on the settings menu and even now that these have been patched in the game still performs very poorly with either turned on and worse will run your GPU and CPU dangerously hot, Over-clockers beware this game can cause damage to your components, though its more likely your GPU will fail and crash the game before serious issues occur. Even if one simply turns off vsync and PhysX the game has a plethora of bugs including but no limited to: Weapon special attacks that crash the game Exploding enemies that crash the gameInconsistent auto-saving that can cause loss of progress or leaving the player in a position from which they cannot progress.All of these bugs will hopefully be fixed in subsequent patches but in its initial state the game verges on unplayable for a significant number of players.Unfortunately the bugs are not the game's only issue. The game's main problem stems from the developer's misconception about challenge, namely, that prolonging a fight makes that fight more challenging. Of the various enemies in the game around 50% have health regenerating abilities of one kind or another, these enemies are supposed to be challenging when they regenerate from nothing to near full health but all this really does is force the player to fight the same fight they already won over again, this saps the satisfaction from combat leaving it boring instead of challenging. This problem is exacerbated during boss battles and while I have only encountered one boss with health regen abilities many of the bosses I have faced have had some mechanic which prolongs the fight unnecessarily usually forcing the player to stop attacking the boss to dealing with smaller, low level enemies. Rather than feeling satisfaction at your mastery after defeating a boss you will instead just be glad you don't have to go through the tiresome mechanics another time.However eventually the game does become a bit more fun. Somewhere around the mid-point you will begin to find weapons that can take off a decent chunk of the more tiresome opponents health. You will be thrilled when you kill an enemy before it can heal. You will begin to realise that Lords of the Fallen is more about gear than skill and the most fun is to be had once you've gathered a decent set of tools to work with. There is certainly a satisfaction to be had as you dominate an enemy that previously caused numerous deaths but at the same time much of the sense of challenge has evaporated. Unfortunately many of the game's bugs begin to rear their heads not long after this point and your gameplay becomes a frustrating battle with CTD's.The game's art style is very much going to depend on personal preference but whether you like it or not it doesn't feel like it has much individuality. Armour, weapons, enemies and scenery could all have been plucked from Diablo 3 though with considerable improved graphical fidelity. Similarly the story will make you long for the quiet cryptic narrative of a Souls game as generic fantasy is drawled with all the emotion of a wooden plank. The character's never give you a reason to feel any kind of connection to them and you carry out the tasks demanded of you simply to progress with no care as to their fates. The game's decision to use a lead character rather than allow the player to create their own seems pointless as the character is never developed. He is generic, gruff, male anti-hero number 5677 lacking even an endearing one-liner that would promote him to generic bad♥♥♥♥♥status.All in all the game feels like squandered potential. There is a good combat system here including a few refinements to the souls formula such as the perfect hit system that From Software should take a look at. But that system is dragged down by bugs, crashes and badly designed enemies. The good news is that these can be fixed. Bug fixing and optimization and rebalancing enemies and bosses could make this game an enjoyable experience. But until then this game is impossible for me to recommend.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Short, and not so sweet:This product is still in alpha phase in my opinion. Here's why:1. Game crashes anywhere from 5-20 minutes. This is a critical and inexcusable issue, and a product of this cost should not be crashing on most players' PCs. This is something would find in Alpha phase with even a halfway compentent QA or development staff.2. Product feels half finished. For what contect there is, it feels like half a game. The story is vague and generic. The characters are not even close to flushed out. The world is particularly small. What the player can do is limited. The camera angle and use in third person (the only viewpoint) is terrible at times. Your character's purpose in the world is a little too simple.I don't like to be completely negative, and there are some good aspects of the game:1. Even though the game can be difficult, it can be fun at times. The combat, although clumsy, is more or less solid and satisfying. Additionally, although simplistic, character development enhances the "RPG" aspect of the game, but it seems to cater to the warrior class and playstyle and punishes any other choice.2. Graphics are up to par for current gen - the gritty art style compliments the use of the various graphic effects employed. Sound effects are well done.Overall, I would only recommend the game if the developers patch the game properly and sell it for about half the price. It's not a half bad game, but not worth the current cost.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												Potentially purchasing a broken game. I want to say it's good, but it really isn't. A poor effort for a full release. Lots of very disappointing, annoying glitches and faults that render the game unenjoyable and potentially unplayable in some cases. Weapons disappear for no reason, the game crashes and freezes on top of very demanding specifications and disk space (powerful PC's  in order to run the game), No navigational indication other than memory and the will to explore; not even labels for the areas you are in or are about to enter (noting a majority of the quests make you travel to areas you are expected to know the location of, which is on the downright silly list). I can go on. I am very disappointed and don't recommend this game unless it is fixed and people start getting what they paid for.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												After having beat the game, I believe I can offer my two centsLords of the Fallen is a game similar to the Dark Souls franchise in mechanics, but lacking the charm of the Dark Souls- I never got the feeling any of my choices had an impact- None of the character's are all too memorable- The story is very confusing- The environments all get very boring, very quick- There's no real exploration, you'll eventually reach your desination by killing enemies- The enemies and bosses are all very generic (Fight humanoid enemy with a sword #5) So, why do I still recommend this game? Because, there are little things here and there that make me love it.+ The armor sets all look gorgeous+ It's insanely fun to play as a tank and smash your enemies to pieces with a warhammer+ There are little snippets of dialogue here and there that furthered my interest in the world+ While I never fully understood why Harkyn was so important, I definitely liked him and wanted him to succeed.+ I got♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off at certain characters and wanted to kick their♥♥♥♥♥♥in, something most games haven't acomplished.All in all, I'd give Lords of the fallen a 7.5/10. It's worth picking up if you want something to play similar to Dark Souls, or just want a good RPG to play.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												Pretty medicore game. I really like the aethetics of the armor and weapons in the game, but most people will probably call it over designed. The environments and effects are pretty well done. The game is a Dark Souls clone through and through, but to me didn't really feel all that challenging throughout the game. The enemy variety feels lacking with most if not all the bosses being some large armored guy. Too many enemies in the game also carry around a huge shield which turns most fights into circle strafe fests. The game felt extremely short and the difficulty wasn't paced very well at all. The last section of the game (the final time you revist the citadel) is 100x more difficult than anything else.  Rogue magic was extremely overpowered from what I saw. Some of the spells were battles themselves to use as they completely impead your vision during their duration. The experience pooling mechanic didn't really add anything to the game. Wasn't a fan of how the sidequests worked with me collecting trivial items throughout the game, but not actually finding the quests in time for who needed them. The story is an afterthought and even after completing the game I'm not exactly sure what happened.The game isn't very good, but is an okay title to run through once if you are bored on a weekend and can get this on sale for $10 or under. It doesn't really excel at anything, it just kind of moves along content at completely being average. It is good to note that I didn't experience any technical issue at all with the title aside from some some bugs in the graveyard area where my character sounds completely disappeared for some reason.

FIX YOUR ♥♥♥♥ING GAME!  Or how about introducing a little quality control somehow? Wow.  Will be asking for a refund now.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												I could say a lot about this game, but I'll try to keep it short. Souls fans will definitely enjoy this game. While borrowing a good deal from the success of Souls games, Lords of the Fallen has enough to define it as an entirely seperate game.Combat feels heavier, and much more similar to Dark Souls than Dark Souls 2. What it does different from DaS combat is implement magic as a part of every build. The only character customization is essentially choosing a heavy armor tank build, a medium armor cleric build, and a light armor stealth build. The estus flask idea carries on with health potions, which replenish at checkpoints. Players can increase their potion count by finding empty bottles, hidden in hard to reach locations.The graphics are beautiful, even better than Dark Souls 2. The lighting provides a dark and intense atmosphere without critically hindering visibility, though players will probably find it difficult to spot traps in the dark indoor chambers.While I won't compare the story to those in the Souls games, the story in Lords of the Fallen is much more direct and is quite good so far. There's a whole tab for discovered lore, for fans who love to delve deeper into a world's history.And finally, the death system has a few tweaks compared to those of the Souls games. Upon death all carried xp is dropped and players are sent back to the last activated checkpoint. Beyond that, no stats or equipment are affected, although players only have a few minutes to reach their death spot to reclaim their xp, and death before retrieval will result in the loss of any dropped points. I suppose that wasn't really a short review, oops. All in all, while Lords of the Fallen originates and borrows strongly from the Souls franchise, the game successfully sets itsself apart as more than a clone. Though some elements of combat may be more forgiving, Lords of the Fallen is still every bit as challenging and demanding as any of the Souls games.

												Liked:- some new combat mechanics (in regard to Dark Souls) such as shield sprint bash and blocking with shield on back- level design (highly interconnected, well detailed), especially at the begining (Keystone)- weapon design (in terms of graphics)- Worshipper - best designed boss in the game, capable of punishing constant distance playstyle, could inspire DS developers how to make bosses not so easily exploitable through ranged attacks- lore presentation (audio logs scattered through the world)Disliked:- bugs - tons of them, repeatable, often save-breaking- performance - requirements don't match visuals or game mechanics, I can't find any reason for this game to require so much horsepower other that lack of developers' talent or nvidia influence to push for physx and their crap- save system - especially painful with crap code quality in mind, continuous auto save system from DS would help here greatly- unskippable cutscenes / dialogs- combat - frustrating with heavy weapons, long windup and even slower weapon movement (who would swing so slowly with heavy weapon IRL?) makes for great imbalance vs most of enemies who can attack without almost any notice- crafting - there is no crafting system, there is socketing system with about 4 types of runes (fire/magic/poison/scaling),some weapons don't have any socket, don't have a clue why- progression system - especially regarding weapons, this is not DS, where virtually any weapon can bring you through whole game, here you have to put points in stat of your choice (str/fth/agi), preferably only one per playthrough, to pass stat requirement for better weapons- enemies - some bosses lack cooldown windows and require (to my knowledge, didn't use any help) cheap tactis such as ranged attacks and poison- 1st playthrough length - about 17 hours, too little for me considering some farming was done and backtracking (no travel system)- replayability - low, I could not force myself to play it again with this amount of bugs,I could recommend it only if it was patched and for a tenner or so.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												"Three crashes in 5 minutes."That was my initial review, which was my first one and written in pure frustration due to all the bugs plaguing that game.I will do my best to explain in more details why I would still not recommend this game yet.First of all, I played only the first Dark Souls and I enjoyed it as much as I hated it at the same time. Some of my main issues with Souls was the lack of convenient checkpoint before boss fights - because I am not that hardcore and would like all the help I could get, I would try to summon NPC to help me fight the bosses. Well, I can not remember how much time I got invaded in front of the Dragon Knights duo chamber. The checkpoints are much mroe convenient in Lords - and I can not really think of something done better in that game.The combat feels heavy and clunky - especially when using greatswords/axes. You need so much time to wind up the attack that unless you time it perfectly, you will get staggered by the lightning-fast enemy attack. And you can barely time it properly because of that - the lightning fast enemy attacks. They might be all in heavy armor and with greatshields, but they are attacking so freaking fast and breaking your guard so easy in the begining it is not even funny - nor fair. And you can not break their guard untill late game - it is just not possible. This makes the fight vs some of the shield weilders true nightmare, especially in early game. Even when you learn how to do it, it is still a chore and too time-consuming to be fun. Now I understand they are super-strong demons from other dimension, but for the sake of freaking gameplay - at least make it so we are able to freaking break their guard.Also on the fighting - how can you possibly dual-weild one handed weapon SLOWER and when using it with one hand and shield? Check The Avenger (I think that was the name of the sword), this is ridiculous. Two-hand weilding does not give you speed most of the time, just leaves you more open to attacks. Also - all greatswords have exact the same identical moves - all the greataxes and hammers as well. Actually, most of the weapons are just a reskin with identical move sets. The game suffers heavily from lack of diversity in that department - they should learn from the Souls.Agility weapons, and daggers in particular, feel very bad. They have nice very high damaging combos, but the last part of the combo is usually (with the case of daggers) charging move... which very often miss due ot enemies just slightly moving aside; or you just move past them by your own. Enemies however dont have that problem - if you dodge to the side, they auto-correct their aim and positioning mid-swing and will still hit you. That feels too unfair and cheap, considering they are as already mentioned with unbreakable guard and lightning-fast attacks.The magical system is there just for the sake of having some magic in the game - I played Paladin on my first playthrough and most of the time when I tried to cast anything I would get staggered by the creeps or bosses - because of the abyssmal long casting time, in which your hero stays in one place and makes fancy moves. I would appreaciate if some kind of mobility was invilved like in Souls, where you can still move while casting, but slower. It is ridiculous and not fun at all.The main thing that put me aside from the game and I will not most probably play it anymore is the loot system. Where is the replayability if in your first playthrough you open all the chests and get all the gear?! What if I got some crappy normal version of a very cool sword, and I want to socket it? Forget it - if you want another better vesrion of the sword, you need to know the exact chest and you need to start a new game and to make sure you have good multiplier for higher rarity chance. It would be much more helpful to be able to upgrade the common variation to higher rarity by crafting - or at least have everything drop again on New Game+ and ++ but with higher chance for better rarity.On a side note, I wanted to play agi char. Well, almost midgame and still the best agi-weapon was the one I foung in the very first 30 mins after start. I just gave up at that point.At this point I do not see any reason to play that game again. I was fooled by the pre-release streaming and the nice setting, but I would have never payed £30 for that garbage. The game is too small, too repetitive, too buggy and definetely not worth the price tag.Also keep in mind I have not played after the last patches and although some system issues might have been resolved, I will still not play it because of the all things mentioned above. All of the above is my personal opinion base don my personal experience with this trash, I mean the game, and might differ from yours. I would actually recommend the game after few patches and on a sale for at least 60% off, but not for full price. Do NOT get it for full price, do not make the same mistake as me.If you really bothered to read that - thanks and game on.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												This short "review" is writen after ONE playthrough and I can happily tell that it was quite enjoyable.Lords of the Fallen is a good gateway into the ruthless world of punishing action-RPG's like Dark Souls. It is a lot beginner friendly and easier, but it isn't too easy and shares the many traits of instakills if you just run like a fool into battle.The fighting feels solid and each swing and block feels heavy and strong. Even the moving is up to par with other games of the genre, it is solid and responding. The more heavier armours and weapons you wear, the slower you get and become a walking statue - whiles the lighter gear makes you swift and quick to strike your demon foes.While the story is something generic in european fashion, along with the voice acting - it is still enough unique and interesting to stand out with it's multiple endings and choices along the way to enrichen the world. Lores are scattered through the worlds as "audio scroll" for not wasting your time and this is quite a positive thing for me - the game is telling the lore to you, not making you speculate everything you find and see.But, with all games, there are some flaws. Many of the game breaking bugs has been fixed by now, but there are some minor bugs still that are just mostly amusing than anything braking. Sometimes the bodies of your fallen enemies flies up to the sky, only to be juggled ontop of your head. Sometimes the player spings rapidly around after doing a killing blow while locked on the enemy. Some minor sound bugs(hard to pin point out) and shadow glitches.In the end, I heartly would recommend this game to any one who enjoyes action-rpg games, especially the more ruthless ones.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Now, Lord of the fallen is a game i was initially wary about. I'd heard from youtuber Totalbiscuit that this game was horrendously optimized for PC. As it turned out he was right, i vastly exceed the recommended specs for the game (nvidia geforce 770 and 16 gigs of ram to give you an idea) But the game still had horrendous framerate, to the point that it almost froze. I ran a test with fraps to see the numbers, and it was consistently at 30 or dropped below that.Now, the game itself is very Dark Soul reminiscent, (Both of them being bad PC ports) And handles very much alike it. You control Harkyn, the main protagonist of the game) From a 3rd person perspective. You've got several different playstyles much alike that of the Soul games. But what i found in this game was that there was no way you were ever going to enjoy the game playing your own way. I started out as a Rogue, because ive always enjoyed sneakily shanking enemies when their backs are turned, and quickly found my♥♥♥♥♥♥on a plate because there had been no proper explanation of a stealth system, or if one such system even existed.And then, right after the tutorial fight with the first Rhogar, i had my first crash.I was ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ I looked at the forum to see if this was a common issue, and indeed this was something that has happened to a lot of people. I then also saw that the forums were infected with the very worst part of both the PC gaming community and the Dark Souls community. So entitled ♥♥♥♥♥♥s saying that anyone who does not own a pc powered by the souls of dead children should have no business playing PC games, and also♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥who ramble about you being a noob if you can't find this one single item burried away in a cave somewhere near a cove behind two secret walls, a fire, and a monster the size of the moon.So i returned, my problem unsolved, when as soon as the Nvidia logo had vanished the game crashed again.So after i'd gotten myself something to drink, and beat my head against the wall for a few minutes, I booted up the game again and it actually launched. To then find that my save file was gone.Grumbling and determined not to let this ♥♥♥♥ing game beat me, i started a new file and created myself a Cleric Brawler, cause i decided that if the game was gonna be a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ then so was i. And suddenly the game was an absolute ♥♥♥♥ing cakewalk, i died two times at the first boss and then he was trashed aswell, Despite this i did find myself cursing at ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t momentum cancelling attacks from enemies. This continued until i reached the third boss.This was where i officially clicked quit game and deleted the damn thing from my PC. ♥♥♥♥ you Lords of the Fallen. Being hard is one thing, but be hard and fair at the same time. A boss that spawns minions that stun lock you and then proceeds to beat you senseless isnt fair, its trying to beat a wall down with your forehead.So in short, can't recommend, maybe try Dark Souls 2 in stead.

number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												Honestly, it's nowhere near Dark Souls franchise, not even close. And it's not a good game on its own at all, but it doesn't mean it's a bad game. There are several flaws which make could make the game difficult to enjoy, but there are also things that make the dealing with all the issues worth it. Overall, I would say picking it up for cheap on a sale wouldn't be a bad deal.Pros:   Amazing soundtrack, the main menu theme is just great Great looking visuals, graphics are truly beautiful Multi-phase boss battles are somewhat interesting Good level design with fair checkpoint placement Enemy variety and design is satifying Cons:  Poor performance and very unstable, crashes left and right Bad voice-acting, uninteresting story and weak character design Unresponsive controls and extremely sluggish main character Very difficult in a bad way, cheap deaths and overpowered enemies Terrible menu design, menus are a pain to navigate Lack of meaningful spell variety for mage builds Gameplay = 6/10 ; Visuals = 9/10 ; Audio = 8/10 ; Music 9/10 ; Story = 7/10Verdict: 6/10 - MediocreLords of the Fallen is more of a mixed bag, but one that I can't bring myself to recommend to anyone except the hardcore Dark Souls fans. There are some really strong such as the amazing soundtrack and beautiful visuals, but there are many critical issues and problems such as instability and constant crashes, unresponsive controls, poor voice-acting and terrible menu design. If you're a Dark Souls fan, I'd say you should definitely grab it on a sale just to try it. Otherwise, there are much better games to play than this.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Played between 3 and 4 hours as of writing, spent about an hour in the rhogar realm.Seems to me to be a relatively poor b-movie equivalent of dark souls. If I'm not fighting hordes of enemies that never lower their shields, I'm fighting the poor, corridor-based level design, the abysmal inventory system, the confusing item switching system, the laughable dialogue or the non-existant story.It's quite a clunky game. Often you'll fight enemies with shields. Shield bash them, or kick their shield, and they'll lower their shield. For about a second. There is no time, even with some of the faster weapons, to follow up with an attack. It's as if Lords took the Dark Souls combat system but forgot to tune it based on their enemies.As for story, there are quite a few side characters about, that all seem to care greatly what's going on. Even the playable character, Harkyn, seems to care what is going on. But I can't for the life of me give a single solitary damn, becuase I have no idea where, who, what I am, why I'm doing it, who I'm doing it with... You're just not given any of that information, so it's rather hard to empathise with any of the 2-dimensional characters.The animations are stiff, in dialogue especially. Dialogue sounds like it was recorded somewhere that wasn't a recording studio, and that the VAs weren't really fully immersed.And after my good 3-4 hour excursion, I've met cumutavely a total of between 5 and 7 different enemy types. There's undead hollow thing, smaller undead thing with sword and shield, bigger undead thing with sword and shield, bigger undead thing 2handing, fat undead thing with a crossbow... It's not the most creative game. Sure, the skyboxes can be pretty if you can make it out behind all that lens flare, but I'm a bit tired of snowy castles and towers.It can be quite entertaining. quite. I've found myself thinking it's like dark souls but with the darksiders aesthetic and lack of fun.In no way could I recommend this for it's RRP. I grabbed this on sale for roughly £12, and to be perfectly honest, at the moment that's about the maximum I'd tell someone to buy it for.
