greatsword+ i've seen word "materials" so there are possibly upgrades or even craft- does not support custom controllers except xbox360, even x360ce (emulator) didn't help me, so i had to use xpadder with distance zones to imitate it. i will try again to get x360ce working, but it is fine already as it is with xpadder.- some enemies are hard to telegraph for parry, may be i'm not used to yet, just half a hour of gameplay so far.- combat may be TOO fluid at times, but still better than dark souls 2 clunkiness- can't parry without shield, so i feel like a ♥♥♥♥♥ having to equip it.- no character creation, but i wasn't really bothered with it, still could be a nice thing to have.+/- (neutral) actual story telling instead of lore. some people may like it, some ds tryhards might say that it's bad, for me - indifferent.+/- (neutral) artstyle is pretty general modern fantasy rpg game (witcher, dragon age), but it's consistent, so no opinion on this. again, more about tastes, but clearly better than dark souls 2 broken contrast imo.currently playing as thief with daggers and hand shield, parrying everything and having a blast, what else can i say?must-buy game, way better than dark souls 2 imo in terms of fluid controls, graphics and general consistency.it is obviously pale comparing to dark souls 1, but still a great fun.my rating 9/10 so far, will update for story and gameplay mechanics differences later as i will see them

number of helpful: 19 of 37 people (51%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												For a game that certainly tries to be Dark Souls, Lords of the Fallen is a good example of why a game like Dark Souls is to hard to pull off. There are so many small things that this game does worse than the former, and it makes the entire thing feel much worse for it. First, the camera is like being followed by a helicopter with Parkinson's disease. It goes from uncomfortably shaky in large, open areas, to almost laughably ridiculous in smaller, tighter spaces. Second, the combat. While a game like Dark Souls is more punishing than trying to fist a bear, it was always...ALWAYS fair. I can count on one hand the amount of times I died in Dark Souls and felt it wasn't completely my fault. In Lords of the Fallen, however, I died a dozen times in just the first area, and while I initially chalked it up to my learning the mechanics of the game, it soon became clear that this game is much, much harsher and even less fair when it comes to combat.While the idea of a bulkier, heavier Dark Souls sounds like an awesome game, this is not that game. It all looks very pretty, but it fails to live up to the standards of the game it so obviously is trying to be. This game is trying to stand on the shoulders of a giant like the Souls series, only to realize that it has no legs. This can all be summed up in an experience I had while trying to fight the second boss of the game. After dying maybe ten, fifteen times to the thing, I finally endured the nearly half-hour boss fight, had finally withered it down to the last fractions of it's health...and the game crashed on me. 2/10Would not buy again(also, it bears mentioning that game difficulty itself is not an issue for me [please refer to the 200 hours I've spent on Dark Souls], it is when a game is difficult without also being fair that I take issue)

												Lords of the Pauldron.In all seriousness, it's alright I guess.Absolutely terrible worldbuilding/story/characters. Combat mechanics are promising but have flaws with a lot of cheap and unpredictable enemy AI that prevent total enjoyment.Commendable attempt at non-linear level design, which is unfortunately derailed by environments that look too similar to one another and preventing players from learning a level's layout.The overall pacing of the game is absolute dogshit, and easily it's worst flaw. This gets more evident later on in the game.One example - a hard boss fight is placed immediately after another hard boss fight. You are physically locked away from the rest of the world and the player has no chance to mentally rest and recuperate by down-tempo exploration gameplay before being flung against another wall.I would be lying if I said I didn't enjoy my time with the game, but the flaws eventually added up and left me with a very sour taste in my mouth.It might be worth looking at, but not at full price.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Pretty fun game. If you liked Dark Souls 1 & 2, you'll probably like this one. Doesn't contain as many features as DS2, but has a similar difficulty level (although DS2 bosses are harder). No character creation, which is a minus, but has a reasonable skill/magic level progression. Only 3 classes, so limited replayability. Especially as (apart from the magic) you can essentially play the rogue and the warrior in one play through simply by changing your armour and weapon, if you put some points into agility. This can actually be helpful as versus some bosses you benefit from increased ability to dodge (champion anyone?). The game is hard at first and can be frustrating but once you get used to each type of enemy it's relatively straight forward until you reach a boss, which you then need to figure out. Like DS2, you drop all your experience when you die, but you can retrieve it. However, unlike DS2 the longer it takes you to reach your XP pick-up, the less XP there is when you get there. So the game can be pretty unforgiving, but if you like that then it's good.Visual style is okay I guess, maybe 2 or 3 years out of date but thats alright. The music and sounds are high quality. I've encountered a couple of bugs where if you die by falling sometimes your XP can't be reached. However, there are special items you can use that allow you to get your XP without actually running and getting it (type of potion). I advise never using these unless your XP is bugged as above, as when that happens these potions are the only way to get it back.Other than that, pretty polished game. Recommended.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												This game is not dark souls, it takes some of the dark souls ideas and game play, makes it easier, simpler and more friendly for casual gamers. if you are a hard core gamer or one that spent a lot of time on dark souls. this game will not last long as you soon realise what works best and will beat the game in a short period of time.Mobs do not hit that hard and when you realise how each one moves you will soon take all of them down. Even though the game offers a few different weapon and armour types, you will find that you go for a mid range weight encoumberment and a mid speed weapon. This is because high speed weapons do next to no damage to mobs/bosses, you will never be able to use a big weapon as they are far to slow also being to heavy ( fatman rolling ) doesnt work. and it wont take long to realise that rolling is pritty much pointless bar a few mobs and side stepping is faster, you stay on your feet for that back stab kill.The any mob will kill you aproach to dark souls is not needed to be taken on this game. But the big downside to this game is there is no real replay worth,      As you can only get items that you havent picked up on your first run so if you explored really well you have already done most things.      Mobs are a little harder to kill as they have more hit points, you know how to kill them and it is so easy you will find that you will go as far as possible without spending exp just for a little bit of risk. so far im just past the 5th boss on the second run through and i havent banked once. I have put recomended on this game as i have enjoyed playing it, all be that its a little to easy, some times hit reg is a bit dodgy, and there was a few crashes near the end of the game. But......if you are not a hardcore gamer, and you havent spent time on either dark souls game. This game is fun it will entertain and will pose a slight challenge to you, looks reasonably good, and after you have done this you might be tempted to really challenge yourself and buy the dark souls games. 10X longer but 10X the challange.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												I just completed my first run through of the game and enjoyed it.It's like Dark Souls, but way simpler and much easier. It has lots of weapons and armor, but the move sets of the different weapons is very small. Hammers all swing alike, Swords all swing alike, axes and so on.The story was muddled, but a somewhat interesting god vs man theme. I never got a clear sense of why I was there doing what I was doing, except that I was a criminal/sinner being used by the people who imprisoned me.  The scenery was quite good, graphics wise, but a good amount of the game is very similar to being inside an oblivion gate from Elder Scrolls: Oblivion. If you showed someone the levels and said it was an "updated oblivion" you'd except that idea without thought; they're so similar.The graphics are pretty good in my estimation. I found myself thinking that Dark Souls should look like Lords of the Fallen and that Lords of the Fallen should play more like Dark Souls. At the end of the day, this is a fun game and I enjoyed it. I wouldn't recommend buying it at full price, but on sale ($20 or less) it's a pretty good game.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												7/10 from me, really enjoyed the gameplay! Well worth it during sale.The first playthrough was fun, did a rogue one as well up till third boss but then continued on my cleric. Was an epic game, I lvled all the way up to 84 in the first run, found almost everything there is to find except 1 sword(core, didn't need it) and 2 armor pieces(the statue things, using Tor). Recently started NG+ and was thinking at least I'll get attribute points from chests where I already found the sword/armor from. But nope, got the same swords/armor as i did last run through from most of the chests. SOME armor chests gave energy or magic resist rune insted which I have too many of already and don't need. So after the second boss on NG+ I have to call it a gg. Lvling up after this point 86 is just mindnumbing and pointless, still wont make you that much stronger. Oh and the weapon aquireing progression through out the game is stupidly done. Any normal game you expect to find better weps as you progress, But I found 1 endgame axe very very early, then almost at the end of the game after finding loads of crap weapons i found an even better one(Last Will) that made anything after that useless again, from the second to last normal enemy before the last boss in the game I found a slightly better one(peacemaker) But at this point I didn't feel like running back and slotting it to just finish the last boss. All in all the game was very fun, but the weapons were so extreamly uneven in dmg they really just look cool but offer close to nothing.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Good:If you play it not expecting Dark Souls, you will have a good time.This game is better than most games out there but sadly in my opinion it had a rough launch and got a somewhat bad reputation from the get go.I bought this game expecting a buggy mess with pretty graphics but with a few hours of playtime. I can honestly say, even after spending many, many hours with the Souls games that, this game is different, rich in weapons and content and fun to play. It is so satisfying to hit things in this game. The multiplier (not multiplayer, this game is strictly singleplayer)- system is a great addition where you can go back to previous areas ang kill weaker enemies to increase your multiplier, and then go and earn some major exp.Sure, the enemies and the locations can get a LITTLE repetetive but no where close to what people are saying, I mean the detailed enviornments are incredible and well layed out. It FEELS like you are making progress and it is FUN.It is not Dark Souls, it does not even come close to that complexity, but it does not fall flat on it's face.The enemy A.I is good and it manages to surprise you. The same goes for the Bosses. Some bosses are harder than those in Dark Souls... I do not know if this game intended this or if it is a result of poor balancing but you can get DESTROYED in a few areas, which is good.There are so many weapons and Armours, and granted you will not use them all, they are there to play around with.The rune system to imbue your gear is good and simple and gives you a reason to grind some enemies, if you like grinding that is.Bad:The lore is forgettable and not really interesting at all, but luckily you can totally bypass it. It would have been better to not have ANY lore, then there might have been a mystery to solve but for some reason they went with a lackluster story.There are a few bugs I have noticed, with closed doors looking like they are open and one crash when switching weapons. I have also heard that there might be a game breaking bug after fighting the second boss but I have not noticed it.The new game system is kind of a gray zone for me. You can not play with the same character past NG++. It is not unlimited like Dark Souls.TLDR:The combat is satisfying and you can choose to play in whatever way you want. There are not many spells but you can use them all. Level up, get stronger, progress. Forget the story and just kill stuff in a very, very pretty world. It is hard enough and the bosses are rewarding. Everything is so BUFF AND COOL AND AWESOME LOOKING OMG. Really good artists. This is one of those hidden gems, plagued with a few issues and a bad reputation, but if you can see past it, you might just love it.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
EPIC GAME!!!! The combat system is amazing, every piece of gear looks awesome right from the start, the score has a very Diablo II sound to it, graphics are top notch and the boss fights are intense!Since the graphics and effects are so stunning, I had hoped for some more interesting looking armour later on but I finished it without finding anything jaw-dropping. Playing it through a second time now, might loot something more interesting this time round, I hope!I only have a few complaints:Bad story telling. A lot of decissions in the game I wasn't aware I made because they weren't explained clearly and there were times I wasn't sure what was going on, for instance (warning, spoilers in this blocked out text): The opening scene which I still don't fully understand even after finishing the game. Is it meant to be a flash back? Whats up with the hammer? Is it Harkyn or someone else? The giant demon who I thought was a fallen lord that vanishes with Yetka, what was that all about!?? And after the talk with Adyr you return to the citadel only to be attacked by the human soldiers, calling you a traitor for no reason. This is later explained a bit by picking up a scroll, but only after hacking through a small army of good guys you don't want to kill. And the mountain in the opening and at the end, what is it supposed to be and why did it break/fall apart?Extremely light crafting system. It would have been awesome if the crafting sytem let you craft gear instead of just unlocking runes and socketing gear, the smith looks more than capable. You can't combine lower quality runes to make better ones, but maybe this was intentional to keep the flawless runes a rare thing.Luck stat/drop modifier doesn't seem to work. It just increases the frequency of rubbish dropping, doesn't increase the quality of drops. Having said that though, I still highly recommend this game! :)

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												First off, most of the reviews complaining about the optimization problems are no longer valid. That being said, there is no excuse for games these days especially non-indie titles, to be released as beta feeling as this game was. Unforunately that seems to be just par for the course these days in the industry and I won't let my personal feelings on that matter apply here.This game is a third person action RPG that uses a similar control set-up to the dark souls games and leveling system, but that is where the similarities really end. You do gain and lose your experience by killing/dying and must go to where you died to retrieve your exp. This exp does start to disappear overtime though, and you're not likely to retrieve most of your exp if you're very far from a checkpoint.The game's difficulty is not high, and most of the struggles you'll face are at the beginning, and very end of the game. The mid-game seems unbalanced and you will be mowing through most enemies.The combat is much faster paced than the Souls games and I'd say it's about a mid-ground between that and Darksiders 2's combat. They did an excellent job of making each weapon type feel differently and I feel the physics here surpass the Souls series by far. The staff weapons were incredibly overpowered during the time I played the game due to it's fast attack speed and good scaling damage. This could always be fixed in balance patches or mods however.The bosses were fairly underwhelming, but there are a good variety of enemy types which take different tactics in order to combat as opposed to the souls series (lock on and circle) method of killing just about everything which detracts from my enjoyment of that particular franchise. There were multiple ways to defeat a few of the bosses, and this allowed you to receieve special equipment upon killing them which I thought was a rather neat addition. Some of the weaker and early bosses become elite enemies that you will fight throughout the game as well, forcing you to adapt your combat style when fighting them as well as a group of lesser enemies at the same time.There are many collectibles in the game, and while the lore is pretty generic, it's still interesting enough to warrant collecting all the scrolls and finding the secret equipment (which there is a good number of).The games length was decent, and it could probably be played through 2-3 times in order to play different styles, and colelct the new game + gear, however, new game+ difficulty does not scale nearly fast enough in order for it to be a challenge.As a final note, I do recommend the game, and while it's not anywhere near perfect, there are some innovative ideas here, and I'd like to see a sequel one day improve on what worked, and change what didn't. This is definitely the best game this particular studio has made to date, and I think they should be supported for adding some creativity to this genre which is pretty much dominated by a single franchise at this point.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
 Background At first i have to say, i own Dark souls I and II, and played boath games for more than 100+ hours. After I heared about this game, i was quit hyped and decided to give this game a go. I am german, but i try to write this review in english. If you find mistakes you are free to keep them ;) Graphic This games lookes really good. The armor and weapons look really cool. The enemys and enviroments are designed well and this game sets you up for its dark and grim world. But this game has a huge downside. This game runs really bad on most of the systems. I had to set all settings to medium, but can run Battlefield 4 on Ultra without problems. Sound The ingame sound suits the game well. The enemys you hear when you go through dungeons, the swing of heavy weapons, its really executed well. BUT the voicacting in this game is really bad. Most of the characters sound like they do not care about their situation at all. They fail to sell you the dark and grim situation they are in. Your maincharacter should not be part of this game, and also does not really care about the things happening around him Story and Playtime The Story really falls flat. Its the basic: The world is getting invaded and you are the only one to save it story. I stopped to care about the story quit early. You can read iteam descritions and listen to the NPCs you meet along the way. But there is not much lore behind the game, you really care about (there is a lot to read, but most of it falls short to games like Dark souls).The playtime of the game is really short! When you are send out to kill the final bosses you have played for like 8-10 hours. I also did a lot of sidemissions and explored a lot. But thits game just feels short. You have dungeons you can explore that are more interesting than the main story, but eventually you will end up doing the main mission. Gameplay The good:+ Weapons are balanced around their size. Daggers can be used to place fast hits in between your enemys attacks, and heavy swords need a setup time.+ Easy to learn, hard to master. If you are new to games like this, you will go for the tank approch using heavy armor and a shild. You can also use light gear and try to parry enemy attacks and use your mobility to fight them+ Risk reward mechanic. You can save your XP, or push on through the game trying to increase your multiplier. This gives you the chance to get more XP and better loot. Or to loose it allThe bad:-The bosses. Most of the bosses(not all!) are really boring. The difficulty is mostly increased when they summon additions minions, which is really cheap. Attack patterns mostly focus in one direction, so after you doge the first hit, the boss continues to attack in the wrong direction. I killed most bosses on the first try without any problem.- The lock on system. Its a JOKE! Most of the time the game will randomly lock on to an enmy infront of you no matter if another enemy (e.g. boss!) is directly infront of you In review This game is not perfect. The bosses are mostly push-overs and only some stand out. The gameplay itself is solid. You can challange yourself to play in a certain styl, that will increase the difficulty. I can not denie the fact, liking the game while playing it. If you are unsure, you can wait for the sale to pick it up.This game gets a 7,5/10 for me. Solid but can be improved :)

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												I initially started this game expecting it to play like Darksiders however it was quite different.In essence the combat is more like Monster Hunter. Especially when wearing heavy armor your character is quite slow which takes some time to get used to.My first attempts failed miserably due to the fact that I wasn't accustomed to the game mechanics. Even the very first enemy took me considerable effort to defeat.However, after you get past that 'hill' and start getting familiar with the controls and how the character behaves the game becomes incredibly fun!The atmosphere of the game is awesome: a dark and gritty monastery in which you uncover one horror after the other. Throughout the game you'll find pieces of lore which help you put the puzzle of the story together. My only gripe here is that in the beginning you get dumped into the game without any hook into the story i.e. you have no clue what's going on.You can find a huge amount of different weapons and armor, each with different stats and abilities and all of them look incredibly cool! The game is also loaded with many secrets which can be uncovered like special equipment, hidden treasure chests, special Portals after defeating bosses etc.The boss fights (i.e. the Lords) are a mix: some of them are quite easy while others are extremely hard. It takes time to learn their attack patterns and to equip yourself appropriately. Especially the final boss was a tough nut to crack. However, I have to add it never felt impossible i.e. even for the difficult fights you will manage to do a substantial amount of damage so that gives hope that it can be pulled off on a next attempt.Saving is done by means of checkpoints. So when you die you start back at a previous point and all enemies are back. Initially I didn't like this until I understood this is the core of the game: you have to redo parts in order to get more XP so you become more powerfull for the later game.When the game is completed you can start a new game +. This allows you to carry over all equipment of your previous playthrough. In addition it allows you to select a new school of Magic. So in this way you can eventually level up in all three schools which is quite nice.To conclude a couple of minor points which I found:- There is no Quest log, so it's hard to keep track of some side Quests. Taking notes is required.- There is no map, so you have to have a good memory where everything is located.- Most of the secrets in the game are not hinted at by the in-game lore. So some you will find by chance while the rest you can only find by looking at forum posts or youtube vids. It would have been much nicer if this info could be gathered from the game itself.- Even after finishing the game I'm still strugging sometimes with the controls (using Controller). In most cases this is caused by the fact that sprinting, rolling and jumping is one and the same button. So more often that not when I want to sprint to perform a heavy leap attack ... my character just rolls and bounces against the enemy only to get pounded. When wanting to jump over a gap ... my character just rolls and fall in the depths. These nuisances could have been avoided by a better control sheme.My final verdict is that it's a great game. It takes some time getting into it, but when you remain persistent (and patient) it becomes an awesome game!Note: After upgrading to Windows 10 I always got a crash when starting a new game. Disabling the NVidia Turbulence fixed this issue.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												Lords of the Fallen is a very fun game that has a lot to offer. It was a big underrated imo. Having said that though, it does suffer from a lot of problems. LotF is basically a Dark Souls clone, but that's not necessary a bad thing. It does bring its own flair to the series with additions like being healed by your fallen souls instead of just quickly retrieving them. It also focuses on a more controlled class design than Dark Souls. In DS, your character can be all over the place with stats and gear, which isn't a bad thing, as it allows you to have complete control over your toon. But LotF has specific class abilities, which do play somewhat different from one another. All the armor and weapons can be used by all three classes, as long as you have the necessary stat requirements. It's much more simplified than DS, so it opens it up to more casual people. One of the biggest changes from the DS series though is that bosses have stages. Each boss has three stages they go through depending on how much health they have left. For example, the first boss you fight will be wielding a greatsword and a shield. The more you fight him, he'll begin losing armor and eventually his shield. Then his tactics change and he just goes berserk with only the sword. It makes boss battle more challenging imo. Once you beat a boss, a rift gate opens up that offers an additional challenge. Sometimes it's just a loot rift, other times its a mob of enemies that you have to fight. Pro:Fun gameplay. Dark Souls like with good powers.Difficult enemies: Bosses and regulars offer a decent challenge. Great Visuals: Game looks really good.Amazing Armor and Weapons: Both weapons and armor look really cool. Cons:Bad Optimization: The game has suffered from FPS drops since day one. Even with a powerful rig, you're still gonna get drops no matter what.Bug: Lots of bugs in this game. It's nowhere near as bad as it was, but it needed more time for polish. Pointless Story/Characters: The story and characters are pretty pointless. Not once did I care what happened to anyone in the game, and the story is very predictable. Overall, I really enjoyed this game. I wouldn't tell anyone to pick it up at full price, but if you see it on a sale for $20 or less, its completely worth your time. The game was directed to be a more casual friendly DS-like game, but it still offers a good challenge. 7.5/10

												I have been playing this game for about 8 hours. I will still play it for many hours because...well this game is awesome. From the outstanding and gritty voice acting, too the UI style and the graphics. I think it looks really well on my high end PC with everything set to max. Real eyecandy. The story so far is very immersive, the charachters are realistic and everything has a grim touch too it. Yes it looks like Dark Souls, yes its hard and you'll die a lot....like Dark Souls. But it still stands on its own legs because the battles, the bosses and the controls as well as charachter development are all really better then Dark Souls..in my opinion. This game makes the perfect combination of magic use, weapons and shields. Everything can be used instantly without going thought countless of menus and then selecting and equiping it. Aside from that, there are a few sidequests, not too much but a few. The game offers a wide variety of weapons and...ARMOR. LOTS AND LOTS OF ARMOR. All the armors looks different and it really looks cool. Heavy armor makes you walk in a different and sluggish style, while light and medium armor makes you more flexible.If you are a Dark Souls fan and you're looking for a game in a similair fashion..look no further. Just buy the game and enjoy it. Im really looking forward too a sequel.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												I decided not to review this game until after I beat it. And after beating it, I can say that I really enjoyed this game. It is "soulsy" but it has enough differences in design and gameplay that its not a simple copy. The magic in particular feels a lot different. Since it acts mainly as a secondary combat choice, it never forces you to go full caster. The level design is also different, it feels really full and there are a lot more open spaces than in dark souls, but it is definitely smaller, and you can tell. There is no real late game areas, the mobs just get replaced with harder versions. The boss fights were all pretty fun and have cool sub challenges within them. The boss variety does leave something to be desired. Almost all the fights are in some sort of arena. The combat is actually really fun. A lot of people call it clunky but I just think its heavier. Everything just seems to hit harder, you included. For me though its the weapons and armor that really shine. There are a lot of sets and weapons for this size of game and every weapon you get usually is useful at the time you get it. All in all if you like the souls series or just like combat oriented rpgs you should check this out. 75/100ps. a lot of the performance issues and crashes have gotten better, not perfect...better.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Third person action game with mechanics similar to Dark Souls 2.Graphics:High end graphics with a lot of indoor areas, however the cut scenes and NPCs are not that great. Also, if you get to close to a wall during a fight you will probably disappear from the screen and take damage from your enemy. Grade: 8/10Sound:SImple ambient music and sounds. Lots of sound reuse and similar sounds that trick you. You think there are more enemies, yet you just killed the last one. You open a chest and the sound tricks you into thinking a enemy is behind you.Grade: 6/10Controls:Copied directly from Dark Souls 2, which is not a bad thing. Right button to lock camera on enemy, L1 to defend, R1 to attack, B for magic, X for items...Grade: 9/10Game Story:Simple story and very straightforward, get ready to do a lot of backtracking and get lost forever indoors at areas that look all alike. Did I mention that I hate games like these not providing us a map? I do hate it.Grade: 7/10 (yes you lost points for not having a fu... map)Difficulty:There are enemies that are harder to beat than bosses, as some require you to find his heart before being able to kill it, others defend like hell and some explode after dying, killing you instantly if you do not retreat. The first boss fights are harder as you are a low level player. After you get to higher levels, the boss fights become a pacience game taking a longer time but easier in the end.Grade: 8/10General Grade: 7,5 - 8/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												"Lords of the Fallen" takes a handful of mechanics from games such as Demon Souls and Dark Souls, which means the game's unforgiving until you get used to the basics, you will die often, and you play as a sword-and-board dude who runs circles (lol).Apart from running around the place (there's quite some backtracking), what you will be doing most of the time is combat, and - depending on your class - fighting can and will feel slow. I picked a warrior and found that many of the attacks were painfully sluggish. Eventually, I finished the game with a light 100% block shield and a one-hander, which feels... pretty standard for a fantasy game like this.If you don't want to play a warrior, you can also pick a dual-wielding rogue, or a cleric who can use staves. On top of this, all classes get a gauntlet weapon you can use to cast spells.The game feels very much eclectic. Core mechanics come from Dark Souls. The visuals are very much inspired by Diablo and World of Warcraft (weapon and armour design), but also by Darksiders (armour, puzzles, treasure chests, spell animations). The setting is very generic and I think it's LotF biggest problem - it just doesn't feel unique in any way. Even the story is bland and merely serves as a means of getting you from point A to point B in a pretty linear fashion.The game also has some technical problems and the devs are not too eager to fix them."Lords of the Fallen.exe" is a quite common issue that might annoy you more than dying over and over again (when you crash, you lose your progress).Mobs, and sometimes even bosses, can glitch out making them easier or harder to kill.To sum it up:If you liked Dark Souls give this game a shot when it's on sale.If you hated DS or this type of games is just not your thing, play something else. You won't like this one either.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												I have to say this games has its pros and cons just like any other game but I'll just say what I've noticed and you can decide for yourself if you want to try it or not. As a whole, I recommend it if you can get passed the things that drag it down a bit, I personally am satisfied with my purchase but I'm not jumping for joy over the game because I expected a bit more out of it. Some things I do like very much is that it has a good solid gameplay to it. The blocking in the game feels like actual blocking where you take no damage (if your energy is high enough to block the incoming attack). The weapon attacks are on the realistic side of the line as well; the heavier the weapon, the slower it swings. Even the dodging feels more realistic which could be good for some gamers and bad for others because you may end up dodging and still getting hit (e.g. the enemy swings at waist height and you dodge, the weapon might still hit you because it was low enough).The targeting can go both ways in this game, in can be a plus in some cases and a detriment in others, you'll have to decide what you like or dislike about it. The targetting locks on to your enemy of choice and you can swap enemies with a quick tap of your camera controls (Right analog if you use a gamepad) in either direction. The problems I have found with it though is there is no quick way to switch targets if one runs behind you (Which they do as a combat technique). Another issue I have found with it is that you can't target unless you have near full view of the enemy which makes it harder on you when coming through a narrow corridor and, unfortunately, there are invisible objects that can get in your way as well (e.g. I found one enemy standing beside a fire brazier and I couldn't target him even though I could clearly see him)."Energy" is basically stamina. It is consumed by attacks (Both regular and power attacks though power attacks take more, obviously), blocking, dodging, as well as sprinting. Your energy recharges on its own at a decent rate, just back up out of range of the bad guy's attacks for a few seconds and your energy will fill up quickly. Your energy will still feel up if you are blocking but it will fill up much slower which means you can't just tank all the hits easily, you actually have to employ tactics to get your energy up while still taking as little damage as possible. I've noticed that bosses will have attacks to completely drain your energy (The first two will slap you with their shields to drain your energy to 0).The magic of the game can obviously play a good part in the game, I can't say I have gotten very far into the game (About 2 hours of gameplay) but I haven't found a need or even desire to use the magic in the game. The magic really isn't anything fantastic. You can heal yourself somewhat, raise your defence, increase attack, do a magic power attack, make a clone of yourself to distract the enemy, but nothing really all that great. You have three "classes" of magic, each has their own benefits.Visually it is fairly good. I can't say it has the best graphics in the world but it definitely has high quality. I'm a bit of a graphics snob and this game is good enough for me visually. I do have to say, the character models are lacking in their mesh morphs because the lip sync with the words is extremely off; laughably so. The characters move their mouths in much the same way as a ventriloquist's puppets do, basically just a jaw flapping down and back up, and they don't move in a way that really goes with the words, they just seem to move at random and half of the spoken words in the game don't have lip movements at all.The lack of character appearance customization may not appeal to everyone or even might make people completely refuse to play the game. I believe that the lack of character customization is simply because you are playing an existing character in this alternate reality instead of creating one. Unfortunately, there are no appearance choices at all. You don't choose hairstyles, genders, etc. You simply play the guy you see in the trailer with markings all over his face. If that doesn't bother you, then pay no heed to this paragraph (I am not bashing lack of character appearance customization, I don't mind either way depending on the game).The movement in the game is rather slow. You run slow, you sprint slow, you dodge slow, you attack slow. Even if you choose the light armor with dual daggers, you still dodge slow. The character is hulking and reminiscent of a golem with his movements. I can honestly say that I went with the daggers first but with the poor movement speed and little to no blocking that you would expect from a lightly armored and quick on their feet character, it was much harder than medium or heavy builds. I honestly didn't see any speed increase with the light build over the heavy build.You carry your exp around with you on your character and the more you carry the more you get from killing things. You don't get this reward with no risk, of course. You can't level anything up without spending the experience you have and if you die then all of the experience you have with you drops and you have to run back to where you were to get it. Over time, the experience amount will disipate until there is nothing left to recover. In essence, you gamble the experience you have so that you can earn more; the more you risk, the more you earn.All in all, I'm pleased with the game though the cons of the game do bother me a bit. I will consider this an overall positive yet neutral review and I hope it was informative rather than biased.Here is the biased part:Pros:-Good blocking-Good weapon weight/speed ratio-Good graphics-Simple tutorial-Great energy recharge rateCons:-Poor lip sync with dialog-Invisible walls preventing targeting-Targetting can prevent you from quickly turning to block an attack from behind-Magic system doesn't seem to be worth the effort-No character customization-Slow movement even when lightly armored

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												This game borrows heavily from Demon Souls and Dark Souls, but compared to those games this one is far less frustrating but also not nearly as challenging. To me it was the perfect balence between challenge and fun gameplay and without a lot of the frustrating grind that is in Dark Souls.The Good:The Graphics and visual design - This is a truly gorgous game, great textures and enviroments comes to life with some awesome Nvidia effects and some great physics. Armor design is really good and they look really nice with the amazing clothing physics. You mostly travel through dark corridors and smaller open areas in this game, but they are very detailed and I never found the game lacked variety when it came to the world. Character lipsyncing and such is not that good though, but on the whole the graphics is outstanding. There are also some really cool looking monsters in the game.The Combat - I played as a Paladin type character focusing on Heavy Armor and Weapons and with some magic mixed in, such as healing. The game focuses on melee combat compared to most RPGs like this game and the game does it really well. Though the combat is very similar to the combat from Dark Souls.The Exploration and Loot - Throughout the game I loved exploring all corners finding new loot, especially since every new armor or weapon had a distinct look and very nice visuals. They are very stylized but very fitting to the setting the game takes place in.The AverageThe Boss Battles - There are some very cool and fun bosses in this game and I had fun taking most of them down. But some are a bit on the easy side though and they can seem a bit samey at times. Don't really have to change your tactics much. The bosses are not even close to as hard as in Dark Souls as I managed to take down most of the bosses on either my first or second try. But they are still fun to fight. It may be a much harder game on New Game+ but I have not tried that yet.The BadThe Story - The story is average to bad, the main character is your typical anti-hero gruff sounding bald guy who has very little interesting to say. You meet a few characters in the game but they don't really have much depth. There are some interesting aspects to the game but nothing that truly stood out. And some bad lipsyncing and presentation when it comes to dialog does not help. That being said it at least has a story and gives you a purpose for doing what you are doing.Lack of Information - This game has no quest log, so when you pick up a quest you pretty much have to remember where they say you should go. And most of the time you get no info at all so you pretty much have to find out by yourself. This is really tedious and very annoying. Hate having to resort to checking out a walkthrough just to find out where I have to actually go. And there are many items and such that lacks any info on what they actually do. Well that is that, it is a good game with some flaws. But I do recommend it for anyone who likes the combat in Demon Souls or Dark Souls but find those games to frustrating. Or to annyone who just want a pretty new world to explore and fight some cool looking bosses, and of course find that sweet sweet loot.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												I was interested in this game since release and finally picked it up during christmas sale of 2014. Dark Souls is one of my all time favorites, so I was ready to ignore negative steam reviews and form my own opinion. The game is highly recommended to every Souls games fan. It is also a nice introduction to these types of games, so if you really wanted to try Souls but wasn't sure it's for you, I'd recommend this game. It's somewhat easier and more friendly, so beginners will have good time playing it.First of all, it is a sure clon of Souls series games and I can't escape comparing it to them. Combat mechanics is absolutely the same, leveling up and saving is almost the same, the spirit of the Souls is here. But with a nice twists here and there. It is surely more a western game, then japanese for starters. The art and graphics are absolutely gorgeous, UI is fantastic and easy to use (which cannot be said about Souls), every mechanic is nicely explained and you don't need to read dozens of guides just to be able to do basic things. But it doesn't mean the game has no secrets, no. Like every Souls game you will miss a lot on your first playthrough, but that's okay.The things I would've liked to be improved in Lords Of The Fallen: - Content and length of the game. I finished it in 16 hours and that's counting some grinding. Locations lack variety, there are disappointing number of bosses and there's no "wow" effect like it was in Dark Souls. I hope next installment brings more epic fights in a bizzare locations - More class variety and leveling up options - More interesting and engaging NPCs. There were some, but nothing to write home about. The only interesting one I think was some dude you had to bring human skulls to - No multiplayer options. May be it was too difficult to achieve, but it would've been nice to at least place some clues for other people.And that's basicly it. Technical side wise the game run nice for me. It crashed only one time and there were couple wierd sound glitches, but nothing too bad or gamebreaking. Developers did nice job patching and I didn't encounter too much problems. Of course they should've shiped more polished game, but they didn't abandoned it, so it's all good.What I did like about Lords Of The Fallen: - Magic is more of an addition to the main combat then focus of it. I liked how easy it was to use and how uncomplicated the system was. It's more of a support style magic and I thought it worked great with this type of game - Design of the world, design of the weapons and armors. Absolutely fantastic. Every time I've put new set on myself, I couldn't believe it can look more bad♥♥♥♥♥ but then I've picked another one and once again was amazed. Just stellar job for designers. Great weapons, ugly enemies, great UI and overall vision. A+++ - Sound design. Music is awesome and right on the money, great ambient sound. Enemies make terrifying sounds. Great! - Although it's a secret, but you can completely respec into a differenet class during a game. Liked that a lot - Story is good. Not super great, but decent. And little pieces of it in form of audio logs were interesting - Different endings depending on what you did during a game, nice little addition - New game + of course - Challenges during boss fights were super nice addition - Level design with shortcuts that wraps around itselfIn the end, I would say that I enjoyed this game very much. In current state it has no technical problems any more and it's very fun. It's not as hard as Souls game, so a lot more people can enjoy it. I would purchase any future projects from this studio.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I have finished this game on a debatably medium PC. It has not crashed once on me. The 1.4 patch did wonders, I guess. Otherwise, I found the game to be quite entertaining. It has a small world, yes, but it's filled to the tip, and you'll be backtracking a lot, since some areas open only later in the game. The design is kind of power fantasy, you look like a spiky tank most of the time, and the enemies are grotesque. The combat is clunky, albeit realistic. It focuses on tactical blocking, evading and timing of your hits, and the heavy weapons WILL feel heavy (some of them need two hands to be used, regardless of your strength). It kinda forces you to use all the tools at your disposal, which is a good thing, since it varies the gameplay and forces you to think up strategies on the go. The main story is meh, but you are a criminal and you can totally mess up humanity if you chose one of the three possible endings, so in the end it's fine by my standards.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												If you have the hardware to run this maxed out you are in for a treat. This is one of the best looking multiplatform games out right now. If not, no worries! The gameplay alone is worth playing Lords of the Fallen™. At its core, the game is all about preparation, strategy, and timing one powerful blow or a perfect succession of fast strikes against a vulnerable enemy. It gets tricky when there's multiple foes and little room to work with. That's where this game shines; when your heart races and you're praying you'll make it out alive. If not, that sucks. Just go find your ghost and regain all that precious lost experience points. Die on that one way trip? All is lost! There's a decent story full of lore and interesting characters, monsters, and set-pieces. There's also tons of armor, weapons, and other gear to keep you happy, and the best catch is what loot drops is tied to how much you are willing to wager you won't die. Cash in your experience and the loot multiplier is reset.I love it, and this is from someone who could never really get into the Souls series.P.S. I haven't had one crash or any other issues.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												Is Lords of the Fallen a good game or is it a bad game? Well, it depends. It's most certainly not a terrible game. It's not that great either. It's like if you took Dark Souls and played it on 1/3rd of the speed, and the game (including the uninspired and monotonous bossfights that hardly ever present a challenge) is mostly pretty easy and boring/tedious. The visuals are pretty nice, though, even if the artistic direction is kinda generic (as is the disjointed and bland narrative and lore), but rather demanding from a performance point of view.My bottom line would be – if you try to make a clone of Dark Souls games (which is what this game clearly and undeniably is, even if some people get really mad when you mention this), changing things here and there just for the sake of not being a direct DS clone without really understanding what really makes Dark Souls such a great series might not be the best idea. I would very much like to see a Dark Souls game with the visuals of LotF. I'd rather not see LotF game with the visuals of Dark Souls, if you get what I mean. Nice graphics really isn't the most important thing to look for in a game.In the end, I give LotF recommended, but an unforgettable instant classic like Dark Souls it ain't. Take it as a 6/10, if you will.(You can read my full review at http://english.edgeoftheworld.cz/2015/08/23/lords-of-the-fallen-review/ if you wish.)

												Stupid crashes. Patch fixed. I played this game a lot, don't know why. Maybe because fighting isn't clunky and frustrating as ♥♥♥♥ compared to Souls. Your choices just change the ending cinematic and gives you achievements (yay achievements!), and some of your choices can actually ♥♥♥♥ you (not cutting the dude's arm and helping him with potion will not let you get super potions near the end of the game). New Game + Is like Souls except we don't get new monsters, but we do get new lore (the lore is infinitely better than the game's main story). Also, not ALL monsters will get strong with the NG+ so you will get very confused most of the time, and will get one-shot without realzing. Warrior is easy as ♥♥♥♥, if you play this game as warrior you will have the worst experience, unless you don't upgrade your Faith for the absurd spells. Rogue gives the best experience, even though the i-frames are a joke. Cleric is fun as heck. You will have the worst time ever at the final battle, if you went full faith without using the gauntlet. Overall 7.5/10.I enjoyed the game a lot, more than Souls, honestly, but Souls is much better polished (except for the ♥♥♥♥ing frustrating combat mechanics).

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												Is Lords of the Fallen a good game or is it a bad game? Well, it depends. It's most certainly not a terrible game. It's not that great either. It's like if you took Dark Souls and played it on 1/3rd of the speed, and the game (including the uninspired and monotonous bossfights that hardly ever present a challenge) is mostly pretty easy and boring/tedious. The visuals are pretty nice, though, even if the artistic direction is kinda generic (as is the disjointed and bland narrative and lore), but rather demanding from a performance point of view.My bottom line would be – if you try to make a clone of Dark Souls games (which is what this game clearly and undeniably is, even if some people get really mad when you mention this), changing things here and there just for the sake of not being a direct DS clone without really understanding what really makes Dark Souls such a great series might not be the best idea. I would very much like to see a Dark Souls game with the visuals of LotF. I'd rather not see LotF game with the visuals of Dark Souls, if you get what I mean. Nice graphics really isn't the most important thing to look for in a game.In the end, I give LotF recommended, but an unforgettable instant classic like Dark Souls it ain't. Take it as a 6/10, if you will.(You can read my full review at http://english.edgeoftheworld.cz/2015/08/23/lords-of-the-fallen-review/ if you wish.)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												This is a review from someone who loved Darksiders (I had graphical issues with 2, so that was a bummer), loved Kingdoms of Amalur, liked Skyrim but hated the way the third-person was done, and played Dark Souls 2 (on PC) for one hour before getting a refund (my first refund request on Steam in seven years).I bought this game as a filler between Borderlands Pre-Sequel and Dragon Age: Inquisition, but I was horribly wrong in thinking that this game would be just a mediocre filler..Lords of the Fallen is downright amazing.  As most people have said, it plays extremely similar to Dark Souls; however where Dark Souls utterly failed, Lords of the Fallen succeeds in leaps and bounds.Here are my pros and cons:Pros The controls!  Nothing kills a game for me more than bad controls (which extends to graphical UI as well).  Lords of the Fallen, as I compare it to Dark Souls, has amazing control and ,once you get used to all of the mechanics, gives the player a feeling of personal extension. The challenge!  Okay, I know a lot of people are rolling their eyes.  "Pfft!  This game is totes easy, noob!"  At times it can be, and then at other times it is pretty brutal.  This is not the typical forgiving game that rewards players just for showing up.  But the real great part is that you, the player, grow with your character.  First you struggle to get a hit in while also blocking and every enemy seems to take 3/4 of your life and your health potions are dwindling.  But a few hours later, that same enemy is swinging at air while you are crushing his head in with ease and losing even 1/10th of your life seems like you just lost focus for a moment.  There is definitely a very rewarding feeling when you grow better as a player instead of just gathering more stat points to win the RNG fight. The variety!  Between strength, agility, and faith weapons, gauntlets, shields, and class spells there is quite a long list of different ways to bash your enemies face in.. and this is without taking into account Runes or Legendary weapon special abilities!  Everything has an optimal use, so there is very little "useless junk" lying around. The replayability!  Ever get frustrated that you run out of enemies to kill, or there is no point in starting a new character?  Lords of the Fallen doesn't have that problem.  Enemies respawn everytime you change instances (which actually slows everything down quite a bit), and the classes are varied enough to warrant at least a few playthroughs. The sound effects are good, but for me that is just icing and not really anything that would keep me or stop me from playing.Cons Graphics Optimization.  Now bare with me here.  The graphics are amazing.. truly, and the art style of the armor, weapons, and character models is inspiring.  But I am used to my quaint gtx660 being able to handle most games at either High, Very High, or Ultra depending on the demands.  Lords of the Fallen has me sitting at Medium, and even then I feel the UI lag at times (especially when using spells that have persistent graphical effects).  I can only assume that there has to be some optimization issues there, but it is certainly not written in stone. Once you find your fav weapon, spell, or armor the game can get a little repetitive.  However this is something that happens in all games, and admittedly this game suffers from this problem far less than others.  Definitely a minor issue.That is about all I can think of.  I look forward to a sequel in the future.  For those who are on the fence about buying this one, as long as your money isn't making you choose between this or Dragon Age: Inquisition, then I would definitely place this one very, very high on the list.  Best action RPG I have played since Darksiders 1.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												This game is not dark souls, it takes some of the dark souls ideas and game play, makes it easier, simpler and more friendly for casual gamers. if you are a hard core gamer or one that spent a lot of time on dark souls. this game will not last long as you soon realise what works best and will beat the game in a short period of time.Mobs do not hit that hard and when you realise how each one moves you will soon take all of them down. Even though the game offers a few different weapon and armour types, you will find that you go for a mid range weight encoumberment and a mid speed weapon. This is because high speed weapons do next to no damage to mobs/bosses, you will never be able to use a big weapon as they are far to slow also being to heavy ( fatman rolling ) doesnt work. and it wont take long to realise that rolling is pritty much pointless bar a few mobs and side stepping is faster, you stay on your feet for that back stab kill.The any mob will kill you aproach to dark souls is not needed to be taken on this game. But the big downside to this game is there is no real replay worth,      As you can only get items that you havent picked up on your first run so if you explored really well you have already done most things.      Mobs are a little harder to kill as they have more hit points, you know how to kill them and it is so easy you will find that you will go as far as possible without spending exp just for a little bit of risk. so far im just past the 5th boss on the second run through and i havent banked once. I have put recomended on this game as i have enjoyed playing it, all be that its a little to easy, some times hit reg is a bit dodgy, and there was a few crashes near the end of the game. But......if you are not a hardcore gamer, and you havent spent time on either dark souls game. This game is fun it will entertain and will pose a slight challenge to you, looks reasonably good, and after you have done this you might be tempted to really challenge yourself and buy the dark souls games. 10X longer but 10X the challange.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Third person action game with mechanics similar to Dark Souls 2.Graphics:High end graphics with a lot of indoor areas, however the cut scenes and NPCs are not that great. Also, if you get to close to a wall during a fight you will probably disappear from the screen and take damage from your enemy. Grade: 8/10Sound:SImple ambient music and sounds. Lots of sound reuse and similar sounds that trick you. You think there are more enemies, yet you just killed the last one. You open a chest and the sound tricks you into thinking a enemy is behind you.Grade: 6/10Controls:Copied directly from Dark Souls 2, which is not a bad thing. Right button to lock camera on enemy, L1 to defend, R1 to attack, B for magic, X for items...Grade: 9/10Game Story:Simple story and very straightforward, get ready to do a lot of backtracking and get lost forever indoors at areas that look all alike. Did I mention that I hate games like these not providing us a map? I do hate it.Grade: 7/10 (yes you lost points for not having a fu... map)Difficulty:There are enemies that are harder to beat than bosses, as some require you to find his heart before being able to kill it, others defend like hell and some explode after dying, killing you instantly if you do not retreat. The first boss fights are harder as you are a low level player. After you get to higher levels, the boss fights become a pacience game taking a longer time but easier in the end.Grade: 8/10General Grade: 7,5 - 8/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												[For those that are not so hardcore] Anyone on the fence about getting LOTF because of the flat out negative opinions by DS fanboys. Don't be / get it for $20 or cheaper. Totally worth it. Is it influenced by DS ,yes. Is it perfect,no. Does it stand up on its own,yes. All games have their issues and DS has its fair share. Some posts make it seem like DS is flawless. DS: The story is buried, the level design can be clunky, doesn't connect the dots well, most people evade enemies to get to the next chest/check point/soul harvest. The fun aspect to Souls is almost non existent -just difficult for the sake of being difficult. The inventory /character scaling is confusing. Sure, you can play,stop,go to YouTube, come back play,die and repeat until you finish the game and then wear your badge of dickishness proudly to bag on other games (just those few). And yes - most DS players look outside the game to figure it out. The view count on DS vids are impressive.LOTF is fun to play. The visuals are great. The camera does suck. The combat system can be tighten up but not to different from DS. The story and npc's are ok,so far. And if you decide on DS, I suggest start with 3. The art is awesome.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Good:If you play it not expecting Dark Souls, you will have a good time.This game is better than most games out there but sadly in my opinion it had a rough launch and got a somewhat bad reputation from the get go.I bought this game expecting a buggy mess with pretty graphics but with a few hours of playtime. I can honestly say, even after spending many, many hours with the Souls games that, this game is different, rich in weapons and content and fun to play. It is so satisfying to hit things in this game. The multiplier (not multiplayer, this game is strictly singleplayer)- system is a great addition where you can go back to previous areas ang kill weaker enemies to increase your multiplier, and then go and earn some major exp.Sure, the enemies and the locations can get a LITTLE repetetive but no where close to what people are saying, I mean the detailed enviornments are incredible and well layed out. It FEELS like you are making progress and it is FUN.It is not Dark Souls, it does not even come close to that complexity, but it does not fall flat on it's face.The enemy A.I is good and it manages to surprise you. The same goes for the Bosses. Some bosses are harder than those in Dark Souls... I do not know if this game intended this or if it is a result of poor balancing but you can get DESTROYED in a few areas, which is good.There are so many weapons and Armours, and granted you will not use them all, they are there to play around with.The rune system to imbue your gear is good and simple and gives you a reason to grind some enemies, if you like grinding that is.Bad:The lore is forgettable and not really interesting at all, but luckily you can totally bypass it. It would have been better to not have ANY lore, then there might have been a mystery to solve but for some reason they went with a lackluster story.There are a few bugs I have noticed, with closed doors looking like they are open and one crash when switching weapons. I have also heard that there might be a game breaking bug after fighting the second boss but I have not noticed it.The new game system is kind of a gray zone for me. You can not play with the same character past NG++. It is not unlimited like Dark Souls.TLDR:The combat is satisfying and you can choose to play in whatever way you want. There are not many spells but you can use them all. Level up, get stronger, progress. Forget the story and just kill stuff in a very, very pretty world. It is hard enough and the bosses are rewarding. Everything is so BUFF AND COOL AND AWESOME LOOKING OMG. Really good artists. This is one of those hidden gems, plagued with a few issues and a bad reputation, but if you can see past it, you might just love it.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												game is ok, not good but ok.Technical issues havent been fixed in almost two years of patching, which is a let down.The gameplay itself borrows alot from Dark Souls, which sounds great, but its not the best from DS, they took the worst and multiplied it.Every second enemy hides behind a shield, turning the game into a long drawn out series of circle strafing and dodging trying to get behind them, the other option for dealing with them is shooting them with the gauntlet for minimal damage OR charging into them with your own shield and using a very small window to whittle down thier HP with one or maybe two hits, rinse/repeat till dead.Some of the level design is nothing more than a series of corridors, which with the enemy mentioned above becomes one of the most frustrating things i have ever come across in a game, if you cant get around it or go through it, well ♥♥♥♥ good luck getting that over with quickly.About the only praise i do have for the game itself is the EXP system which rewards you more for enemies killed without using checkpoints, the multiplier on how much an enemy is worth goes up the more you kill without using a Crystal (bonfire) which would be awesome if the fear of random crashes, freezes and driver destruction didnt put the fear of losing all your progress in you, which makes this system useless unless you exploit it, which is way too easily done.I picked the game up for five bucks on a sale and cant really say its worth the money, if they ever get it working in a stable manner then maybe.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												I was waiting until I finish this game to make a review about it. I was hoping that if I finished the Story it would surprise me but I decided to make the review even before that. And why? Because this game is not good. Period. I didn't play a lot of Dark Souls to compare it to, but I can recognize a broken game.  I had huge expectations about this game, but now I really regret that I pre-purchased it. It's not worth the price. And I'll probably won't purchase other CI titles.Some reasons that I don't recommend this game (Warning: Spoiler Alert)- I lost the count of how many time I was holding the defense button with the shield selected, facing my opponent and with full action bar and, even with all these things right, I ended up receiving damage from my enemies and dying. - When you're using the gauntlet you can shoot at an enemy holding a huge shield that covers all his body and he'll take damage anyway.  - At the same time, you'll face some archers that will shoot fire arrows at you and, even holding a shield the whole time, you'll take fire damage. - The enemies (archers specially) can see you from far away and they'll hit you for sure. No matter how far you are. What else do I have noticed? The game crashes sometimes.* Do I have anything good about this game?Only that the graphics are impressive. But, what good is having great graphics if the game does not work right?If you have any interest in this game, wait for a huge promotion. That's my advice.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												First off, most of the reviews complaining about the optimization problems are no longer valid. That being said, there is no excuse for games these days especially non-indie titles, to be released as beta feeling as this game was. Unforunately that seems to be just par for the course these days in the industry and I won't let my personal feelings on that matter apply here.This game is a third person action rpg that uses a similar control set-up to the dark souls games and leveling system, but that is where the similarities really end. You do gain and lose your experience by killing/dying and must go to where you died to retrieve your exp. This exp does start to disappear overtime though, and you're not likely to retrieve most of your exp if you're very far from a checkpoint.The game's difficulty is not high, and most of the struggles you'll face are at the beginning, and very end of the game. The mid-game seems unbalanced and you will be mowing through most enemies.The combat is much faster paced than the Souls games and I'd say it's about a mid-ground between that and Darksiders 2's combat. They did an excellent job of making each weapon type feel differently and I feel the physics here surpass the Souls series by far. The staff weapons were incredibly overpowered during the time I played the game due to it's fast attack speed and good scaling damage. This could always be fixed in balance patches or mods however. The bosses were fairly underwhelming, but there are a good variety of enemy types which take different tactics in order to combat as opposed to the souls series (lock on and circle) method of killing just about everything which detracts from my enjoyment of that particular franchise. There were multiple ways to defeat a few of the bosses, and this allowed you to receieve special equipment upon killing them which I thought was a rather neat addition. Some of the weaker and early bosses become elite enemies that you will fight throughout the game as well, forcing you to adapt your combat style when fighting them as well as a group of lesser enemies at the same time.There are many collectibles in the game, and while the lore is pretty generic, it's still interesting enough to warrant collecting all the scrolls and finding the secret equipment (which there is a good number of).The games length was decent, and it could probably be played through 2-3 times in order to play different styles, and colelct the new game + gear, however, new game+ difficulty does not scale nearly fast enough in order for it to be a challenge.As a final note, I do recommend the game, and while it's not anywhere near perfect, there are some innovative ideas here, and I'd like to see a sequel one day improve on what worked, and change what didn't. This is definitely the best game this particular studio has made to date, and I think they should be supported for adding some creativity to this genre which is pretty much dominated by a single franchise at this point.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												While not leaving as strong an impact as Dark Souls did years ago, Lords of the Fallen has the same great Dark Souls combat, a brooding atmosphere, and truly spectacularly challenging boss fights. The only downside is the forgettable story and characters, but those are of little importance when the combat is weighty, precise, and rewarding. And being a single player game, you can't rely on that online co-operative crutch that can make Dark Souls boss fights incredibly trivial.Maybe a little too expensive to recommend at full price, but before you just pass it off as a Dark Souls rip-off, I implore you to give it a proper look. Because even if it has similarities, Lords of the Fallen is very much its own harrowing beast.

												[For those that are not so hardcore] Anyone on the fence about getting LOTF because of the flat out negative opinions by DS fanboys. Don't be / get it for $20 or cheaper. The combat system can be tighten up but not to different from DS. The story and npc's are ok,so far. And if you decide on DS, I suggest start with 3. The art is awesome.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												game is ok, not good but ok.Technical issues havent been fixed in almost two years of patching, which is a let down.The gameplay itself borrows alot from Dark Souls, which sounds great, but its not the best from DS, they took the worst and multiplied it.Every second enemy hides behind a shield, turning the game into a long drawn out series of circle strafing and dodging trying to get behind them, the other option for dealing with them is shooting them with the gauntlet for minimal damage OR charging into them with your own shield and using a very small window to whittle down thier HP with one or maybe two hits, rinse/repeat till dead.Some of the level design is nothing more than a series of corridors, which with the enemy mentioned above becomes one of the most frustrating things i have ever come across in a game, if you cant get around it or go through it, well ♥♥♥♥ good luck getting that over with quickly.About the only praise i do have for the game itself is the EXP system which rewards you more for enemies killed without using checkpoints, the multiplier on how much an enemy is worth goes up the more you kill without using a Crystal (bonfire) which would be awesome if the fear of random crashes, freezes and driver destruction didnt put the fear of losing all your progress in you, which makes this system useless unless you exploit it, which is way too easily done.I picked the game up for five bucks on a sale and cant really say its worth the money, if they ever get it working in a stable manner then maybe.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												This game cannot avoid being compared to the Souls series. So I'll split this review into two parts, first I'll describe it for those, who's not familiar with Souls games, the second part will be a comparison between LOTF and DS1+21. If you've never ever played Souls series, this part is for you.LOTF is a strictly single player game where you most of the time you fight with enemies and spend the rest on rare cinematics, dialogs and playing around with your stats and equipment. Imagine a Diablo game with direct control over a character and you'll get the feeling of what this game consists of. Right, this is a melee-oriented action game, not an RPG. A good news here is that the action part is great. It's not a Devil May Cry or Castlevania madness of endless combos and dashes, the fight here is much slower, but also more realistic. It requires (mostly) less reaction, but more thinking. The strategy depends greatly on a build you create (which can be changed relatively easy mid-game), but mostly relies on managing stamina and timings. Controls are good and the battles are satisfying. If not, just try another battle style, you can switch whenever you want.Some claim this game to be hardcore. What this means in this game, is that generally your build and gear do not limit you much, though having higher stats and better equipment definitely helps. You can beat any situation you meet with anything you have. That's great. But the thing is that each time you meet something new it'll try to make you invent a new tactics to overcome it. Bosses have different mechanics. Regular enemies get new weapons with different movesets and defense tools, locations change from corridors to labyrinths, etc. If you can't beat something, you just need to make a stop and ask yourself a question "How should I adapt to this using my resources?" The game is quite balanced in this aspect, even though it's not obvious from the first glance.This lead to the next aspect - punishment. The game is planned in a way to kill you. Each time you meet a new type of enemy you could die due to your old tactics not working. Each new boss requires some new strategy to take on him, sometimes you'll not be able to adopt from the first attempt, etc. You'll die, and you'll loose some of the experience that you've gathered lately, and the mobs will respawn. Other than that you don't loose anything at all, so that small piece of experience doesn't matter, you'll get it again from the same mobs.  The point is if something killed you, learn how to avoid it next time and then go kill it yourself. This is a point of the game.Story wise, it's average. It's enough to explain nicely why you go somewhere killing something, but is not good enough to keep you intrigued like other games do. Not a problem, this game is not played for it's story anyway.2. How is this similar to or different from Souls?I haven't played Demon Souls, so I'm comparing it only to Dark Souls 1 + 2 + DLC for both of them. I don't want to spend you time here as you know the basics, so I'll just provide the list of pros/cons+ Pros:Skill still means much more than stats and equipmentAlmost identical to DS  battle mechanicsAlmost identical to DS controlsArmor really protects you from physical attacks, not just slows you downGreat variety of weapons and armorsArmor comes in setsLight and heavy builds differ more than in SoulsSome regular enemies really make you change tacticsBosses have unique mechanicsCan get unique versions of already unique boss weaponsSide quests seem as side quests, not like hidden achievements you randomly accomplishBackstabs and parries still rockYou can go to areas where you are not planned to be yet early in the game. Harder enemies for better loot and exp.No cheap deaths and dirty tricks (woo, what a nice narrow roof, and what are that new types of enemies on the other side? New archers of some sort? Gonna come closer to see what they can do :D )- Cons:The story is much palerNo multiplayerPoise is not explained in game well enough (attack power vs poise)Battle seems slower (in reality it's not that slow, but it seems, dunno why)Less variety of enemiesBosses seem to be much easierVery little punishment for deathLess supply itemsThe world is not seamless+/- Different:"Bonefires" here work differently. No DS-style buffs on weaponsMelee oriented. Ranged and magic were planned for support mainly.Warhammer-like visual style instead of medieval-phantasy styleNG, NG+, NG++ only, each new plus opens extra options for development of your characterAction takes place on a much smaller area, but it's planned/detailed much better than in DSNo fast travel, but a lot of shortcuts, more like DS1Crafting is much simpler, but allows experiments as all materials can be extracted back againMy personla rant:No guesture to praise the sun? Seriously? C'mon devs, it should be added to all games!My personal opinion:This is not DS and not a clone. Don't expect it to give you more DS content. However it's still a singleplayer good game with very similar battle mechanic and a different risk/rewad system. If you liked playing DS without much coo/pvp, you'll probably like this. If you liked playing mi/maxed characted on higher NG+ playthoughs pushing over the edge or played mostly for CooP, I think you could skip this.
