content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												im going to first say that if you want to buy this game as a bloodbourne warm up (if you have a ps4) then id hold your purchase. when this game works properly it plays well. the problem here is that is crashes far too often and with the check point system this can mean losing all progress made after departing the last crystal. To put it in other words; its like the game crashing is the same as dying in game. if this incredibly frustrating issue ever gets fixed then I can safely say that this is a good somewhat souls style action RPG.gameplay: if you played the souls franchise this game will feel fimiliar if slower. the biggest emphisase in combat is timing, dont get greedy. there is magic in the game but dont expect it to be as varied as dark souls as there are only two types: your starting class spells and a magic gaunlet found later. there are 3 classes each with four spells to level. the class system however only appiles to magic, all other aspects such as equipment and weapons are talored to stats. so i you played a souls game you know what to expect there. most of the enemies in the game are well designed with a few frustrating exeptions depending on what play style your going for. the best fights in the game are the bosses not counting the final (which is a bit of a letdown), which demand cunning and strategy. you feel an emense sense of satifaction when you finally bring one down gaining a special reward after a victory. the only downside is that there are a limited number in the game. as for the common enemies, there are 2 that will quite possibly make you rage quit a few times. one has the ability sap health from you at a range as well as put defence thorns on himself (if you hit him you also hit yourself) and one you need to fing a jar containing an item to pick up or he will constantly regenerate at critical health. if the game balanced these out more it would be a better product but for now they are a head ache. and if your looking for an online aspect, there is none. story: not much to talk about here. the story is presented in a more traditional manor than dark souls but even so it realy only amounst to "dark god sends demons, kill them and save the world." the charater you play, that is Harkyn is your typical brooding tough guy with no personality what so ever they might as well had a silent protaginast. there are npc to interact with but they are just as booring. the only reason to progress in the game is to see all the cool armour sets and weapons in the game. there are instaces of player choice but you will often not realy care about the out come of these nor do they realy matter in the end. all in all the story feels phoned in. level design & art: symply amazing, the level design is brilliant in how sprailing and interwoven the world is. as for the art, this is one of the best examples of high gothic dark fantasy I have ever seen. weapons and armour all have this gloriously powerful and embolding look to them like somthing out of warhammer fantasy. the bosses have the look of giants clad in imposing dark armour brandishing fearsome weapons. if the developers put in as much effort into the bug testing of the game i would give this a recomendation. technical: this is where the game has problems. there area far to many minor bugs in regards to the sound and ui to count. there are far to many instances of enemies shooting trough walls or walking out of backstab animations or extreame hit box problems to say this is a must buy. but the one thing that keeps this game so low is the constant crashing. the biggist fear i had while playing this game was not from the towering demons but from the "lords of the fallen has stoped working" screen. when this happens, you lose all progress gained from the last check point including looted items. this is unacceptable for a game that wants to be this punishing. Summary: Lords of the fallen is a game that has the potential to but much greater if some key glaring problems are fixed but for now, wait for this game to be patched.

And why? Because this game is not good. Period. I didn't play a lot of Dark Souls to compare it to, but I can recognize a broken game.  I had huge expectations about this game, but now I really regret that I pre-purchased it. It's not worth the price. And I'll probably won't purchase other CI titles.Some reasons that I don't recommend this game (Warning: Spoiler Alert)- I lost the count of how many time I was holding the defense button with the shield selected, facing my opponent and with full action bar and, even with all these things right, I ended up receiving damage from my enemies and dying. - When you're using the gauntlet you can shoot at an enemy holding a huge shield that covers all his body and he'll take damage anyway.  - At the same time, you'll face some archers that will shoot fire arrows at you and, even holding a shield the whole time, you'll take fire damage. - The enemies (archers specially) can see you from far away and they'll hit you for sure. No matter how far you are. What else do I have noticed? The game crashes sometimes.* Do I have anything good about this game?Only that the graphics are impressive. But, what good is having great graphics if the game does not work right?If you have any interest in this game, wait for a huge promotion. That's my advice.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												This game was inspired by Dark Souls, with emphasis on the combat execution, sharp controls and tough enemies. I liked that this game is fair, so whenever you got killed, you were aware why that happened. Also the game does reward the more curious and determined players by having plenty of secrets, or several tougher side-quests. Your choice of magic and weaponry does affect the gameplay significantly, I found myself testing out different weapons against different enemies, because the different weapons have different moves. Your agility is also affected by how much you are burdened, so playing as a dual-knife-wielding rogue in cloth armor feels very different from a steel-clad knight waving a giant polesword. Graphics and enemy design are very satisfying, sometimes stepping into the grotesque, but nothing that breaks the atmosphere. Detailed textures, particle effects, good animations - all present. As you play along, you get to know each enemy type and how to beat them. But sometimes the bad guys synergize in a killer combinations and then you have to pull them from the pack and dispatch them one by one.Level design is also inspired by Dark Souls, using a hub-like system with interconnected locations, where you unlock shortcuts as you progress, eliminating the need for fast travel system, as everything is relatively nearby. This can lead to confusion at times, because the in-game objectives are quite vague, so once or twice I needed to take a look at a guide to see what to do next.Overall, I cannot avoid comparing Lords to the Souls. This feels like a love letter to Dark Souls, but is a good game on its own. The missing piece, why I won't be playing it over and over again, is the absence of multiplayer, which added so much to Dark Souls - observing, how others beat the boss, checking out different builds and movesets. Here you are all alone.Yes, I would buy it again.

Posted: January 3, 2015
												Disclaimer: In 30 hours of inflated gametime, I have experienced two crashes. My sympathy goes out to all who were not as lucky as I was. At the time of writing, I have completed the game as a cleric and I'm wrapping up my NG+1 mode as a Warrior. I had to cut a lot of content for this review because of the word limitation Steam puts on it's user reviews.++Let's start with the good stuff first. While graphics aren't important anymore in this day and age, because every single game looks gorgeous these days, it must be noted that Lords looks absolutely stellar. Even though my system can barely run it, you can clearly see that there is a lot of hard work that went in almost every single area of the game. The game doesn't look as magnificent like in the screenshots though, but don't let that dissuade you: this game looks superb.++I liked the compactness of the game world. While every single RPG of the last 8 years is trying to be the next World of WarCraft or Skyrim, Lords keeps it neat and tidy. Lords doesn't have many locations, and, logically, every location in the game looks gorgeous and lavish with detail. They all look like real, believable places. There is no silly padding, no unnecessary: "Harkyn! Please kill ten demon hounds and then return here!" questing. There is one main quest, about ten side quests and a neatly compacted game world consisting of a handful of locations for you to do them in. If you're great at the game, you'll just blast past all the content in a matter of a dozen hours and have seen all the locations. But I really like this style of RPG and it's a system I definitely I want to see more of. ++Honorable mentions: Awesome looking armor and weapons. They're a real treat to behold and there's a huge amount of armor and weapons lying around if you look hard enough. The XP system is also a real treat. It allows the unskilled player to grind himself XP, plainly making him more powerful versus other enemies, but since it costs so much to gain a level, I think it maintains a very nice balance, not allowing the player to become overpowered. Above-average soundtrack, very appropriate tunes that don't get boring or samey.--And now for the bad stuff. My problems with Lords (and the Souls games for that matter) are actually very simple and yet difficult to explain in few sentences. Souls, but especially Lords feel difficult for no good reason. For me, the very core of a game, the single most important aspect, the goal of any video game developer should be the endless quest of making sure your players are having a good time with the it: that they are having FUN. I would truly like to discuss both these games with a mature Dark Souls player and ask him or her to explain to me why he or she loves these kinds of games. I think I'm the only one who doesn't enjoy these games because everybody who hasn't slept under a rock seems to be enjoying this huge 'Souls'-fix. The argument I always hear is that in game worlds this depressing and bleak 'fun' is not something you should be experiencing and I find that to be such bullsh*t. You CAN have bleak virtual worlds and the concept of fun mashed together, guys. Ever played Deus Ex before? Or Bioshock? Or Wolfenstein: The New Order? Or hundreds of other games I'm sure exist with this combination. I do not find dying in a game fun. There are only very few and very specific games that get away with 'dying a lot' for me. Super Meat Boy comes to mind, and that game was magnificently designed. When said game is not created perfectly, dying over and over and over again should never, EVER be the goal of a developer. And yet, both these games have had developers behind them wanted, WISHING you to die over and over again.  --The reason why I claim that Lords and Souls feel difficult for no good reason is because when you look at these games they just seem like regular third-person hack 'n slashers where your character feels like he weighs a billion tons and moves ridiculously slow. Your adversaries can move much faster than you do and when they hit you it eats 75% (figuratively of course) of your lifebar away. The enemies themselves, however, take many, MANY hits to go down. Most have a shield that can block any attack coming from you, and the weaknesses they show go away in an instant, only giving you time to get in one attack if you're lucky. Surviving some encounters often feel like strokes of luck rather than skill. Both games often feel like the developers made these games and just tweaked the sliders for health bars and damage outputs. I've had enemies in the early hours of both games stunlock me to death over and over again, resulting in screaming frustration, something I haven't experienced in over a decade in a video game and yet, it's only games like these that bring so much depressing anger for a product that should be designed as fun. --Even when you get used to the combat, there are moments where you feel the game itself is actually taunting you. There are fat demons who are hunters in Lords who usually have a wild dog with them. When you try to hit the dog, it understandably usually dodges your very slow attacks. The hunter demon simply jumps backwards like a nimble ballerina and attacks you again. It defies all logic that so many enemies in Lords can dodge attacks that should not be dodged, predictably leaving you with more loss of health and an even bigger loss of stamina, until you finally push him in a corner and finally kill him.--When I say that the combat is slow, so is the magic. It would be quicker to educate me in magic in real-life than Harkyn doing his spell in the game, I'm not kidding. Magic, which usually plays a supportive role in Lords, is often essential for certain situations, providing you with a protective shield for especially hard-hitting enemies or a spell that stuns lighter, simpler enemies when they attack you. And when you are in dire need of a spell in the game, then you can kiss you sweet experience goodbye because you are going to LOSE. Not because of the mana requirement, not because of the decades of game time it needs to be cast, but because it's the kind of magic that cannot be interrupted. One hit, and it's canceled out, often leading to your demise, as usual. You almost have to know the placement of the enemies in advance BEFORE you cast your spell. --The 'bankable XP system' that people seem to be praising so much isn't that amazing or exceptional. Considering the amount of crashing this game does for most people, and how ridiculously easy it is to die in this game, I actually see no point to hold on to the XP you are carrying. The interests of the multiplier aren't that huge, and when you are early in the game you desperately need all the XP you can get. When the time comes you can hold your own in this game to let that multiplier go up, you already have all the tools you need to win the game anyway so the bankable XP system is rendered completely null and void in the end. --Extremely long loading times and frequent FPS drops.Closing thoughts on Lords of the Fallen: Lords of the Fallen is a game that is too hard for its own good, and would've been a million times better if it focused more on story aspects rather than trying the be Dark Souls: Viking Edition. I have completed it almost twice, but I know after uninstalling it, I'll probably never play it again. The reason I completed it twice was because for what little good the game did, it does it exceptionally well: I was nuts about the aesthetics of the game, the very idea of a Space Marineish character battling hordes of demonic creatures sent by God to annihilate the world in a snow-buried castle, and you are all that's standing in their way. I will be interested in seeing a sequel for the game that fixes my issues with it. Only buy it when it'is very cheap in a sale.   My specs:Windows 7 64-bitIntel Core i7 920 2.67GHz6GB RAMMSI 660Ti OC Power Edition

content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												I recommend buying this, but only at a sale. It's basically Dark Souls, but worse. Way worse. CombatThe combat is unresponsive and slow. Some attacks will hit you when they shouldn't. Rolling is unreliable. The developers clearly built the game with a Strength build in mind, disregarding the Agility build. Enemies with a shield will be a pain for you if you're an Agility character, unless you use Magic. You will get hit and it's gonna hurt, because you can't use heavy armor because of the roll speed. The fact that most enemies don't stagger at all if you use an Agility weapon will not help you. Despite all that, the game is pretty easy, but you'll use magic a lot. And using magic is even more boring than Melee combat. You get used to the enemy attacks quite quickly because there are not many enemy types.BossesThe bosses are uncreative. They all feel the same. None of them felt threatening at all. They're all slow and they choreograph their attacks like they're in slow motion. They repeat their 3 or 4 attack types over and over again until you kill them.Map DesignOne thing they got right, I believe, is the map design. It's all interconnected, and you open up shortcuts as you progress; just like Dark Souls. I give them props for that. We need more of these map designs.OST and StoryThe soundtrack and the story are terrible. Skip every cinematic whenever possible. Nothing else to say about it.Technical IssuesNow, my biggest gripe about the game. This game has crashed my PC at least 6 times. It consumes my CPU and GPU completely, at 100% capacity. When I first started the game, it ran like CRAP. Stuttering, low FPS, and inconsistent FPS at random points of the game. I had to spend hours trying to solve it. Testing out different graphic configurations, playing around with the driver settings, modifying .ini files. And to this day, I'm still not sure if I solved the crashes. I had to run the game at the lowest possible settings, except for Texture quality; when it shouldn't be that way, because I can even run Battlefield 1 at medium settings at over 60 FPS. Note that I'm writing this on 09/02/16, so they had PLENTY of time to solve these issues. Make sure to save everything in your computer before you start playing, and be mindful of your CPU and GPU temperatures, because this game might melt them.Final ThoughtsI am aware that this review was very negative, but the game did manage to entertain me enough to beat it and play it for 18 hours. I can't take that away from them. If you like Dark Souls, there's a good chance that spending $15 or so in this is worth it.Specs: i7 2600k, GTX 660 Ti, 8 GB RAM

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												READ: I havent suffered a crash yet however many others have, I do experience some frame drops that are annoying . This game DOES have technical issues that will hopefully be fixed SOON!!!!!!!The Game : In progress PRONE TO CHANGE: TLDR : Enjoyable , I have some frustrations regarding design decisions but overall im enjoying it so far.Story: You are Harkin a prisoner released to fight the "LOOOOORDS OF THE FALLENNN" I havent peered into the story that much and i am not that far into the game yet to give an in depth verdict . There are lore entries in the form of audio logs that appear as scrolls and playback the voice of a character in the world of lords - its a nice touch . The narrative is given to you straight and there is some loose information in the description of weapons that can give you some lore and background to the game but its nothing that has me really intrigued as of yet - TLDR Its nice that its there but its not mind blowing.Graphics - The game looks bootyfull and has a very WoW/Diablo aesthetic style which compliments badass demon enemies and bad♥♥♥♥♥armour and weapon designs. Its a pretty game if you like that sort of thing and there are some cool effects take the first boss for example as he unleashes flurries of greatsword swings and as he dances towards you with his vicious blade embers and particles cover him like a cloak of fireflies. TLDR : Damn bootyfullGAMEPLAY: You have a Health bar, An Energy bar (stamina) and a mana bar, the gameplay is very souls infact some people are calling LotF a SoulsLike experience for "casuals" ,  The game is basically a Role playing 3rd person Hack N Slash with a heavy empasis on tense fights and methadolical encouners to put it shortly ( Sound familiar?)  Overall positive , Im a MASSIVE Dark Souls fan and i cant help but compare the gameplay in souls to LoTF. Now lets get the bad out of the way first : The camera - Its almost as bad as MGR: Revengeances camera in the way that it will climb up walls and spaz out if you are against a wall, Its a gripe I have but it hasnt ruined the experience for me : YET.Bad No.2 : Bosses while not bad are SO FAR kinda generic and dont have much going for them: This is where i compare it to DkS1 . Bosses in DkS1 seen a lot of variation and had intriguing design to them which varied each fight take the four kings for example - You HAD to end the fight as fast as you could or else you would be murdered, this adds a layer of tension to the boss. ANOTHER few examples : the gargoyles - they introduced the player to a 2v1 fight and made you panic, Orns and Smough - same deal only after you killed one the other got buffed (also had amazing sound design and music to it) and my favourite (although DLC) Artorias - intensely fast and strong but the fight fitted the movement of the player perfectly and the boss had you constantly moving and dogding flurries of attacks building up to your counter attack. In Lords i have yet to see a boss that changes the formula of Dodge, Attack, roll away repeat (infact i tell a lie the Commander boss had a layer of multiple enemy fights to him in the form of some enemies that were easy to kill but he was incapicated for that duration.) Obviously DkS1 had more to the boss fights than the Dodge attack and roll away as i have given examples for (believe me its only a few i could have given loads more) and in LoTF i have yet to face a boss that gave me the same "Whoaaa" factor Sif or Gwyn did. - TLDR: Bosses are average but enjoyable however so far they fail to live up to the standard of a souls title.Bad No, 3 : So far the environment looks the same as it did in the first hour of play - a minor gripe .This is really prone to change however.Bad No. 4 Challenge: Now this is less of a bad and more of a personal taste for me- The game varies from hard to very easy and I found that the warrior archtype was easy mode while Rogue was hard mode .  - Now this can be seen as a pro since this is organic difficulty (Ill get to that later) Now my main gripes are out of the way lets get to what i LIKE.1. The core gameplay is fun! (and challenging when conditions are met) - The fighting as i said is similar to a souls game but is different enough to feel like LoTF , The biggest difference is that its VERY heavy and as a result it can lead to some very tense moments. You move slower than you would in a souls title and your heavy weapons REALLY, REALLY, REAAALLY feel like you are swinging a truck at someone - Personally i love this feeling on my greatswords and axes . 2. The enemies can really mess you up if you underestimate them although they arent going to pull a dark souls on you all the time.  Ive noticed that the overall feel of LoTF is a lot more 1 on 1 focused than a souls game which makes sense given the weight of Harkin.3. the timing mechanic - This is the thing that made the combat feel more rythmic than souls but in a very good way . basically : You time the swings of your attacks and as a result you lose less energy (Stamina) as a result i really like this touch - it rewards timing and makes combat feel smoother as a result.4.Organic difficulty is there but less than a souls title : For example you can forgo a shield to lose your block and ability to parry, Another : The three playstyles/ Classes Warrior (Heavy)  , Cleric (Medium)  and Rogue ( Light) all have different difficulty to playing them , Warriors are basically easy mode ( remember when i said armour matters?) You are tanky - VERY tanky you can take a boot to the balls and still tank through a hit although you move and roll like you are suffering from intese artheritis ,Clerics are slightly harder to play due to their armour being slightly weaker but they have a better roll and they have swag points for their armour looking cool as ♥♥♥♥ and finally Rogues - Weakest armour best roll, Now you probably want to know why they could possibly be harder to play- welp the rolling in this game has less I - Frames than Souls rolling and while the rogue roll does have I - Frames and is faster than the other 2 roll types you still take a massive amount of damage from a hit and you might get stunlocked to death - You have less margin for error and are punished more as a result.  Ultimately i cant say its exactly done amazingly but its done to an acceptable extent although some playstyles are less viable than others which is something that was handled well in Dark souls 1. 4. Oh man my hands - rewarded for risky playing : What I mean by this is that you are rewarded for not using checkpoints . You are given a multiplier for each kill you get which increases EXP by 1.25 for example and increases the more kills you get without dying - this rewards balls but since you skipped checkpoints if you die have fun getting back to your "Ghost" . Your "Ghost" is pretty much a bloodstain containing your exp - an interesting twist is that your exp depletes over a certain threshold of time and so you are pressured to retrieve your Ghost before you lose a good percentage of EXP- You are also given a passive regen when you are near a ghost which adds another layer of organic difficulty (Having a hard time with this boss? Just leave your ghost to sustain the regen buff AT THE COST OF EXP HAHAAH) .I have failed to mention other minor gripes and minor likes about the game but jesus my hands are killing me so give me a break.Sound : Mostly positive - Great OST really sets the mood , weapons sound amazing when you strike metal or rend flesh but I noticed that some instances just felt like a sound was missing or that during a cutscene certain sound effects were missing.Remember this is in progress so some things are prone to change for better or worse.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												You will find many people are comparing this to the beautiful and near perfect Souls series. This isn't a fair expectation or comparison, FROM has had 3 games now to perfect their formula and Demon Souls pales in comparison to 1 and 2 while still being great.This is the case with Lords of the Fallen, a highly enjoyable ARPG to fill the void between DSII's DLC release and Bloodborne in February. Lords manages to have a few unique mechanics that sets it apart from other ARPGs. One mechanic I really enjoyed was the kill streak mechanic, meaning the more enemies you killed without "healing" at a checkpoint you got more exp up to a 2x multiplier. This rewards patient and careful play and can really rack up exp quickly.There are some technical issues currently but they are working on it and have already released one patch to address this and in the future I doubt there will be issues. The combat is enjoyable and while some say much slower than souls, I would say it's about equal if you have light armor and possibly medium with a fast weapon such as a staff. I would say in a nutshell, it's worth the $50 and I am having a blast.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												I would've like to recommend this game. But as a game developer I value gameplay and especialy experience over graphics, this sadly wasn't up for it.A few plus points about the game: graphics, animations, music, sound effects, awesome looking armor (eye-candy) and I liked the storyline although It lacked a bit depth (not getting dragged into it enough).The bad part: the combat was bad. Enemies do not follow the same rules as the player, making everything tacticly impossible, resulting in ditching tactis and starting to run and button bash until the other was dead. Even physics rules don't always apply to enemies; a full charging shielded guy can rotate 180 degrees instantly and knock me back, fire arrows hitting my tower shield sets me on fire, enemies thrusting their polearm into my shield gives me damage (100% physical damage reduction and still got enough stamina), I could go on with these flaws but I won't; simply honor rules of physics or how we look at magic.If you played the Dark Souls series and loved their combat, don't think this will be like it. Well you can just ditch all your knowledge and the observating mindset. The thing I missed most was the feeling that I (myself) did it wrong when I died, falling into pits because of auto-targeting (not the lock-target) and dying because of physics flaws and animation/attack timing issues (for good and for bad) didn't really motivated me to hone my skills further (player leveling).Hopefuly the developers will keep this stuff in mind for their next game and if they do I would love to buy it.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												You will find many people are comparing this to the beautiful and near perfect Souls series. This isn't a fair expectation or comparison, FROM has had 3 games now to perfect their formula and Demon Souls pales in comparison to 1 and 2 while still being great.This is the case with Lords of the Fallen, a highly enjoyable ARPG to fill the void between DSII's DLC release and Bloodborne in February. Lords manages to have a few unique mechanics that sets it apart from other ARPGs. One mechanic I really enjoyed was the kill streak mechanic, meaning the more enemies you killed without "healing" at a checkpoint you got more exp up to a 2x multiplier. This rewards patient and careful play and can really rack up exp quickly.There are some technical issues currently but they are working on it and have already released one patch to address this and in the future I doubt there will be issues. The combat is enjoyable and while some say much slower than souls, I would say it's about equal if you have light armor and possibly medium with a fast weapon such as a staff. I would say in a nutshell, it's worth the $50 and I am having a blast.

												Excellent game; a lot of fun.Pros:- Good, responsive controls, similar to Dark Souls. You can parry and riposte against almost any humanoid enemy. Dodging is key.- Very pretty graphics.- Fun boss battles.- Replayable; not only is there a good use of the New Game +, but there are also three classes to play as, which have unique playstyles.Cons:- The fight in the trailer never happens.- Variety of enemies could be better.- Save points are a little too rare in some places, and too prevalent in others.All in all, a solid action game that a skilled player can appreciate.

												A pretty good game, with a big world, unique story, and enemies. The graphic is not the best but, it's not the worsest. The game is hard, but wait... it's not hard, it's annoying! The enemyes are often stronger than you, and when you wear lightweight armor they can kill you with 2-3 hits. And the shields... why not block the full damage of an arrow? I used the commander shield (tower shield), wich fully blocks physical damage. The flame arrow penetrated it, like I holding nothing, and did a full damage. The game sometimes fu*king annoying, but I reccomend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												I got the game in January 2015, after the initial disastrous launch with everyone having crashes at game launch etc.The game actually played  nice for the first 30 mins , until after the first boss:- I was running everything maxed out with Nvidia turbulence at 1080p, getting around 55-60 fps.- my system specs are i7 4770k , 16 GB ram, 2x GTX770 evga  oc edition 2GB in SLiAfter the bossfight and when the game transitions to the exterior, I started having huge random frame drops, going from 60 fps to 7-10 fps and the game became unplayable. This is unacceptable.I had to disable nvidia turbulence, disable cromatic aberration (ugly and terrible decision to include this in the game) and disable most post processing options to get back to 50-80 fps.Now my problem is that I get totally random crashes while playing (most of the time during boss fights, which is infuriating).The game itself has decent story and good graphics but suffers from a problem: It wants to be a "Dark Souls Clone". And it fails. If the devs would give the player the ability to save at any point, the game would probably last 3-4 hours max with all sidequests done, so this means the game is artificially lengthned by this gimmick saving point system.Also the camera issues while fighting are real and most often than not responsible for ridiculous deaths of your char and more wasted time.Fighting responsiveness is also close to none which on a fighting game really says it all. There will be plenty of times when your char will not respond accurately to the controls.I would recommend this game ONLY if you get it on a sale around $10 (or lower) , it's not a AAA title in any way with this kind of technical issues.At the current price point, in January 2015, please find something else to play as this game is somehow still in "beta testing".Peace,Sycharth

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												If this game goes on sale for 20-30$ i would say pick it up but as a full price package this game is frustrating (for the wrong reasons). Yes, it is pretty short but problem is the replay value really isn't worth while for couple extra items. I could go on and on but ill just make a quick pro/con list to speed it up.I only ran as a Heavy armored/Sword and shield spec with cleric spells. I tried other styles and didnt care for em.Pros-Very pretty graphics through out.Kinda a pro and con fact that a shield spec heavy armored run only seemed helpful for bosses which is nice but really crappy against some of the later enemies in the game forcing me to switch to a 2 hander for them which i didn't care for 2 handed weapons in game at all.Cons-Most of the shield enemies are very annoying due to fact its a good 70% shield enemies that like to turtle slows down the game alot.Spells...... for love of god they take so long to cast it almost renders them useless when really really need them most.The bosses are incredibly lame and simple even the last boss i killed on a 2nd attempt due to lame OP power he spams on you when sitting there thinking wtf is he doing.Story is very standard. None of the extra characters are fleshed that you help and main character is pretty cookie cutter kick♥♥♥♥♥take names later affair.More of a personal issue to me but Weapon variety seemed very low. Either greatsword this greataxe that couple swords and daggers with some hammers thrown in. Took while to find a 1 handed str sword which was the style i liked rather then slower heavy weapons.Overall if they get a sequel i would like to see what they bring to it but wait for this to be on sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												What I thought I got: A more action-oriented edition of Dark souls, with somewhat thinner story, but with better graphics and more fast-paced, immersive combat. Easier, and more linear story-progression.What I actually got: No story at all, uninteresting characters and flat voice-acting, run-of-the-mill "dark fantasy" world, with evil demonic tossers, invading a gothic world. Combat i more slow-paced than Dark Souls, at least to me, as there is barely ever an opening in your enemies guard, and it takes three years to raise your shield after finishing an attack. Also, half the time, you take damage or get stunned, even though you're rolling.No enemy variety either, bosses: Tall guys with swords.Normal minions: Guy with axe, guy with shield, guy with crossbow, idiotic  and blind abominations and then spiders.It feels clunky and unpolished, even though you figured out the attack pattern of an enemy, you will rarely get a proper chance to attack without taking damage yourself, because after an attack, your character goes to an idle animation before being able to raise the shield or gtfo of the way.Also, it took me 40 minutes to get the game running. And it still ran pretty bad, with severe FPS drops.It does show a lot of potential, but perhaps this is just the extent of the developers capabilitites. Taken into account their other releases, that is very likely the reason.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Aight.Pros+Gameplay is fun and engaging for the first hour or so.+It looks very nice and the physics everywhere adds to the immersion, that is until bodies start flying but that happens in every physics engine once in a while.+Music is alright, nothing memorable but adds nice ambiance. +Level design is decent. A lot of areas loop around without you even thinking about it.Cons-The game is way too easy. And I mean WAYYYY too easy. I only died on one boss due to a instakill spell but as soon as you find out how to avoid it he goes down as easily as the rest. Even the final boss is a cakewalk, he went down in a couple of attacks and did hardly any damage to me.-Some weapons are just blatently better than others.-Not a fan of the armor design personally. Armor is 90% shoulderpads.-Too short. I think I finished the game in about 10 hours or so. For a first run that is just way too short.The game is too short and easy to justify the 50 dollar price tag. Wait for a sale or something and if you haven't already played it, I recommend picking up Dark Souls instead of this game. It's cheaper, more challenging and longer than Lords of the Fallen.TL;DRToo short and easy.Buy on sale.Buy Dark Souls instead.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												The game is not horrible, however it is very frustrating (more so than usual) for any who have played Dark Souls. While the DS series has combat involving lots of dodging, timely attacks and timely blocks, the combat system in this game feels like trying to play DS with a tablet. The moves your character does are all just too slow and require too much time before you actually make them, making the execution of combat horribly slow. Combine that with a dodge function that doesn't help at all because most important enemies are faster than you, and can turn faster than you can roll out of reach and it gives you a game that thoroughly annoys the player by making you able to see all enemy attacks coming but not being able to do anything about it.4/10 (5/10 for anyone who hasn't played Dark Souls)

												First of all Lords of the Fallen is not Dark Souls 1,2, or 3. I came here with the same expectations, but I understood that I should stay away from that comparison so I could enjoy that game. So allow me to contradict myself here. Lord of the Fallen is like Dark Souls little brother. You won't die... a lot, but the game gets easier as you acquire better gears and learn your bosses (youtube,...). Gameplay has its moment where I was like "WTH"(clunky at time,camera,..) but I stuck with it.I had no issues, crashes, so I can't talk for those who encoounter them. Lord of the Fallen is not a bad game, good game, not great. It's just a break from all the genres I play, and I really recommend it.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												An excellent character action game that is no doubt the obvious comparison as a derivative of the Souls games. While it's overall length and difficulty seem to fall short of the challenge Dark Souls brings, I found it's changes to the formula refreshing. As a person who enjoys character creation, I would rather not be playing as Harkyn although he is far from the worst protagonist ever. That being said, the story doesn't seem solid enough to warrant his sole inclusion as the main character. I see no reason they couldn't have made the story fit to just about any created character with some generic alteration to dialogue. This is a personal opinion however and doesn't really mean the game is not thoroughly enjoyable. At the time of this review (10/31/2014) there are some techinical problems with the game, primarily a massive memory leak that pretty much causes it to max out memory usage on any machine. I personally have not had any crashes, glitches, or major roadblocks, but just some slightly poor performance overall. I hope that they see it through and find fixes for everyone. Aside from those issues, the game is marvelously gorgeous. I believe the texturing, color choices, and overall aesthetic to be more compelling than that of a game like Dark Souls, which is not devoid of color but uses it more sparingly. The spell particle effects, lighting, and tone variance are nothing short of breathtaking. Due to current technical issues I'd have to recommend this with caution, but when those are fixed it is a must buy for those waiting for Bloodborne or the next Souls game introduced by From Software.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												Dark Souls had a baby with a WRPG and it came out a little premature. I enjoy some of its design decisions but it's incredibly short (with DLC it took me under 9 hours), and I can only ascribe so much of that to my experience with similar titles. However, it has actual useful kb/m controls, and is a solidly programmed title on this platform, so that's a huge plus over the aforementioned's PC edition.I'm incredibly fond of its risk/reward mechanic: the longer you go without laying down a save/dying, the higher your XP multiplier becomes. XP functions as currency and level-fodder, but can be gained also via exploration, sidequests (yes! those exist in this!), and a "checkpoint" system which lets you choose a new respawn point/effectively quicksave, without resetting the multiplier. The multiplier only applies to combat-given XP, but that makes perfect sense, and it's not like that doesn't make boss encounters more tense as you try to take them out in one so you can turn them from one level up into four.Other positives: bosses all have a specific kill condition to upgrade their drops (which is hinted at in some of the lore or notes) for further risk/reward and playstyle changes, you get a shotgun (or just projectile weapon, but I liked using it as a shotgun) which can be used offensively or defensively if you want to make that your build, and the various spell schools allow for some drastically different play, if you want straight offense, healing, or a more subterfuge-based style. I'm all over this and I hope some of its systems get lifted for future titles, because apparently lately I only play evolutionary dead-end titles.

content:

												Heard the game was like Dark Souls, so I picked it up on sale. Thank God it was on sale or I would have been pretty upset.The graphics are amazing!+weapon and armor design+Scenery is just really well done+Monsters are well detailed+rewarded for doing something extra like an achievement for each boss fightThen the rest of the game must have gone to another studio that literally never played a game before and ruined the foundation.-Head bobbing, it's not a little bobble, but literally if you were on a sea ship in a violent storm head bob. You will get sick after a while and thier is no option to remove it.-Story line just like Dragon age 2-Character interaction is just wanky, like your characters eyes are looking up when talking to someone-Combat is a slower version of Dark souls 2 - but the game doesn't reward skill, Monsters (especially bosses) have 350 degree attacks that even when you dodge, the back hand swing will somehow hit you, stun you, and you get your face wrecked. I can't tell you how frusturating it is to use a two hand melee weapon in this game, insane damage if you don't get interupted by every little attack or when you swing at a boss and they move their 30 foot long limb and some how you keep missing it.I'm to the point that I don't even care if I beat the game which is very rare for me not to do. I' m just punishing myself with the horrible combat system, predictable story, and nausiated by the head bob.If you are a die hard adventure fan and have literally nothing else to do, wait till it goes on sale.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												A good Dark Souls-inspired action RPG... worth around 20$. Too tired to write a full review, so here goes tl;dr :Pros:+ Looks great+ plays pretty well + very nicely designed world - better than Dark Souls 2, even if much smaller+ side quests+ very realistic take on equipment weight - you can really feel it+ soundtrack+ freedom in exploration of the world+ brutal+ pretty difficult, not like Dark Souls, but pretty difficult+ while heavly inspired by Dark Souls, it's not a rip-off+ nice dark fantasy setting+ superb visual design of pretty much everything+ while there are "classes", they mostly mean spell sets - you can play the way you prefer regardless of what you chose at the start, because it's almost all based on your equipment+ varied equipment, a lot of choices+ an interesting take on experience - all enemies have a set of experience they give you. However, with every enemy you kill, your experience multiplier grows. It resets when you activate checkpoints and refill your health and potions. That means the riskier you play, the more experience and better loot you get. High risk high reward kind of situation. Cons:- hit detection is lacking, but I've seen worse- run of the mill story- even as Rogue you're like the tanky guy from DS, no FAST classes- only three classes- very few spells- almost all enemies are CQC-focused- conversation animationsPlayed for 12 hours, one playthrough, had a lot of fun.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Aight.Pros+Gameplay is fun and engaging for the first hour or so.+It looks very nice and the physics everywhere adds to the immersion, that is until bodies start flying but that happens in every physics engine once in a while.+Music is alright, nothing memorable but adds nice ambiance. +Level design is decent. A lot of areas loop around without you even thinking about it.Cons-The game is way too easy. And I mean WAYYYY too easy. I only died on one boss due to a instakill spell but as soon as you find out how to avoid it he goes down as easily as the rest. Even the final boss is a cakewalk, he went down in a couple of attacks and did hardly any damage to me.-Some weapons are just blatently better than others.-Not a fan of the armor design personally. Armor is 90% shoulderpads.-Too short. I think I finished the game in about 10 hours or so. For a first run that is just way too short.The game is too short and easy to justify the 50 dollar price tag. Wait for a sale or something and if you haven't already played it, I recommend picking up Dark Souls instead of this game. It's cheaper, more challenging and longer than Lords of the Fallen.TL;DRToo short and easy.Buy on sale.Buy Dark Souls instead.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Lords of the Fallen is a Dark Souls copycat, and that's good.  Emulation is the highest form of flattery, and Dark Souls is awesome.However.It falls short entirely in the combat department, which lacks the finesse that Dark Souls boasted.  Rather than ducking and dodging, for the majority of the game all you seem to have to do is lock on, lift your shield up, and run in circles.  It makes me ♥♥♥♥ing dizzy.  The bossesi n particular produce very few obvious openings and seem to have the same strategy as you - Hide behind their shield.  It becomes very drawn out.I thought Dark Souls 2 had repetetive and boring combat (in PvE that is), but this takes the cake.Couple that with the fact that your main character is a boring, generic space-marine circa 1200AD, and there you have it.  Decent visuals, but ♥♥♥♥ing boring to play.I am happy for what the game REPRESENTS, and that's perhaps more Dark Souls-esque games in the future.  But I'd hope further attempts to emulate Dark Souls will also capture the game's unique combat technicalities.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												From the authors of The Chickenator comes Lords of the Fallen, a game which is supposed to be a Dark Souls clone. Unfortunately the game fails to live up to the one it was based upon in every way, but most of all, the combat. The combat feels clunky, slow (even by Souls standards) and repetitive, with no rewarding and satysfying victories which feel rather hollow. The bosses have nothing to offer, all being virtually the same. The story is quite uninspiring and the main character is as generic as can be, with no option to create your own character at all.It really isn't enough to take some elements from the Souls games to mae equally good game, the devs seem to have failed to understand what makes the Souls series so great...Another disappointing release of 2014, which seems to be the trend. Maybe worth picking up for €15-20 to give it a try, but no more than that.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												The combat:The combat feels rather slow-ish but very impactful. The movement is very weird. Rolling feels kinda wrong. Even fast rolling  seems slow. Walking away seems more effective but rolling generates alot of invincibility frames. It's overall really strange. And in addition to that, there are no running attacks making boss fights a bit more difficult and anoying.Overall, not to shabby, not great either. Map design:The map design is a bloody mess. Alot of corridors look exactly the same and alot of objects blend into the enviroment.I overlooked NPCs aswell as the paths where i was supposed to go. Also, there is no teleport system. While you can acess the blacksmith from alot of different stations, you can't do that with the monk who enhances your potions. Alot of backtracking is involved in this open world game. Shortcuts open up rather often so its not to terrible but it's still no good. Also, you never really know where to go. Since all the paths look the same you run around in circles alot and if you get lost. That's beyond anoying. Its especially terrible in the later sections of the game.Item distribution: The beginning seems solid. They give you alot of variations that all look nice. However, at the later stages of the game they just throw at you plenty of epic weapons and armor that are twice as good as the ones you used before. That felt awefully off.Difficulty:It's solid. I managed to do a couple of bosses on my first attempt. Some not. Overall, still challenging.Graphics and Performance:The game performs finely. 60fps @ highest settings with a gtx 970 is nice to have. Overall it looks impressive. Only the hair of characters look aweful. Also, the game crashed twice within 10 hours and the voice acting is all over the place. Conclusion:I'm in love with this genre. And because of the lack of games that adopt this genre i am willing to overlook all of its flaws and play more of it. If you are like me, thirsting for more games like Dark souls then you can pick it up. If not, stay away from this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												This review is from someone who has not played any of the Dark Souls games. To start I think this is a good game and worth your time. The first 3 hours or so of the game I found frustrating. The combat seemed clunky, the game was confusing and lacked direction, the areas were confusing and there is no in-game map. After those initial 3 hours, I started to get the hang of the combat. I still feel it isn't super tight, but you start to learn what will hit you and what won't. You learn the attack windows and get the hang of the various weapons. The structure eventually becomes familiar and you understand how progression will take place. Give it 3 or so hours, you'll know if you like it by that point. I put about 15 hours into the game, and I think that was good for the price. I didn't really have a desire to go back and do New Game + but its there too. Pros: - Looks nice. I really liked the armor and weapon designs. - Lots of options for character creation and leveling. - Cool bosses. - Worked great on a controller. - Lots of secrets for those willing to explore carefully. Cons: - Combat feels clunky. It gets better, but still don't feel it is super tight. - Difficulty ramp was sort of reversed. Harder at the beginning than torward the end. Somewhat due to leveling, but also due to being better at the game. - NO MAP!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												So I played this game before I played Dark Souls. Here are my pros and cons.Pros:- Reasonable difficulty level. Each enemy has its own strategy to defeat it, but mistakes are punished hard.- amazing graphics- non linear world/map layout. lots of things to explore- no minimap or map in general. you have to look twice to find everything ( i have missed several treasure chests because of rushing through an area)- easy to learn, hard to master combat system- few class options but significant changes in playstyle ( equipping another weapon could feel like a whole new class )- advanced equipment system needs you to care for things like weight or poise- lots of non randomized gear- rewarding experience system ( the more enemies you kill without dying/saving the more exp you'll get from a kill)- the game runs very stable. i had no crashes or something in over 30 hours playingCons:- heavy backtracking. this whole game basically takes place in one giant keep and most of the doors are locked until later in the game- story is very standard. dialog choices are mostly irrelevant- magic is very buggy. it misses often - descriptions of trinkets are often unclear. look them up to see what they are doing- no new weapons in "new game plus" or aboveI had a lot of fun with this game and i recommend it to everyone who likes action-rpgs and overcoming challenges. And I also recommend to finish this game at least twice to find all items.edit after playing Dark Souls 2 SotfS: Lords of the Fallen is way better than Dark Souls 2. Much better graphics, better controls, better item customization, better overall fairness/difficulty.Only the length of this game is shorter, but i guess Dark Souls is only longer because you will die so often to bugs or unfair things like mobs hitting you through walls or somebody invading you as you try to catch your lost souls. buy this game - have fun

												TLDR:  Buy if you are desperate for a quick game that is heavily inspired by the souls series but BE prepared to be dissapointed because it is waaay shorter. AND NEVER BUY THIS GAME WITHOUT A DECENT STEAM DISCOUNT!    PROS : -good graphics. waay better than the souls games ( other than bloodborne ofc),- Great melee combat, more realistic version of souls melee. with actual weight behind attacks -  great character design -well designed levels -Great armor and weapon design   CONS : -WORTHLESS NEW game +!!!! AND THIS IS THE WORST OFFENCE. ONLY 1 new armor set in new game + Just ONE! ( if you guys find more equipment pls tell me. I for one cant find any )-no gameplay outside of the main story.  No exploration.-Flavour text makes no sense, I got a legendary sword that gets stronger with each kill and a weapon from another world.... both of them deals half as much damage as the weapon you get from frkn palace guards in the late game that in the lore , couldnt even kill 1 rhogar lord! but they wield weapons 3 times stronger!!! WTF-SPOILER !!! ......A certain point in the game sets it up so that you get to choose sides, but you actualy dont!  Near the end of the game you find out that your true enemy is someone else from the "god" you are supposed to kill. and instead of being given the choice whether to belive him or not harken belives him just like that! and procedes to fight against the entire human army! How does he know that the ghostly figure of his dead friend is not an illusion? -Plot is barely explained. as detailed by my rant below -World map size is small not even half of dark souls 1- game length is short. I only got to 20 hours because I forced myself to get the secret weapons of the bosses. which by the way are all useless as they rarely deal more damage than the weapons you get before facing them.- skills are there but barely needed for actual combat. I went warior but never and I mean NEVER needed to use my skills other than for solving an ocational puzzle. I got them just for the sake of being able to enjoy the warior class but I could and normaly dont use them anyway. they could have given skills more importance or impact in the game.-weapons and armor are recolored and reused. at first you Apreciate the good looks of equipment. then you realize that the late game version is a recolored version of that same armor. hell even the kinks and scratches are in the same place! WTF Long Rant version :-Bought the game on sale and went in knowing that it is a  subpar dark souls. and despite that I enjoyed the game, that is untill I got to new game + Frgn new game plus barely has anything + about it. only I found only 1 new armor set! WTF Kind of new game + is that? Oh and the story is even more vague than Dark Souls. Why is Harken a prissoner? What the hell was the opening scene about?  What was the hammer that he got in the opening cutscene? Why did the final boss turn into that? And the world map is barely as big as half of the Dark souls original map. Probablt only as big as Anor Londo + sens fortress + Seaths  castle. And though the armors in the game do look cool the problem with them is that the late game armor is nothing more than a recolored version of earlier armor pieces. And the item descriptions are fckn dissapointing. You get a legendary weapon of some sort that has half the damage of the weapons you get from the palace soldiers late in the game? wtf .

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												I really enjoyed this game. I actually played it back to back (two different play throughs) with using two different builds (Cleric then Rogue). If you are new to this type of game, i would recommend starting with a cleric build. These builds can take a beating and Protect spell will allow for ample healing later on the game. It plays like a Souls game (concept wise) but I don't think it is a fair comparison. I'm a huge Souls fan and appreciate the mechanics of the game genre. Many reviews state the game play is slow for combat. This is somewhat true. Most of the weapons are heavy and require good timing to swing, but this adds the reality to the fighting. Two handed weapons would be this slow in true combat. I think if you approach this game with the mindset of having a Souls experience, you may be disappointed, but if you keep in mind that this is more of a mechanics type of souls experience then you will enjoy the game. in my opinion the game starts off as hard as a Souls game but you eventually build your charactor high enough were you start dominating the game, unlike souls, no matter how high you level up you are still always vulnerable. in any case. Great graphics, cool environment (levels do connect like the original Dark Souls 1 levels), fun fighting. Story is OK. But this is a fun play (while you are waiting for Souls III :) ).  My only complaint on the game would be the camera angle. At time during battle the camera will move to an angle where some part of the environment would block your view. This was annoying at times but only happened a handful of times throughout the game.Enjoy

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
Lords of the Fallen was quite hypnotizing experience.Another game by Polish developers that came out in recent years that is of great quality and gameplay. Story isn’t too strong as this game focuses on fighting aspects and gameplay mechanics which were quite solid. I always wanted to go into Dark Souls series and knew that the gameplay there is brutal so I decided to try this game instead and was quite happy about it. It took a while to learn most of the fights especially with bosses and character build plays important role here. Initially I had tons of trouble with trash enemies until I started using magic together with the sword. The world is small but very beautiful and dark in its appearance. The save system is designed around checkpoints and game has great experience system.Pros+ Great boss fights that give achievements to drops if fought correctly+ Great fighting mechanics where you feel you feel the weight of your weapon and armor+ Great experience gaining system in which the more you kill without save the more rewarding it is + A ton of weapons and armor and run customization+ Great soundtrack and sound effects+ World is very beautifulCons- Forgettable characters who really do not add too much to the weak story- Some builds are very weak and you tend to spec character to one build only- World has very narrow passages and progression through it is very linearEven with some faults this game was difficult to put down even when I was playing titles like Fallout 4 at the same time.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												Great game. Very well done implementation of secret locations, obtainable items, and achievements. Ninja Gaiden fans should like this. I was impressed from the moment the game started. There was nothing special about the story but I did not dislike it. Game suffers from the inclusion of certain moves such as the shield charge and also magic spells that remove the challenge of the base combat. I would suggest that the magic system be reworked or removed in favor of being replaced by the magical abilities of the weapons being augmented with the faith stat. The most difficult battle may be the first boss which may also be the most balanced, fun and challenging; this is how the whole game should remain. This problem arises in part due to stat leveling and equipment balancing. Having the player characters stats and equipment determine the scale of the challenge might solve this.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												I don't write a lot of reviews, but it seems criminal to me that Lords of the Fallen's current Steam average is "Mixed," so I'm doing my small part to tip the scales. This game isn't perfect, but it's a lot of fun and I highly recommend it if you can catch it on sale (I bought it for $9.99). GraphicsMy PC isn't top-of-the-line by today's standards, but I was able to keep visual settings pretty high and maintain a solid framerate. The environments are beautiful, your character looks like a total badass no matter what weapon or armor combination you equip, the common enemies are well-designed and intimidating enough, the Lords are terrifying, and the animations are smooth. There was never a moment in-game where I was disappointed in the visuals, but I guess if I'm digging for a "con" here, I'd say that there wasn't a huge variety in the environments. SoundSometimes, music and sound effects can make or break a game experience for me, but this wasn't one of those times. The theme song is great and there were a couple of times when the music crescendoed while I was fighting a Lord (which was cool and added to the "badass" factor), but for the most part, I didn't notice the music at all in this game. That's okay, I guess. The sound effects were impressive, especially the growls and roars of enemies and the impacts of weapons against shields and walls. The one thing I really wished as I was playing through the game was that enemy footsteps were more audible. There are times when you find yourself navigating corridors where enemies are patrolling, and you should be able to hear that big dude with the axe stomping around just down the hall...but you can't. The voice acting was well-performed throughout the game. Some were better than others, but for the most part, these people did a good job (the most cringeworthy line in the whole game is probably Harkyn's "My vow of defiance!" in the opening sequence). StoryOkay, to be fair, the story isn't what will draw you into this particular game, but it is well-crafted, and so many minor details are revealed through picking up scrolls, which activate voiceovers that describe enemies, experiences, or locations. Even if you don't find yourself caring about the lore, you learn more and more through the words of characters that you haven't even met...and this is often a rewarding experience. You learn more about this world and its history if you care to, but it feels more alive, regardless. There were people here before you, and you get to hear their stories and connect the pieces for yourself. GameplayThis is it. This is why you start the game, and this is why you continue it...even after you've been killed 30+ times by the same enemy and you curse so loudly that you wake up your wife and fear for your marriage. The gameplay is just. So. GOOD. Okay, okay, with the boss fights, it sometimes feels less like you're exploiting weaknesses and more like you're just memorizing patterns, but for some inexplicable reason, it's still fun. Blocking, dodging, rolling, slashing, thrusting--it all feels so...right. Now, granted, it takes a while to get there, and it takes even longer if you're experimenting with different weapon types, but once you get the hang of it, this combat experience is beautiful. My first piece of advice: don't just spam your attack buttons. This took me a while to figure out, but each weapon type has a narrow interval after each swing (slash, thrust, etc.) when you should activate your next attack for a quicker follow-up, with less of an impact on your energy. You can even practice this without enemies around--just try out different combinations and watch your energy bar. It will flash with each perfectly-timed attack.Also keep an eye on your equipment and Endurance. If your Weight score is green, you'll move and execute combinations more quickly (this may be less important for warriors wearing heavy armors and shields, but I played primarily with short swords and daggers, so speed was extremely important). You have quite a few customization options as far as character development and equipment, but you need to keep a few things in mind. This is a combat RPG with a strong emphasis on melee combat. Your ranged attacks are limited to spells and your gauntlet, which also uses up your magic. In general, you won't be fighting or killing enemies from a distance. You also won't be collecting tons of loot and trading/selling items. It's just not that type of game. Personally, I was okay with that...lately, when I've played some other RPGs, I've hoped that the enemy I just killed didn't drop anything, because it felt more like work than play to be constantly managing my inventory.  There are runes that you can equip to weapons and armor, and there are attributes that you can improve as you progress, but this is not nearly as involved as, say, Skyrim or Diablo or even Borderlands.SummaryTo sum things up: Lords of the Fallen is an excellent combat RPG. Just know what you're getting before you get it. You'll die (probably a lot), but the combat is amazing, and you'll feel a sense of accomplishment with each enemy that you defeat.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												This is my first review but I just felt obligated to do a review on a game I passed up for so long.So i'm sure you've read in just about EVERY review/comment/description of LotF that it draws heavy similarities to the Dark Souls series. And it definitely does. But a key point I've only seen one other reviewer make is that it also feels just as similair to Darksiders with a bit of Shadows of Mordor. If you enjoyed any 3 of those games you should pick this game up (preferably on sale!). The Good, Neutral, and Bad + The difficulty curve is very well done, boss fights are about half as hard as Soulsborne bosses I'd say, but some of the regular enemies can be just as difficult and annoying.  Just make sure you're upgrading your weapons, armor, and stats as you go!+ Really liked the XP multiplier mechanic, sometimes it's worth it to go big and not use a checkpoint since the XP can go all the way up to being doubled what you'd normally get.+ I don't normally like using Magic all that much in 3rd Person Action RPGs, with the exception of Shadows of Mordor, but I really liked it here. You have regular spells which can buff/heal/distract and you also have what's called a Gauntlet, which is a cannon-like thing on your hand that shoots 3 different styles (Shotgun blast-like, Projectile, and Explosive/Grenade). More importantly you can imbue the different shot styles with elements (Poison, Fire, Magic, etc) which more likely than not will provide a great DoT. The fact that some of the Gauntlet shots go through shields of enemies sometimes proved INVALUABLE, as some of the Tower Shielded foes can be very hard to hit and provide a very small window to attack them after they do. Just imbue some fire to a projectile and watch those suckers burn behind their wall of wood. = Generic fantasy medieval setting, but the graphics are above average= Combat will be very familiar to any Souls vet, albeit a little clunkier, and without the fantastic multiple combos the series is known for.- My biggest complaint is the fact that there is no multiplayer at all. At the very least I feel like the game could of excelled from having a designated phased area where players could PVP, there's a good enough diversity in builds and playstyles to support it staying relatively fresh. Co-Op could of worked well too.- My second biggest complaint is just a personal one and it's more a QoL issue. There's no Fast Travel. You'll have to do a bit of backtracking in the game at some points (the game does provide numerous shortcuts though thankfully), and you might want to return to earlier levels to farm/hunt for items so the fact that there is no Fast Travel at any point in the game can be quite the bummer at times. I'm not asking for a Fast Travel for every checkpoint crystal, as there are numerous, but an option to port to the beginning of each major area would of been nice.Overall I'd give it a solid 8/10. No more, no less.If you've played the Soulsborne series to death and are itching for a fix before the GOTY 2016 holy grail masterpiece god-sent Dark Souls 3 comes out, pick this up.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												The combat:The combat feels rather slow-ish but very impactful. The movement is very weird. Rolling feels kinda wrong. Even fast rolling  seems slow. Walking away seems more effective but rolling generates alot of invincibility frames. It's overall really strange. And in addition to that, there are no running attacks making boss fights a bit more difficult and anoying.Overall, not to shabby, not great either. Map design:The map design is a bloody mess. Alot of corridors look exactly the same and alot of objects blend into the enviroment.I overlooked NPCs aswell as the paths where i was supposed to go. Also, there is no teleport system. While you can acess the blacksmith from alot of different stations, you can't do that with the monk who enhances your potions. Alot of backtracking is involved in this open world game. Shortcuts open up rather often so its not to terrible but it's still no good. Also, you never really know where to go. Since all the paths look the same you run around in circles alot and if you get lost. That's beyond anoying. Its especially terrible in the later sections of the game.Item distribution: The beginning seems solid. They give you alot of variations that all look nice. However, at the later stages of the game they just throw at you plenty of epic weapons and armor that are twice as good as the ones you used before. That felt awefully off.Difficulty:It's solid. I managed to do a couple of bosses on my first attempt. Some not. Overall, still challenging.Graphics and Performance:The game performs finely. 60fps @ highest settings with a gtx 970 is nice to have. Overall it looks impressive. Only the hair of characters look aweful. Also, the game crashed twice within 10 hours and the voice acting is all over the place. Conclusion:I'm in love with this genre. And because of the lack of games that adopt this genre i am willing to overlook all of its flaws and play more of it. If you are like me, thirsting for more games like Dark souls then you can pick it up. If not, stay away from this game.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Lords of the Fallen is a Dark Souls copycat, and that's good.  Emulation is the highest form of flattery, and Dark Souls is awesome.However.It falls short entirely in the combat department, which lacks the finesse that Dark Souls boasted.  Rather than ducking and dodging, for the majority of the game all you seem to have to do is lock on, lift your shield up, and run in circles.  It makes me ♥♥♥♥ing dizzy.  The bossesi n particular produce very few obvious openings and seem to have the same strategy as you - Hide behind their shield.  It becomes very drawn out.I thought Dark Souls 2 had repetetive and boring combat (in PvE that is), but this takes the cake.Couple that with the fact that your main character is a boring, generic space-marine circa 1200AD, and there you have it.  Decent visuals, but ♥♥♥♥ing boring to play.I am happy for what the game REPRESENTS, and that's perhaps more Dark Souls-esque games in the future.  But I'd hope further attempts to emulate Dark Souls will also capture the game's unique combat technicalities.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												I don't write a lot of reviews, but it seems criminal to me that Lords of the Fallen's current Steam average is "Mixed," so I'm doing my small part to tip the scales. This game isn't perfect, but it's a lot of fun and I highly recommend it if you can catch it on sale (I bought it for $9.99). GraphicsMy PC isn't top-of-the-line by today's standards, but I was able to keep visual settings pretty high and maintain a solid framerate. The environments are beautiful, your character looks like a total badass no matter what weapon or armor combination you equip, the common enemies are well-designed and intimidating enough, the Lords are terrifying, and the animations are smooth. There was never a moment in-game where I was disappointed in the visuals, but I guess if I'm digging for a "con" here, I'd say that there wasn't a huge variety in the environments. SoundSometimes, music and sound effects can make or break a game experience for me, but this wasn't one of those times. The theme song is great and there were a couple of times when the music crescendoed while I was fighting a Lord (which was cool and added to the "badass" factor), but for the most part, I didn't notice the music at all in this game. That's okay, I guess. The sound effects were impressive, especially the growls and roars of enemies and the impacts of weapons against shields and walls. The one thing I really wished as I was playing through the game was that enemy footsteps were more audible. There are times when you find yourself navigating corridors where enemies are patrolling, and you should be able to hear that big dude with the axe stomping around just down the hall...but you can't. The voice acting was well-performed throughout the game. Some were better than others, but for the most part, these people did a good job (the most cringeworthy line in the whole game is probably Harkyn's "My vow of defiance!" in the opening sequence). StoryOkay, to be fair, the story isn't what will draw you into this particular game, but it is well-crafted, and so many minor details are revealed through picking up scrolls, which activate voiceovers that describe enemies, experiences, or locations. Even if you don't find yourself caring about the lore, you learn more and more through the words of characters that you haven't even met...and this is often a rewarding experience. You learn more about this world and its history if you care to, but it feels more alive, regardless. There were people here before you, and you get to hear their stories and connect the pieces for yourself. GameplayThis is it. This is why you start the game, and this is why you continue it...even after you've been killed 30+ times by the same enemy and you curse so loudly that you wake up your wife and fear for your marriage. The gameplay is just. So. GOOD. Okay, okay, with the boss fights, it sometimes feels less like you're exploiting weaknesses and more like you're just memorizing patterns, but for some inexplicable reason, it's still fun. Blocking, dodging, rolling, slashing, thrusting--it all feels so...right. Now, granted, it takes a while to get there, and it takes even longer if you're experimenting with different weapon types, but once you get the hang of it, this combat experience is beautiful. My first piece of advice: don't just spam your attack buttons. This took me a while to figure out, but each weapon type has a narrow interval after each swing (slash, thrust, etc.) when you should activate your next attack for a quicker follow-up, with less of an impact on your energy. You can even practice this without enemies around--just try out different combinations and watch your energy bar. It will flash with each perfectly-timed attack.Also keep an eye on your equipment and Endurance. If your Weight score is green, you'll move and execute combinations more quickly (this may be less important for warriors wearing heavy armors and shields, but I played primarily with short swords and daggers, so speed was extremely important). You have quite a few customization options as far as character development and equipment, but you need to keep a few things in mind. This is a combat RPG with a strong emphasis on melee combat. Your ranged attacks are limited to spells and your gauntlet, which also uses up your magic. In general, you won't be fighting or killing enemies from a distance. You also won't be collecting tons of loot and trading/selling items. It's just not that type of game. Personally, I was okay with that...lately, when I've played some other RPGs, I've hoped that the enemy I just killed didn't drop anything, because it felt more like work than play to be constantly managing my inventory.  There are runes that you can equip to weapons and armor, and there are attributes that you can improve as you progress, but this is not nearly as involved as, say, Skyrim or Diablo or even Borderlands.SummaryTo sum things up: Lords of the Fallen is an excellent combat RPG. Just know what you're getting before you get it. You'll die (probably a lot), but the combat is amazing, and you'll feel a sense of accomplishment with each enemy that you defeat.
