content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												Great game. Very well done implementation of secret locations, obtainable items, and achievements. Ninja Gaiden fans should like this. I was impressed from the moment the game started. There was nothing special about the story but I did not dislike it. Game suffers from the inclusion of certain moves such as the shield charge and also magic spells that remove the challenge of the base combat. I would suggest that the magic system be reworked or removed in favor of being replaced by the magical abilities of the weapons being augmented with the faith stat. The most difficult battle may be the first boss which may also be the most balanced, fun and challenging; this is how the whole game should remain. This problem arises in part due to stat leveling and equipment balancing. Having the player characters stats and equipment determine the scale of the challenge might solve this.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												oK... I'm not gonna lie... this game is very difficult... especially for people like me who have never played any of the Dark Souls games... However it CAN be done... It takes patience... lots and lots of patience! The combat system is quite elegant in its own right, a very well thought out and complex system where weight of armour slows you down, weight of the weapon and whether or not you are yet strong enough to be able to swing it with one hand while holding a shield in the other... Stamina every swing,  block, parry and riposte costs you stamina... As well as agility, faith and whatnot. You cannot simply just run in to a group of Rhogar (the bad guys) and expect to win... Not even on easy difficulty setting. All the Lords and their warriors (although can eventually be slain with pure brute force), require different techniques into bringing them down... some techniques may take you a minute to learn, some may even take you 2 hours to learn... There has been times I have wanted to fist my monitor and throw my keyboard through the study window.The graphics on Ultra setting are quite beautiful, the artwork is fantastic, Dark and Gothic environments with enemies that look like they have come straight from the lower depths of hell... The art team should be pleased with their work... although the cut scenes were a little on the crappy side. The soundtrack is awesome... dark music that helps you immerse into your environment and sets the mood. The story line is a little lacking not plot wise but it's just missing something.The inventory and upgrading systems are very easy to deal with... you don't need to be some sort of mathematician to work it out...Overall... I give this game an 8/10... it loses two points because: 1 - The easy difficulty setting should be way more easier than what it is... for new comers it should be much more forgiving because some people (like me) enjoy playing games at a consistent pace first and then increase the difficulty when we play again... But hey No big deal... just practice practice practice!!2 - The story and cutscenes were a little lacking, but it wasn't too bad...3 - Would like to be able to jump without rolling when landing... A few little spots to navigate which proved more difficult then they should have...4 - A map in the menu screen would have been sensational... just coz sometimes I like to know where I'm going (especially the catacombs :/ )

number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												GOOD:- The combat feels Dark Souls style, and it's pretty challenging, so if you wanted more Dark Souls, you should try this game.- The story is interesting, though it's not as detailed as the devs promised it to be.- Lots of different weapons and armor, and overall good loot will keep you interested in the game.- It's good for you if you like Darksiders. You'll find lots of similar moods and design decisions in this game.- Graphics are great. It's not Crysis 3, but lights and particle effects look stunning. Character models are also good.BAD:- PC version's optimization is AWFUL. Frequent crashes (especially last few hours of the game), FPS drops on the high-end PCs, and so on.- Camera's behavior is really odd sometimes.- Although Dark Souls style, combat is very slow. You may find yourself annoyed by how slow Harkyn's moves are. Especially his rolls.- Locations often feel repetitive.- Bosses aren't impressive, they're mostly humanoid, and bossfights are not as satisfying as they should be.- Rogue style of playthrough is much more difficult than Warrior.- The game's too short, I've completed it in 13 hours.- Characters' lip-syncing looks incredibly stupid, lips' moves and voices don't match at all.VERDICTI liked the game, and I think it has lots of potential. However, first of all, the devs need to fix the PC version's issues (as I've heard, PS4 version has lots of bugs too) for the game to be playable and enjoyable. I'll be clearly doing a second run as a rogue or warrior after the game is fixed! I'm looking forward to that. As for now, the game is good, but it's not as good as I wanted it to be. And it's definitely not better than Dark Souls or Darksiders.RATING: 68/100. The game is good. Just good, that's it.If you want to read the thoroughly detailed version of this review, please visit:http://alessusreviews.blogspot.com/2014/10/review-1-long-awaited-piece-of-art.html#more

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												Anticipating at least a modicum of a poor man's Dark Souls, this f|ngerlicking $crotum stain was a great disappointment.Your character is a Gears of War-broadshouldered, slow-as-syrup-moving 60 year old guy with emphysema. While he's rolling you can make yourself a cup of coffee and watch the news and weather before he's back up. Striking a few times with a weapon leaves our hero gasping for air like a 400 pound chain-smoking runner. It's super off-putting and becomes annoying within a few minutes. Attacking takes forever and makes the combat dull as yeast-infected dishwater with the sparkle of a rotten cancer-mole.Inventory is unnecessary confusing, greeting you with all the warmth of a Calculus 3 exam, menus splattered on the screen with no order to it whatsoever. You're also stuck with a camera that is all over the place, even failing to adjust correctly as your character moves up and down simple stairs, or effectively zooming out when enemies press you into a wall and you can't see sh|t.Hit-detection is reminiscent of a drunken, back alley-circus knife throwing act; results vary from horrifying to laughable. Will this swing hit you/the enemy? Place your bets, gentlemen.There's no poise or stagger like you're used to from the Soul's games it tries to copy, not even a plunge attack is present, and it's obvious that a poor man's Dark Souls isn't even fitting this title; it's just a stinking turd dressed up in pretty colors.Many times you can't cue for example a roll action when you are getting massacred, even when you still have enough stamina to do a roll - which would often save you and make the fighting and dodging so fun in Soul's games. Nope, game doesn't register the button press until your character comes to a complete £vcking standstill. Which means you'll see over and over again that "I am going to be hit now, I have stamina left to do a roll, but the game won't let me and....I died again". Bvllsh|t like that would leave anyone p|ssed because it hampers your actions instead of actually letting you act upon your skill and observations during the fight. Instead you can't but stare helplessly at your character dying, while the stamina bar shows that you should be able to continue the fighting and then some.I ended up beating the first boss and I felt...irritated and aggravated. Like I'd had a gruesome day at work, been stuck in traffic for an hour, only to come home to someone b|tching at me for not having taken out the trash and having dinner ready. There was absolutely no sense of joy, accomplishment, or challenge. Just spite and resentment.And that's when I quit.Like the bimbo you met last night at the bar; the lights are on, but no one is home. So you leave an honest review on the toilet wall for others to see, and keep looking for personal entertainment actually worth a damn.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												If you'd like to see my (very condensed) stream-through of this game for the first time, feel free to click on the link below.  WARNING:  I swear frequently.


YouTube™ Video: FIRST WARDEN - Aazzdos Streams Lords of the Fallen (Blind) - PART 1 

			Views: 459		

			Lords of the Fallen is the first western Souls-like game that I'm aware of. How does it play? WATCH LIVE ► http://www.twitch.tv/Aazzdos FULL PLAYLIST ►...		

I'll preface this by saying that I'm a huge Dark Souls fan.  However, I'm extremely critical of all games that I play, including those dear to my heart like the Souls series.  All of my experiences playing this game are as a lightly armoured Rogue.  Apparently, the game is much different (easier) for heavily armoured Warriors, but I lack the experience to comment on that.  Scroll to the very bottom for the TLDR-style conclusion.REVIEWThis game is the only one in several years to crash on me.  My PC should be able to handle it without a hitch on High, maybe even Ultra settings, yet I was forced to turn off all the extra effects and go Medium just to make it playable.I don't remember anything about the soundtrack.  Voice acting is stiff, but sometimes to comical effect.The story is dull, the characters are forgettable and the writing is flat out bad.  I for one can actually appreciate the comedic potential of bad writing, but most people won't be so forgiving.  The majority of the story is told through collecting Audio Logs.  This is a nice touch, as it lets you understand the setting while you continue exploring.Combat is... all over the place.  Sometimes combat is fluid and makes sense.  Other times enemies will immediately counterattack and stun you without an animation, making you sit through free damage.  Many enemies have giant shields, and just like in a Souls game, they're extremely monotonous to fight.The pacing of combat is very slow compared to either Souls game, where your fast roll feels like something between a medium and fat roll from DS1.  I wouldn't say the change in pace is a good or bad thing, just different, and Souls vets will definitely take time to adjust.  Boss fights drag on with huge health bars and little variance in attacks, making them a chore after the first few moments.  They do, however, use a 'phase' system similar to bosses in MMOs, which can make the fights more interesting.  The game uses a combo system that encourages you to chain attacks together for increased damage and poise breaking.  This sounds great on paper, but in practice, you'll rarely be given an opportunity to use them because......poise is an absolute mess in this game.  When staggered, enemies will often break out of the stun to continue attacking you, which defies any sense of game logic.I didn't use magic to comment, but the gauntlet - a ranged magic weapon - feels extremely forced into the game, as if it was something for the devs to tick off their checklist.  Same thing with destructable items.While the graphics are very good and well detailed, the game world is tiny and forces you to backtrack so much that one can only assume there were budget restraints.  The game tries to emulate the joy of Souls shortcuts, but for every one that makes sense, there are ten that don't... or ask you to come back much later in the game.  On foot.There's really not much selection in weapon types, especially considering you'll be locked to your stat of choice.  Agility, for example, has daggers, shortswords and staves, along with one axe that feels slow and heavy like a Strength weapon.  You can socket items similar to Diablo games, but in similar fashion you'll be using the exact same gems every time to min/max.Finally, let's talk about bugs.  Crashes.  Animations being skipped.  Enemies standing still and attacking you from bizarre angles.  Invisible enemies.  Frequently absurd hitboxes.  And yes... this game has almost been out for a year.CONCLUSIONLords of the Fallen is a shorter, buggier and often nonsensical version of Dark Souls 2 but with superior graphics and an art style reminiscent of Warhammer.  While I wouldn't call it a terrible game and did enjoy my playthrough at least somewhat, there's a lot of barriers blocking the way for 'fun'.  Impatient players and Souls players in particular will be rubbed the wrong way by this game.  I cannot recommend this game in good faith simply because you can buy Dark Souls 2: Scholar of the First Sin for the same price, a game that is superior in almost every way.  Only consider this game if you can get it at a very reduced price and are prepared to muscle through bugs and poor optimization.  What I will say, however, is that it's very important that this game exists, because it shows that companies other than From are willing to take a shot at Souls-likes.  Let's hope the next attempt is a better one.

content:
Posted: January 20
												This is my unbiased review with the game as a lot of people seem to be comparing to darks souls for whatever reason; I've never played dark souls. This game is a garbled mess.For some reason some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of a developer thought that placing flavour text riddle style for all armor and weapon stat descriptions. This is insufferably annoying because here in 2017 i am unable to find a resource that tells me the set bonuses for specific armor sets. How is a player suppose to create a build when information is missingThe combat is clunky. Several required skill movements and combos aren't even shown to the player. For example, fighting enemies using shields is frustrating unless you use shield bashing.The recommended hardware on the store page is also lying. You would probably need at least 12 GB of ram because I had to set my paging file from 8 Gb to 12 GB to stop crashing every ♥♥♥♥ing 15 minutes; this is running only high textures and not ultra. The worst part is that the first day i played the game it was running flawlessly for 4 hours so no refund was possible for me.Price tag of $50 CAD honestly this game is a turd; this was the release price from what i can remeber. If you manage to get this game on sale for 15$ - 20$ CAD its okay if you really want to play this game inclsuive of all dlc and what not. But honestly this game does everything in its power to just annoy the player. Hidden stats, clunky combat, risk/reward that makes no sense (because you actually have to 'store' your earned exp to gain a higher loot drop rate and exp rewards) as it stops you from progressively leveling.Story so far is just cliche and main character is unlikable so its not even a good single player experience.I honestly wouldn't buy anything from this developer again due to the quality of this game being so poor.

content:
Posted: January 28
												I'm sorry but the frustrations outweigh the fun in this game. Too many enemies hide behind a shield and are only vulnerable when they attack or are shield bashed by you. You shield bash the enemy, hit them, have them recover from the shield bash, shield bash them again, hit them again, rinse and repeat. It gets so boring so quickly, especially since the game reuses so many enemies. The game's combat is too slow that it feels wrong. It's not fun when everything feels like it's in slow mo. Some weapons almost feel useless because they take so long to swing that the enemy will I have have hit and stunned you before you finish your attack.  And not one of the bosses is fun to fight. They're slow, repetitive and cheap. The only thing that makes the bosses hard is the fact that they do a ton of damage and stun lock. Being hard does not equal good. The camera's also a pain to deal with and the lock on is annoying since it doesn't move from enemy to enemy very well. Other than that, the armor sets are pretty cool and the areas look decent. If this game had faster, better combat, it'd be so much better.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												I want to reccomend this game to people, because the combat system is great, the art is great, the story is entertaining, and it really has potential to be a staple game. However,t he company just did not finish their product. The game itself has performance issues. No matter how low I turned the graphics down, the game had long loading times and would slide show occasionally. Putting it in borderless window mode helped this, but not completely. The also randomly crashes. Not frequent enough to be a huge issue, but enough to be annoying.Furthermroe, the game not only refuses to hold your hand but flat out doesn't give any direction what so ever. I loved the souls series for their lack of hand holding, but i always coudl tell whether Iw as goign the right way or not and generally understood the direction I was heading. LotF felt like I was constantly stumbling around. So many times I'm just trying to find the right way and no sure if I'm even int he right area then bam boss fight out of no where. I can't count the amount of times I just sat there a moment wondering where I was.Then there's the stat system which didn't make any sense no matter how you cut it. Most weapons had damage scaling. I put 3% on one weapon got a huge boost in damage, another weapon had a natural 9% and did half the damage. I don't even know what the percentages mean. percetnage of what? 3% of 29 strength isn't 40, so it can't be that. I have no idea.TL;DR I'm about to fight the last boss and: I don't know where I am, I hav eno idea how the stat systems work, despite having a solid gaming PC I'm playing on pretty low graphic settings, and I jsut saw a blue screen of death for the first time in ten years.

number of helpful: 15 of 31 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												If I could describe this game in one word, that word would be slow. My goodness, this is slow. The combat - which was clearly trying to imitate that of the Souls series - is painfully slow and difficult, and I don't mean that in a good way. The combat is passable when fighting one normal enemy at a time, but extremely tedious and frustrating when fighting more than one at once, and don't even think about fighting a boss. In the two I fought - one only just barely defeating, and this was the tutorial one - it was an agonizingly slow, tedious and frustrating experience. Every single swing is very, very slow, and don't even think about rolling, it takes several seconds, and you'll just end up getting hit. Everything feels like it's so weighed down and heavy it's almost impossible to move fluently or quickly. Anyway, away from the combat. The graphics are alright, with the environments looking quite pretty at times, and some good lighting effects. The more stylistic approach to presentation means it isn't as murky and ugly as the graphics of the Souls series. The characters look acceptable, though lip movement is below average, and not really acceptable in this day and age of gaming. Faces are a bit bland and lifeless, too. Story and characters, urgh... there isn't much. I'm aware I've only played a very limited amount of this game, but I feel no desire to continue. The story is very generic and takes itself way too seriously, with not a glimmer of humour in it. The characters spout generic and cliche fantasy dialogue that would not be considered above a B-grade fantasy novel. The Witcher, this is not. In my 1 hour of play, I barely did anything, yet was bombared with heaps of weapons, armour and equipment, so much so that I didn't know what to do with it, what was good and what wasn't, and what I should keep, so I never changed from the generic start-off equipment I had. Balancing things out over time would have been appreciated. I'm glad I didn't buy this game for myself - even on sale - as I just played it from my friend's shared library. The combat and gameplay range from passable Souls clone to downright bad in boss fights, the graphics are fine but nothing special, and the story and characters and bland, forgettable and generic. I'm being generous in giving this a 6/10.

number of helpful: 12 of 25 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												1. MASSIVE framerate issues. R9 290x and frames still drop to below 20.2. Boring and tedious enemy encounters. Blind guy, guy with big axe, guy with sword and shield, headcrab thing...GO!3. Immutable enemy physics. Is he swinging at you? You'd better not be also swinging unless it's a killing blow! Enemies are wholly unlikely to stagger against even strong attacks, even when they're NOT attacking you!4. Breakables breakables breakables aka roll over ALL the things. Not a fan of this at all. You'll spend minutes at a time just rolling around the room trying to break every object possible because it MIGHT have an item. Stop it, this is not fun. Even Zelda narrowed their list of rewarding breakables.5. Incoherent enemy physics. Back to this again. This is EXTREMELY apparent with the First Warden (5 minutes in), enemies often exhibit motion that belies their skeletal structure. Try rolling behind an axe guy as he swings at you. Watch as he spins around on a dime mid-step and mid-swing to stay on target. The player cannot benefit from this level of precision homing.6. Forgettable story and characters. Right from the start, I can't seem to care about even the hero, let alone the people he encounters. Maybe part of that is the terribly awful dialogue animations. Maybe they're just poorly written. Maybe both.This game tries very hard to be Dark Souls with a Darksiders feel. It fails at both of these things significantly. I wouldn't recommend paying more than $15 for this game, if you're into that sort of thing.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												A decent "Dark Souls copy", pretty short story (first/blind run ~15 hours) which involves getting lost a few times. Dying isn't a problem either since there are checkpoints behind almost every corner. The storyline is alright, but not good enough to read as a bed-time story. Enemy types vary a lot: tower shield sword dudes (oh man I love these guys), tall guys with battle axes, crossbowmen, blind zombie things who freak the ♥♥♥♥ out when you make noise, and midgets who charge at you before you get the chance to see them. These enemies are literally everywhere. But the bosses you encounter are unique and have their own special combat style which is cool. The graphics are great, but there aren't very many options to choose the game's appearance from. At times my FPS dropped roughly but returned to normal after a few seconds, this was bearable and had little effect on the gameplay itself. The weapons and armor have amazing details and looks to them, and there are a lot to choose from because, you know...Fashion Souls.  I personally spent a lot of time to admire all these fine pieces of art along with the scenery I came across. Miracles are alright too, I guess. Unfortunately there's only 3 per class (+prayer which acts the same for all classes).The areas look great and bring a certain atmosphere to them, and thus it is sad that there are just 3 main areas you spend most of your time in. I also spent a few hours being lost in these areas, which became somewhat unpleasant after a while.I think that's all there is to say. If this game gets a sequel, I'd most likely play it. Even though it doesn't beat Dark Souls in the gameplay or difficulty, but rather in frustration and unforgiveness, it still offers a very enjoyable gaming experience.EDIT (26.11.2016):Played this game again, this time on a desktop PC. The game is still a bit choppy in certain places, but that's because of the poorly made PC port. This time around I started the game as a warrior, and didn't really get lost since I still remembered where to go for the most part. The areas, enemies and most of the bosses still made me die plenty of times, but still not as much as during my first playthrough. Not because of the previous experience, but because of the choice of class and "build". It's still a pretty and challenging game.

												Played this game for roughly one hour and ordered a refund. To make it short: The game looks beautiful, the sound design is good, BUT the combat is clunky as hell and the impact of your attacks feels like you're fighting with a towel instead of a man sized hammer (funny thing: you're facing some barrels and a box and your swing misses all of them even though your hammer clearly passes through the objects). Rinse and repeat until your enemy is down or you are, because the delay denied you that crucial dodge.

												LOTF is the first of a new genre called Souls-like, and it's doing an okay job at it. There are some stupid mechanics that shouldn't be in a game that follows in the foodsteps of a legend like Dark Souls. There seems to be only one solution to whatever problem you might encounter, and it gets quite boring after a while. The best example I have is (spoilers!) the champion boss which does a charging attack where you have to either have a tower shield to cower behind or do a shield bash with a medium shield. This will result in you stunning the boss and you'll get a few hits in, then it's back to baiting out the charge attack. It gets old real quick.All in all, LOTF has plenty of good things going and if future games learn from this game, they'll do great. LOTF, however, did not do that great and I don't recommend it.

												Take a second and easily research just how many people have problems with this game crashing and you probably won't want to bother with it. Or at least you shouldn't, anyway, and are just foolishly wasting your money if you still do. I looked up how to fix crashing after a crash during the first boss fight and thought I had fixed it. Around 16 hours in, it crashed during another boss fight. At 23 hours in it crashed again during the tough side boss Keeper fight so I am done with this♥♥♥♥♥♥ It takes too long to have to get to a boss again going through respawned enemies even if I am really powerful, and boss fights are way too long to have to sit and do over again and just pray it doesn't crash again. Boss fights are extremely long so that's why crashing during them is such a game killer. Crashing is the biggest no-no that games can commit.A 7.5 out of 10 game beaten flatter than a sheet of paper by crashes0/10 should be refundable to anyone who owns it regardless of time played.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												As someone who liked the idea of the Souls games, but not the execution, I've been enjoying this game. It has the weighty, punishing combat but manages to not feel cheap. You're punished for making mistakes, but rarely killed outright, giving you some time to learn enemies' patterns. There are usually checkpoints a short distance before boss fights, so you don't have to spend hours upon hours just fighting your way back to them only to be killed again in 3 seconds. Speaking of bosses, I was able to explore and find a boss that seemed way too hard for my current level - I could barely scratch him. Satisfyingly, with some persistence and a total change of strategy, I wore him down in an epic, edge of seat, half-hour long battle and won the day.My (fairly minor) gripes so far are a slight lack of enemy variety and that the spells seem a bit limited and shoehorned in.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												How do I describe this game?  It is a horribly made game.  I know several people have called it a "hidden gem" or "dark souls lite" but I would suggest you play dark souls instead.  Lets start off with a break down of pros and cons.Pros1.  Graphically better for the most part2.  Sound is better3.  It has voice acting and tries to flesh out its story more directly than a souls game.4.  Linear for the most part, save for a few areas it is hard to get lost.  You just keep going forward and you will eventually find your way through most roadblocks.Cons1.  Uninspired enviornments.  You will spend most of your time trudging through dark areas or fiery areas.  Do not expect vibrant areas with variety.  You are either in castles, caves, or some mixture of the two.2.  Very glitchy.  I have seen enemies scale invisible ladders and get stuck in the sky box only to be unattackable save for magic.  This might not have been a problem if I went full magic, but using the warrior archtype I had to use one or two spells then wait for magic to regenerate.3.  The magic feels underwhelming.  I did go melee but I had a decent amount of faith, my magic however depleted far faster than I feel it should have to be effective.  This may be due to an armor penalty but I noticed no difference in magic consumption between heavy and medium armors.4.  Magic/Skills feel uninspired in this game, like they were tacked on as an afterthought.  Some skills felt outright useless and others felt like they were completely overpowered.  As a warrior I could pop rage and just power through most boss fights in one or two uses.5.  Enemy AI is terrible.  Souls games aren't known for great AI, but they are HAL 9000 whem compared to LotF AI.  Boss attacks are far to easy to bait out with encounters and offer very little in the way of challenge.6.  When you get lost, you get lost hard.  While many areas you can just head forward, there are some places where you can find yourself walking around for hours trying to find out where to go simply because the game has a very poor progression funnel in certain areas (I am looking at you Annihilator).7.  Combat feels sluggish and can swing from boring to frustrating very quickly.  Once again I am viewing this from the warrior archtype, but two handed weapons have such a long wind up and awkward attack angles they feel like Harken is more of a flailing idiot than any skilled warrior.  Some enemies would stand there and take it while others would dance around or attack endlessly giving you little to no chance to recover or plan a counter attack.8.  The kick is useless.  It requires a huge amount of stamina and I have yet to see it be more efficient at breaking a turtling enemy than just spamming attack combos and smashing through them.9.  Exploding enemies.  Har har you have a booby trapped enemy that explodes on death.  Real cute and I could let that one slide, except these enemies are usually very powerful and there are far too many of them in the latter half of the game.  There is a specific mage type enemy that can deal horrendous ranged damage, put up a damage shield around him, drain your life, and has an annoyingly fast melee attack that will knock you down.  The blast radius of the explosion will result in you taking damage more often than not.10.  Main quests have a tracker and sub quests do not.  This is just annoying.  If you don't want a quest tracker fine, but don't go half way.  Either let us choose the quest to track or make us use a log.11.  Quest NPC's can just up sticks and leave.  This may be a glitch, but when I tried to turn in human skulls for a quest the quest giver just decided he had better things to do and went fishing or something, because he wasn't there when I arrived to turn in.12.  Rune upgrade system feels tacked on.  You can use runes to upgrade your equipment, but don't expect any major changes to your playstyle.  Some runes will provide enough of a benefit to give you notice, but most are borderline useless.13.  The game is just a slog.  Nearing the latter half of the game I just wanted it to be over.  Playing it felt more like a chore and less like entertainment.  The fighting was uninspired, there is very little enemy variety (plenty of reskins though).14.  The story is about a generic as you can get.  You can smell the plot twist coming from a mile away.  Some side elements have no effect on the story.  The ending is a carbon copy rip off of Fallout 3 where specific choices are recapped.15.  Damage scaling makes little to no sense.  I had a harder time fighting the lightly armored twin swordsman rogues than I did fighting mages or heavy knights.  My armor offered no defense against their all melee damage and they could begin an attack after my starting frame and stun me with a single hit before I was able to connect.  In the latter half of the game poise becomes a useless stat as any human enemy can stagger you with one strike.The game is exactly what it is trying to be, a cheaply made knock off of souls trying to cash in on its success.  They took out a lot of the components that made the Souls games fun and shoveled in AAA game concepts that just hobbled our outright broke the experience.  Stats and builds become more important than skill the further you get into the game.  With appropriate skill and planning I can do a SL1 4 kings run and become a darkwraith, but in this game I just don't see that being especially viable.  Doable?  Yes, but I doubt you would get any enjoyment out of it.  The armor looks nice but at the same time it appears ripped clean out of Warhammer without any editing (the trinket flags look suspiciously like the mark of Chaos).  If you want to experience this game just get a Souls game, you will save money and derive more enjoyment from it.  Souls is a better designed game, hands down, and while it may appear "more difficult" the difficulty feels less hamhanded.  LotF's difficulty doesn't feel rewarding, its just one slogfest after another.I haven't had buyer's remorse this bad since Brink

The bad Dark Souls copyGame is still buggy 2 years after release. Few times during boss fights the game would simply crash and the whole fight would reset. Number of different enemies is really low and the game is really short. After you discover new region you will find out that it is connected to the previous region with a door that was locked earlier. This can be confusing at times when you don't know where you need to go next. Basically the game has 2 regions. Interesting thing is that some minions deal more damage than the boss and can easily one shot you.Controls are cluncky and the character reacts slowly to them. Often I would use normal attack and then dodge, but character would just attack once and then stand in front of an enemy like a moron and then get hit in the face by a heavy attack. Archer arrows are also funny, they fire it at you and you dodge or roll. And the arrow follows you like a heat seeking missile.After you get used to the fact that it is much slower than the souls game, you can have some fun with it, but those moments are few and far inbetween.

												The game has so much potential and so much it could've done right, but did wrong. Not going to be a long review that way people looking to buy can skim through the mixed reviews. First off this game is fun, don't get me wrong, the main mechanics behind the game are good. The optimization is meh, the art style is good, and the gameplay is decent.Where the game really fails is it's enemy design and how to counter these enemies. The game doesn't give you a choice on how to do something. For example early on in the game there's a shield enemy that can one or two shot you easily, break through your shield, and is IMPOSSIBLE to get around, the only way to kill him is to blast him with magic, there's no other way. The game itself is good but the bosses and enemies are too generic, the game needs artifical difficulty, not diffuculty that's going to ram you in the♥♥♥♥♥ There's a difference between a game with good challange and a game with bad challange, this game tries to give you a challange, which it does, but goes about doing it incorrectly.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												The path for your redemption is drenched in the blood of your enemies. Lords of the fallen delivers smooth combat, diverse arsenal and supports many different playstyles. Visually, it is an eye candy (and a very tasty looking one, too). With different enviroments, enemies and side missions, it keeps things enteresting and immersive. The problem is that it constantly kept crashing on me in multiple locations and on vastly different settings (ranging from ulra high to low), which is strange considering I have a GTX 780, i7 processor @3.6Hz and 16gb of RAM. In the end, I do recommend this game but would advise to wait a bit for some patches and slight AI fixes.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												I am really enjoying this game so far. The first thing I noticed is how well polished it is. The controls feel smooth and the UI is very intuitive. I so wanted to get into Dark souls 2, but I just couldn't. This game takes a lot from Dark Souls and, imo, does it better. It's beautiful and can be brutally challenging at times. Unlike Dark Souls, the controls for mouse and keyboard work well. I tried both a controller and M+k and I personally prefer M+K better. The sounds are well done and help to create an immersive experience. All in all I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a challenging and rewarding experience.

												Very artifical difficulty.Majority of enemies have shields which block 99% of your damage, who constant have their shield up and won't give even a second of opening after an attack, requiring cheap tactics such as backstab fishing and constantly using the decoy.Some enemies will even instantly turn around and hit you for 80% of your hp while you attack them from behind. number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												TL;DR - too many shields/10If you're like me, you played and enjoyed the souls games and are looking for something similar but with a new take. Keep looking this game is not for you.This game is not for anyone. It's not that it's too easy,  or nothing but a souls clone because it does add to the souls formula in good ways (I like the faith/magic system for example). The biggest, most glaring problem is the enemy design and boss design. The first boss is okay - not much too him but he's the first boss so w/e. The second boss is where you see the problem: f****ing shields. The entire fight is walking around him until he decides to do something because blocking negates 99.9% of all your damage. Who the hell thought this was a good boss design!? You wait. And then you deal about 1/15th his health, then wait some more. Then kill some adds, and repeat. It's embarrassingly bad. I killed him twice because the first time the damn game crashed on me during the cutscene and there's no autosave. I figured if this was the worst there was that's okay, I'll keep playing. OH BUT THEN. MORE. F***KING. SHIELDS. I do not feel like spending 5 minutes circling shield enemies waiting for a small opening to deal a small amount of damage to. This is BAD DESIGN.Don't buy it. Don't consider it. Move along.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17
												Whoever at Deck13 or CI Games thought that was an adequate difficulty for a first boss, after a pitiful tutorial and mere 5 minutes of proper gameplay, surely has some sort of a psychological disorder, autism or something else preventing them from experiencing the world from another human being's perspective.I see no evidence that they even playtested this with anyone who wasn't a game dev or a dark souls pro. There's challenging a player and there's punishing a new player who barely had time to get a grip on basic mechanics. In many games you wouldn't see such a boss until after at least an hour or two of gameplay, when the player had time to digest the basics and was able to concentrate on finer points of gameplay.This is a decent fighting game for masochists and/or experienced DS players (who AFAIK consider this not challenging). Everyone else should steer clear if you value your nerves or seek entertainment and not frustration in the games you play. This is just a cheap and artificial way of prolonging games.Too bad, could have been a decent experience.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												Summary: "And here I thought Dark Souls 2 was slow, but here we have the aptly nicknamed: Clunky Souls."Definitely would recommend a controller; the lack of camera centering button could easily have been incorporated like with Dark Souls' lock-on style: press to lock-on if enemy is present or centre camera if there aren't. Moreover, movement would be easier as the enemies seem to have a huge attack hit-box that can swing at almost 360 degrees.I was drawn into this game due to the combat style where, like Dark Souls, it was a little more than mere button mashing to knock out your opponent (see Skyrim).  And coming from Vaatividya's video I saw it could be an enjoyable game. However, I found this game to be quite unplayable.One major flaw when I first played this game was that it eats up so much memory and froze often. Annoyance is an understatement as I had cleared the first boss and a bit of the area thereafter, but had to restart the game only to find all my progress had been lost. Subsequent attempts at beating the boss again reinforces the name: "Clunky Souls" where I found fighting the game mechanics more so than the actual enemies.But speaking of enemies, the ones with the greatshield are the worst, including the bosses. Their numerous attacks leave you with little stamina after dodging to get behind them and get even a single hit in. They hit hard, have ridiculous defence and are difficult to punish. Of course, baiting the right attack to land the backstab is possible, but it's very tedious just going round in circles.My lack of gameplay time has been due to frustration with the game's performance and unresponsive combat. While it's flattering for it to be compared to Dark Souls, in my opinion, it's just more of a comparison of how Dark Souls does it much better. I really wanted to like this game because I wanted the sophisticated combat, but unfortunately it fails to give me another Dark Souls experience.EDIT no. 3: my opinion on this game keeps changing. While it can be enjoyable to an extent of exploration and combat, the enemy designs are terrible. For one thing, once they hit you, it's nigh on impossible to avoid their follow-up combo, draining both health and stamina if you were blocking, already making counter-attacks unlikely. And the second is that so far there are only a few enemy types in the game. They are introduced gradually but from what I've seen there are only about six basic types whose health and damage spike without warning.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												Do NOT buy this game. I spent nearly 3 hours trying to fix this game just to get it to work.First, the game freezes at the numerous adverts before the title screen even appears. Something involving non-windowed mode and smaller resolutions can help with this.Second, if you can get around that, then the game goes to permanent black screen at the title screen and just plays music indefinitely. This is because there's no saved game available, so it won't continue.Third, if you did not alt+tab out of the game during the load up, the game will crash on loading the save file. In some cases, the opposite is true and that alt+tab will cause it to crash at title screen. It's pot luck.Fourth, if you've managed to get passed all of that (which I did not), the game will then crash at any opportunity it can. Boss fight? Crash. Cut scene? Crash. Turned around too fast? Crash. Did nothing but stood still waiting for a crash? Crash. All of this from countless horror stories online I stumbled across during my search for a fix.The real problem is that these bugs have apparently existed since at least 2014. The fact the developer has not fixed this at all is a major concern.Since it took so long to try to fix this game (and to no avail) I'm now outside of the refund time. I'm hoping that the support team will at least factor in the broken nature of the game, but I can't say yet. number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												Do NOT buy this game. I spent nearly 3 hours trying to fix this game just to get it to work.First, the game freezes at the numerous adverts before the title screen even appears. Something involving non-windowed mode and smaller resolutions can help with this.Second, if you can get around that, then the game goes to permanent black screen at the title screen and just plays music indefinitely. This is because there's no saved game available, so it won't continue.Third, if you did not alt+tab out of the game during the load up, the game will crash on loading the save file. In some cases, the opposite is true and that alt+tab will cause it to crash at title screen. It's pot luck.Fourth, if you've managed to get passed all of that (which I did not), the game will then crash at any opportunity it can. Boss fight? Crash. Cut scene? Crash. Turned around too fast? Crash. Did nothing but stood still waiting for a crash? Crash. All of this from countless horror stories online I stumbled across during my search for a fix.The real problem is that these bugs have apparently existed since at least 2014. The fact the developer has not fixed this at all is a major concern.Since it took so long to try to fix this game (and to no avail) I'm now outside of the refund time. I'm hoping that the support team will at least factor in the broken nature of the game, but I can't say yet. Don't make the same mistake I did.Edit: The support team refunded the game for me, so I at least have my money back now. Looks like it will go on Dark Souls II instead.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11
												If you've played Dark Souls you'll find the setting and some of the combat mechanics familiar and kind of enjoyable. At first.However, any Souls veteran (or any Hack n' Slash veteran for that matter) will eventually see where this game falls short, as soon as he fights a few enemies:The combat (at least for Rogues) is bad.It's not immediately obvious, but to those of us used to the polished combat of games like Dark Souls or DMC, this kind of combat is unacceptable. The easiest way I can describe  the issue is that the combat is not "tight". It's basically many little failures in the combat system that make it a huge pile of trash when combined. TERRIBLE enemy AI, with enemies who have absolutely random recovery times when they perform an attack, turtling enemies whose shields don't drop with one kick but need many, and their attacks are as quick as a dagger, unreliable dodge/sprint, and the tracking, MY GOD the tracking. Enemies don't pivot with the movement, but they spin on an axis. Combined with their ridiculous recovery times they're just not fun.Maybe a sword & shield works better, but the Rogue I played with daggers/fists was just frustrating. And not in a challenging sort of way, but in a why-won't-you-follow-my-inputs kind of way.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												I really want to recommend this game, since I like the Dark Souls formula. But the more I play this particular game, the more I'm convinced nobody else can get it right. This game is difficult, but in all the wrong ways. The controls are awkward no matter what configuration you use, enemies will almost always break your attacks even if you wear the heaviest armor, and sometimes areas become impossible due to the sheer volume of damage you can experience from even one enemy by itself.Like I said, I wish more games would adopt the Dark Souls method of fighting, but that game punishes you based on whether or not you become skilled and able to utilize your abilities and equipment. This game is simply a grindfest where it's all about luck whether or not an enemy will go down in two hits or overhwelm you with an unlimited hit combo. I do not recommend this game.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												It's hard to recommend this game in its current state.  It's an incredibly buggy and unoptimized game.  Until the developers make serious strides in fixing these issues, I'd say hold onto your money.  This is mainly a consequence of the game's qualities just barely overcoming its shortcomings.  When the technical difficulties are thrown into the mix, those qualities have just that much more to contend with.  First, this game is very much in the line of Souls games.  The similarities between the two are numerous: no map, tough enemies, nebulous story, a weight-based movement system, and a leveling/checkpoint system very similar to Dark Soul’s bonfire-based system.  The similarities don’t end there but this game’s status as a “Souls clone” has been well-established.With that said, the game does many things well.  The art direction, while it has proven to be somewhat divisive, is quite good.  While some armor has been recycled, the sets look good and fit the world they inhabit.  The animations are fluid.  Hitboxes are generally well done.  Enemies are far more likely to hit you on the back end of their swings than in any of the Souls game.  Whereas in Dark Souls, many encounters could be beaten by simply rolling into enemies, the same cannot be said for Lords of the Fallen.  One must think about his rolls and the direction they will take.  The weight system is practically a copy-pasted system from Dark Souls—a system I’m much more partial to than the system in Dark Souls 2.  On the whole, the game is generally enjoyable to play.  Unfortunately, there are various issues that make it difficult to appreciate the game’s qualities.  Technically, the game is prone to crashes, the framerate is atrocious, and bugs run rampant.  I won’t spend time much time on the technical issues, though.  As for the game, frankly it’s too easy.  Most bosses are easily beaten on the first attempt.  Enemies aren’t too varied which affords the player enough experience within the first handful of hours to breeze through the rest of the game.  The developers try to curb this ease by throwing in, seemingly random, enemies that, while looking like typical enemies, have more health and do a great deal of damage.  Entire sections of the game, especially toward the end, feature enemies that do more damage than any boss in the game does while having a substantial amount of health.  This is fairly frustrating and inconsistent with the world the game is building.  Other issues include the targeting system, which is barely functional.  The magic system is poorly implemented.  Some spells are either poorly designed (Mimic which obscures your character and the enemy), only function a handful of times (Stab, which misses seemingly a third of the time), or are simply not useful (Prayer).  All of these spells also cost a great deal of mana.  My faith build (essentially a magic build) could get off maybe 2-3 spells before going OOM.  Add in the ridiculous cooldown that all spells have and one can hardly be faulted in wondering why magic exists at all.  I’m going to stop here.  The bottom line: the cons outweigh the pros in this offering.  Perhaps a few patches from now and a Steam sale later this game might be worth picking up.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Now that my perfomance issue have been patched oput i can finally recommend this game.It's a nice twist on the popular Souls sub-genre that's all the craze right now and is it punishing but fair.Unlike Dark Souls 2, LoTF features a much more responsive combat that expand on the Dark Souls foundation and combined with an impressive moveset of hand-crafted weapon (which there are a lot) and a variety of weapons creates lots of tension and fun to the swordplay.The game is beautiful and detailed, you can see that it's mainly a PC release, loading times are short and particle effects are damn impressive.It is not awfully long, but if you want to do sidequests and clear out the treasures it can easily stretch a lot, not to mention all the fun challenges and New Game+ modes.There's also seems to be a number of endings and the amount of secret sutff is refreshing. Weapons are damn sweet, and i must point out my favourite "Stain", you'll see why it's called like that after you equip it!All and all it's a fun and beautiful game, i recommend it, maybe even buy it off-sale if you think it's up your alley.The perfomance patches and new drivers fixed most of the problems people experienced, so it should be safe to play.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												I am not quite sure what this game is trying to be. It is kind of like Dark Souls, but not really, which is not exactly a bad thing. It is not like Dragon Age at all which is a bit of a dissapointment. And it is not like Kingdoms of Amalur either, even though I have heard it compariered to all three. However, this is one of the most boring, monotonus, and overrated games I have seen in years. And here are three reasons as to why.1 The Basics: gameplay, graphics, mechanics ect.For starters, it is a hack and slash job, meaning that the gameplay is going to be a johnny one note eventually once you hit a stride. This is not always that bad, Dragon Age could be argued as a hack and slash but it is so good that it over comes that querk. What lets this down for me on that end is the way you fight. Once you figure it out, combat is down to this formula, block, stab, dodge, counter attack, rinse and repeat, rinse and repeat, rinse and Zzzz, Zzzz. There is not other truely effective tactic regardless of class used, not that the classes are all that different mind you. It will not matter which you choose, I will get into this later but it is quite bland. To make things worse, you cannot choose what your character will look like so you are stuck with one ugly SOB with a shaved head, bad beard, and stupid tattoos all over his face. Give up any asperations of running for government office. Not that you ever see it that much, the camera control is pretty much locked up to you rear end both in and out of combat, the only time you can ever see what you look like is in conversation, which is only marginaly better than the one found in Kingdoms of Amalur. Not that this matters either because the graphics are a big let down for a title of this price and rating, and this only came out a little over a year back.2 There is no F***ing castor class!!!!!!!!In Dragon Age, I prefer mage, Mass Effect, Sheperd is a Sentinel, and I go full Battlemage in Kingdoms. Three guesses which class I like, hint it sure as little green apples ain't here. The class system here is a little confusing, you begin by choosing three "magics" that have nothing to do with magic in any respect with the exaption of prayer, maybe. Next you choose which of three weapon and armor types that leave you in the same place, heavy armor, big weapons, and no finesse. In total, there are nine classes that can be chosen, first time I went out I came up with Ranger,the second, Paladin, third, Brawler. All three felt exactly the same, no kidding, the exact same gameplay, I gave up on each just a few minutes in due to sheer bordom. If you are like me, avoid at all costs.3 This kind of thing has been done to death, ressurcted, and done to death again.Big picture, massive evil army of death dealing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s out to kill everything in sight. Dark Spawn, Reapers, Uruk, Dreadic, Thalmor, whatever, they are the smae thing now they are called the Rhogar. Top points for sounding like the noise I make when I have bronchitis. Long story short, the market for this kind of this is saturated to a point where it is raining bits of archdemon in my house. You would think something like this would work to seperate itself from the pack with something, but if you look at it closely, Lords is a Frankenstine's Monster. Bits of gameplay and stories have just been cherrypicked around from other games. It is official, the guys here have less imagination than the guys who draw the bodywork for Porsche.Final words: I am dissaponted, this game received alot of praise when it first came out and I was hopping for a hit I could rack up a couple of hindred hours on and stand around with baited breath for the sequel. Nope, I will not be playing this to 200 hours and I am not waiting for the sequel, if there ever will be one. This game had somuch potential and failed to deliver on every level. Thank you Steam Refund.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Anyone coming form any Souls game or games like Bloodborne and Dargon Domga will crush this game within 10hours. NG+ you are pretty much a god. Not that there is a reason to play after you beat it once. If you are bored and can find it for 10$ on a steam sale go for it, but don't wast anymore money than that.Pros++++Graphics++The story is very linear and simple, but I liked it.++I got it for 9.99$ on the x-mas sale, for 9.99$ it's a solid game.++The game does have "decisions Cons----Short as ♥♥♥♥. 8-10hours before you hit NG+.--No reason to play NG+. Yes you'll find some new items, but it's all useless at this point.--NG+ you are godlike, I finished NG+ in under 6hours.--No PvP, like Souls and BloodBorne. Or some type of interaction with other players like Dogma.--Being that it's 8-10hours of game play, you'll be spending most of that time back tracking. You'll spend at least 2hours back tracking. Because thats how the level design works.--16 total different type of mobs about 50% of the mobs you fight are swordsman or archers. It's the same♥♥♥♥♥♥over and over again.--Class design is linear, nothing new about it at all and very simple.--You'll crash, a lot. Sometimes every 5-10mins. When you reload the game, you'll be back at a checkpoint and everything will be respawned. When I think about it... That may of made about extra hour plus of game time....backtracking...I'm sure I could think of more problems with this game, but I'll say this. Any reveiwer saying this game "unfair" they are just bad at this style of game. It's that simple,

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												At the time of this review, I've logged 29 hours into this game, so I clearly find something redeeming about it, but it's hard to recommend.  I've reached near the end of the game with 2 different builds, and am stuck because the game is too hard and throws too many enemies at you at once.  Also, in case you're thinking "mad cuz bad", I've logged 1700 hours in Dark Souls and ~500 hours in Dark Souls 2, and never thought that about those games.The game is poorly designed in so many respects.  Voice acting, storytelling, story-arcs, level design, enemy design and variety, all sub-par, lots of bugs.  Some of those things are laughably bad.I have a weird relationship with this game, and may continue playing it, but is it something I could easily recommend to someone?  NOT AT ALL.  I would have to explain so much to that person about what they were about to subject themselves to first.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												Ok let's get out of our system that this game is HARD.Hard much like his inspirer, Dark Souls and Demon Souls, but a bit less that those at the same time.But the graphics are something so amazing that many of your deaths will come from distraction from looking at the details of scenery, enemies and items in the game world.This game is also heavy on resources that it requires to run, i've seen many threads of people unable to play it due to crashes and errors, luckily this never happened to me (yet) and im having a blast during my sessions.I feel a bit "meh" about the weapons and armors, either i was very lucky in the beginning finding a very good weapon or there's something wrong with equipment progression, nonetheless all the weapons feel great to use and have pros and cons based on the type, even tho i feel the enemies are always a bit OP even when changing equipment.Combat is very strategic, every hit and every miss counts, expecially the one you take from enemies, you have to be very careful in avoiding hits and striking your own as to not end up dead and with no potions.Overall the game is fun and good enough to keep you busy for a few hours (i've heard it's about 15h long, which for this kind of games is a bit short but it is still fun) if you like a challenge then it's a decent game with awesome atmosphere, it's like Dark Souls invaded Darksiders.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												Hard to rate this game in a world in which Dark Souls exists. I'd say it's not a bad game, but if you've played DS and loved it, this will simply not do. At all. If you just wanna have some fun or get an easy initiation into "souls" games, you can get this one instead and see if it's anything you like at all. Maybe wait for a discount. So, my review will be heavily flavored by Dark Souls references. Bear that in mind. This game wants to emulate this certain type of game play, so it must also be judged against it. Why a "no recommend" then? Too many bugs. Quest NPCs stopped working suddenly for example. Or simply disappeared completely...or never showed up. So annoying.Step by stepStory:Meh. Forgettable. Uninspiring. Despite having voice acting and cutscenes and audio logs, it's just not gripping. The characters are extremely shallow, the dialogue boring. In DS you don't have any of the polish here, no one really tells you about the lore, you have to find out most of it for yourself. And yet, the world is way more interesting somehow.Graphics:Pretty decent, especially nice lighting effects. Armore looks badass. YOU look and move like a badass. Animation quality is good. This is probably the biggest plus vs. DS. It doesn't look dated.Sound:Same thing. Sound is heavy and good. Voice acting is ok.Combat:You can choose between 3 classes to start with (Warrior, Cleric or Rogue) and choose 1 school of "magic" in your first playthrough. Magic is rather bland. Each school has 4 spells, which you gradually unlock via leveling up (i.e. killing stuff...over and over). Casting them, however, takes quite a while. For example, my Warrior was a "Brawler". He has 1 spell that amplifies his damage. This sounds particularly interesting in boss fights. The problem is that it's very risky to even cast the spell, unless the boss is currently incapacitated or whatever. And then you may miss your opening to actually DO damage, and when the next opportunity arises your "buff" has already worn off again. Meh.Regular combat is "fine, it's weighty, it's heavy or it's stabby stabby. There are you usual weapon types in the game, from swords, axes, maces and daggers to staves, great swords, great axes, great hammers and poleswords. Unlike in DS you will rarely find any non-special weapons, most are named. You will require either strength, faith or agility to wield them. Starting out as a rogue when you're a newbie is also perhaps not recommended. Warriors rely on strength and big weapons and shields. However, I found that most "big" weapons either need to be wielded in 2 hands (the game even tells you so) or are way too slow to begin with. In DS you didn't wield Ultra Greatswords until late in the game, here it is actually possibly, but just not feasible. The first of these weapons I got and actually liked was almost at the end of the game. Unlike in DS these big weapons often don't stagger an enemy as easily. Especially since SO many enemies wield shields and can pretty much block all your attacks. Most slower 1 handed weapons also have the nasty habit of taking too long to recover after a swing. I often found myself hitting a boss or enemy once after an opening, but not being able to block or roll away from the return strike.I've never tested staves, but daggers are really fun. You can dual wield them and then alternatively attack with left and right for massive damage and staggering effects even (which is funny that my cheap daggers go through an enemy's poise with ease while a greataxe has almost no effect. The real issue are shields though. The game differentiates between 3 classes of shields: Tower, Kite and Buckler. Tower Shields are massive and heavy and you can hide behind them to avoid damage...niche feature. However, they seem to be the only shields that can't easily be staggered. Kite Shields are smaller, but can also block 100% of the damage in theory. You also have a shield bash to try and stagger enemies. Meh. Best use I found is just run at an enemy, raise your shield and then knock him on the ground...Usually works on most enemies. Bucklers on the other hand are the only shield that can be used to actually "parry" enemies. Parrying seems to work pretty well on some enemies and not at all on others. After a parry you can counter strike for massive damage...You can also backstab enemies.Combat roll is also the same as in DS...fast, mid or heavy roll depending on your equipment burden. You never wanna be "fat rolling" though. Rolling is the best way to avoid damage, since it makes you temporarily invincible if you time it right.World:The world in this game is really small. It took me about 15 hours to get through, but I did lots of research as well, guess you can easily get through in half of the time, if you never back track and don't care about side quests or what have you. I'd say the "citadel" you play in is perhaps as big as the entire Undead Burg (without the catacombs) of Dark Souls, just a lot more rooms, since almost everything takes place inside. Very disappointing.Enemies:Not all that many, to be honest. You have some kind of wildly slashing tombie, a standard shield bearer, a big 2 handed guy and a sort of rogue with a buckler. Then these get upgraded later on. Later on there are a few more enemies like a mage, a ghost, and a few beasts. Maybe a dozen really different enemies. None of them are particularly flashy though. In Dark Souls every enemy had "soul", character. These here are just meh. They also have the annoying habit of continually trying to shield bash you, which leaves you open to a ton of damage.Consumables:Healing potions that get more and better later on, resistance potions and energy regen potions. That's pretty much it.Crafting:Non-existant. You get access to a crafter about halfway through the game, but all you can do is slot runes into armor and weapons...Stats:Only 3 main stats (strength, faith and agility) of which you only ever need to raise your main weapon stat and perhaps faith if you want to cast a bit, but it's definitely not necessary. Other than that only Vitality, Energy (for attacks etc) and luck, a stat you won't be levelling at all in your first playthrough (if you can stomach playing NG+ or NG++ after you beat the game).Bosses:Perhaps the most disappinting aspect of the game. The bosses just lack soul. They have great names such as "Warrior", "Commander", "Worshipper", "Annihilator", "Champion", etc. Almost all of the bosses are larger than life humanoids, but they are just interchangeable and boring and usually not challenging either. Some have small gimmicks you need to pay attention to, but most are just lackluster.Other stuff, the good and the bad:- Side quests are terribly, since they apparently bug out somethimes, and you have no way of keeping track of them- Some areas get cleared out due to story reasons, which is neat. Adds some persistence to the game world- Boss fights do NOT require you to run through the level again for 1 minute, the save portals are usually right in front of them.- Inventory is a bit of a mess, however, you can equip a whole set with 1 button press if you own all pieces of the gear.- Gear is uninspiring. Some have resistances, however, you can't really tell, how much better "1" resistance vs. "0" resistance is...- You can "bank" experience to level up later, meaning it's not all lost if you die, but if you do die, you only have a certain amoount of time until your lost xp starts to decay and eventually vanishes. On the other hand there are items that will let you immediately recover them.- No special items that in any way change the game- A weapon simply disappeared and was never seen again after a relog...- Only ranged weapon requires mana1 story DLC, but it's bad, just has you running around in circles and the boss is a total ♥♥♥♥♥.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												I tried this game hoping for a Dark souls style gameplay and a challenge. I would say just like dark souls, it has its challenge and fast paced gameplay, that with knowledge can become easy. I personally liked this game, until i started to notice the ground shake and the constant camera shake. This is where i ended up quiting. I at first didn't think the camera shake could ruin the game for me, but it really hurt my eyes to play for more than an hour at a time. I looked for fixes, patches, and in game settings, but failed to find a fix. As a result i have to give the game a do not play, until it has been fixed.

												Its a boring version of dark souls just get dark souls and save your money. It takes an hour to swing the weopons in the game. Picking rogue will fix that issue but you will die in one hit and do about 2-3 damage so it will take 3 weeks to take out a boss. As i mentioned just stick with Dark Souls series they are harder and much better to play. This is basiclly tesco value dark souls.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												After many many patches the game appears to be functioning finally. Staying solid 60 fps with a 970 GTX. There are still performance issues; I doubt they will ever be fixed given the nature of the dev response to on the community hub.There is also the pervasive issue of the presence of Denuvo. While no solid evidence have been presented regarding the assertion it had negative effect on hardware (damaging SSDs) and/or reducing the games performance, it is still a unecessary bloatware and affects only legitimate paying costumers.I bought this on release and was only able to actually play it now; thus the release price was not justified.Best buy it on sale.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												I bought this game thinking it was like the soul series. And in a way it is. But at the same time this game is so poorly balanced that its become impossible to enjoy. Im only several hours into the game and standard enemies can take up to 5-10 minutes to kill, and thats only if im hiding behind a shield and spamming spells while waiting for my magic meter to slowly refill. The enemies are INCREDIBLY powerful. I get that this is supposed to be difficuilt. I played through every soul game with no problem and really enjoyed it. I cant even play this game because of how strong the enemies are. One example is fairly early on, after the second boss there is one enemy RIGHT next to a checkpoint/health crystal thing. You cant kill him. He does over a third of your hp with one attack, which he spams in a 3 hit combo. One attack from him completely drains your energy if your behind a shield. He has an attack where he knocks your shield away and then immedietly attacks for over 3/4 of your hp. No way to dodge it its incredibly fast. And dont even think about hurting him.  Literally whenever hes not doing insane amounts of damage, hes hiding behind his shield. If you attack him here you do ONE point of damage and your weapon bounces off. Doesnt matter if its a light attack, heavy attack, one handed or two handed. Always one point. Always bounce off. And you cant get around him because the ♥♥♥♥er spins like hes in a roller disco. I thought this game was going to be good. And it would be with some more balance. But holy ♥♥♥♥ the enemies do way too much damage and take hardly any damage in return. Your also slow as ♥♥♥♥ing hell. Any weapon that isnt the monk staff has the slowest ♥♥♥♥ing attack animation in the history of video games.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Not bad for a Soul's-like. Of course people will compare to it as it is its main inspiration, Though i think the title is a little weaker in many points, starting with the level design and the sense of freedom and exploration. In fact, most of the game (at least what i've seen so far) resolve around corridors that leads to enemies that open doors to another corridors bound together by cutscenes and so it can feels slightly brainless.Also, the lore and story aren't a big suprise even if quite decent, but it might sounds dull if you grew bored of that sort of, like, regular heroic fantasy with muscles and big boobs. Characters are a bit cliché when not completly blank...Yet it's not a bad game. Combats are fun and the game does a pretty good job at giving you reason to just go through the corridors. At least if you're a bit curious.So yeah, i'd recommand it. Not at full price though. I think the game would be better at around 35$ or something.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												The game is really fun, what little I can play of it.  The combat is crisp and the customization is a blast.The one, and MAJOR problem is that it absolutely crushes a system.  I had a pretty decent rig that can play most anything and I'm willing to turn down some features here and there to make the game go....but this is almost unplayable.  I will have good 5 to 7 second hang ups every time I have more than one or two items moving on screen.  This means that in an action game where timing and mobility is key, I end up dying or missing animations because the screen locks up.Good game, but can't recommend it unless you have an absolute MONSTER of a machine, and even then, it may not work properly. This game needs optimized for the PC and I hope the developers are taking this into consideration.
