content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												ConsWill crash at random which is my main reason for not recomending to buyThis game performs very uneven you can run around an area experiencing 60 fps and when you turn the camera it can suddely drop to 20-30 fps and this happens often.Though this can and probably have been argued this game can be unfair I think. Monsters will be placed on certain spots making it impossible to avoid the first time you walk around that corner or something like that. and some of the monsters and even bosses hitboxes are too big so you get hit when "you clearely see that´s impossible" but as I said this can be argued.Gear and loot is not explained very well or clearely so you might end up having to go online looking for info. I  can see this as a  pro and a con depending on what type of gamer you are. Some of Dark Souls alure was that you where left to understand and take it on and learn through trail and error. It feels like Lord of the fallen tries to mimic that a bit with mixxed results.Sound glitchesDark Souls / Demon Souls must have been an inspiration for the developers I can see many aspects of wich it mimics but with less punishing gameplay. At the same time this games difficulty is somewhat random. Most of the mobs in the starting area don´t do too much damage but later in the earlier levels you come across some spitting spider thingies that will do an insane amount of damage only to leave a taste that this balance is looked over and unbalanced. Maybe the developers thought of it as a way of making the game feel difficult and to offset you, this can be argued.Lord Of The Fallen as a whole feels like a powertrip with a big stick swinging at you some times. The games balance seem overlooked or is passed on as a way of making it feel more random and as such more difficult, I would argue that this is a hit or miss, good game design or bad game design.Even though Lord of the fallen have many great strong points those are outweighed by the cons, the constant crashing and the random performance cuppled with what I think is really uneven balance.ProsBrilliantSort of my dream gameSomeone made the game I want to playAwesome character looks and feelLootLots of secret ways to unlock sections and more lootCan look amazingly awesomeBreakablesBoss battles but they are hit or miss fun wiseExtra layer of gameplay if you kill the boss in a certain way you get an upgraded version of the weapon it drops.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
Lords of the Fallen(patch 1.6) ReviewCTRL+FSpoiler filter, being informative&giving constructive critisismI am going to use spoiler filter to filter out both Story elements&gameplay mechanics but not all Gameplay mechanics - just advanced-mechanics.My review is ment to be informative about LOTF, give constructive criticism to to the devs. and not to ruin the experience, gameplay&story to the player.StartLords of the Fallen is an Action-RPG very similiar to Demon Souls - with more focus on story.StoryThe Story starts of with a battle between an unknown man with tattoos on his face & a giant monster. After the battle - the unknown man, with the tattoos, guides an elderly priest to Keystone('not sure if this is a flashback or...)Story - some actions One of my biggest complaints I have with LOTF is that it's not clear whether you are doing something good or bad with some actions. For example: I saw what looked like a bonfire - I lit it, got some XP, fought some monsters and I thought to myself ''Cool, I got XP. I did well :)''. Later on, soldiers in the Castle says ''Curse the moment we saw that beacon'' I'm like ''What? what are you guys talking about? oh well, it's probabley some random dialogue-nonsense''After I beat the game, I decided to look up info. for a different outcome. A piece of info. that took me by suprise was something that read ''don't light the beacon'' after reading that and seeing a picture of it - everything clicked & I was all like ''What? How was I suppose to know that?GameplayGameplay is very much like Dark Souls but a bit improved, especially a better roll-mechanic.Blocking attacks with your shield in LOTF is at times pointless. As a Melee-class - I found myself relying on wearing light armour, using a buckler that repels attacks and rolling.Some enemies(Tyrant) can penetrate through your shield which makes blocking sometimes pointless... Why can't rolling & blocking be equally as good?Speaking of Blocking in order to break down cracked walls, you have to shield charge at them. Why not just attack the cracked wall with your melee weapon?Gameplay - Dual-wield; no projectile-weapons? When it comes to Dual-wielding, You can only dual-wield weapons that are crossed on their portrait.The games' in-game tutorial tells me anything I can do the enemies can do too. If that's so,  why can't I use projectile-weapons as well?Gameplay - magic-system The magic-system in LOTF is good, with some flaws. No matter what magic-tree you choose - they feel the same. Any class can use the ''gauntlet''. You can choose one more magic-tree, but only after you beat the game... Why can't you choose another magic-tree while you play?Gameplay - XP-systemEverytime you kill an enemy, you will recieve an XP-multiplier&you can bank your XP. Why didn't the soul-games think of this?Gameplay - upgrades By the way, about upgrades, there is only one smith. You can upgrade your weapons, gauntlet&armour. I was kind of hoping that the smith could craft legendaries. Why can't you make legendary weapons out of the boss's... er... XP...? Instead, if you want ''something special'', out of the boss's weapon drops, you have to defeat the boss in a ''special manner''(there is a list online)GraphicsI love the games' art-style - it's a real eye-candy. For me, LOTF art-style is more apealing to me than the Soul-series.MusicThe games' music is ok. The music blends itself with the background. I barely noticed the music was there about 75% of the time, except when it came to bosses. Personally, the music isn't that memerable for Me.Pros and ConsPros:a very appealing art-style. I love the ''Dark-Fantasy'' atmosphere.simple combat; improved rolling-mechanic and XP multiplier.good story.Cons:there is no indication of how to get your desired ending. There is no indication if your actions, are good or bad. Just like the beacon part  you shield charge at a cracked wall to get to hidden areas. Why not attack the cracked wall? Blocking&rolling isn't equally as goodConclusion Before I get to the ''Conclusions'', let me make one thing clear: all the complaints, that I've pointed out through out the review, does not reflex how much fun I've had with the game. I had fun playing LOTF and I like the story of LOTF.Though I will admit, I too encountered annoying bugs/crashes. I think LOTF should've been released during Xmas 2014 or summer 2015.In conclusion, Lords of the Fallen feels like a prologue, a great warm-up start of an upcoming sequel. Can I recommend Lords of the Fallen? Yes. I can recommend LOTF to both parties: those that have or haven't played Dark souls.Deck13 & CI Games, thank you for develping Lords of the Fallen. Complaints aside, I enjoyed playing through the game. I can't wait for the sequel.What I'd like to see in the sequelprojectile weapons.dual-wield any weapon you want - even 2h-weapons.skill-tree -system.more NG+bigger story.blocking&rolling should equally as good.Normal-attacks  will unveil hidden areas.better magic-tree.memorable soundtrack.a better smith. I'd like to see a smith that can craft legendaries.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												I'm going to be comparing this game to Dark Souls since it is VERY similar to Dark Souls except not as good.  It's so similar that the controls are virtually identical when using the "alternate" control scheme.  Even the special moves have the same controls, ie parry/riposte, jump attack, backstab, rolling attack.The world is a decent size but pretty small compared to Dark Souls, and it all kinda looks the same.  Maybe equivalent to about 3 areas in Dark Souls.  The game does encourage you to go back to old areas to find new items and open doors that were previously locked, but when you go back most of the enemies are trivially easy to defeat so it's not that great.  The combat is pretty similar to Dark Souls too.  You can use shield+weapon, or dual hand weapons for more powerful/faster attacks.  I found the strength based weapons painfully slow to use, but the agility based weapons behaved a lot more like Dark Souls.  It also has the Dark Souls system of fatroll vs fastroll depending on what % of your carrying weight you are using.  The enemies have a decent variety although nowhere near what you'll find in Dark Souls simply because it's a much smaller world.  The animations and hitboxes are a bit off sometimes though.  You get used to it but it's nowhere near as "crisp" as Dark Souls.The game also has a system of weapon/armor upgrades where you place runes into slots, but a lot of weapons don't even have any slots for runes, and even the ones that do usualy only have one slot.  Because of this most of the runes don't actually make a huge difference.  Sort of like upgrading a weapon to +5 or something in Dark Souls, instead of being able to go to +10 or +15.  You can also add things like poison/fire/magic to your weapon but because most weapons only have one slot you are sacrificing physical damage to use those runes.The story in the game is pretty generic and boring.  That's not the reason I bought this game, but even so this is one of the areas where if differs from Dark Souls the most.  Dark Souls has a very subtle/mysterious story and lore that you could totally miss if you weren't paying attention, whereas LOTF hits you over the head with it.  Luckily there isn't a ton of dialogue/cutscenes but still a lot more than Dark Souls.This game also has no multiplayer at all.  No PVP or co-op which really limits the replayability of the game.  I would also say it's easier than Dark Souls as long as you have the right weapon for your playstyle.  Maybe that's just because I've played a lot of Dark Souls though.Whatever performance issues the game had when it was first released, they seem to be sorted out now.  The game ran perfectly for me.  I think it's worth getting on sale for someone itching for some more Dark Souls-like gameplay.  Just realize before buying it that you probably won't like it as much as Dark Souls.  I hope more devs in the future try to create games like this though, hopefully with some more original ideas in them too.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												I have really really tried to like this game.  The graphics are amazing however the combat system needs completely reworked.  In an attempt to make it more difficult they made it damn near silly.  Your weapons are slow and cumbersome to use even using rogue daggers your weapon speed is slower than many of the enemies.  The bosses are not hard in the sense they are fun they are hard in the sense it makes no damn sense.  You are standing in front, the boss starts a down slash to the ground, you roll.  He turns half way down to ground and drops the blade on you.  Pretty sure you CANT stop a full force down slice with a heavy weapon mid way and turn 90 degrees to the side.  Just sayin.  Make it fun, make it realistic, make it harder ONLY if it makes sense.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												I'd be lying if I said I don't find some enjoyment in this game, but every time I start to really get into it, something comes along and ruins it.It starts out quite promising, but soon you realise that all 10 bosses are nothing but an exercise in your ability to strafe around the arena and be patient as you whittle down their unnecessarily hefty HP bars. There are only about 15-20 enemy types(not including bosses) in the 15 hour campaign, which start to get very stale. The game is also filled with technical problems ranging from minor annoyances to infuriating crashes and random alt+tabs in the middle of combat.I would say pick this game up on sale, but it is definitely not worth full price. Dark Souls 1 and 2 have more content, and are better designed in general.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												The combat mechanics are wonky at best. Shield bash breaks the entire game (you can do damage as fast as you can click the bash button which trivializes everything). Playing without a shield, on the other hand, is unplayably annoying because the game loves enemies that block 95% of the time and you can't get past blocks without a shield (or at least I haven't figured out how, the kick is pathetic) - you have to wait until they charge, hit once, wait again, repeat. Boring.FPS is terrible on my pretty high-ish-end system (your mileage might wary) until I turned most of the graphical fanciness off, and it still dips at times. Plot is awful and utterly nonsensical, feels like they cut most of it out and forgot to fill the blanks because the dialogue makes absolutely zero sense at some points.It's not irredeemably bad - the combat has a great feeling of weight to it and is pretty fun-ish when you're not fighting shield enemies or bashing everything. Maybe they can build on the good parts on a later title. If it goes on sale for 5-10€ and you lust for a Dark Souls-clone and don't mind wonky mechanics, maybe.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												Step one: Take Dark soulsStep two: Add...  .abhorrent pc optimization regardless of setup  .random crashes  .this effort to expand the combat with combos (makes no sense in a game where you're meant to time attacks between enemy's because actually doing these combos is lengthy and clunky)  .a silly gulf between the effectiveness of armor (try and stay light more than two hours in and enemies will start killing you in two hits, and there's barely a difference between light and med mobility anyhow)  .annoying camera that leaps around mid combat and sometimes reverses the camera during critical attacks to show nothing but your shins wiggling and unable to see other attackers when you're done  .annoying tracking to your attacks that can send your character flinging himself off cliffs when you're trying to fight  .most painfully strained dialogue iv'e heard from a game in a long time that kills the little bit of mystique the game likes to pretend it has in spadesI really wanted to hop on the train of the "Souls Like" genre some people think this game is kicking off but it lacks in most everything that makes the souls series stand out from other action rpgs.  Even without the comparison its a messy effort in general.

												I'll start with the pros : beautiful scenery and music, gorgeous equipment so far, and... that's it.Lots of cons on this one : Dull gameplay, unfair combat system, no storyNo dynamism on combats, you have to repeat the exact same combos all over again, for every single fight.Enemies with shields are a nightmare, you simply can't attack them, and there is a ton of them at the beginning of the game. Maybe equivalent to about 3 areas in Dark Souls.  The game does encourage you to go back to old areas to find new items and open doors that were previously locked, but when you go back most of the enemies are trivially easy to defeat so it's not that great.  The combat is pretty similar to Dark Souls too.  You can use shield+weapon, or dual hand weapons for more powerful/faster attacks.  I found the strength based weapons painfully slow to use, but the agility based weapons behaved a lot more like Dark Souls.  It also has the Dark Souls system of fatroll vs fastroll depending on what % of your carrying weight you are using.  The enemies have a decent variety although nowhere near what you'll find in Dark Souls simply because it's a much smaller world.  The animations and hitboxes are a bit off sometimes though.  You get used to it but it's nowhere near as "crisp" as Dark Souls.The game also has a system of weapon/armor upgrades where you place runes into slots, but a lot of weapons don't even have any slots for runes, and even the ones that do usualy only have one slot.  Because of this most of the runes don't actually make a huge difference.  Sort of like upgrading a weapon to +5 or something in Dark Souls, instead of being able to go to +10 or +15.  You can also add things like poison/fire/magic to your weapon but because most weapons only have one slot you are sacrificing physical damage to use those runes.The story in the game is pretty generic and boring.  That's not the reason I bought this game, but even so this is one of the areas where if differs from Dark Souls the most.  Dark Souls has a very subtle/mysterious story and lore that you could totally miss if you weren't paying attention, whereas LOTF hits you over the head with it.  Luckily there isn't a ton of dialogue/cutscenes but still a lot more than Dark Souls.This game also has no multiplayer at all.  No PVP or co-op which really limits the replayability of the game.  I would also say it's easier than Dark Souls as long as you have the right weapon for your playstyle.  Maybe that's just because I've played a lot of Dark Souls though.Whatever performance issues the game had when it was first released, they seem to be sorted out now.  The game ran perfectly for me.  I think it's worth getting on sale for someone itching for some more Dark Souls-like gameplay.  Just realize before buying it that you probably won't like it as much as Dark Souls.  I hope more devs in the future try to create games like this though, hopefully with some more original ideas in them too.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
Lords of the Fallen(patch 1.6) ReviewCTRL+FSpoiler filter, being informative&giving constructive critisismI am going to use spoiler filter to filter out both Story elements&gameplay mechanics but not all Gameplay mechanics - just advanced-mechanics.My review is ment to be informative about LOTF, give constructive criticism to to the devs. and not to ruin the experience, gameplay&story to the player.StartLords of the Fallen is an Action-RPG very similiar to Demon Souls - with more focus on story.StoryThe Story starts of with a battle between an unknown man with tattoos on his face & a giant monster. After the battle - the unknown man, with the tattoos, guides an elderly priest to Keystone('not sure if this is a flashback or...)Story - some actions One of my biggest complaints I have with LOTF is that it's not clear whether you are doing something good or bad with some actions. For example: I saw what looked like a bonfire - I lit it, got some XP, fought some monsters and I thought to myself ''Cool, I got XP. I did well :)''. Later on, soldiers in the Castle says ''Curse the moment we saw that beacon'' I'm like ''What? what are you guys talking about? oh well, it's probabley some random dialogue-nonsense''After I beat the game, I decided to look up info. for a different outcome. A piece of info. that took me by suprise was something that read ''don't light the beacon'' after reading that and seeing a picture of it - everything clicked & I was all like ''What? How was I suppose to know that?GameplayGameplay is very much like Dark Souls but a bit improved, especially a better roll-mechanic.Blocking attacks with your shield in LOTF is at times pointless. As a Melee-class - I found myself relying on wearing light armour, using a buckler that repels attacks and rolling.Some enemies(Tyrant) can penetrate through your shield which makes blocking sometimes pointless... Why can't rolling & blocking be equally as good?Speaking of Blocking in order to break down cracked walls, you have to shield charge at them. Why not just attack the cracked wall with your melee weapon?Gameplay - Dual-wield; no projectile-weapons? When it comes to Dual-wielding, You can only dual-wield weapons that are crossed on their portrait.The games' in-game tutorial tells me anything I can do the enemies can do too. If that's so,  why can't I use projectile-weapons as well?Gameplay - magic-system The magic-system in LOTF is good, with some flaws. No matter what magic-tree you choose - they feel the same. Any class can use the ''gauntlet''. You can choose one more magic-tree, but only after you beat the game... Why can't you choose another magic-tree while you play?Gameplay - XP-systemEverytime you kill an enemy, you will recieve an XP-multiplier&you can bank your XP. Why didn't the soul-games think of this?Gameplay - upgrades By the way, about upgrades, there is only one smith. You can upgrade your weapons, gauntlet&armour. I was kind of hoping that the smith could craft legendaries. Why can't you make legendary weapons out of the boss's... er... XP...? Instead, if you want ''something special'', out of the boss's weapon drops, you have to defeat the boss in a ''special manner''(there is a list online)GraphicsI love the games' art-style - it's a real eye-candy. For me, LOTF art-style is more apealing to me than the Soul-series.MusicThe games' music is ok. The music blends itself with the background. I barely noticed the music was there about 75% of the time, except when it came to bosses. Personally, the music isn't that memerable for Me.Pros and ConsPros:a very appealing art-style. I love the ''Dark-Fantasy'' atmosphere.simple combat; improved rolling-mechanic and XP multiplier.good story.Cons:there is no indication of how to get your desired ending. There is no indication if your actions, are good or bad. Just like the beacon part  you shield charge at a cracked wall to get to hidden areas. Why not attack the cracked wall? Blocking&rolling isn't equally as goodConclusion Before I get to the ''Conclusions'', let me make one thing clear: all the complaints, that I've pointed out through out the review, does not reflex how much fun I've had with the game. I had fun playing LOTF and I like the story of LOTF.Though I will admit, I too encountered annoying bugs/crashes. I think LOTF should've been released during Xmas 2014 or summer 2015.In conclusion, Lords of the Fallen feels like a prologue, a great warm-up start of an upcoming sequel. Can I recommend Lords of the Fallen? Yes. I can recommend LOTF to both parties: those that have or haven't played Dark souls.Deck13 & CI Games, thank you for develping Lords of the Fallen. Complaints aside, I enjoyed playing through the game. I can't wait for the sequel.What I'd like to see in the sequelprojectile weapons.dual-wield any weapon you want - even 2h-weapons.skill-tree -system.more NG+bigger story.blocking&rolling should equally as good.Normal-attacks  will unveil hidden areas.better magic-tree.memorable soundtrack.a better smith. I'd like to see a smith that can craft legendaries.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Its a good game, but the difficulty is extremely high for really no reason. It feels like you are in an mmo raid instance and keep wiping on trash mobs over and over. Like no matter how much gear you get, you're constantly way undergeared for the place you are in, and it would be nice to have an option tone that down slightly. Most opponenets have a distinct weakness that you have to find on your own, and until you do you'll probably die several times. Quest objectives are very vague. All that said, the combat is good and I like the idea of fighting only one or two enemies at a time, instead of a swarm. It gives combat a layer of depth and skill and timing that other games can't have. I'd like to see this concept implemented in other games now that engines support complex blocking mechanics. 3.5/5

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												After 50+ hours of play and ready to kill the last boss and start NG++ I can say this game is epic.  If you enjoyed the Dark Souls' games then LOTF is mandatory.  Some have suggested LOFT is merely riding on the coattails of Dark Souls but I disagree.  Very much like Dragon's Dogma, LOTF proves developers can take the Dark Souls formula and add their own style and make a fantastic game.  Performance issues which have largely been resolved with v1.4 slightly mire the game.  Some users have claimed they suffer random CTDs, or the game simply won't load at all but I have not experienced these problems myself.  LOTF2 has since been announced and I look forward to CI expanding on the game world.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												First and foremost, Lords of the Fallen is an excellent game!  It's impossible not to compare the game to Dark Souls.  I would agree Dark Souls is a slightly better game largely due to its' setting, atmosphere, and gear crafting depth.  However, Lords of the Fallen is without a doubt a superb action RPG in a fascinating would with epic boss fights!Secondly, while the game has a reputation for bugs and stability issues, as of patch 1.6 I can tell you I only encountered a handful of very minor glitches.  If this concern has held you back from purchasing the game, then worry no longer the game is solid.Lords of the Fallen is a superior PC gaming experience over Dark Souls.  The graphics are nothing short of phenomenal by comparison as they really take advantage of the muscle power of modern PC gaming hardware.  Additionally, you can see by the patch history they care enough to fix bugs and stability issues, and not leave PC gamers with year old bugs (*cough* Dark Souls 2 durability *cough*).I'm hoping we'll see a Lords of the Fallen 2 complete with multiplayer in the near future!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												A Dark Souls-like game for those of us who have neither the time nor the patience for Dark Souls.Pros:+ Forgiving checkpoint system+ Balanced and fair combat+ Nice variety of enemies.+ Great graphics. Particle effects of Unreal Engine 4 in full effect here.+ Great soundtrack. Reminiscent of Diablo II soundtrack.+ Audio logs. A lot better than reading about the world and the voice acting is good as well.Cons:- Not the best optimized game, but the frame rate is steady. If you must have 60 fps, you'll have to turn down some settings. I'm fine with the 40-50 fps I get.- Story is pretty barebones. That's not why I'm playing this game though.- Camera can get wild with multiple targets in a small space like a hallway.Conclusion: I have tried to get into the Dark Souls games, and I respect the design of them but I simply can't replay the same content bonfire to bonfire over and over again. This game provides an alternative experience and is the first competitor/clone of the Souls games. I picked this up from♥♥♥♥♥for $15 and it is well worth the price. If you want to get into Dark Souls but would like to start with an easier (still difficult though) experience than Dark Souls, this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
 A far more better alternative to Dark Soul 2 When it comes to gameplay and fun, I think this title beats Dark Souls 2 in many ways. It is just sad, there is no coop mode. But instead it offers you the following benefits compared to Dark Souls 2:- far more better visuals. You don't have the feeling some state of the art visual mechanics are missing. Lightning, shading, animations. All feel more suitable- a better fighitng mechanic, even if you don't lock your target, you hit it with your strike. In Dark Souls 2 I managed it to miss a target lying right in front of me, cuz the devs force you to lock all your targets. Here you can even fight without this mechanic and beat your enemies. It feels far more intuitive and fluent.- a better and advanced dodging and evading system, so melee fighting feels a lot better and more fluent.- adequate keymapping options, you can map all functions to your desired mouse and keyboard buttons. In Dark Souls 2 e.g. all mouse buttons were restricted except, left right and middle. Generally both titles make a Gamepad dispensable and playing with your desired WASD config more fluent. But here you can map your keys like you expect it in titles released after 2010! So related to this, all functions like the character menu are accessible very fast; no workaround by using an inconvenient menu like in Dark Soul 2.When it comes to setting, I think both have their own and unique style. Lords of the Fallen reminds me somehow of Diablo 2 - Lord of Destruction. A snowy countryside is raided by some unfriendly creatures. Feels really great to pass the areas crowded by friends and foes.But even an alternative has its flaws. 1. I liked the design and ideas for enemies a lil bit better in Dark Soul 2. Sadly the devs messed this up with the outdated visual technique, animations. They should put more effort into visuals and usability like in Lords of the Fallen.2. The story and the background - it is very short. Could have been more content when it comes to enemies and locations.3. The mouse view has to be adjusted very, carefully, otherwise it is too slow / fast. But this can be done by the options very good.In the end I can say it is worth at least 10 bucks.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												First I would like to adress all that played just after release - game is now stable, great looking and many of the flaws mentioned in early negative rewievs are gone. It`s nice polished gem - smaller then Souls, yet with its own value. I played 3 runs - NG, NG+ and NG++ and if not for so many other games waiting for my attention, I would love to play more. Maybe that`s just the best thing I can say about Lords - I played 105 hours and still could play more. Anyway, try it guys - it`s worth it. Especially it shows on many sales now.SPOILERSNow some small advice for all who will play:- don`t use attribute shards as long as You can- collect them - they pass to NG+ and NG++- just before the end of NG invest 25-30 points in luck - 90% of  boxes will have attribute shard (instead of equipment You got on 1 playthrough) on NG+ and NG++ and with that amount of luck it took me tops 2 tries to get it from each box - some boxes have fixed shards and willl not change but they are few,- save Your Heroes Shard on NG+ and NG++ for later and respec (utilizing Your luck before final NG++ Judge fight can give nice edge),- don`t spend even one point of exp on magic ( I ended NG++ with over 70  unusable magic shards),- no matter how green You are in heavy armour according to Your burden meter light armour is always FASTER,- if You will try to get all achievements kill Judge with Keeper`s Weapon on 1st run while giving Adyr`s rune to blacksmith or slotting it into armour (On my 1st playthrough I simply rushed in the end to Judge so fast that I forgot about Ancient Labirynth, on second I got strenght based Gauntlets from Keeper but my 2H sword took one more swing too much and I was forced to do Labirynth again on NG++, take Faith based Greataxe, sloth it with Adyr rune as I already gave it to Blacksmith on NG, and then used it on Armour on NG+ - well killing him with faith based 350 dmg Greataxe was doable but not easy ;) )- gauntlet, even with circa 120 Faith is not powerfull enough to be Your first weapon- Mimic is Your best friend- take Your time and enjoy the views :)

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												Lords of The Fallen is Action RPG isnpired off the Dark Souls Series, as so it seams. Lords of the Fallen takes certain aspects from Dark Souls that made it great, puts it into Lords of the Fallen, flips it on its side, and attemtps to make it better but in a different way. They succeed in some aspects and fails in others, however, Lords of the Fallen is a fun experience and should not be missed if a sale comes by your way.PROS: Great combat, feels slow at first but after an hour or two it feels more naturalParrying that feels satisfactoryHard but rewarding bossfights Very Unique armor sets and rewardsThe player gets rewarded for taking risks with the games unique risk and reward systemCONS:When preforming a backstab animation or parry, the camera will change to an awkward position.Some boss fights may have difficult movesets, but some fights are only difficult because of an INSANE healthbarCRASHES occur no matter if you have a amazing pc or not. ( I have crashed a decent amount and I have a powerful PC.The game is not very well optimized which lead to the crashes.Lots of random glitches and bugs that just make the game feel unpolished.The level design left me wanting more, instead I just kept revisitng the same areas.There are several enemies in the game that are invincible all the time and they suck, until you find a way to make them vulnurable which is possible for all those type of enemies, except for one in particular. The one you can never kill ( at least I couldn't and I did almost everything optional) is very very agrivating, especially in small halways.Verdict:Lords of the Fallen in the end is a well made game. It did not fail and is not perfect However, it suprised the gaming community with a difficult, rewarding, yet a fresh new experience that is one of the first games to take inspiration off the Souls genere and succeed. If you have the spare cash to pick up Lords of the Fallen, do so, but preferabley at a reduced price in my humble opinion.Rating : 8

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												My first note is that the game is very short. I beat it in 8 hours of playtime. No multiplayer, limited sidequests that are very vague and confusing levels had me getting mixed up all over the place. There were not very many bosses and they were all pretty easy. Only two bosses actually killed me.This game is NOT Dark Souls. Not even close. It uses dark souls combat mechanics like health potions that refill at checkpoints, dodge rolls, and left hand/right hand on LB/LT and RB/RT. The same mechanics are in it but the feel is much different. Everything in Dark Souls is very thoughtful and you can learn your opponents moves and such to make it a lot easier, but even as a magic build I found myself just smacking everything in the face with my hammer and ignoring damage.It was a very easy game, the only challenging part was that the level layouts are confusing and mazelike. I did enjoy the game, but it felt like it could have been so much more. I will probably do the NG+ but I don't recommend it for $50. Get it on sale and it will be fun for a while.TL:DR Fun but too short and no multiplayer. Do not expect it to be like Dark Souls. Mechanics are similar, but the game is way different.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												This review comes along time after finishing my first play through. I became interested in this game before it launched. I was looking for a game to quench my thirst for more Dark Souls. It appeared to have similar gameplay/character control. You will find many people comparing this to Dark Souls or saying that this game copied Dark Souls. I will tell you that this game establishes itself. The combat shares similarites. However, there is a total different feel to it. Magic and items have a different feel to them. The game does offer weapon enhancement, experience multiplier for the longer you go without touching a save shard. The visuals look great for the atmoshpere it is trying to achieve. The soundtrack and music is not as memorable as some other games. Enemy design is well thought out and the puzzles you encounter in the game take some thought to overcome. All in all a decent game to quench ones thirst. Give it a shot, it plays much better now than it did at launch. I will say that the final boss is a beast. The story has not stuck with me as much as Dark Souls. Although there were many more hours dumped in that game than this.

												This is prolly the most underrated game  iv played in a long long time. (darksiders imo is also a underrated game but that has a decent following). Compareing this to dark souls is just stupid, thats like saying... Ford came up with petrol engine so every petrol car is a ripoff.GRAPHICSI love the visuals and i am surprised that why most reveiwers dont use this game to benchmark GPUS.When i bought this game I was running it on a r9 290x @ 1080p, Recently i upgraded to a 980ti and am now running the game uber smooth at 1600p. All play the same it depends on your style. The game isnt very long which is a dud. It should have been longer and left me with a feeling of wanting more, the DLC they added wasnt all that fun tbh I was way too op for it.Sound.Not much of a sound nerd but i like how this game sounds :)so if u r a action rpg fan who loves to play pretty games and if u like the artstyle of darksiders and if you think darksouls was too difficult...get this game!!!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												First I would like to adress all that played just after release - game is now stable, great looking and many of the flaws mentioned in early negative rewievs are gone. It`s nice polished gem - smaller then Souls, yet with its own value. I played 3 runs - NG, NG+ and NG++ and if not for so many other games waiting for my attention, I would love to play more. Maybe that`s just the best thing I can say about Lords - I played 105 hours and still could play more. Anyway, try it guys - it`s worth it. Especially it shows on many sales now.SPOILERSNow some small advice for all who will play:- don`t use attribute shards as long as You can- collect them - they pass to NG+ and NG++- just before the end of NG invest 25-30 points in luck - 90% of  boxes will have attribute shard (instead of equipment You got on 1 playthrough) on NG+ and NG++ and with that amount of luck it took me tops 2 tries to get it from each box - some boxes have fixed shards and willl not change but they are few,- save Your Heroes Shard on NG+ and NG++ for later and respec (utilizing Your luck before final NG++ Judge fight can give nice edge),- don`t spend even one point of exp on magic ( I ended NG++ with over 70  unusable magic shards),- no matter how green You are in heavy armour according to Your burden meter light armour is always FASTER,- if You will try to get all achievements kill Judge with Keeper`s Weapon on 1st run while giving Adyr`s rune to blacksmith or slotting it into armour (On my 1st playthrough I simply rushed in the end to Judge so fast that I forgot about Ancient Labirynth, on second I got strenght based Gauntlets from Keeper but my 2H sword took one more swing too much and I was forced to do Labirynth again on NG++, take Faith based Greataxe, sloth it with Adyr rune as I already gave it to Blacksmith on NG, and then used it on Armour on NG+ - well killing him with faith based 350 dmg Greataxe was doable but not easy ;) )- gauntlet, even with circa 120 Faith is not powerfull enough to be Your first weapon- Mimic is Your best friend- take Your time and enjoy the views :)

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												If you are looking for a game to play after Dark Souls, give this one a pass.Combat is slow and clunky. Class balance is completely skewed towards sword and board warrior turtle playstyle. There is no pure spellcaster class, most of the spells are purely supportive with gauntlet being the only ranged weapon in the game.Agile characters are punished by terrible claustrophobic level design filled with hulking enemies that block your movements most of the time. And speaking of level design, its linear, with every area feeling compressed in every possible direction, even the few outdoor areas feel that way.Story feels like an afterthought with absolutely nothing of interest in it, the game world looks and feels generic and boring. Aesthetically the game is trying to make everything in it look as badass as it possibly can, and that only makes it more boring. There is no contrast of any kind.Without comparing it to Dark Souls (which is hard, when even its developers are doing it) its an average third person action "role playing" game, good enough for a purchase on sale, if you are bored enough, provided you never played Dark Souls, or hate how it plays.PS: Forgot to mention, it's short, with very limited replay value.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												I went into this not expecting much as people tend to dismiss this game out of hand. I was plesantly surprised.I'll say right off the bat that this is a Dark Souls 2 clone. I say two specifically because this feels much more similar to the sequel than the original (or Demons'). Nearly all your enemies are humanoids, for example. It plays a lot better than Dark Souls 2 though. No enemies pivoting on the spot mid swing to auto-track you, all the hitboxes seem tight and what you expect. Also it looks a shed load prettier for what that's worth.The conversation system is a bit pointless, and I was a bit dissapointed in the weapon upgrading system. You can slot gems into your gear for things like +4 dmg or +10 melee protection. But most weapons can only take 1 or 2 runes, so you never really feel like your changing anything dramatically. You won't get that Dark Souls feeling of taking a crappy starting weapon and upgrading it to +10. Though you can freely swap runes in and out as you wish so it's a bit more fluid. If you're looking for more Dark Souls then give this a shot. It's a straight up clone with a fresh coat of paint. In comparison to the other games like this I'd say this comes in somewhere inbetween Demons and DS2 in terms of quality.Worth a punt, especially if you see it on sale.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												Dark Souls Jr. in basically every sense of the title. Not necessarily a bad thing, but it's good to know what you're getting in to.Imagine if Dark Souls was shorter, easier, smaller, and simpler. That's basically Lords of the Fallen. It looks and runs great, and the controls are acceptable (there's a control scheme that is a direct rip of Dark Souls). The story isn't great but is passable. Mechanics (leveling, combat, etc) are solid.It's not a bad game, really. I guess if you only had time to play one game, you should play Dark Souls instead. If you've already played through Dark Souls and Dark Souls 2, and you want more, similar gameplay, then hey, give it a shot.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												You might get some enjoyment out of this game if you're a die hard Dark Souls fan. That's really the only reason I picked it up. Ultimately, it's just a failed clone. This game is one hundred percent a Dark Souls rip off. From the combat to respawning enemies to the refillable potions (estus flask) at check points, they blatantly attempted to cash in on the success of Dark Souls with this game. Which I would not have minded at all had it been a good game. Sadly, it is not. I would only recommend Lords of the Fallen if you pick it up on sale for super cheap and have an unquenchable thirst for Dark Souls game play. And even in that scenario, don't go in with high expectations.+CONS:-The story is weak. I just beat the game an hour ago and can't recall the plot if that's any indication of its impact. -The characters are uninteresting. And instead of a custom made, mute protagonist (like DS), you play as Harkyn. A very boring, grumpy, unlikable big buff white guy. -The controls are nearly identical to DS. Nearly being the keyword. They're so close that the few buttons they switch up constantly messed with me the whole game. There is no custom button mapping. Only two pre-mapped set ups you can choose from. -The armors are dull. Finding new sets doesn't feel that rewarding when they all look almost exactly the same. -The enemies are bland. Most designs are cliche and/or unmemorable. -The combat is flawed. You'll often find yourself taking damage despite a very well timed dodge roll. They did a decent job of emulating DS combat overall yet it somehow ends up feeling not nearly as satisfying. -The magic is wonky. You are forced to choose one of three builds (each with 4 specific spells) at the beginning of the game. But you don't really have any clue what any of the spells will do or how useful they'll be. So you're blindly picking and are then locked into that build the rest of the game. You can't change. Nor can you eventually branch out and use the spells from the other two builds. I randomly chose 'Rogue' and ended up spamming the 'Stab' spell the entire game. Your magic automatically refills after about 10 seconds so spamming is an accurate term here. Magic does far more damage than physical attacks. So you'll often find yourself running and dodging to kill time between OP magic casts.+PROS:-Pleasant graphics?I did get *some* enjoyment out of this game. More so early on. However, finishing it became more of a chore. And the ending is extremely unsatisfying. If asked 5 hours into the game, I would have said it's decent. After finishing it, I have to say it's not really worth the time.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												It is very similar to the souls series, complete with bugs, crashes and dodgey hit boxes. The mechanics in this are nowhwere near as complex and interesting as the souls games, but still fun and functional in its own right.  Most enemies are humonoid with exception of a few (most of which are dogs). The writing is terrible as is the story, the npcs seem to know exactly whats going on at all times but neglect to fill you in, if i didnt know better i would assume they are the masterminds behind it all.The graphic while great are not optimized and are quite intensive even on supercomputers. There is a very basic crafting system, but i honestly dont see why they didnt just let us socket runes from our inventory rather than making it overly complicated.The magic is interesting and often overpowered, but the magic guantlet is next to useless.The starting class feels like an important choice without it locking you into a specific play style.Bosses have additional challenges that reward improved versions of their equipment, though they are generally easy enough that you will complete them accidently alot.Enemies and bosses themselves are all very unique and fun to learn how to beat.Unfortunetly like dark souls you are required to trial and error your way through the game.The world isnt at all interconnected and is very linear especially at the beginning.Bonfires are over complicated and not explained very well (yes i know there not really bonfires).Overall its not worth the asking price, but is definetly worth considering if on sale.Definetly nice if your looking for more dark souls but are bored of the souls worlds.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												My thumbs down is not an hard one i had fun playing lotf, but when i was comparing this to the DS franchise, and they are just better in every aspect but the graphic.I was able to finish the game the fist time with no difficulty at all. The game was easy, shield are OP, the animations of attack were slow (probabily more realistic, but waiting 1 second to deliver a blow could be a bit frustrating. This might be a fault of Souls game that get us used to see the berserk's sword swinged easly as longsword). The game got some balance issues with pacemaker you can easly achive 5XX dmg, comboing 2k dmg. That damage is insane!!! (socketing the ENDGAME rune give you ~16 damage, the luck give you ~200). Trading blow with bosses is efficent, imho it SHOULD NOT BE efficent, you got tons of pots, they can just repeat the attacks.Spells are game breaking, creating a clone of you that taunt the enemy is broken.(i didn't tested other spells, didn't needed to).To find the game a bit more challenging i dropped the shield and the spell and used only slow 2h weapon, maybe i'll try again with a stealth/agy class and the game will be really hard, i hope so!!Prothe game look fantasticThe armors and the weapons are really coolThe weapon got weight when they got swinged, and mobs react to that.The reward weapon got some cool effects (only them).The enemy are cool, they seems to have a nice AI, and the skinny undead are really unpredictable.The game is easyer than DS 2 and DS 1The game have nice ideas (event challenges are really cool).ConsThe objective of the boss fight is not shown before the bossYou got the same animation for almost every weapon of the same class.The armors and the weapons are really cool (every armor is too cool).The game have no pvp/online.The game is quite short(yea you can play in ng+/++)[dark souls 2/1 have the same price and the world "bigger" and it is filled with more content].The story was not so good, imho.The game is easyer than DS 2 and DS 1Stereotypical npc with low personalitySome area go recycledBtw i had fun smashing mobs with my 2handed axe/sword/hammer but sadly it didn't last long, but it was quite funny!!I rank this game 6 only because we already got souls game to play with, but if we would have not, i would have ranked this game higher.~ Levirax

Posted: December 6, 2014
												My first note is that the game is very short. I beat it in 8 hours of playtime. No multiplayer, limited sidequests that are very vague and confusing levels had me getting mixed up all over the place. There were not very many bosses and they were all pretty easy. Only two bosses actually killed me.This game is NOT Dark Souls. Not even close. It uses dark souls combat mechanics like health potions that refill at checkpoints, dodge rolls, and left hand/right hand on LB/LT and RB/RT. The same mechanics are in it but the feel is much different. Everything in Dark Souls is very thoughtful and you can learn your opponents moves and such to make it a lot easier, but even as a magic build I found myself just smacking everything in the face with my hammer and ignoring damage.It was a very easy game, the only challenging part was that the level layouts are confusing and mazelike. I did enjoy the game, but it felt like it could have been so much more. I will probably do the NG+ but I don't recommend it for $50. Get it on sale and it will be fun for a while.TL:DR Fun but too short and no multiplayer. Do not expect it to be like Dark Souls. Mechanics are similar, but the game is way different.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												This game glued me for screen like not many games managed to do so. Even though I have played 16 hours I haven't finished the game and I do enjoy the game a lot. Lords of the Fallen have good mouse and keyboard controls!  I haven't played Dark Souls because I don't have controller, don't like the controller and controls for mouse and keyboard are horror (I was fighting with controls in Dark Souls since they didn't let me fight the monsters). I thought after seeing so many videos that I have enough patience for this combat type - I was so wrong! First 4 to 6 hours I spent only learning how to be patient and careful. It was infuriating! Once I settle that down, only then I started to learn how to play Lords of The Fallen. Every weapon is a bit different and it is very punishing if not used properly. This is one of those games where the main focus is on playing again and again. There is no way around it. This is not the bad thing - on contrary! It is done in such way where player learns from his mistakes and tries again thus improving himself. Pure Warrior, Cleric and Rogue give quite diverse playtyle and I would advise anyone to start with pure aproach before making hybrids (my first save was hybrid and it is wrong).I encountered few crashes. On 16 hours I had like 6 crashes. I have everything on High except model detail on Very High but I think I should bring that back on High. Visually, game looks very polished. There are no blank unfinished spaces. Everything is designed to feel like finished game (this is the reference to Dark Souls where many areas feel barren and unfinished). Animations are quite good. Harkyn really moves like a human - he is not wooden imitation of a human motions. I am very pleased to see that a side from first initial intro, all cutscenes are ingame engine realtime rendering. The only thing I don't like in those is when upon killing a warden, Harkyn has no helmet for the duration of cutscene (they could make animation where he lifts his helmet and then rest of cutscene continues as usual.Gameplay, well as someone who could not play Dark Souls because of controls, I really enjoyed this game so far. In long time there was no game that glued me for screen. There is something in improving yourself and trying things. On top of that, even though simplified, character builder is very intuitive and gives enough info what will happen. One exception is last 4th spell where it states only Faith requirement but it also require 5 points spent in spells as another requirement.

												The Game itself is great! I love the Dark Souls series and since this game is basically a easier version i like this too.BUT!  It seems like it still has a ton of problems. In my case it would be the constant crashes. I mean 6 crashes in under an hour? I'm patient but that is kind of awful. And before anyone asks, i did update my graphics card drivers. Since the reviews split into 2 camps, meaning those who have the crashes and the those who dont, there is no accurate way to tell if you should recommend it or not. But right now, i do get the crashes and i think i should have waited to purchase this. So recommend it or not?Not right now. Will change if something changes or if there is a resolution to fix it. If you still buy it you probably have a 50/50 chance it does work. Do you feel lucky?EDIT: So i may have judged this problem too fast before really looking into it. It works fine for me now and another 2 hours into the game i do think have an explanation.So it seems like the Nvidia Trubulance feature caused the constant crashes, which is kind of weird because i have n Nvidia GTX 970. So by deactivating the feature it didnt crash on me again. So basically what the problem seems to be for Nvidia card owner is that the function itself causes some kind of problem and thus creating the crashes. And i guess alot of ppl don't have that problem because the have AMD card's and this feature is in general turned off? I don't really know, that is just my guess.Anyways.....having a lot of fun playing it. For Dark Souls fans a nice  treat ;)

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												First I would like to adress all that played just after release - game is now stable, great looking and many of the flaws mentioned in early negative rewievs are gone. It`s nice polished gem - smaller then Souls, yet with its own value. I played 3 runs - NG, NG+ and NG++ and if not for so many other games waiting for my attention, I would love to play more. Maybe that`s just the best thing I can say about Lords - I played 105 hours and still could play more. Anyway, try it guys - it`s worth it. Especially it shows on many sales now.SPOILERSNow some small advice for all who will play:- don`t use attribute shards as long as You can- collect them - they pass to NG+ and NG++- just before the end of NG invest 25-30 points in luck - 90% of  boxes will have attribute shard (instead of equipment You got on 1 playthrough) on NG+ and NG++ and with that amount of luck it took me tops 2 tries to get it from each box - some boxes have fixed shards and willl not change but they are few,- save Your Heroes Shard on NG+ and NG++ for later and respec (utilizing Your luck before final NG++ Judge fight can give nice edge),- don`t spend even one point of exp on magic ( I ended NG++ with over 70  unusable magic shards),- no matter how green You are in heavy armour according to Your burden meter light armour is always FASTER,- if You will try to get all achievements kill Judge with Keeper`s Weapon on 1st run while giving Adyr`s rune to blacksmith or slotting it into armour (On my 1st playthrough I simply rushed in the end to Judge so fast that I forgot about Ancient Labirynth, on second I got strenght based Gauntlets from Keeper but my 2H sword took one more swing too much and I was forced to do Labirynth again on NG++, take Faith based Greataxe, sloth it with Adyr rune as I already gave it to Blacksmith on NG, and then used it on Armour on NG+ - well killing him with faith based 350 dmg Greataxe was doable but not easy ;) )- gauntlet, even with circa 120 Faith is not powerfull enough to be Your first weapon- Mimic is Your best friend- take Your time and enjoy the views :)

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												This is prolly the most underrated game  iv played in a long long time. (darksiders imo is also a underrated game but that has a decent following). Compareing this to dark souls is just stupid, thats like saying... Ford came up with petrol engine so every petrol car is a ripoff.GRAPHICSI love the visuals and i am surprised that why most reveiwers dont use this game to benchmark GPUS.When i bought this game I was running it on a r9 290x @ 1080p, Recently i upgraded to a 980ti and am now running the game uber smooth at 1600p. I must say this game is prolly the best looking RPG right now, It looks better than witcher III which is saying something.Gameplay.Its nowhere as difficult as darksouls ( i spent around 400 hours in dark souls 1 on PS3) And that is a good thing, I like how the world is interconnected, I do wish they had a ranged  specifc class system which would have made the game much for fun , There are basically 3 main classes which can further be merged into more classes. All play the same it depends on your style. The game isnt very long which is a dud. It should have been longer and left me with a feeling of wanting more, the DLC they added wasnt all that fun tbh I was way too op for it.Sound.Not much of a sound nerd but i like how this game sounds :)so if u r a action rpg fan who loves to play pretty games and if u like the artstyle of darksiders and if you think darksouls was too difficult...get this game!!!

Seriously. Lords of the Fallen... to the Bugs... i guess.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												Was never going to live up to the Dark Souls comparisons. In some ways it's a mix of Dark Souls and Dark Siders, which has really nice results at times. I had a lot of fun with this, and the game looks great - especially all the gear you find. Two major gripes: 1) some kind of control glitch meant that about half the time I wanted to do a leaping attack, simply jumped and rolled. Super annoying. 2) I don't have a problem with short games, and this one isn't, really, but on the other hand I still felt like the content was a bit skimpy. Most of the enemies get heavily reused, and much of the game is stretched out by having you go back through previous areas. I only remember there being 5 or 6 main areas to the game.In all, it's a fun game, but certainly not worth full price. Worth grabbing if it's on sale for $5-10.7/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												So I feel safe reviewing this due to the fact that it's been about a year since my inital playthrough, and my opinion of it is unchanged. It's alright.My first playthrough was a lot of fun.  You'll go through the standard stuff of discovering new weapons, rerolling to use different stuff, and the inital thrills of exploring the areas.  Like everyone else has mentioned, the combat is very Souls-like.  It's a little more clunky and slower-paced, but that's not a bad thing.  The difficulty is pretty low; most of the boss fights are super gimmicky.  The story is bland and the dialog is atrocious, but it's not too invasive and does an okay job linking one area to the next.  I enjoyed exploring the world, trying out different weapons, modding them in different ways, and reaching the conclusion, but that's where the enjoyment stopped.  There's some replayability, different classes, different stats with different weapon sets, and a few different endings, but I felt no desire to go back through the game and find them.  I moved on with my life and came back across this game recently and decided to give it another shot with some fresh eyes.  The level design is a certain kind of bland, it's so unremarkable that the layout is memorable but not enjoyable.  After just about a full year of not playing it, I still didn't have much of a desire to go back through the game.I believe I got the game on sale, and I got a solid 15 hours of gameplay out of it that were very enjoyable.  I'm sure that's more than enough to justify whatever I spent on it.  I see that it's currently on sale (posting during the winter sale of 2015) for $9, and it's a phenomenal game for that price.  The base price of $49.99 seems a little steep.  If you don't have a habit of restarting when you find cool gear, you can probably get through it faster than I did.  If you're new to the action-rpg genre and struggle with the difficulty, it might take you 20ish hours for a full-explore playthrough.  Either way, the game is enjoyable, but quickly forgotten.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												I bought this game a while back and began to play it.  After some false starts, I began playing in earnest.  I liked the game for the first 2-3 hours of trial and errors.  It may be that I've been consolized or other such term, but I just couldn't figure what to do/where to go next after enough time was spent exploring.  I uninstalled the game, not in a rage but just apathy in the 3rd area.  You're supposed to perform a task, but there's no information on how to do it (do I need to collect something, go to someplace in particular, pull a lever, what?), none of the NPCs are helpful and it seems to be more than just kill everything (I can do that one fine).  After a full afternoon of playing, I just couldn't care less. On a good note, it looks pretty good, the combat is fluid, hitboxes are fair.  I liked it more than I liked Dark Souls.  I just didn't like it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												From the first time that we saw the Lords of the Fallen videos we could not help our­selves but com­pare it to the Dark Souls games. Even though the game does fol­low the Souls game mechan­ics, it does offer an inter­est­ing and some­what eas­ier gam­ing experience.Lords of the Fallen tells the story of Harkyn, an impris­oned crim­i­nal who is set free in order to save the world from the inter-dimensional Rhogar and their Lords. The story tries to keep things inter­est­ing through cutscenes and var­i­ous moments where the player is allowed to choose a spe­cific course of action. Unfor­tu­nately, the choices do not seem to be of any sig­nif­i­cance towards the pro­gres­sion of the game; their exis­tence how­ever does make things more interesting.Read the rest of my review here: http://www.blowsomesteam.com/lords-of-the-fallen/

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												While the game has some potential, poor level design and constant crashes make this a game to avoid. Yet another game sadly ruined by an extemely buggy release! Even after supposedly patching to improve stability the game still crashes to desktop roughly every 5 minutes if i'm lucky, making it almost unplayable. The combat system is very good and for the most part feels pretty fair, though unless you want to add misery onto the already frustrating bug filled experience that is Lords of the fallen stay away from the rogue until you really know the game. The story, while a little thin so far at least makes an attempt at a story, though the over-use of copy paste makes for some very average level design. The voice acting is pretty bad as is the lip-syncing for the characters as is the in-scene animation, which feels comically wooden. I want to like this game, I really do, but sadly the game feels rushed to release and incomplete. Maybe when the stability problems are fixed I may revisit this game but at the moment I don't think so. My advice, wait until it's been patched... A LOT and wait till it is in a sale if you really want a fix while waiting for Bloodborne.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												This game is an amazing Rune....Almost no game is completely perfect.  This game is not perfect by any means of the imagination.  However, this game has some amazing maps, monsters and difficult challenges.Pros - The graphics are super sweet!!  I played this at 2560x1440p with a G-sync IPS  monitor and averaged between 80-100 FPS most the game.  The game looks fantastic- The monsters in this game are really fun to fight (not to mention they have cool names).  You fight people like the Beast, Champion, Annhialater, Worshipper, Guardian, etc... and they range in difficulties, but are all fun to fight!- The controls are good.  Some people complain that sometimes you hit someone and it doesn't register.  This is true, but it doesn't happen very often.- The loot system is nice because you can carry endless amounts of items.  However, you still have to be careful how much you are actively carying, because this will cause you to become overcumbered.  - Once you beat the game, you restart and can select a different area of magic and you keep your XP and weapons, abilities, spells, etc.. and play again.  This time the monsters are really difficult and it really feels like you are starting over!- It's not Dark Souls- Got this on sale for $9.99 (worth every penny)Cons - When I first started playing this game, it crashed on me a few times.  When it crashed, I lost an hours worth of saved XP and almost rage quit the game completely.  After the first few stages, it never crashed again!- In two of the portal (challenge areas) areas, I immediatley died when going in there and my XP simply vanished!  I was so upset, that I found a youtube video to farm experience to get my XP back.  Take that game!!! - Lesson learned, be careful when going into the portal challenge areas!- Voice acting is laughable.  The story isn't very good either, but you will meet fun people along the way that help you stay engaged throughout the story.- Not really a con, but sometimes you will get stuck trying to find an objective and you will run around for long times trying to find out where to go next.Summary - Buy this game if you want to have an awesome experience in an open world RPG.  Yes it does have its own issues, but if you like Dark Souls, then you will like this game.  It's great!  I'm really hoping they make a Lords of the Fallen 2!!!!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												It's hard to talk about Lords of the Fallen with out immediately comparing it to Dark Souls, both are 3rd person ARPGs in medieval settings with stamina driven combat; at a quick glance LotF seems like little more than your standard Souls-like, but there are multiple things that seperate it from DkS both good and bad.First I'd like to talk about what LotF does right, and that's its interesting take on risk/reward; while playing you will notice that every kill increases an experience multiplier, this multiplier lasts until you either die or activate one of the games checkpoints. This incourages you to be a bit reckless and make decisions on whether you want to play it safe or push on and reap more rewards. This system is made even more risky by the fact that when you die you have a limited ammount of time to recover your experience before it starts to decrease, meaning that skipping checkpoints not only makes survival riskier since you won't be  replenish your consumables it makes recovering your experience a bit of a risk since you might spawn several multiple checkpoints from where you died and will need to fight your way back as fast as you can.When the system works it's incredibly satisfying, and if LotF was fast paced and fluid as it's inspiration it could have made the game an instant classic. Unfortunately LotF feels incredibly slow and clunky, which in turn makes every encounter feel like a labored effort; but I will come back to that later.In order to understand what exactly keeps LotF from being a great game I think you need to look at what makes DkS a great game. Souls games are known for being difficult and throwing a variety of challenges at you; what it is also known for is giving you an incredible array of tools and choices to deal with these challenges. It's this freedom to face challenges any way you'd like with any number of possible strategies that keeps DkS feeling fresh and appealing to such a wide base. LotF however doesn't do this at all... Instead from the very beginning of the game LotF feels like it is constantly bottlenecking you into using specific strategies and character builds.Between it's unchangable class choices, its stong emphasis on balanced upgrades over min-maxing just so you can use your class abilities, and it's lack of weapon upgrades and minimal stat scaling forcing you into using heavy weapons just to deal enough damage to keep up with enemy health levels and healing LotF constantly feels like it is forcing you to play in a pretty specific ways; and unfortunately those ways aren't really all that fun.You are left between min-maxing to make the most of your damage and survival odds or dropping all your experience into spells/faith to make use of your class; you are given the choice of using fast weapons that do very little damage against enemies, some of which can heal faster than you can deal damage, or use high damage weapons that can take out enemies but are insanely slow and leave you open to be staggered constantly. The end result is a slow and clunky process that never really manages to make you feel like you are making meaningful choices instead of simply putting experience where the game wants you to, and that's ultimately what makes LotF feel so unfulfilling.

Posted: March 3
												Lords Of The Fallen™.Also known as "What if Dark Souls had a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cousin" and "What's optimization?"The frame rate is bad, The V-sync is horrible because instead of dropping frames when there is some heavy effects (just some fire or more than one enemy) the game will jump from a locked 60fps to 30fps, if you disable v-sync the tearing is unbelievable.the game is slow, there is no character creation, only 3 classes, i started as warrior and i had fat roll from the start, enemies are easy, you can backstab everything from the start except bosses. when you block an enemy attack they go back flying like they hit a wall or something.There is a lot of naration in this game, and music, you can't skip the monologue of some old dude when you pick up some items.The Story is... i don't know.You can't fall of ledges or hit a wall when fighting in a small room.The character menu can be accessed while fighting, you can also pause.This game is really special, i got this game for $1,60 so please if you want the game for some reason, don't buy itfor more than 5$ because i don't think it's worth more.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												If you've played Dark Souls, you know that the game's calling card isn't that it's hard, but it's a very fair game. When you die, it's your fault and you don't feel cheated.Lords of the Fallen takes the core mechanics of Dark Souls and adds a bit. The graphics are beautiful, the added roleplaying aspect is neat. But at the end of the day, the core mechanics that it stole from Dark Souls are implemented weakly. Hit boxes are awful. I haven't died once where I thought "Okay, that's my fault I got greedy/hasty". The problem is always the mechanics killing you. And that is not a good game.Lords of the Fallen tries to be a Dark Souls clone and gets everything about it's inspiration horribly, unappologetically wrong. It's difficult for the sake of being difficult so the designers can say "We made a hard game." 4/10, because the graphics are beautiful and that's really the only redeeming quality of the game. I'll be requesting a refund.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												Short summary: A linear dark souls style RPG with a more direct narrative but glaring issues in combat balance, general stability & performance and unfair AI.In depth:Combat felt unfair despite being told enemies follow the same rules as the player, it did not feel like that in any shape or form. At times it'd be laughably easy circle strafing enemies to backstab them and other times enemies would treat your shield as if it were made of paper because you went the wrong way.Finding where to go boils down to trial and error, did that enemy kill you in 2 hits? Try somewhere else in this bland landscape to explore, it's difficult to get your bearings when so much of the environment looks the same.Performance wise I am running the game with 2 Nvidia GTX760's on SLI and am seldom seeing the framerate go over 40, it sticks in the 30-35 range for most of the time. Animations on enemies looking very jarring at times, stuttering as they moved in combat with me, taking me out of the experience entirely.side note:A potential fix for Nvidia users is to switch physx control over to CPU instead of your GPU, doing this got me an extra 10fps though your mileage may vary.Addition:I gave the game another chance and shortly after the 3rd boss and its convuluted tactics I encountered an enemy that used a grab attack on me, which then caused my character to fall through the floor of the game and land into a room below of which there was no way out as the door could only be opened from the other side. I had no choice but to quit the game, losing my progress.In closing this looks and feels like a Dark souls clone trying to jump on the bandwagon before it even got rolling. With the horrible issues in combat, exploration, bugs/glitches and optimisation, I would not recommend playing it at all in this state.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												I'd just like to open by saying I'm a huge Dark Souls fan, and that fundamentally, I enjoy this game.  It does a lot of things right, but given it's marketed directly to Dark Souls players, I feel a warning is due.I'm gonna start with the good.The game looks and sounds /fantastic/.  The VFX engine is absolutely gorgeous, even on lower graphics settings, and for a next gen game, it runs fairly well on aging hardware, with some small FPS hiccups.  On top of that, as an audiophile, the sound downright thrills me.  It's deep, punchy, and weighty - armour and chains rattle realistically, a weapon striking metal lets out an endlessly satisfying 'clang', and the soundtrack is excellent.  It's also got a massive variety of interesting weapons and armour - less variety than Dark Souls, but there's something here for most playstyles, and with items of varying rarity on top of random rune cards, the game has, functionally, a more complex loot system than Dark Souls.  Some may not like this, but I'm a sucker for random loot.  It also adds some interesting gameplay mechanics - the game rewards you for going long periods of time without saving by granting you a progressively increasing XP multiplier and improved loot drops for every enemy you kill without accessing a checkoint, but it also discourages checkpoint-scumming by making it so that checkpoints can only fill your health and replenish your health items a certain number of times before needing time to recharge.But you can see the big red thumbs-down up there, so it's time to get to the bad.This game is harder than Dark Souls.  Not more challenging, just harder, and this is due to a large number of lazy, shortsighted, and downright perplexing design decisions.  This is a game that wants to be like Dark Souls, but didn't study the source material carefully enough.  Boss arenas are littered with rubble you can get hung up on and plants that can obscure your view.  All enemies can spin on point to face you without any intervening animation, making maneuvering around them nearly impossible outside the designated 'attack windows' - this is a massive pain when it comes to fighting enemies with shields.  The lock-on system has far too short a range, making keeping larger boss enemies at a distance very difficult, because your lock will drop and your camera will snap to something else seemingly at random as you back off.  Some bosses have tiny crash boxes that make no sense - the ankles of the Beast boss are the worst offender.  Some enemy design makes absolutely no sense.  Slippery rogue enemies can sponge hits while tanky guys with tower shields go down in three.  Fat, bloated enemies that look about five hundred pounds can nimbly dodge and evade your attacks, while effortlessly breaking your block with a single floaty punch.  And that's not even going into the game's poor writing, story, and mediocre voice acting that inexplicably varies from louder than normal to barely audible.To wrap things up, I personally enjoy this game, but I have a habit of liking bad games, and this one frustrates the /hell/ out of me.  In Dark Souls, I always kept playing because my death was my mistake, while I find myself frequently ragequitting from Lords of the Fallen because the game has done something stupid and it's gotten me killed.  Fundamentally, it's got some solid ideas, and it's outstanding in a few areas - I find myself genuinely enjoying the time between boss fights - but its poor enemy design and frequent mistakes in other areas make said boss fights an absolute chore.TL;DR: Good in places, but blindingly frustrating in others, Lords of the Fallen can only be recommended to those with the patience to put up with the poor choices made by the developers.
