number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												I played this game at a friends house on the console, and when the Steam Summer Sale started I picked this up at what I would consider a somewhat good deal. However, everything didn't go to plan and I ended up refunding the game pretty quickly, my short rundown...The Good: For one, this game looks beautiful. One of the prettiest games I've ever seen, and the artistic style of the world, its inhabitants, and the gear are great. The performance was  also really good given the amount of visuals the game pushes. The gameplay itself (which strongly resembles the Demon/Dark Souls style) was also fun, with its own quirks compared to other games out there. I actually liked the leveling system for a game like this, and the interface (although not the most keyboard friendly) was really helpful telling me what I needed.The Bad: As of June 16th, the day this was written, I just couldn't get over the crashes from this game. What's worse, when you crash you'll be left off the last save crystal you used. When a feature of the game is NOT to use them to build up a monster  multiplier for the equivalent of bonus XP, a crash is devastating. In addition, I noticed a ton of odd audio anomalies with the game. Voices were never a consistant volume, and it didn't seem audio positioning was done very well either. The voice acting of the game was...not so great, and the lip sync wasn't that great either. Your character's attitude seems a bit silly at times, and overall the story was a bit hit and miss.I really want to like this game, and if it didn't have so many problems I think it could've been a really fun game. But my time in game was spent redoing everything I had just done due to crashes, coupled with the fact that the game didn't really seem to entice me to push the story forward, something the Souls series does fantastically.At this time, I can't give a solid recommendation for the game, but it's definitely on my list of games to revisit in the future, because it seems like this could have good potential.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												FINAL EDIT: OK, so finished it finally and actually giving NG+ a whirl. The pure garbage comment was just rude and i take it back. However, this is still not a recommended game. Anyone reading this, disregard everything below these pros and cons. Pros: - Nice visual style, very attractive at first glance - Some good choices along the way that are recapped when you complete the game in a sequence that i found oddly emotional  - If you want a Souls game with a more gothic/germanic feel, this might be something to look into- Some nice ideas like the gauntlet and magic Cons: - Nice graphics that hardly ever change and get boring quick: no diversity in environments, characters, effects - Painfully slow and cumbersome combat - Ludicrously maze-like levels that are just annoying, not interesting to explore, like someone did this on purpose to be an A-hole rather than with thought- Really much harder than Souls games as there is no summoning others for help and most players will be lucky to have 6-7 health potions by the end of NG. This leads to lots of frustration without reward, as some of the bosses make the worst Souls bosses look like child's play- Bad camera system and collision detection- Iffy target lock on - Relatively short story at around 30 hours compared to the 70-80 you get out of a similarly priced Souls game - Tons of gear that makes little to no difference- Leveling up also barely makes a difference beyond a very early point - Unfairly tailored to a very specific character build that makes the game much easier. Other builds this game is a nightmareOverall 5/10, do not get it unless it's heavily discounted and you're really craving this type of experienceEDIT: this game is pure garbage, so buyer beware. It's like the purely annoying version of Dark Souls. If you want the full review, read on, otherwise avoid. After 30 hours decided it was simply not worth it anymore. The entire game, and you can see this via YouTube videos, was designed for one build: warrior, rage spell, two handed greatsword. With that all the bosses are a cakewalk. Any other build and this♥♥♥♥♥♥is ten times harder than any Souls game, minus all the good parts. Avoid even if someone gives it to you as a gift. Got this on release day, which was like ten months ago...and can't bring myself to sit down and finish it because it's borderline boring. Still manages to be somewhat compelling, but just imagine all the difficulty of a Souls game minus the intrigue, mystery, reward, fluidity, natural exploration...and pretty much every other positive aspect. This is like a soulles (pun intended) copy of a Souls game done by an AI. Mind you i haven't had any major technical issues with this game, and don't understand why people say it's easier than Souls/Bloodborne. It's actually harder, there are very few bonfires/safe places, enemies respawn endelessly, you typically can only carry very few health potions, your guy Harykn feels like he's a tank wading through maple syrup even with light gear and high agility, and the map design is just convoluted: not interesting, not challenging, not lending itself to exploration. Just random maze-like, as I said, something an AI with no imagination would design because it was told to "make it difficult and reallly not linear". Sorry Deck 13, I'd say nice try but it isn't nice, it's the very epitome of mediocre.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												I feel like I can safely review this after just a few hours.  If you've ever played any of the Souls games then you'll get the combat system right away.  I didn't even need the tutorial and the keybinds for a controller are literally the same as Souls with a few minor exceptions due to spells.  If you enjoyed the combat system of the Souls games then you'll enjoy Lords.  If you are coming here looking for an epic story then turn around...the story is the weakest part of the game.  It doesn't give you that feeling of dread like the Souls games do.Graphics are outstanding, as are the combat animations.  You can safely run this game at 30 fps on high settings with a last gen video card (i.e. nvidia gtx 660 minimum).  Difficulty is something to be desired.  I cleared 2 major bosses without breaking a sweat or dying once.  I still have not died after a few hours of gameplay.  The game is a tad difficult in the first hour but quickly gets easier as you pump points into stamina so you can swing that sword like 20 times and the monster doesn't have a chance. As for the price...well here is where I disagree.  Its a full priced AAA game that has no multiplayer mode.  So what will happen is you'll spend 15-20 hrs completing the campaign then just do it again on the same toon to level up all your stats; fans of the souls series will know what I'm referring to here.   If you can, wait until a steam sale when its half off, then it'll be worth your time.  I still reccomend it right now though if you're a fan of action rpg's and you have some throw away cash.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Fortunately you don't need more than two hours of gameplay to notice that this game, in fact, shares much with Dark Souls. The bad stuff, not the good - just in time to get that refund, though.- A constant barrage of glitches and issues with performance and rendering. This game uses nVidia PhysX and other bull$hit libraries, making it barely playable for both nVidia and AMD users from what I saw on the forums while trying to make it work. Nice job, nVidia. You did it again. Weird shadow artifacts made the game painful to look at. Graphics settings are almost non-existent, like on a botched console port. Various things, along with anti-aliasing, are hidden in a global "postprocessing" setting, and the game doesn't even try to explain what that might cover. No matter which graphics setting I changed, it always ended up rendering in a different way, seemingly random, but always worse than before. Even when moving from lower to higher settings, even when playing with anisotropic filtering multiplier, which isn't a very noticeable or GPU intensive feature, made this game looking worse and worse. I stopped trying when it started to look like upscaled 720p (except for the interface), just as if it decreased the rendering resolution, which isn't even an option.- Combat is painfully, unimaginably slow. Comparisons to Souls or Monster Hunter or other titles couldn't even begin to shed light on this. I cannot grasp how anyone could even compare this to Darksiders or any other action adventure game. I was very critical of many games that deliberately try to be difficult and frustrating (as opposed to challenging) by implementing archaic nintendohard / "i will gobble all your arcade coins" gameplay design, but this title takes the cake. It just takes your gaming instincts and turns them upside-down, and not in a good way. Your character's starting stamina only allows you to make three or four attacks with your weapon before before being depleted, which is suicide, because you need it to block and dodge. You are discouraged from using even the most basic triple hit combo. Your character's combat animations are so slow that the best approach is to use just a single strike against enemies that may retaliate. And they often do, because unlike you, most of them aren't staggered into a stupor when receiving damage. Dodging doesn't make much sense, because it leaves you open to damage while moving you in a single direction with the speed of walking. I'm not joking, you just tumble on the ground like a headless corpse. You might experiment for a while and try to guess if you should start dodging just before the enemy strikes you, during their attack, or maybe just before it connects. You will observe that during a single dodge animation your enemy will be able to attack you more than once, rendering dodging useless. Blocking isn't much better, as two or three hits in the shield (or even a single one in case of bosses) will completely break your stamina, sending you flying to the nearest wall or to the ground, open to attack. It all seems to be a very very hard try at making the game "gritty" and "realistic", at the same time allowing your enemies to swing giant blades and gargantuan two handed warhammers with the speed of a fine rapier*. I get it, you're fighting some demonic monsters, but I can't help feeling like half of the people that play this game would be a far better warrior than the antihero that we are supposed to play AS, at least in terms of speed and stamina.- Hit detection in this game is a mystery. Either the developer doesn't know what "hit detection" or "hit box" means or simply doesn't care*. Flaming blades will swing whole feet above your head and deal damage to you either way. Meanwhile you will gaze upon your weapon's model clearly clipping through enemies without any reaction on their side. It's like the de facto area of effect of each attack (either yours or your enemies) is one thing and the attack animation is something else entirely, just a symbolic visual representation. This is simply atrocious.- Clearly stolen from Dark Souls is the cherished mechanic of the player losing all unspent experience points upon death*. Then you are return to the last checkpoint and given a chance to reaquire you "lost soul" so to speak and recover the lost XP, for which there is always a time limit*.- Enemies are bullet sponges, because there is no better way to increase a game's difficulty than making the player repeat succesful control inputs over and over again*.- Enemies respawn infinitely, because who doesn't love grinding?- After defeating a boss or a tough fight there is that masochistic feel of accomplishment that Souls fans crave, but in this title's case it is washed away by feelings of lost time, like completing a joyless chore that won't amount to anything in the end. It just doesn't feel FUN, it never does.- Voice acting is very uneven - sometimes good, sometimes atrocious. Some written text fragments have weird syntax or other mistakes, which leads me to believe that the english version of this game wasn't proofread by native speakers. This ruins immersion and makes plot difficult to enjoy.*Because going out of your way to make a game difficult and unnatural to play and impossible to progress without flawless execution means FUN, as you give the player a chance to feel like a champion for braving your bad design and botched mechanics.tl;dr - if you're a hardcore elite fromdrone Souls fan then definitely try this game, you should like it if you like everything about Souls. If you're just looking for a challenging game to master then I suggest you look elsewhere. Beat DOOM on Ultra Nightmare, Spec Ops: The Line on FUBAR, Darksiders II on Apocalyptic, Devil Daggers, Triple Frozen Crown on Pillars of Eternity, do all Arkham City achievements, whatever. This game just doesn't offer any fun for a multitude of reasons.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												It's hard to talk about Lords of the Fallen with out immediately comparing it to Dark Souls, both are 3rd person ARPGs in medieval settings with stamina driven combat; at a quick glance LotF seems like little more than your standard Souls-like, but there are multiple things that seperate it from DkS both good and bad.First I'd like to talk about what LotF does right, and that's its interesting take on risk/reward; while playing you will notice that every kill increases an experience multiplier, this multiplier lasts until you either die or activate one of the games checkpoints. This incourages you to be a bit reckless and make decisions on whether you want to play it safe or push on and reap more rewards. This system is made even more risky by the fact that when you die you have a limited ammount of time to recover your experience before it starts to decrease, meaning that skipping checkpoints not only makes survival riskier since you won't be  replenish your consumables it makes recovering your experience a bit of a risk since you might spawn several multiple checkpoints from where you died and will need to fight your way back as fast as you can.When the system works it's incredibly satisfying, and if LotF was fast paced and fluid as it's inspiration it could have made the game an instant classic. Unfortunately LotF feels incredibly slow and clunky, which in turn makes every encounter feel like a labored effort; but I will come back to that later.In order to understand what exactly keeps LotF from being a great game I think you need to look at what makes DkS a great game. Souls games are known for being difficult and throwing a variety of challenges at you; what it is also known for is giving you an incredible array of tools and choices to deal with these challenges. It's this freedom to face challenges any way you'd like with any number of possible strategies that keeps DkS feeling fresh and appealing to such a wide base. LotF however doesn't do this at all... Instead from the very beginning of the game LotF feels like it is constantly bottlenecking you into using specific strategies and character builds.Between it's unchangable class choices, its stong emphasis on balanced upgrades over min-maxing just so you can use your class abilities, and it's lack of weapon upgrades and minimal stat scaling forcing you into using heavy weapons just to deal enough damage to keep up with enemy health levels and healing LotF constantly feels like it is forcing you to play in a pretty specific ways; and unfortunately those ways aren't really all that fun.You are left between min-maxing to make the most of your damage and survival odds or dropping all your experience into spells/faith to make use of your class; you are given the choice of using fast weapons that do very little damage against enemies, some of which can heal faster than you can deal damage, or use high damage weapons that can take out enemies but are insanely slow and leave you open to be staggered constantly. The end result is a slow and clunky process that never really manages to make you feel like you are making meaningful choices instead of simply putting experience where the game wants you to, and that's ultimately what makes LotF feel so unfulfilling.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Bought this on sale (fall 2015), thoughts after 7 hours in:I am an average Souls player and i finished them all (all Dark/Demon/Bloodborne).TLDR: Has great graphics and sound, gameplay feels very clunky and not all hits connect - 7/10 - get it on sale, WORTH trying.I somehow like the feel of the game. Weapons feel heavy, and heavy armor slows you down. Combat is sufficiently diverse with guard brakes, parries, charges, dual wield chained combos - fun for everyone.But at the same time, this clunky-ness makes it really hard to progress and fight what this game throws at you. I can currently face two bosses which i am very underpowered against (Champion and Infiltrator).And common enemies are... not unbeatable, but just too hard to beat, so grinding them would take all the pacience in the world. They hide behind huge shields and are always locked-on on you. it's very difficult to get behind them or get an opening to hit them. And when you do get that small window of opportunity, your moves are either too slow to hit (big strength weapons) or do little damage (fast agility weapons). So you just have to grind those moments, and enemies can feel like a grind on their own.The game just doesn't make all the effort feel worthy. Maybe it's just me, maybe i'm way underleveled, maybe i'm missing something... But i might not want to complete this game.Maybe others would want to. So yeah, Recommended !LE: 16h in - game finished. chosing agility build may not have been the best idea, but i wasn't looking for an easy game :D rating still 7/10

content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												After more then a year (or is it 2 now?) it is STILL bugged, STILL crashes and really, now that DS 3 is out, if you want a hard dark fantasy game, get that.Gameplay is fine, however there are some major flaws that this type of game really shouldn't have!- Enemy Tracking: What I mean by this is that enemies basiclly always face you once they spotted you. They insta turn and face you. You can't role around them or walk around them unless they are stuck in an animation. however as soon as the animation is over they will be facing you again.- Shield / Faith beats everything. This is basiclly just a balancing problem, however it is pretty severe. You have next to no reason to go light armor dodge focus builds (sure there are a few attacks that you can't block / aren't worth blocking but you can still dodge no problem on medium weight. Blocking and heavy/medium armor (you don't want fat-role) is the way to go with strength builds and then there is faith builds that just make the game a walk in the park (though a really slow one).- The platforming (thank god there really isn't too much) is horrendous. - Lots of bossfights and enemies are really samy and just a test of patience. As in they have a few attack patterns and one of them leaves them really vulnerable (Hmmm, when should I attack the boss... me no understand).Worth mentioning though is that the graphics are great if your machine can handle it and the atmosphere is rather spot on.The Combat mechanics are while not flawless definitly good other then the above mentioned. Great Animations aswell.Maybe get it if its reduced price if you really want another dark fantasy game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												Lords of the Fallen had, and may still have great potential, but technical flaws and not enough unique takes, leave it a little behind the competition.Pros:-Great visuals, effects, and combat system-Amazing looking armor and weapons, and other loot, await you right from the start-Engaging properly spaced Boss fights-Heavy deep dungeon Dark Souls Esq feel-I really can't stress how fun the combat is, it might not have as much content to it as Dark Souls, but it feels better, swings really have weight to them, your character can feel really badass at times.-Interesting areas, enviroments that really draw you in, even if you may not 100% understand where you are sometimes.-Replayable at least 2 or 3 times.Cons:-Heavy technical flaws on launch, numerous crashes randomly and on launching the game, low FPS on high end systems, save file corruption, game breaking bugs, and option settings not saving if you don't use a controller to set them. These are the biggest problem with Lords of The Fallen right now for many people.-No difficulty adjustment, some people love an insanely hard challenge, others might find it too easy, but regardless you don't have a choice in the matter, which will be frustrating to some. Sometimes enemies can be cheap, a lot of the "difficulty" can be an illusion. One example is many stronger normals or boss enemies can just outright kill you, they are almost always AOE spells or abilities that if hit, will automatically end your life and wipe all progress from last checkpoint.-Game can get generic at times, lacking  standout customization, magic, etc...and the variety on these isn't that high.-A little short-Easy to get lost without any sense of direction, and the objectives don't update enough for you to tell if you are on the right path; this leads to a lot of backtracking and aimless wandering.Summarrize:4.5/10 The technical flaws, generic feel, and especially the lack of any navigation system or sense of direction are the biggest downfalls with this game, that being said there is a decent game underneath here if the dev follows through on fixing the heavy technical problems of the PC version. Right now I would say if you want to try this game, wait. I mean you can wait and both get it on sale later, and after the kinks have been ironed out if at all.I can thumbs up this, but only barely. The developers have released two patches already, so if they follow through and get the game to a more playable state... Well, there is a good game underneath, it just needs to be pulled out yet.Additional Questions:Is the game minimize friendly? No.Is the game Steam Overlay friendly? Sometimes.Stong Chormatic Abrretion? Yes, but can be disabled but you must disable all Post Processing FX.EDIT: I had to come back and lower my review to a negative this time. About 3 bosses from the end of the game, it just ♥♥♥♥ed up my save file when I died, so I now have to delete it and start the entire game all over again, which after this dreadful experience, I am not doing.This game has been a nightmare of tech problems, which is a shame, because there was a good game in here, beneath terrible level design, difficulty imbalance, and the many many MANY tech problems.Other people have had similar problems, the bugs are not small, they are game breaking/ending, as in you hit a bug thats it, game over, delete and restart all over again:http://fextralife.com/forums/t39758/stuck-in-a-pit-in-the-catacombs/

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												It starts off feeling like Dark Souls, but later takes those game mechanics and creates something else with it.  The game starts off somewhat difficult, feeling under-powered, and enemies hit hard; and areas that seem gated by your level to keep you from going in that direction until you're ready (catacombs early on really showed me how weak I was).However, it get's easier pretty early on as well.  I started play as a cleric type, and once I had enough points into the Daze spell, things just got a little too easy, especially bosses.  Dying became irrelevant , as fidning potions to recover your ghost after death were plentiful, as well as attribute/spell point shards to increase your stats even more.  I think I finished with 20 VIT, 30 Faith, and 20 End, wearing the Fallen armor set and wielding a massive club, making end game bosses a joke.New Game + was a pleasant suprise, as I found the enemies scaled very well to it, though the bosses were still pretty simple.  I tried being a rogue for NG+, but with the amount of experience needed for a single attribute point becoming increasingly expensive, I relied mostly on those attribute/spell point shards to boost my stats.The story telling was done in a way that I like, picking up audio notes to listen to the lore as I fought, instead of finding a note and having to read it to take away from the action.  The story, overall, was pretty decent in my opinion, and with the audio notes found, it gives you a deeper understanding of the world and just what it is that has happened/is happening.  The one part of the lore I would like to see expanded upon is the main character, Harkyn.  I don't know what sins or crimes he has committed in the past, but his face, if one could understand it, tells the tale.  The only thing I can gather is that he was a soldier, as the captain you meet in the game knows Harkyn, and vice-versa.Decent story, solid mechanics, and fun gameplay; I recommend this for anyone who is a, "Souls," fan, though don't look for an exact clone, but a game that took many elements from the series and expanded upon them in it's own way.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												For those who greatly enjoy the hardcore combat RPG genre introduced with the Dark Souls series, this game delivers!  It's a tremendous improvement in discoverable weapon abilities and combat styles that counter every type of enemy you face.  Secrets, puzzles, and quests everywhere you turn - just be careful, because that next turn could be deadly.You should already be used to death...lots of it.  It will happen often, and even more than you think possible.  But it's part of the game, and definitely part of discovering how to complete each area you find.Character customization is unique, yet familiar, and even the experience you earn has some very interesting and appealling uses - besides just leveling up your characters.  There are times where you'll be battling that desire to spend your experience, or hold onto it...this can be a tough choice!For anyone new to this style of gaming, you must come to terms with the fact that dying is part of the game.  For those who already know and understand it, you won't be disappointed!

content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												Score: 6.5/10It's a much easier Dark Souls, but doesn't have near the same polish. I'm on the fence with it, but I would still give it a thumbs up if only slightly. It teases multiple playthroughs, but once was enough. There's a lot to like here, but it feels a bit half-baked at times. It's a strange game that wants to let you explore and then punishes you by doing something cheap, and it's not as rewarding once you've overcome it. On the other hand, it's not nearly as frustrating as Dark Souls can be.- You'll get hit through walls and see all manner of glitchy things.- You'll face enemies that will use cheap tactics to land hits on you. - You will find the yo-yo difficulty to be hard and then easy, then difficult again. - You will find the gear to be mostly useless.- Exploration isn't too rewarding.- The risk/reward system is a joke. Saving up kill streaks to earn more XP is barely noticeable.Get it on sale and play it over a weekend.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												I'm ambivalent about recommending this game.Taken on its own as an action rpg, it is a solid offering with reasonable difficulty, and moderate plot, with good mechanics.The problem is that it is trying to take Dark Souls and make it a little more approachable, which I actually think it does well enough. However, this makes me realize that when you make concessions about difficulty and playability, you can end up with a much worse game.I absolutely loved Dark Souls, and this game pales in comparison, which is why I have some trouble recommending this game. DKS has a fully continuous world, where LoF uses area transitions to allow for better graphics. However, I still think the asthetics of DKS is better.Admittedly, LoF has a coherent story that is delivered to the player, but I actually liked the obfuscation of the story in Dark Souls, and it made the moral choice not just ambiguous, but also not readily apparent.I would have tried to review the game in the absence of my knowledge of Dark Souls, but it's just not possible for me to do so, so I tried to compare as best as possible.In short, I think it was good, though I haven't done a second playthrough yet, so that may change things a little, but I'm reluctant to think so.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												Thought these guys were supposed to be PC game developers. But 60% score on Steam? On Steam?? Check the negative reviews. All complaining of technical issues. It's disheartening, to say the least. Whatever. It's still a good game when it works. The content lacks, but the gameplay doesn't. Feels like Dark Souls but with more thought gone in, instead of difficulty due to large gaps between player and NPC damage/hitpoints. And you shouldn't be suffering more than a couple cheap deaths (if at all) so long as you play it smart. Different tactics can yield widly different results. Surprisingly, rushing the enormous melee boss with my two handed axe jump-slashing at his knees was the best way to win in one instance, where hanging back with a big shield previously was hardly helping at all. The game is short though. And the plethora of technical problems discourage a second run through the story. But hell, if you see it on sale for good, I'd still reccomend it, since the devs at least are releasing patches.

												I finished the game as warrior. The graphics are next-gen (think Unreal Engine 4, altough it is something else).Four things that annoyed me, you can fall and die. To add insult to the injury, the enemies' hits usually throw you in various directions and those directions happen to be in the falling areas sometimes, and you die, and die, and die and die again.And the second thing is the character's hack'n'slash is slower than the player's input, so it won't be a fast one and 80% of the time enemies get to hit you before you even lay a finger on them.Another thing is that enemies usually spawn and respawn if  you enter or leave different areas. Additionally, all the doors are reset and if you happen to have unlocked the door from the other side, you have to do it again next time you visit the same area, once you left it.Lastly, there is no map, nor there is any arrow pointing you to the quests, so you can go around sometimes for an hour to figure which door is the one that leads to the next step.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												There's no end to the problems with this game. The combat is clunky, poorly timed and often unfairly difficult rather than actually difficult. The boss fights in particular have some interesting gimmicks that seem like a positive at first, but really only make sure you never want to play through them ever again because no-one likes solving the same puzzle twice. There are 0 likeable or relatable characters, period. The main man is built like a brick shithouse with a past obtusely obscured, has no discernable motive in any way and is acting for other characters whose motives are nebulous and poorly explained at best. The world is littered with audio notes that serve to fill in the backstory, but since the game wants to try and avoid having an ENTIRELY linear progression, trying to use those notes to learn the history of the world is tedious and scrambled. The dialogue options all feel entirely without consequence. The game has a horrible fascination with giving zero direction to the player except a one sentence task and that's ultimately what killed my enjoyment. I got to an area, realised that I was being given no direction (and in certain cases outright lied to about my direction or given conflicting information by characters and questlog) and put down my controller. After 13 hours I realised exactly how little fun I'd had at all. It's such a shame, as well. The game is graphically beautiful, the aesthetic of the character design and world design is incredibly cohesive and often remarkable. The new twists that LotF brings to standard RPG elements serve it well and are pretty damn unique. It's let down by how little I care about anyone and anything in the world, how boring a lot of the combat and exploration can be and how little the developers care about directing a player through their world.I'd recommend picking it up at maybe $5, checking it out and seeing if you get more out of it than I did.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Don't let the pretty visuals fool you; save your money for a game that is remotely playable!I don't know why developers feel the need to make games like this one: games where you can play for over two hours and not be able to defeat the FIRST boss in the game (I only tried over 20 times...).  You actually LOSE experience when you die, and even if you stockpile enough XP to level up (in a reasonably designed game, at least), you can't use it because you haven't reached a certain spot in the game yet.  So those who aren't gaming ninjas are left essentially without a mechanism to even beef up their character to the point of being able to defeat said *first boss*.  Disgusting...  The boss that hits you even when you roll out of range of his attack, kills you in two to three hits, moves faster than you, has unlimited stamina - compared to you being crippled by just two to four attacks (all of which barely dent his health, even when you stab him in the back).  I was *behind* him a few times and got hit by *his* sword, yet mine did a measly *two* damage compared to the 50 his weapon did to me!  Yeah, I could go on.  You basically have NO advantage to use against this guy.  I literally had no way past this first area to even start the actual main portion of the game.  Wasted money...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												The Short:Its a Dark Souls clone.You say it like its a problem.The Long:Lords of the Fallen is a game that takes heavy inspiration from the Souls games, but does enough on its own that it can be rightfully called its own thing. From the spellcasting being closer to that of a traditional RPG (hurray for mana bars!) to the way the characters and enemies feel, I find it to be just as fun as any Souls game.Fiords of the Lawnmower (one internet cookie should you get that reference) has a very pleasing visual style. and by pleasing I mean everyone looks bad@$$. Skulls and flames are on basically everything and while it may get old after alittle bit, I still find it to be much more exciting than Dark Souls traditional medieval gear. Everyone has pauldrons the size of a small city and the detail in the armors and weapons are gleefully over designed. The graphics are absolutely gorgeous even with a medium spec'd rig such as mine. It runs very well outside of the occational open area where the framerate noticably dips, but it never becomes unplayable. Particle effects and such are everywhere; sparks flying when an attack bounces off a sheild, snow swirls, and ash sprouting from flaming weapons and torches make sure it looks extra pretty.Combat is very weighty, even with the light weapons. All of them feel like they have weight to them and it feels wonderful, especially when you bring a mighty greathammer down on a cowering enemy and watch as they are crushed and the screen shakes from the shear force of it all. Your attacks feel like they're going to do something as your character grunts from the strength needed to heave an axe with the head as large as one of your pauldrons over his shoulder and into an enemy.The controls on keyboard and mouse a great (I'm looking at you, Dark Souls) as are the ones using a controller. The buttons can all be remapped to your liking, but the default ones should be just fine.The gameplay is similar to all the Souls games, with you exploring a castle (or 2), fighting enemies, getting loot, and dying. Alot. However the game is easier than Souls, due to it not punishing you as much when you do inevetably kick the bucket. Another thing is how experience is gained. every time you kill an enemy you gain an experience multiplier. The more enemies you kill, the higher the multiplier gets and the more XP you get per kill. However, whenever you go back to a checkpoint to refill your potions, level up, and save; the multiplier is reset so weighing whether or not you want more XP or to live is a key point. The game also encourages multiple playthroughs allowing you to select an additional spell tree on each go. This allows you access to weapons you may not be able to obtain on other playthroughs. From my research an average playthrough takes around 15-20 hours.Overall, this game is a great pick for those who finished up the Souls games and want to have a game that plays much the same or for someone who wants to get eased into this style of gameplay and found the Souls games too unforgiving.LotF gets a solid 8/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Remember auto-tracking overheads from dark souls? This game is that, minus overheads.At least, that's what it seems to be, since I can't get past the first boss. The first boss is harder to me than any boss in any game, simply because the game is too fluid. Good games like dark souls shouldn't be fluid. If it is, that means that animations have start up times, and from start up to actual animation is about half a second. That may not seem like a lot, but in the world of reactions, it is. I have the weight for the fastest roll, which, much like dark souls, is a quarter of your maximum, and it still takes forever. Not to mention the fact that the roll takes forever to come out of, and the hit stun is way too long, and a bunch of other technical junk that just doesn't feel right. I got this game because it looked like a good way to satiate the dark souls hunger pangs, but it just reminded me of what I didn't like about some dark souls mechanics. I'm not completely cynical though, so I will add to this after I've beaten the boss, and depending on what there is, maybe I'll change my recommendation.UPDATE: Alright, I've beaten the first boss, and I'm now at the second boss. Each boss has a strategy to beating them, no shocker, but much like the rock in the Friday the 13th NES game, whether or not it works all the time is completely up to whatever RNG is deciding whether or not you are worthy enough to progress. And now we get to the interaction scenes. You meet this girl in front of the area for the second boss, and in your first interaction, you tell her whether or not to kill this monk. Alright, good moral decision. Then she tells you about a lost family heirloom, and all the answers are "be a♥♥♥♥♥♥" Then, when you go to end the conversation, you say "I don't care." Not the morally ambiguous "I must go now" or some♥♥♥♥♥♥like that. You instead say "Tata for now ♥♥♥♥er." I'll probably play more though, because I have a problem.UPDATE 2: Admiteddly, I didn't play a lot of this game when I first said I don't recommend it, however now that I've beaten the second boss I can say that this game is alright. It's not great, but it's not attrocious. The rating it has on the store page is what I'd say is perfect. I have mixed feelings for it, where part of me just says this game is not fun, but another part (my DS mind) says I could play this a lot longer. P.S. The hit stun is affected by poise, but I'm not sure how much, because I haven't tooled around with it.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												I'm ambivalent about recommending this game.Taken on its own as an action rpg, it is a solid offering with reasonable difficulty, and moderate plot, with good mechanics.The problem is that it is trying to take Dark Souls and make it a little more approachable, which I actually think it does well enough. However, this makes me realize that when you make concessions about difficulty and playability, you can end up with a much worse game.I absolutely loved Dark Souls, and this game pales in comparison, which is why I have some trouble recommending this game. DKS has a fully continuous world, where LoF uses area transitions to allow for better graphics. However, I still think the asthetics of DKS is better.Admittedly, LoF has a coherent story that is delivered to the player, but I actually liked the obfuscation of the story in Dark Souls, and it made the moral choice not just ambiguous, but also not readily apparent.I would have tried to review the game in the absence of my knowledge of Dark Souls, but it's just not possible for me to do so, so I tried to compare as best as possible.In short, I think it was good, though I haven't done a second playthrough yet, so that may change things a little, but I'm reluctant to think so.

content:

												Thought these guys were supposed to be PC game developers. But 60% score on Steam? On Steam?? Check the negative reviews. All complaining of technical issues. It's disheartening, to say the least. Whatever. It's still a good game when it works. The content lacks, but the gameplay doesn't. Feels like Dark Souls but with more thought gone in, instead of difficulty due to large gaps between player and NPC damage/hitpoints. And you shouldn't be suffering more than a couple cheap deaths (if at all) so long as you play it smart. Different tactics can yield widly different results. Surprisingly, rushing the enormous melee boss with my two handed axe jump-slashing at his knees was the best way to win in one instance, where hanging back with a big shield previously was hardly helping at all. The game is short though. And the plethora of technical problems discourage a second run through the story. But hell, if you see it on sale for good, I'd still reccomend it, since the devs at least are releasing patches.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												This game shares a lot of obvious mechanical similarities with the souls series but really does stand out as its own title.  This is a relatively linear action rpg with some castlevania esque backtracking and a lot of hidden side quests and rewards for those of us that are itching to explore every nook and cranny ( like souls, but you know where to go nearly all the time to progress the story).  The story is played out through fmv cutscenese and for the most part  the game does a good job of letting you know what's going on and where to go next.  It's not all hand holding however as there are no quest markers or maps.  no, you'll have to get accustomed to the area and recall location names if you intend to follow the leads to that special magical item you're trying to discover.  Misc Pros:Leveling and the whole purchasing stats to level thing works similar to dark souls here with its bonfire mechanic.  There are alternate hard mode challenges for each boss that rewards extra loot.  There are challenge portals that appear after a boss is defeated for those that remember to backtrack a little and get some more loot and items.  Mobs are varied enough and the bosses are distinctly unique.  Misc Cons:You can't avoid damage in this game so much as mitigate it.  Sure you can avoid a lot of it but theres much you can't or just isn't worth trying.  Second, there are relatively straight forward, clear and linear upgrades for weapons and armor types.  Third; the movesets don't change much from weapon to weapon in each wepon class (ie: all greatswords handle pretty much the same.  Just go with the one with the biggest damage.)  That being said this game holds its own as a very good title.  Coming from someone with over 700 hours across the soul titles, i happily played through this game and immediately rolled into a second play through.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Excellent Dark Souls-esque aRPG that expands upon the basic Souls gameplay in pretty much every aspect, and does it well. Fighting rewards correctly timed attacks instead of R1 mashing, the bloodstain mechanic evolved past a simple pick-up to a choice between safety and boosting your combat ability when near it, armor finally has a noticeable impact. Enemies attack accordingly to their gear - you won't see a knife-wielder wind up as if he's carrying a massive club.The art design is brilliant, I really enjoy the armor and weapons, as well as the scenery.Overall I enjoyed it for what it is. Just don't go into the game expecting Dark Souls 3.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												™ Arpium -  10.2s: Lords of the Fallen has some really great combat mechanics, you can charge bash with a shield, power swing, combo, dodge roll, backstep, counter, block (except for ridonculously big attacks that pierce your sustainability)....there isn't a vast amount of different npc models but there is a lot of different mastery of how to combat each one. The boss fights are dreadfully hard the first time around, especially the third boss. Everything has to be maneuvered just right or else you will pay for your mistakes big time. You can choose to do hardcore which provides better rewards by not emptying any gained experience into upgrades. The game is fun and very frustrating at times, I don't recommend trying the hardcore route first play through. The game is definitely a 9/10 in my book, especially since the developers are a new face in new-gen gaming advancements. Dark Souls knock-off or not, this game will satisfy action-rpg players until the Witcher 3 is released. I have a 2012 top notch gaming rig, max graphics in this game require a 2014 top-tier gaming rig for positive framerate pool, but the graphics are definitely up there with far cry and crisis series.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												Score: 6.5/10It's a much easier Dark Souls, but doesn't have near the same polish. I'm on the fence with it, but I would still give it a thumbs up if only slightly. It teases multiple playthroughs, but once was enough. There's a lot to like here, but it feels a bit half-baked at times. It's a strange game that wants to let you explore and then punishes you by doing something cheap, and it's not as rewarding once you've overcome it. On the other hand, it's not nearly as frustrating as Dark Souls can be.- You'll get hit through walls and see all manner of glitchy things.- You'll face enemies that will use cheap tactics to land hits on you. - You will find the yo-yo difficulty to be hard and then easy, then difficult again. - You will find the gear to be mostly useless.- Exploration isn't too rewarding.- The risk/reward system is a joke. Saving up kill streaks to earn more XP is barely noticeable.Get it on sale and play it over a weekend.

												As a newcomer into the 'dark soul' type of game, this was surpringly easy to get into, but hard to master. There are plenty of secrets to find and bosses to get stuck on. After updating my geforce drives, it seemed to reduce substantially, but occasional crashes still kills the experience. However, I'm sure more patches will come soon or there will be mod options.In summary, I think this game is a good start if you wanted to get into the genre and hopefullly pass the time for vererans until Bloodbourne is out (assuming you have a ps4).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												I RECOMMEND THE GAME ITSELF. NOT THIS VERSIONI have had no issues in my 20+ hours but MANY other have, so while I will say the game is great fun,the PC version suffers from major instability issues on some systems while others like mine are totally fine.So buy at your own risk****Lords of the fallen is a "souls-like" Action Adventure RPG with a heavy focus timing and positioning.The comparison to the Souls series is a given, and this game proudly wears its influences on its shoulders. This is not exactly a bad thing, but it will cause a lot of people to bandwagon hate the game (as will the DRM it uses and the PC port issues).Combat is best described as "heavy souls", your attacks and your enemies attacks are highly telegraphed and take quite a while to wind up. This means you need to make every shot count and since the rolling is far slower than the Souls roll mechanic, you will need to be more aware of your relative positioning to enemies. The combat is very fun and has a very meaty visceral feel to it that the souls games simply do not provide. Which is not to say there are not issues with the combat. Attacks seem to "hone" in on enemies as do theirs to you. Some attacks do it, some dont. Makes positioning difficult at times especially if you dont like locking on.The level's, while linear are both well designed and have a more dark souls 1 feel about them. By this I mean the world feels like it winds and interconnects in a realistic way. This may not be the case exactly as I have not looked up geometry maps but I always felt like the levels just made sense in addition to being beautifully detailed.The story was alright. Nothing special and nothing I will fondly look back on. It's a far cry from the Souls method of story telling. Its far more straight forward and told thru cut scenes. I personally didn't care about the story so I really cant say much other than how forgettable it was. Now for some lists...Similarities to the soul's games.........*Slow "difficulty" based ARPG gameplay*Potions [estus] that refill at checkpoints*RPG leveling system*Overall Feel of the game (like I said this is inspired by the Souls series and it does not hide this)*Different weapons have different move sets*A currency loss system for death Now some differences.............*Actual physical save points, so if you die (or crash) between them you lose all progress since the last save*MUCH more accessible mechanic wise (level up at any checkpoint)*Using the crystal thing [bonfire] does not reset enemies, only zoning or dying does*MUCH slower combat *You actually lose potions as you die over and over. Can be frustrating when you dont know the mechanic and it seems like you're losing potions for no reason.* MUCH more forgiving death mechanics. You can not only use an item to recover your points but you actually heal while standing around your EXP mass. * Simplified spell system* Simplified stat system* True blue combo system* functional pause* no co-op/PVP (PVEers dream)* Few more things I cant recall at the momentOverall Lords is a great game which manages to do enough different to avoid being called a Dark Souls clone. They simply have changed too many mechanics to make this game feel unique and different from any souls game to be written off as a simple clone. What this game is tho, is a game that was CLEARLY made by people who loved the souls games to death and wanted to create their own take on the game. It's similar, but different enough if that makes sense.So if you want to roll the die and see if this game will work on your PC, go for it. Otherwise get it for the next gen consoles as im told those versions are generally much more stable.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												OK first off, this game may have a few similarities with the Demon/Dark Souls series, mainly controls and the stamina/energy system, but that's where it ends. Lords of The Fallen is a great game. Graphics are stunning and even better if you make some small tweaks. If you are having problems making it look good for you then i suggest changing your GPU settings and have them override the ingame settings. I changed the settings in my Nvidia Control Panel to really make this game look amazing.With the controls being similar to DS/DSII you might start trying to play the same way but try not to because the combat in LotF is very different. It's nowhere near as difficult but it's much slower. You have to time your attacks carefully when there are openings to counter attack. That being said it's not too punishing if you mess up as long as you don't get sloppy. The combat can be very satisfying if you take your time.There are plenty of different weapon and armor types to choose from that directly affect your weight and encumberance to suit your play style. I prefer great axes myself in this game because when timed right your attacks are brutal and the ragdoll force looks awesome after a kill but not overdone. Hit boxes in general are very tight and realistic in my opinion. The story is ok. Nothing epic there. The problem is that it's very easy to lose focus on the reason the protagonist is there in the first place. "Oh yea. I'm more than a demon-killing badass, there's something I'm supposed to do." I found myself with this thought a few times after i would complete a part of the main quest and the story brought me back in. Other than that, it's fine. Voice acting, in my opinion, is very well done.The game world isn't as big as some other games in the genre. You'll find yourself going through some of the same areas to get to different objectives. Also there is no compass or radar or anything like that to give you a general idea of your location. You have to memorize the areas to get around more efficiently. I personally liked this, adding to the immersion for me, but i can see how this can be frustrating to some due to frequently getting lost or going in circles. Exploration is encouraged as there are plenty of secrets and lore to be found and even more after you complete your first playthrough, which adds to the replayability factor of Lords of the Fallen.Character development and growth is straight forward and easy to manage. Some rpg's can get a little extensive with their leveling system and attribute and/or skill distribution making for a lot of useless skills or abilities. Lords of the Fallen lets you level your character in different ways depending on your combat choice, warrior, rogue, or mage, all with useful and practical abilities that you will use all the time. You can allocate attribute points to your strength, vitality, faith etc. separately to raise the attributes you actually need and ignoring less needed ones for your play style.LotF does suffer from a few bugs. You can basically read about them all over the reviews for this game. I've seen a few glitches here and there but nothing game breaking. Mostly stuff like occasional frame rate drops or bodies glitching here and there. The only noticeable bug that i encountered was my graphics settings not saving while i was tweaking them when i first bought the game. But haven't ran into the issue again.Lords of the Fallen is a great third person action rpg that is visually breathtaking (after some tweaks) with a satisfying and rewarding combat system when patience is used and a story that can start becoming an afterthought after a few hours in but brings you back in at key points, overall it's pretty decent. The bugs are present but don't break immersion in my opinion. I really enjoyed it and hope for more like this from City Interactive.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
 100% Recommend this game. There are many Negative reviews for this game which almost kept me form buying it, and the 'Mixed' reviews really scared me, but I'm VERY happy that i purchased this game.     This is going to be a rather long section as i feel there is a very large amount to talk about. The game has the same 'Souls' feel that we all know and love with some differences here and there that really help it feel like its own game, and not just a clone as i was expecting.

       Speed: 
     This game has a very unique feel to it. The combat is slower than the Souls games, which each action having a small amount of 'wind-up' time as you would expect in real life. This is not a complaint. Yes it makes your attacks take longer than Souls titles but it also does the same for your enemies

      Movement: 
     This is a big one for me, as i always play the nimble rogue in Souls games. I feel like the movements in the game feel VERY good. Very organic and natural like you would expect from a real person diving around. 

      Crashing: 
     The one thing that ALMOST stopped me from playing but surprising enough, upgrading my gfx drivers actually solvedthe issue (something that in the past has never affected much). Definately recommend doing this BEFORE any other fixes you find. Overall i REALLY love this game. Personally i think the gameplay is better (albeit similar while also very different) than Dark Souls 2 (which really was a letdown in my opinion, but i digress).  RECOMMENDED

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Lets get the important bit out of the way first.STAY AWAY IF YOU CAN'T TAKE TROUBLESHOOTING.Stability. Stability. Stability.It took me over 3 hours to get the game to load past the first cut scene. Turns out my problem was lack of virtual memory. Popped it up to 4Gigs and off I went with no crashes in sight. I've got 16 gigs of ram so I don't know WHY it NEEDED VM at all.This game is wonderful. It's immersive, powerful and rage inducing at times. (Beside the stability issues)Pros:-Beautiful world and armor choices-Heavy response based combat.  Each swing feels more realistic than Darksouls.-Full fantastic voice acting-Difficult but not too terribly mind numbingly painful.-Powerful musicCons:-Crashing crashing crashing-Lip synch during cut scene is just horrible. They didn't even try.-First half of the bosses were so-so-Lack of keybinding support. There's no way to set up a custom config for a controller.-Lack of enemy variety. -I got lost a lot... Level design is composed of a lot of tight hallways and caverns. No necessarily a con but was bloody annoying after getting lost in the same place 3 times.When it comes down to it it was a great game, albeit short (13.4 hours first run through), fantastic combat that took forever to get the nuances to. Have a guy with a huge shield? You have to have a mace to knock it down. Low armor fast assassin type? Use a short sword or fists. You really have to adapt to who and what you are fighting through out the game or else you'll have to get creative or have a bad time. It took me about 6 hours to get the combat system down right.I picked this up for $20 and it was $20 well spent. The standard $50 is a bit steep for the time spent though there are a lot of incentives to play NG+ more spells, armor, weapons, hidden items, side quests, multiple endings, etc. I pray they make a second one with twice as much content and a wider variety of foes to sink my axe into. All in all I think I've enjoyed this more than Darksouls II and that's saying something. I just wish it was a bit more rounded out.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Review on Lords of the Fallen:After finishing Lords of The Fallen, it gave me a "Mass Effect 3" ending disappointment. The game is Overall Pretty Good, though the back-stab is rather iffy. but I swear the amount of bugs I went through really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off which I will list down there later.Positive points:1. Just as current day gamers categorize Rogue-Like and Rogue-Lite, I agree with other reviewers out there that this is Dark-Souls-Lite. The game is very similiar to Dark Souls but the game was designed for you to take hits even if you choose the rogue agility class. Other classes will take damage from the beginning of the game until the end, but for the rouge, you have to take some damage at the start of the game to kill enemies and get experience to level up. After leveling up to a certain point and obtaining your final magic ability, that is where the fun begins and you can sneak almost every enemy, "Stab" and back-stab.2. The weapon timing mechanic is very interesting especially when you dual wield. When you dual-wield, you cannot unleash your combo unless you successfully execute the perfect timing strike two times consecutively, any remaining stamina after that can be used to continue the multi-hit combo if you, once again, successfully execute the perfect timing strike.3. I've played heavy-weapons as well, and it relies more on timing the strikes or tanking enemy hits to deal a heavy blow. Early on, the perfect timing strike allows you to attack 2 times and dodge roll before having your stamina deplete. Without perfect timing, you may only attack twice and have your stamina depleted, leaving you open to attacks. Also, with this stat called Poise, more Poise means you can take larger hits without getting staggered or falling down. It is a pretty nice way to portray the "Tanky-Feeling" of Heavy Armor.4. The stamina/energy recovery is relatively fast compared to Dark Souls/ Dark Souls 2. In my opinion, this makes it a bit more enjoyable. Remember, this means the enemy has the relatively fast regeneration too.5. The enemies in the game are quite normal and it was easy to figure out their pattern. Boss attack patterns are also easy to figure out cause every attack has a distinct preparation pose. This does not necessarily mean it is easy to beat them, you still have to figure out which attacks do they combo with. Depending which magic class and armor you chose to play with, you have to react accordingly. This makes it fun, it gives me a monster hunter feeling.[The style reminds me of monster hunter, but why I did not use monster hunter as an example is because in MH, attacks do not consume stamina. In Monster Hunter, you can throw caution to the wind when fighting common mooks, and only fight seriously and learn the pattern of the boss monster. Whereas for Dark Souls and Lords, you have to fight every unit with the seriousness of a Monster Hunter Boss] 6. The Rune crafting is quite interesting, depending on what type of equipment you put the rune in, it provides different stats and different runes do different things too.Negative Points:1. Seems to me if you are a rogue and you meet an enemy with a shield, you must bring out your own shield which most likely won't work because you have low poise OR cheese'em with the magic gauntlet of pew pew. This kind of makes me feel like I'm forced to NOT play Rogue 2. Some bosses and units are too easy to cheese with the gauntlet, I experiment "the cheese" for a few shots and proceed to fight normally, when the boss changes style I experiment again to test if it can be "cheese-ed" and continue to fight as usual.3. The walls will make your camera get screwed up. When you run into a wall, chances are that your camera will zoom into your face and you cannot see the enemy. Another possibility is that you get to look inside the wall and nothing else. Therefore, besides the enemies in front of you, you have to remember, walls are you enemies too. It would have been nice if they would make the walls transparent when you go too close to the walls and zoom out but hey, maybe it was intentional to make walls your enemies too.4. The choices you make in game don't really matter which makes me feel like I should just do the main quest and nothing else if I ever play the game from start again. Just slight changes for the end, which gave me a "Mass Effect 3" ending disappointment, as said on the top.5. Sometimes when you attack, you clip through the enemy and all you see are their undergarments (loin cloth) or armor. Screwing your camera up in the process, leaving you vulnerable. Also, when this happens, 50% of the time, your damage will not register.6. The magical illusions are flawed. Not "Prayer", other skills like the Rogue's "Stab": occasionally the enemy will register that "Stabs" illusion is a target-able unit like all Magic Classes "Prayer" and proceed to attack that illusion. It is an advantage to the player but that is not suppose to happen.7. I may have said that the Rune Crafting is interesting but there is too few variety of runes. Which make it quite dull at the same time.[BUGS] Before Patch 1.4:1. Subtitle not disappearing if you change area when the subtitles are present;2. Death but not death: black screen never fades back into game except when i pause, happens when you fall into a death pit but there are stones that block your way down to the bottom which make you take damage but so happens that part of the pit is also the death line;3. Units flying into the sky during death animation and stays in the air (this one is ok, just funny);4. Run to checkpoint with enemy chasing, checkpoint disabled animation did not proc, kill enemies; checkpoint cannot proc reactivation animation; checkpoint forever disabled;5. Even after lowering graphic setting, I can't move my character as soon as the screen fades in. In two ways, holding down the button cause I knew there are units there, disabled my WASD. (yes im playing with keyboard) and another way is that when I see the screen fade in, I press any of the WASD key, he does this little shuffle to that direction and barely even moves an inch. (Note: I had 3 enemies in front of me and i'm a rogue)[no movement means death]6. The dodge invulnerability time is odd,[for the early part of the game i tried using it, after that I just didnt bother using the invul time anymore]sometimes it works sometimes it doesn't; some times you get invul at the end of dodge, sometimes i get hit at the end of dodge, doesn't make sense to me. In addition to that, the enemies' weapon hit box seemed irregular to me.7. Whether this is a bug or not, whenever a rouge uses the ability Mimic, the spirit will block your vision and you cannot see what's in front of you most of the time, this is the worst skill I have ever used if this is not a bug.Conclusion:I enjoyed playing this game, but the bugs of the game really got on my nerves. There are times I found the game ridiculous, there are times I found the game interesting and almost genius. Thus, the score is given below.Lowest I give the game : 6 .5/10Highest I give the game: 8.0/10Overall I give Lords of the Fallen: 7.0/10.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Excellent Dark Souls-esque aRPG that expands upon the basic Souls gameplay in pretty much every aspect, and does it well. Fighting rewards correctly timed attacks instead of R1 mashing, the bloodstain mechanic evolved past a simple pick-up to a choice between safety and boosting your combat ability when near it, armor finally has a noticeable impact. Enemies attack accordingly to their gear - you won't see a knife-wielder wind up as if he's carrying a massive club.The art design is brilliant, I really enjoy the armor and weapons, as well as the scenery.Overall I enjoyed it for what it is. Just don't go into the game expecting Dark Souls 3.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												™ Arpium -  10.2s: Lords of the Fallen has some really great combat mechanics, you can charge bash with a shield, power swing, combo, dodge roll, backstep, counter, block (except for ridonculously big attacks that pierce your sustainability)....there isn't a vast amount of different npc models but there is a lot of different mastery of how to combat each one. The boss fights are dreadfully hard the first time around, especially the third boss. Everything has to be maneuvered just right or else you will pay for your mistakes big time. You can choose to do hardcore which provides better rewards by not emptying any gained experience into upgrades. The game is fun and very frustrating at times, I don't recommend trying the hardcore route first play through. The game is definitely a 9/10 in my book, especially since the developers are a new face in new-gen gaming advancements. Dark Souls knock-off or not, this game will satisfy action-rpg players until the Witcher 3 is released. I have a 2012 top notch gaming rig, max graphics in this game require a 2014 top-tier gaming rig for positive framerate pool, but the graphics are definitely up there with far cry and crisis series.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												When this game released it crashed a lot apparently.  I'm on AMD with the latest version and it's totally smooth and not a crash yet.  A lot of the bad reviews were for that reason so keep that in mind, a lot of them.This game is fantastic.  I know the whole graphics don't make a game thing but if you love art as I do you'll appreciate this game.  I love to just look around at all the detail everywhere, you armor and weapons, the world, the way when you open a chest the force of the heavy lid will nudge the whole thing a little bit as would really happen.  If your coming from Dark Souls you'll appreciate the controls which are copied.  Ain't broke, don't fix.  Now when you try to play it like Dark Souls is where you will get a nasty shock.  I played this for a bit then stopped cuz it was to damn hard.  Then I came back to it fresh and really tried to understand THIS game and I'm now loving it.  It's hard to explain exactly, maybe just that the combat is more realistic in that these huge weapons have massive weight.  But there are lighter weapons as well but you have to play the game in it's own way, once you do that it's a great challenge with lots of fun secrets to find and things to dispatch.  Backstab is once again your friend.  The magic and gauntlet are great fun to use as they add a strategy as well as offense.Lets face it all these games are Dungeons and Dragons come to life and if you like the genre, love exploring decaying old dungeons and fortresses then don't hesitate.  I wonder if my 14 years old self was plopped down in front of this game what would happen.  Actually I know what would happen my brain would explode in a rainbow fireworks display.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Game finished, review too:) TL:DR at the end;pSo far, quite good. Level design is great. Armors and weapons looks awsome. Combat feal relatively realistic (apart from walls that does not stop yours or enemy weapons like in Dark Souls, which was great idea in these games), you can see that your weapon has weight and it is seen on enemies when you hit them, you can see the impact. Other mechanics are a lot like Dark Souls, you still have exp/souls to collect in order for better loot and lvl up your main stats. Chcaracter wise, you can choose from 3 archetypes (brawl, deception, and faith) and then you select your starting gear (rogue, warrior and cleric)  which gives you 9 possible cobinations which is quite good. Althou there is no mage charcter per se. Only Ranged magic attack is gountlet, which is found after 2nd boss (around 1 hour into the game).Speakin of bosses, in my opinion they are nothing special. Most of them, if you played and completed DS/DS2 can be beat on your first go. I write most of them as there is few interesting mechanics (like insta kill on Worshipper boss). Each boss has some kind of gimmic that you need consider in order to beat him. Speaking of ♥♥♥♥♥shipper (pun intented), as far i know more bosses in game features summoning adds mechanics, which is not bad lets say on Commander (which have sense as he commands), but on this Worshipper boss, level of toxic atmosphere created by summoning golems (that stagger you while attacking) and boss can summon multiple adds at the same time, which happens to be instadeath for you as these little golems can jump-attack ridiculs amounts of space and stagger you to death. Which is really bad boss decision. In fact this mechanics remembers me Royal Rat Authority from Dark Souls 2 which was crucified by fans as not interesting, frustrating and very poorly wittern boss fight. Looks like creators of Lords... had no better solution to make bosses challenging, just insert add mechanic. Which is bad. Following this little rant of mine, if you are still interested in this game (and you should, even with failed boss adds) i have encountered few annoying bugs. Here is an example of such bug:- in catacumbs (omfg great lvl ;p) i died near entrance, when i respawned i could not find my exp/there was no timer nor any indication that i had died (apart from lost exp/pots etc.) - enemies tends to bugout, you cant target them or attack, even if you cant get past them, as they block your only exit. - execution camera is wierd, it tends to zoom in like crazy, and all you see is piece of armor (if you are lucky) - for AMD users, you should manually disable PhysX in 2 seperate ini files ( just google it) - poor optimalization. - voice acting and lip sync is super wierdOk final verdict: 7,5/10why? i flippin enjoy this game, if you stop looking at these annoying things game is enjoyable. So far i have 7 hours, and i still enjoy it.TL;DR:  After finish game with Warrior Brawler, i must say, fun game, deffinitly worth your attention and money. Yes, you will encounter few bugs, like vanishing monsters, but its nothing that breaks the game. Fun title.

												Had some performace issues, but much better after turning off volumetric lightning, single CTD yet ( one in 4 hours).Pros:-Similar to Dark Souls-Great Visuals-Good controls, I like how favorite weapons are not considered in equip load unlike Dark Souls, the item/magic toggle and use is pretty good as well, but jump could be better.Cons: -Some weird hit boxes-Bad magic system, too long to cast, too flashy, more like small buffs than actual spell casting, Gauntlet laser is nice, the others aren't.-Attribute system with less freedom to try out weapons-No autosave, frustrating if I expect another CTD especially with the exp multiplier stuff.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												As a newcomer into the 'dark soul' type of game, this was surpringly easy to get into, but hard to master. There are plenty of secrets to find and bosses to get stuck on. The maps seem huge until you complete the game you realise how small it actually is after unlocking shortcuts or routes back to earlier parts of the game. I see this as a testiment to good map design and there are plenty of varied enviroments- from castles, to prisons, graveyards and even demon realms.Overall this has consumed my time and I'm close to completing NG+ at the time of writing.However, right now there are random crashes to the game. After updating my geforce drives, it seemed to reduce substantially, but occasional crashes still kills the experience. However, I'm sure more patches will come soon or there will be mod options.In summary, I think this game is a good start if you wanted to get into the genre and hopefullly pass the time for vererans until Bloodbourne is out (assuming you have a ps4).
