Posted: November 14, 2014
												I honestly don't know where all these  bad reviews are coming from i have not suffered a single crash in my 17+ hours of gameplay. The game looks stunning on ultra settings and the art style is is interesting and consistent. The game might be a little on the  easier side if you're used to games like dark souls but that doesn't mean that there is no challenge . while the bosses aren't super stunning like those found in dark souls they are still a lot of fun to figure out and they all have a special way you can defeat them so they drop a special weapon. Im glad that more developers are willing to work on the formula that dark souls has established. Just like we have metroidvania and rouge likes I cant wait to see more souls like games its one of the most rewarding gaming experiences and this game does it fairly well. it’s a fun game with realistic combat that presents a decent challenge in a unique atmosphere. The story is okay but it is nothing to write home about but the weapons and equipment collecting is where the most fun is to be had

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												I RECOMMEND THE GAME ITSELF. NOT THIS VERSIONI have had no issues in my 20+ hours but MANY other have, so while I will say the game is great fun,the PC version suffers from major instability issues on some systems while others like mine are totally fine.So buy at your own risk****Lords of the fallen is a "souls-like" Action Adventure RPG with a heavy focus timing and positioning.The comparison to the Souls series is a given, and this game proudly wears its influences on its shoulders. This is not exactly a bad thing, but it will cause a lot of people to bandwagon hate the game (as will the DRM it uses and the PC port issues).Combat is best described as "heavy souls", your attacks and your enemies attacks are highly telegraphed and take quite a while to wind up. This means you need to make every shot count and since the rolling is far slower than the Souls roll mechanic, you will need to be more aware of your relative positioning to enemies. The combat is very fun and has a very meaty visceral feel to it that the souls games simply do not provide. Which is not to say there are not issues with the combat. Attacks seem to "hone" in on enemies as do theirs to you. Some attacks do it, some dont. Makes positioning difficult at times especially if you dont like locking on.The level's, while linear are both well designed and have a more dark souls 1 feel about them. By this I mean the world feels like it winds and interconnects in a realistic way. This may not be the case exactly as I have not looked up geometry maps but I always felt like the levels just made sense in addition to being beautifully detailed.The story was alright. Nothing special and nothing I will fondly look back on. It's a far cry from the Souls method of story telling. Its far more straight forward and told thru cut scenes. I personally didn't care about the story so I really cant say much other than how forgettable it was. Now for some lists...Similarities to the soul's games.........*Slow "difficulty" based ARPG gameplay*Potions [estus] that refill at checkpoints*RPG leveling system*Overall Feel of the game (like I said this is inspired by the Souls series and it does not hide this)*Different weapons have different move sets*A currency loss system for death Now some differences.............*Actual physical save points, so if you die (or crash) between them you lose all progress since the last save*MUCH more accessible mechanic wise (level up at any checkpoint)*Using the crystal thing [bonfire] does not reset enemies, only zoning or dying does*MUCH slower combat *You actually lose potions as you die over and over. Can be frustrating when you dont know the mechanic and it seems like you're losing potions for no reason.* MUCH more forgiving death mechanics. You can not only use an item to recover your points but you actually heal while standing around your EXP mass. * Simplified spell system* Simplified stat system* True blue combo system* functional pause* no co-op/PVP (PVEers dream)* Few more things I cant recall at the momentOverall Lords is a great game which manages to do enough different to avoid being called a Dark Souls clone. They simply have changed too many mechanics to make this game feel unique and different from any souls game to be written off as a simple clone. What this game is tho, is a game that was CLEARLY made by people who loved the souls games to death and wanted to create their own take on the game. It's similar, but different enough if that makes sense.So if you want to roll the die and see if this game will work on your PC, go for it. Otherwise get it for the next gen consoles as im told those versions are generally much more stable.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Don't let the pretty visuals fool you; save your money for a game that is remotely playable!I don't know why developers feel the need to make games like this one: games where you can play for over two hours and not be able to defeat the FIRST boss in the game (I only tried over 20 times...).  You actually LOSE experience when you die, and even if you stockpile enough XP to level up (in a reasonably designed game, at least), you can't use it because you haven't reached a certain spot in the game yet.  So those who aren't gaming ninjas are left essentially without a mechanism to even beef up their character to the point of being able to defeat said *first boss*.  Disgusting...  The boss that hits you even when you roll out of range of his attack, kills you in two to three hits, moves faster than you, has unlimited stamina - compared to you being crippled by just two to four attacks (all of which barely dent his health, even when you stab him in the back).  I was *behind* him a few times and got hit by *his* sword, yet mine did a measly *two* damage compared to the 50 his weapon did to me!  Yeah, I could go on.  You basically have NO advantage to use against this guy.  I literally had no way past this first area to even start the actual main portion of the game.  Wasted money...

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												Lords of the Fallen had, and may still have great potential, but technical flaws and not enough unique takes, leave it a little behind the competition.Pros:-Great visuals, effects, and combat system-Amazing looking armor and weapons, and other loot, await you right from the start-Engaging properly spaced Boss fights-Heavy deep dungeon Dark Souls Esq feel-I really can't stress how fun the combat is, it might not have as much content to it as Dark Souls, but it feels better, swings really have weight to them, your character can feel really badass at times.-Interesting areas, enviroments that really draw you in, even if you may not 100% understand where you are sometimes.-Replayable at least 2 or 3 times.Cons:-Heavy technical flaws on launch, numerous crashes randomly and on launching the game, low FPS on high end systems, save file corruption, game breaking bugs, and option settings not saving if you don't use a controller to set them. These are the biggest problem with Lords of The Fallen right now for many people.-No difficulty adjustment, some people love an insanely hard challenge, others might find it too easy, but regardless you don't have a choice in the matter, which will be frustrating to some. Sometimes enemies can be cheap, a lot of the "difficulty" can be an illusion. One example is many stronger normals or boss enemies can just outright kill you, they are almost always AOE spells or abilities that if hit, will automatically end your life and wipe all progress from last checkpoint.-Game can get generic at times, lacking  standout customization, magic, etc...and the variety on these isn't that high.-A little short-Easy to get lost without any sense of direction, and the objectives don't update enough for you to tell if you are on the right path; this leads to a lot of backtracking and aimless wandering.Summarrize:4.5/10 The technical flaws, generic feel, and especially the lack of any navigation system or sense of direction are the biggest downfalls with this game, that being said there is a decent game underneath here if the dev follows through on fixing the heavy technical problems of the PC version. Right now I would say if you want to try this game, wait. I mean you can wait and both get it on sale later, and after the kinks have been ironed out if at all.I can thumbs up this, but only barely. The developers have released two patches already, so if they follow through and get the game to a more playable state... Well, there is a good game underneath, it just needs to be pulled out yet.Additional Questions:Is the game minimize friendly? No.Is the game Steam Overlay friendly? Sometimes.Stong Chormatic Abrretion? Yes, but can be disabled but you must disable all Post Processing FX.EDIT: I had to come back and lower my review to a negative this time. About 3 bosses from the end of the game, it just ♥♥♥♥ed up my save file when I died, so I now have to delete it and start the entire game all over again, which after this dreadful experience, I am not doing.This game has been a nightmare of tech problems, which is a shame, because there was a good game in here, beneath terrible level design, difficulty imbalance, and the many many MANY tech problems.Other people have had similar problems, the bugs are not small, they are game breaking/ending, as in you hit a bug thats it, game over, delete and restart all over again:http://fextralife.com/forums/t39758/stuck-in-a-pit-in-the-catacombs/

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												™ Arpium -  10.2s: Lords of the Fallen has some really great combat mechanics, you can charge bash with a shield, power swing, combo, dodge roll, backstep, counter, block (except for ridonculously big attacks that pierce your sustainability)....there isn't a vast amount of different npc models but there is a lot of different mastery of how to combat each one. The boss fights are dreadfully hard the first time around, especially the third boss. Everything has to be maneuvered just right or else you will pay for your mistakes big time. You can choose to do hardcore which provides better rewards by not emptying any gained experience into upgrades. The game is fun and very frustrating at times, I don't recommend trying the hardcore route first play through. The game is definitely a 9/10 in my book, especially since the developers are a new face in new-gen gaming advancements. Dark Souls knock-off or not, this game will satisfy action-rpg players until the Witcher 3 is released. I have a 2012 top notch gaming rig, max graphics in this game require a 2014 top-tier gaming rig for positive framerate pool, but the graphics are definitely up there with far cry and crisis series.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												Lords of the Fallen is usually compared to Dark Souls (sometimes unfairly), and while yes, it IS similar, there are differences that make it its own game.The game play is very similar, and if you own a controller and have played dark souls you'll feel right at home.You gain experience from each enemy which can either be gambled or stored, and monsters only seem to respawn if you die, so it will balance earlier.The beginning of the game is very much a tutorial, and it does (thankfully) get a little more difficult as you progress through the story (for me one of the very positive aspects).You also get challenge portals linked to lords. Kill a lord, and then go into the challenge portal, survive and you get loot.The more you have of these, and the more risks you take, the better you will do in the game.The balance of the game is set for people who will use the Checkpoint system, so you may find it either too difficult, or too easy if you circumvent it.The experience is engaging, and quite addictive.Positives:  Great aesthetic  Challenging  Good story/Strong story telling  Rewarding feeling (loot / challenges / accomplishments)  Large levelsNegatives:  There are frame rate issues, and stuttering. Sometimes it will freeze for 1 second or so (seems related to asset loading)  Crashes (I've only had two and they seem to be related to alt+tab) - Alt+tab == crash.  Mixed balance - some enemies are too easy, some are too tough (for no apparent reason - though this may be related to an area you shouldn't yet be in.)

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												There's no end to the problems with this game. The combat is clunky, poorly timed and often unfairly difficult rather than actually difficult. The boss fights in particular have some interesting gimmicks that seem like a positive at first, but really only make sure you never want to play through them ever again because no-one likes solving the same puzzle twice. There are 0 likeable or relatable characters, period. The main man is built like a brick shithouse with a past obtusely obscured, has no discernable motive in any way and is acting for other characters whose motives are nebulous and poorly explained at best. The world is littered with audio notes that serve to fill in the backstory, but since the game wants to try and avoid having an ENTIRELY linear progression, trying to use those notes to learn the history of the world is tedious and scrambled. The dialogue options all feel entirely without consequence. The game has a horrible fascination with giving zero direction to the player except a one sentence task and that's ultimately what killed my enjoyment. I got to an area, realised that I was being given no direction (and in certain cases outright lied to about my direction or given conflicting information by characters and questlog) and put down my controller. After 13 hours I realised exactly how little fun I'd had at all. It's such a shame, as well. The game is graphically beautiful, the aesthetic of the character design and world design is incredibly cohesive and often remarkable. The new twists that LotF brings to standard RPG elements serve it well and are pretty damn unique. It's let down by how little I care about anyone and anything in the world, how boring a lot of the combat and exploration can be and how little the developers care about directing a player through their world.I'd recommend picking it up at maybe $5, checking it out and seeing if you get more out of it than I did.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												I was really hoping to enjoy this game but the combat, which is really the biggest part of the game, is sooooooooooo slooooooooow and clunky. Even just running feels slow. The responsivness just isn't there.The first boss was ridiculous, a later boss was easy just took a long time as I had to fight off other enemies periodically and the main guy had a huge shield I couldn't do much against. You can't get behind shielded enemies unless the attack even then they turn quick but you can't, even with the lightest armor.Shortly after that there is a enemy with a big shield, not a boss just a higher than normal ranking enemy, and he is impossible because he hardly takes any damage. Totally absurd leveling and consistency.Some of the voice acting is pretty bad. Graphics are great though. That is about the only good thing going for this game. I have 13 hours on record but have only played about 2 hours into the game because I have restarted that many times trying to give it another chance. I just can't deal with how slow the combat is and the lack of response in the game. I really don't get what the devs were thinking here.Anyways, big waste of money and time I won't get back. Would be nice if the devs fixed the combat as there seems to be potential for a good game, but that probably won't happen.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												This is probably one of the most overlooked and under-rated games I have come across.  A real hidden gem.  The art makes it look like any other western fantasy game with oversized swords and shoulderpads, but if you look deeper underneath those fur-padded pouldrons you will find a very well put together game.  The game setting is kinda generic, but it is so well executed that when you start playing you wont even care.It is worth mentioning that the bugs that plagued it at launch are gone, so don't wory about that.The graphics are amazing, though I find the post processing a little overdone.  It is easy to turn off though.The level design is fantastic, and is outdone only by the dark souls franchise itself.  The same goes for the combat.The combat is really satisfying, bug free, and very engaging.  Button mashing will not see you through.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												I've tried very hard to like this game but I'm just not having fun. I knew going into it that it was a slow and clunky dark souls, but I thought it would be a case of 'different is not worse'. I'm now not so sure about that. I am constantly frustrated by combat mechanics that simply don't work as well as they should. There are also a few frustrating non-combat mechanics which seem to have no good reason to exist. Doging and parrying are too slow. The majority of parryable enemy attacks are too fast to reaction parry. If you want to parry you will often have to anticipate blind. Even fewer attacks can be dodged on reaction; the dodge is pretty useless except for bosses with extremly slow attacks. There are some enemies with combo attacks for which the first attack is dogeable on reaction but the second is a guranteed hit because rolls can't be chained; there are too many vulnerabilty frames between successive rolls. And since the buckler isn't very good at blocking this all adds up to an agility character having virtually no reliable tools. It's not fun to play. Like DS, if you die you drop your xp and you must return to the spot you died to recover it. The difference however is that in this game there is a timer. If you don't get back in time then they are gone.  In DS I might die often, but I rarely fail to recover my souls. In this game however it seems like the opposite will be the case; recovering my xp after dying seems like it will be rare. If I die early then I can recover but the xp dropped is insignificant, and if I die late (when carrying a lot of xp) it seems impossible to get back before the timer expires. Also like DS, you can return to the checkpoint to recover your healing items. However in this game that does *not* cause the enemies to respawn. It makes absolutely no sense. If you're not going to respawn the enemies then why make me run all the way back and forth through the empty stage to refill my healing?? The only incentive offered to not do this (besides the hassle of running back and forth) is that is resets a xp multiplier that increases slowly the longer you go without resting. However, for casual players, the xp multiplier is insignificant compared to the risk of dying and losing all your xp because of the stupid recovery timer mentioned above. Playing this game involves constantaly running back to the previous checkpoint to refill healing and bank xp.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												I paid 9€ so I don't want to be too hard on the game, but it's far from perfect. I heard it was difficult, but that's not the word I'd use. I'd go more with unfair (I mean, I've died only once from the start until a bit after the 2nd boss, and it was because of the lock screen button bug). The combat feels kind of sloppy, and it's too slow (you don't have many ways to do things faster without getting hit), which is fine for some enemies, but not for every single enemy in the game. The first bosses are boring and spammy, plus they're just biggest version of the other enemy knights.Pros:- The game looks great.- The combat feels good against certain enemies (specially those that don't have a giant shield and take 2h of running around to kill).Cons:- The game tries to imitate Dark Souls' combat mechanics, but fails. Most of the combats up until now have consisted of running in circles around the enemy until they decide to attack, because if you try to attack first, you'll get hit.- The 2nd boss adds to that the ability to spawn adds, so the fight consists of: a) Run around the boss until it attacks so you can avoid the giant shield. b) You hit it 2/3 times, so it shields up, becomes invulnerable and spawns 1/2 adds. c) Rinse and repeat.- The "Lock camera on enemy" button works only when it feels like it... I got hit a couple of times in a boss because it didn't work.- All the enemies look the same.- The 1st ability I got feels totally useless, so that isn't encouraging either.- The dialogs and characters (up until this point, at least), don't help to make me want to keep on playing.I'll try to continue, but everytime I face one of those knights with a giant shield and we start to dance around each other, I feel like just deleting the game.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												Probably one of the first reviews for a game on Steam i've made...but it has to be done.  I'm not averse to challenge or a steep difficulty curve.  But that's only acceptable when the game's mechanics and controls are tight enough to overcome those hurdles.  Lords of the Fallen does the complete opposite.  First off, the good parts. The game looks pretty damn good.  The graphics and surroundings are very atmospheric and draw you into the game's world.  It runs smooth on a moderately spec'd PC with shadows turned to low since they're mostly a resource hog that provides little to no immersion (IMO). The armor and weapon designs are awesome. I'm a huge fan of variety when it comes to gear, and that was one of the main draws to this game for me.  The leveling mechanics and loot drop boost based on how much XP you're carrying is actually pretty clever, although the increase you get based on the amount of XP you have is almost pointless, 5 levels worth of XP to get a 1.2 times boost? Um...no.  Then there's variety in gear choice based upon stats.  You can choose to be a walking fortress that's slow but tough with heavy armor, or a nimble rogue with super quick reflexes and little armor to weight you down!...or at least that's how it SHOULD be.  Sure with your carcass clad in plates of metal you roll as slow as an overweight armadillo attempting to do a cartwheel, which is only normal I suppose.  But get butt naked and you can now roll with the speed of a mongoose and the reflexes of a cat!....which is where the bad comes into play.  Weight stats on armor and weapons are a lie!The game pits you against mobs ranging from tiny annoying spiders to monster sized tower shield weilding enemies.  Regardless of what enemy it is, they can attack two or even three times in the same window of opportunity it takes you to get 1 maybe 2 swings if you're lucky.  But wait...didn't the game say that the enemies are governed by the same rule set that you are? Meaning that they can be stunned, staggered, blocked or dodged just as well as you? Sure, so long as you're aware that your character isn't really Harkyn, but his stupid cousin Derpkyn, who takes 3 seconds to swing a 1h axe with a weight of 1.00 and can't roll out of the way of an enemy to, well, literally save his life!  Let me break it down in Derpkyn like terms.   You're slow.  And when I mean slow, i mean ♥♥♥♥ing slow!  A 1 handed axe, the starter shield and all Rogue light weight armor does NOTHING to increase your ability to dodge incoming attacks!  The weight stats are a complete lie.  Sure, the animation makes it LOOK like you're rolling as fast as Sonic on crack while going after a Chili dog, but it's all in your head.  Because even though you may look like you're about to break the sound barrier you get your butt plugged by an enemy who's 4 feet taller than you, has more armor than Iron Man and a weapon that should take the power of a thousand white hot suns to move!Derpkyn is slow.  Regardless of armor and/or weapons.  The game isn't hard because of mechanics or learning curve. The game is hard because the movements of all your attacks are slow as frozen balls.  Plain and simple. False difficulty due to forced sluggish combat is lame.

content:
Posted: April 7
												People mention that this game is not Dark Souls and should not be reviewed as if it were a Dark Souls title. That being said, a game creates an experience for the player, and if they made a game influenced by Dark Souls then that relationship will be inherent in the experience because that is how it was designed. The Good: Exploring the level is enticing and bound to create some interesting experiences. The "bonfire" mechanic where you can opt out of a character refresh for higher experience points is an interesting take on the checkpoint system for a harcore ARPG.The Okay: The combat is really sluggish and clunky. You need to get used to slower dodge mechanics and a slight input delay if you are coming fresh off of a Souls experience. Once you get used to it, the game is definitely doable and offers a unique challenge. The feeling it provides the player is less of a nimble assassin, or powerful warrior, and more of an old man doing his best not to die. Not bad necessarily, just different. The Bad: Boss Battles and Crashes. The boss battles are very drawn out. This would be fine if there was multiple phases, or that gameplay led to a high paced action battle. As mentioned earlier, the combat is slow. A long slow battle becomes boring. Even when you have been trying over and over again and finally succeed, you don't let out a victory cry, you just feel like you came off a slow day of work and are finally done. This game loves to crash in the second half of boss battles, as if it wasn't tedious enough.This game is a different experience that is not super terrible. They tainted the experience by drawing a lot of influence from Dark Souls and missing the boat on some of the significant elements that created such a strong community. If they modified the bonfire and souls aspects to make it less like dark souls and more like its own game, the experience may have stood out and been judged by its own merit.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												not a bad game, while the combat and style is similar to dark souls this is a very different game with a more vocalized story. how ever by comparison the over all feel of the game is a lot more clunky with almost every armor build leaving you feeling heavy and some unintuitive weapon attack styles. at times the camera can be horrible offering you little to no view of the fight as the game often stuffs you into tight hallways leading to your death. Waiting for an opening can be tedious as enemies can take quite a while to launch an attack and with no way to provoke them, small openings, and some builds lacking the ability to break an enemies gaurd comabt can sometimes get frustrating. the powers are very intersting and unique but some are more usefull than others in cases where many of support powers have no effect on bosses leaving people that took offencive powers with a signifcant advantage. while most bosses are fun and even offer a challange there are a few that are way to strong with way to much health and a gimic that doesnt work, either they recover too quickly, dont have any form of tell just simply launch an attack leaving you scrambling to find the counter or change their pattern so irregularly that the gimic required for the fight simply is ineffective. the two biggest let downs of this game however are its pittiful replay value offering nothing more than slight change to the ending cinamtic where you don't even get to view the conciquences of your actions it is displayed in a way that makes it seem as though nothing changed. and the worst part of the game is its length, this is a full price game and in one run i got over half the achievements found almost all of the secrets and cleared all the story and sidequests. All this took a total of 16 hours and the NG+ feature is trivial once you've spent the time to power up your character during your first play. all in all i had fun with the game but its just simply not roth full price 4/10

												Lords Of The Fallen attempts to seize the crown of the Action RPG genre.Maybe another time.PROS:+ arguably, aesthetics(fans of Warhammer will be pleased by armour and weapon designs)+ using heavy weapons is great+ occasionally, combat..CONS:- ..which(combat), most of the time, is clunky as hell- the plot; you couldn't care less about the fate of Harkyn and his world- the general "heaviness" of the game(works just fine when using a two handed weapon and an ultra heavy armour, in other cases it is infuriating)I understand the creative process behind this game.Take a successful formula, give it a spin or two and- voila!Sadly, the end result is simply not enjoyable enough.If the game is meant to be challenging and difficult, it has to present the player with, at least, decently polished mechanics.LOTF's gameplay is neither precise nor tweaked enough to make the experience rewarding.I tried to convince myself a few times that the game has enough value to be recommended.Don't help Lords Of The Fallen get up.It isn't worth your time.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												Easiest way I can describe this game:It's like Souls. Only with broken hit boxes, broken parrys, stun locks that go on for a frame longer than needed and punishing in the wrong ways. Think playing Souls 2, but as though it relied on a shoddy netcode that resulted in lag. That's about how some of the deaths feel. Dodge the same attack 4 times, but that 5th time  you get hit and it feels like you were desynced or some♥♥♥♥♥♥.. even though it's obviously a single player title. So it's like Souls. But the hussied up Chinese quality version. It's pretty, does what you wanted and It was a good price on sale; but after a few hours you find yourself wishing you had just spent more on the brand named item. Each time I find myself thinking that I'm enjoying the game it quickly reminds me of why the reviews are a solid "mixed". In short. It's a knockoff . Nothing more, nothing less. A lot off superficial work that went into something meant to be a cash in on the "Souls-like" genre.I do plan on seeing it through... but something tells me the journey and payoff is going to feel like  a road trip gone wrong. You set out planing on having a good time, but after 2 days on the road, seeing nothing interesting and eating ♥♥♥♥♥♥ truckstop food you finally get to where you  were going. Only to find out it's just a tourist trap and not worth staying at for more than 30 minutes. You've wasted time and money doing nothing actually interesting... but sort of have a story to share in the end.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												Pros:It's fun when it decides to actually workThe graphics are pretty ((aside from visually glitches, which you get a lot of, like A LOT)The "hardcore" system makes sense and adds meaning to dying, forcing you to play smarter (not unlike darksouls, but by no means can this game even come close to the master piece that is darksouls and demon souls)Cons:Visual Glitches, once every half hour i get one xDBoss battles aren't all that epic and are way too easy once you figure out how to kill themA lot of mechanics don't really work, like the large shield bash (he decides how long it's gonna be stuck in the ground before he attempts at moving again) oh geez the combat system it self is pretty shotty at best (character will stand still after animations, sometimes not even respond to the controls)Speaking of controls, good god why, why is there no way to use a gamepad... WHY!!! if the mouse and keyboard controls weren't so awkward it could be over looked, but they are extremely awkward and hinderingThe targeting system... it's awful, they tried to mimic the souls games targeting style but it didn't work. There is no real way to pick who on the screen is going to be targeted leading to your death constantly Ranged enemies, christ i spent so long trying to time my role to dodge the bolts or arrows or what ever the hell else the guys would throw at me. But if you watch their animations it wont help you because the moment they aim at you theyve already fired. Very unrealistic and very anti fun.Lastly if you want a game like darksouls, go play darksouls. This game is a shallow try at an amazing game, side questing is terrible. Gameplay is so dependant on if the game is having a ptsd episode or if it feels like not listening to you at all. I DO NOT RECCOMEND THIS GAME, AT ALL

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												Probably one of the first reviews for a game on Steam i've made...but it has to be done.  I'm not averse to challenge or a steep difficulty curve.  But that's only acceptable when the game's mechanics and controls are tight enough to overcome those hurdles.  Lords of the Fallen does the complete opposite.  First off, the good parts. The game looks pretty damn good.  The graphics and surroundings are very atmospheric and draw you into the game's world.  It runs smooth on a moderately spec'd PC with shadows turned to low since they're mostly a resource hog that provides little to no immersion (IMO). The armor and weapon designs are awesome. I'm a huge fan of variety when it comes to gear, and that was one of the main draws to this game for me.  The leveling mechanics and loot drop boost based on how much XP you're carrying is actually pretty clever, although the increase you get based on the amount of XP you have is almost pointless, 5 levels worth of XP to get a 1.2 times boost? Um...no.  Then there's variety in gear choice based upon stats.  You can choose to be a walking fortress that's slow but tough with heavy armor, or a nimble rogue with super quick reflexes and little armor to weight you down!...or at least that's how it SHOULD be.  Sure with your carcass clad in plates of metal you roll as slow as an overweight armadillo attempting to do a cartwheel, which is only normal I suppose.  But get butt naked and you can now roll with the speed of a mongoose and the reflexes of a cat!....which is where the bad comes into play.  Weight stats on armor and weapons are a lie!The game pits you against mobs ranging from tiny annoying spiders to monster sized tower shield weilding enemies.  Regardless of what enemy it is, they can attack two or even three times in the same window of opportunity it takes you to get 1 maybe 2 swings if you're lucky.  But wait...didn't the game say that the enemies are governed by the same rule set that you are? Meaning that they can be stunned, staggered, blocked or dodged just as well as you? Sure, so long as you're aware that your character isn't really Harkyn, but his stupid cousin Derpkyn, who takes 3 seconds to swing a 1h axe with a weight of 1.00 and can't roll out of the way of an enemy to, well, literally save his life!  Let me break it down in Derpkyn like terms.   You're slow.  And when I mean slow, i mean ♥♥♥♥ing slow!  A 1 handed axe, the starter shield and all Rogue light weight armor does NOTHING to increase your ability to dodge incoming attacks!  The weight stats are a complete lie.  Sure, the animation makes it LOOK like you're rolling as fast as Sonic on crack while going after a Chili dog, but it's all in your head.  Because even though you may look like you're about to break the sound barrier you get your butt plugged by an enemy who's 4 feet taller than you, has more armor than Iron Man and a weapon that should take the power of a thousand white hot suns to move!Derpkyn is slow.  Regardless of armor and/or weapons.  The game isn't hard because of mechanics or learning curve. The game is hard because the movements of all your attacks are slow as frozen balls.  Plain and simple. False difficulty due to forced sluggish combat is lame.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												I paid 9€ so I don't want to be too hard on the game, but it's far from perfect. I heard it was difficult, but that's not the word I'd use. I'd go more with unfair (I mean, I've died only once from the start until a bit after the 2nd boss, and it was because of the lock screen button bug). The combat feels kind of sloppy, and it's too slow (you don't have many ways to do things faster without getting hit), which is fine for some enemies, but not for every single enemy in the game. The first bosses are boring and spammy, plus they're just biggest version of the other enemy knights.Pros:- The game looks great.- The combat feels good against certain enemies (specially those that don't have a giant shield and take 2h of running around to kill).Cons:- The game tries to imitate Dark Souls' combat mechanics, but fails. Most of the combats up until now have consisted of running in circles around the enemy until they decide to attack, because if you try to attack first, you'll get hit.- The 2nd boss adds to that the ability to spawn adds, so the fight consists of: a) Run around the boss until it attacks so you can avoid the giant shield. b) You hit it 2/3 times, so it shields up, becomes invulnerable and spawns 1/2 adds. c) Rinse and repeat.- The "Lock camera on enemy" button works only when it feels like it... I got hit a couple of times in a boss because it didn't work.- All the enemies look the same.- The 1st ability I got feels totally useless, so that isn't encouraging either.- The dialogs and characters (up until this point, at least), don't help to make me want to keep on playing.I'll try to continue, but everytime I face one of those knights with a giant shield and we start to dance around each other, I feel like just deleting the game.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												It is no secret this games tries to mimic Dark Souls, so there are 2 questions:>Is this game succesful copying Dark Souls?A> Not at all.>Is this game good/worth it on its own?A>Not even close.The game looks good graphically and i didn't have any major performance issues or crashes. I thought it could not be that bad, at least for playing something light, and boy i was mistaken. The game is just uninspired, no story, bad voice acting, bad animations and dull gameplay. It is slow and may seems strategic, but it is not, it is tedious and repetitive (slow attacks vs high HP enemies which can still change the attack direction by spinning in their axis from start to end).This game is a time waster with no depth or solid mechanics, en even then apparently is only 15 hours long.Seriously, avoid.

The leveling mechanics and loot drop boost based on how much XP you're carrying is actually pretty clever, although the increase you get based on the amount of XP you have is almost pointless, 5 levels worth of XP to get a 1.2 times boost? Um...no.  Then there's variety in gear choice based upon stats.  You can choose to be a walking fortress that's slow but tough with heavy armor, or a nimble rogue with super quick reflexes and little armor to weight you down!...or at least that's how it SHOULD be.  Sure with your carcass clad in plates of metal you roll as slow as an overweight armadillo attempting to do a cartwheel, which is only normal I suppose.  But get butt naked and you can now roll with the speed of a mongoose and the reflexes of a cat!....which is where the bad comes into play.  Weight stats on armor and weapons are a lie!The game pits you against mobs ranging from tiny annoying spiders to monster sized tower shield weilding enemies.  Regardless of what enemy it is, they can attack two or even three times in the same window of opportunity it takes you to get 1 maybe 2 swings if you're lucky.  But wait...didn't the game say that the enemies are governed by the same rule set that you are? Meaning that they can be stunned, staggered, blocked or dodged just as well as you? Sure, so long as you're aware that your character isn't really Harkyn, but his stupid cousin Derpkyn, who takes 3 seconds to swing a 1h axe with a weight of 1.00 and can't roll out of the way of an enemy to, well, literally save his life!  Let me break it down in Derpkyn like terms.   You're slow.  And when I mean slow, i mean ♥♥♥♥ing slow!  A 1 handed axe, the starter shield and all Rogue light weight armor does NOTHING to increase your ability to dodge incoming attacks!  The weight stats are a complete lie.  Sure, the animation makes it LOOK like you're rolling as fast as Sonic on crack while going after a Chili dog, but it's all in your head.  Because even though you may look like you're about to break the sound barrier you get your butt plugged by an enemy who's 4 feet taller than you, has more armor than Iron Man and a weapon that should take the power of a thousand white hot suns to move!Derpkyn is slow.  Regardless of armor and/or weapons.  The game isn't hard because of mechanics or learning curve. The game is hard because the movements of all your attacks are slow as frozen balls.  Plain and simple. False difficulty due to forced sluggish combat is lame.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19
												Lords of the fallen is often accused of being just a dark souls rip-off, to be honest it doesn't rip-off dark souls because this is not dark souls, the game is extremely linear, barerly to no exploration and the level design just can't compete with dark souls 1.Does this mean that the game is bad? well no, it's not awful, it does a lot of thing right but it has a lot of issues.Issue 1: The game performance is extremely inconsistent.My pc is not stellar in any way but i think that most pc users will not enjoy this port's perfomance, my frame-rate varies to 40fps to 8fps, sometimes even when there is nothing on the screen it drops to 15 or even 10 fps.The graphics look incredible at max settings, but at low they look horrible, i know that low settings the game does not have to look spectacular but the thing i don't understand is why my fps gain is 5 or 10 compared to max settings, even lowering the resolution does not help me at all.Issue 2: Combat:Combat in lords of the fallen is somewhat of a mixed bag, it starts just like a dark souls game but then it becomes extremely unfair and boring with bosses.It's unfair because most enemies will practically do massive damage to you while knoking you to the ground, just so you will get up and then KILL YOU BECAUSE THEY SOMEHOW FORGOT TO MAKE YOU INVINCIBLE WHILE YOU GET UP (you can't dodge while getting up on the ground), or you could equip a weapon that attacks faster but does little to no damage to those enemies, and to make it worse those types of enemies always go in packs of 3 or more.The boss-fights are complete and utter♥♥♥♥♥♥ this is another huge complaint i have, they only have like 3 or 4 attacks max,one when they are close to you, another one when you are far and one special attack. They are extremely predictable but worse of all is that it makes battles boring, it's just attack, dodge, attack, dodge... you get the idea.Issue 3: Exploration and the landscape.For a game that it's said to be based on dark souls is very suprising to find that they didn't implement one of the best things in the dark souls games, the exploration. It's an extremely linear game with barerly any exlploration at al and when it does offer you a chance to explore, it ends with a room whitout nothing in there or an item, it never goes beyond this and it's extremely frustating.The places you go in the game are not very inspiring either, they look like they just look at hellish monsters and places, while they at first look inspiring, it quickly becomes clear that it's the only theme you will see with the monsters.Issue 4: ChallengeOne of the most nerving things about this game is that unlike other games that provide a hard challange, but are fair is that they give you enough room to prepare and learn from your mistakes, this game does not, it's not a challenge to be thrown in a room where you will get constantly killed by a monster that takes 100 hits to kill while it kills you in 1 or 2 hits, and to make it worst he has other monsters that chase you and want you dead, just so can drive you ♥♥♥♥ing insane, if this was, you know optional i would say, meh it's not worth it, but when the game does this 3 or 5 times it gets really on my nerves, so no this is not a challenge it's ♥♥♥♥ing unfair.So no, i will just continue to play dark souls, which is what i should be doing in the first place.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												After a year of being unable to play this game, I finally played it today, and I'm rather disappointed.Story: 3/10 - The story is very close to non-existent. You play a hardcore criminal named Harkyn who was conscripted to defeat the bad guys and keep them from doing what all bad guys do - dominate or destroy. When the game first starts, you're thrown into the middle of cutscene that has no real solid foundation. Cool visuals, but you have no idea what's going on. Once the cutscene finishes, you build your character (simple decisions of starting equipment and magic spells you want to be able to unlock), and then, without any sort of information or story events leading up to it, you're suddenly in the room of some tower with some scholarly type guy and you're looking for some other guy who is apparently "The Guy."The story is all over the place, assuming there was a story in the first place.Gameplay: 4/10 - Basically a spiritual clone of the Dark Souls games (only difference is that you can pause, when all is said and done.) There's talk of fantastic, powerful attack combos, but each weapon only really has one or two attacks, and it's either rapid swining, or slower swinging that doesn't really do much more damage. Nothing comboish about it. The Gauntlet is supposed to be your magical long ranged attacks. Good for doing a chunk of damage to an enemy, but, unless you use a magic energy shard, which you don't ever have many of, you can only shoot the gauntlet maybe once every 30-60 seconds. Utterly useless against bosses. Of course, I wasn't specializing in magic attacks, but I doubt they're much better in a Magic build. You also lose all your experience when you die, and have to run and grab that experience without dying again - because the huge chance that you'll lose all your progress is just so appealing these days. Sure, you can put in all the experience into a checkpoint crystal, but those aren't around every corner like Starbucks. This game is only for the masochist at heart.Visuals: 6/10 - Not the best looking game, but it does look pretty awesome. Weather effects and environments are pretty cool. Other than that, just about all the environments in most games these days are pretty cool, so LOTF doesn't really bring anything breathtaking to the picture.In the end, Harkyn's an anti-hero you really have no desire to connect with, the enemies are needlessly tedious to fight, chances are you're not going to find any equipment worthwhile if you go the Light Armor/Deception route (That's basically the rogue build)..... not really a fun mix of crap at all.Overall: 4/10 - Could've been something. Had a lot of potential, but the devs just made bad design choices and couldn't quite pull off what they managed to put in. Definitely not worth the year wait. Or the $50.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												 Dark Souls Lite has all the real Dark Souls taste you've come to know and love with only half the Souls for those who are watching their soul intake. You know exactly what you're getting. You're getting a game that saw how popular the Dark Souls style game was and quickly made their own. It's not as good. That's just a fact. If you're looking for more Dark Souls, just play Dark Souls again... But if Dark Souls was just a little too subtle for you and you felt it would have benefited from a more overt plot, you should give it a go. I'll be the first to admit I never finished this game. I enjoy taking my time in games like Dark Souls, but with this I felt like I was losing time, not spending it. If you're a hipster and Dark Souls is just too damned mainstream for you or if you just want to branch out and try something similar but not identical, you'll have a good time... Or in the case of the hipster, you'll do mental knot tying to convince yourself you're having a better time than people playing Dark Souls and be sure to tell everyone about it.

number of helpful: 25 of 52 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Lords of the Fallen is an action rpg that plays very similarly to Dark Souls though it's a considerably better looking and also a lot more forgiving game. The boss battles i fought before the game got unplayable was very predictable and too passive which makes them too easy to defeat but it doesn't mean you can just slash away and hope to defeat them, the bosses still have attack patterns you must learn to defeat them just like Dark Souls and that in itself makes it feel rewarding just not to the extent of Dark Souls.Lords of the Fallen isn't a straight copy of Dark Souls however and tries to have more focus on the story and have more interactions between Harkyn and npc's to mixed results since the dialogues are often uninteresting and awkward much thanks to the less than stellar lip sync and facial/body expressions which could have used a lot more work to be more natural and the story is nothing to write home about either since it's the usual save the world from demons (Rhogar) that have been done so many times before and better, a generic story is not always a bad thing but it needs to stand out imo  because it have been done so many times and this game fails to do it for me personally.I would argue that yes the story in games like this is less important than the gameplay and therefore i could have overlooked it if the rest of the game was well done but more of that later.As for the main character Harkyn, you are an criminal that tries to atone for his past crimes and while there's potential in that i couldn't connect with him as a character because he feels empty and void of personality it's feels like there's nothing that drives him which obviously his strive for atonement and will to save the world does but the game fails to make that connection with the player.Now to the most important aspects of the game, gameplay and perfomance which i expected a lot from but was left disappointed. I really wanted to like this game and that it would be a worthy rival to Dark Souls and for all it's faults i really liked the gameplay WHEN it WORKS then it feels heavy, satisfying and impactful just like it should but every know and then it gets stuck in it's clunkiness and unresponsiveness and forces you to click several times to strike your enemy and dodge an attack which often makes you miss or fail to dodge in time almost like the animation for it is too slow, also the lock on feels very unprecise and could use more tweakes.Now to to the main offender it's performance which is absolutely horrible, very disappointed and the day one patch didn't do anything for me personally, the game feels very sluggish even when the fps is fine and add constant crashes to that which made me give up when i got to  the commander boss, 7 tries and 7 crashes and 5 of those was near the end of the battle, gg CI gg not acceptable at all and Lords of the Fallen is just another in a long list of broken games that's been rushed out lately and my total playtime yet ended with a staggering amount of 40 crashes.For that reason i can't recommend this game for full price and will wait for a bunch of patches, maybe then it will finally reach some of it's potential and be a fun game, there's a lot of potential in this game but the edges feels way too rough right now.Current Score: 4/10- but if they patches the performance and tweak the gameplay a bit to make it smoother and more responsive then i will happily raise the score to a 7/10 a good but flawed game.Last Words: the score may seem low but be aware this is from my experience with the game and might differ from yours but with these many crashes/bugs it feels unplayable atm and thus i can't justify to spend full price on it until it's sorted out.

number of helpful: 13 of 28 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												I bought this game on release day, I paid full price. You may notice I only have 0.1 hours on it, that's because I can't get further than the Nvidia splash screen without it crashing. I've tried EVERYTHING to fix it. I upgraded my ram (I was excited and thought it'd be worth it), I verified the game hundreds of times, re-downloaded it just as many and I've tried launching the game with commands to skip the cutscene or at a lower resolution and much more.Had enough of trying, it's been over a month and it's costed me more than it's worth.Specs:i5-4670k8gb 1833mhx Hyperx RamAsus Matrix Platinum 280xCrucial 250gb SSDGigabyte Z97 DS3HEDIT: I had to re-install Windows 8 so everything was wiped and I installed new drivers, I managed to get to the menu. I will play the game and add onto this review.EDIT: I've played the game for a bit now, if I could I'd bring it up to a neutral review. The inital effort of getting this game to work has turned me off it but the gameplay is quite good!Things to note:- Nice looking game- Combat feels heavy and patience in combat pays off- Quite a lot of items and weapons, there's varity- The magic was fun to use, there's quite a few different types in the game- Bosses seem to take forever to die, requires a patient gamer. Is not the same 'feeling' as a Dark Souls boss! Maybe I'm rubbish though.- May have been inspired by Dark Souls but it really isn't the same, it's different enough to stand on its own- This is definitely a game worth getting in the sales, I would not buy it at full price knowing what I know now.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												I bought this game charmed by the trailers. When I start playing it was like its fine, graphics are good mechanics do its job. As soon as I made my progress in game I saw a lot of influence of games like DarkSiders, Dark Souls etc but unfortunately with a bad performance. As we progress the plot is simply shallow I seriously hoped for more. The "Choices" that you make barely influence the gameplay only cinematics in end game changes. The ending is just a big disapointment cinematics made in the style of Fallout series, there could be much more about it!Boss fights are pattern like all along and boring some casual creatures gave me more trouble than some bosses...The Great plus is hack and slash type of gaming and graphics rest need a serious re-do. The skill tree for each class is to small. 4 main "spells" when you play NG+ you have another 4 skills from another class but game just gets boring as I progress (made brawler then assasin). The only thing that is chalenging in this game is try to beat it without checkpoints and thats all. The whole idea of a game is great packed in nice graphics but game needs a lot of development in plot and boss mechanics. If You didn't play darksiders or darksouls this game will look ok but if you want to spend money and you consider games I mentioned above buy one of DS.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Where do I start ? The graphics engine is very, very poor optimized. And the graphics are like DARKSIDERS (a 2010 game). But Darksiders is a MARVELOUS game and LoF is crap... I refuse to coment on Dark Souls comparations because it´s like comparing water and wine... The sounds are... Where the sounds are ? I really don´t know.... Playability and level design are ok, at least. But the controler response are erratic, the game frames freeze at times (and you die) and, in the end, it´s irritating. The first boss are ridiculous, your weapons are a joke, you move like "slow motion" EVEN whithout armor... It´s VERY frustrating to play games like this if you like games like Darksiders or Dark Souls. Do yourself a favor and don´t buy this.- Enemies just teleport to places. They just "appear" out of nowhere. Very annoying.- Rolling sucks. A LOT. Many times you will roll in the wrong direction - or will be stuck in a corner or a wall.- Magic bar bug - no fill above 80%.- Save bug - sometimes you will save in a way that you will die in a loop. You will lost ALL your progression.- Enemies STAMINA - I think there´s NO STAMINA to Enemies, because they can beat you, defend, roll, and kill you and they even blink....- STAB Power - You will have to wait A LOT to be capable to use this and... It MISSES half of times. Its ♥♥♥♥ing RIDICULOUS !- Magic bar is very, VERY SLOOOOW.... Gauntlet is useless....- Gameplay - If your build is a TANK with a MASSIVE armor and a very BIG WEAPON, the game is so easy.... other way around, if you like to play a "agility" build...you are ♥♥♥♥ed ! There´s no balance. You only have one choice: go Tank, or be a weakling....- ONE hit kill... you WILL be very angry. Believe me !- Very confuse world. There´s no map AND you get lost so easily....- Crashes. A lot....

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Dark Souls Lite: Prepare to Crash EditionPros:-Looks pretty-A slightly more forgiving soulslike, generally (see cheesy enemy types below)-Interesting leveling/loot system in theory-Combat feels weighty, if a bit slowCons:-Crashes frequently-Some enemy types are walking blocks of cheese, and the best way to deal with them is with even more cheese (hurr durr shield charge)-Game heavily leans toward a str/heavy/turtle playstyle (hurr durr shield charge)-Said shield charge is wonky as hell, leaving you standing there next to an enemy with your♥♥♥♥♥♥in your hand half the time-Crashes frequently-Combat and movement feels a bit slow/sluggish for a soulslike-Annoying leveling/loot system in practice-Save system was recently nerfed, compounding the annoyance of the leveling/loot system-Terrible voice acting and writing (though kind of expected tbh)-Did I mention this game crashes frequently?I really wanted to like this game, but it was quite disappointing.  If you can find it in the $10-15 range, I'd say it's worth giving it a shot if you're into the Souls games, otherwise you might want to just pass.  It's hard to justify spending more than that with the frequent crashes, lack of MP, and relatively short playtime (10-20 hours), though there is ng+ if you're a glutton for punishment.  I will give this game another shot down the road probably, and hopefully most of the issues and kinks will have been worked out by then.

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												For those who didn't play Dark Souls much, if at all ( i didn't i was gonan smash my computer that game was so difficult) This game take from DS in terms of difficulty, though tones it down a notch. And makes the combat nowhere near as tedious. Combat is still kinda tricky sometimes, as stamina plays the biggest role in it and with switching a single gear item, your char could go from fairly agile, to a ♥♥♥♥ing slug in a second. this i've found is the most difficult part of the game, managing speed and attack. At the start of the game you can 3-4 hit enemies and they die. After the 2nd boss, which isn't very far in, you can no longer rely on those tactics. Enemies with shields become promonent and, for me, some encounters can take 5 minutes to complete. AND then you got 2 guys coming at you at once, and the attack patterns get all ♥♥♥♥ed and its hard to read enemies. For me, this is the hardest modern game i've played, and enjoyed playing. DS was too unforgiving and tedious for me to care for. But LotF find a right spot i think.Caution: If you are not a fan of dying alot in the same area, 40 seconds after you respwan, for like half an hr at a time, don't get game. It will happen at some point.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												A beautiful game with gorgeous environments that tries - and utterly fails - to be Dark Souls. Weapons swing too slowly by far, and enemies recover from strikes - both their own and staggers - far too quickly. Environments are crowded and character models are far too large for said environs. Bosses are larger enemies with enormous health bars and quick recovery from animations. All in all, its more exercise in frustration, than challenge. I recommend most fans - and especially those who came for more tight Souls like game play - avoid this title. Hopefully many of the weapon speed and animation recovery issues will be fixed in a patch, but barring that, skip this and go back to Dark Souls or its sequel, as both are far superior to this blatant clone.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												NOT A SOULS GAME. Now if this wasnt being called " a Souls game" It would have been better.Enemy AI is dumb as all they do is block and strafe side to side makeing SINGLE LOW-CLASS MOB BATTLES go on for MINUTES on end. I for one, dont like this idea. There are ways to break their guard (like chargeing with your sheild up) but they have such a fast recovery time its nearly impossible to get a hit off with your greatsword of heavy weapon before they bring their sheild up again (and dont even talk about useing a faster weapon as they deal so little damage it'll take just as long to fight them). This DOES add to difficulty but not in a good way. Bosses on the other hand, are REALLY dumb as much as you can bait nearly all of them into doing a single move where you can just dodge and hit. Very Underwhelming. I have yet to beat game but i can already tell its not going anywhere different with this setup.Oh and the bugs. ITS VERY BUGGY. Wait till an update or a patch before buying it. So many bugs from, the game just crashing on start up to, my Mouse just not working in the Status screens. Makeing it VERY Annoying to level up.On the GOOD side (which isnt  much), It looks very good. LOVE the way it looks, the cloth physics and the shine. Its very fun to look at.I dont normaly write reviews but after i had bought into the hype of this game being a "Souls" game, I was VERY disappointed and i felt like i needed to get this off my chest. So take mine for what you want either it for being nonsense or just plain butthurt.Overall, its an OK game, Just very poorly optimized. I hope they can fix ALL of the bugs in the future, till then it'll just sit in my Game Library Unfinished.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												Some dark forces invade, again. Some guy is released from prison to fight the aforementioned dark forces, again. We don't know what exactly is happening, again. We have to fight an kill every one, again. We die, the sector is repopulated and we try to kill everyone, again. You probably see where I'm getting at, the game is a pretty and somewhat polished collection of clichés  with an emphasis on 1 on 1 (maximum 1 on 3) sword/axe/hammer/etc fight and some magic. The game is similar to the Dark Souls series, with an emphasis on combat and loss of experience in case if you die (no quick saves here). It is a nice action RPG based in a citadel and *drum roll* dimension of the evil invaders. The game will also take some time to get used to controls and some glitches.Pros:•	Sometimes interesting battles•	Reflexes are important•	Audio/video quality of the game is 9/9•	some battle realismCons:•	somewhat glitchy controls and camera•	no map (yep, you have to memorise the locations)•	battles become systematic once you learn the enemy types•	boss fight are often frustrating because of controls, and become easy once you figure out bosses' fight patternAll in all this is a solid mid-tier action RPG, it is not worth the full price, so I can only recommend it for $20-25 if you have 12-20 hours to kill.One Grumpy Russian score: 6 out of 10 - not as tempting as vodka, but an a nice alternative when you have none and have no mood for Dark Souls.For more reviews join: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ogrreview/

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												This game on the surface looks beautiful, but unfortunitly it has at least three major flaws (besides the known technical issues) that really take the fun out of the game.1) The big issue for me was the combat. In Lords of the Fallen, all, and I do mean ALL of the combat is based off of timing. This means that combat moves pretty slow and feels clunky and one tries to position the enemy into just the right spot and then waits to swing the weapon. Weapons are fairly heavy in this game and so they take a good amount of time to swing, which means one has to mentaly calculate how long it is going to take you to swing your weapon, how long your enemy is going to take to swing his, and then determine the window of oppertunity. This leads to an awkward period in which on is trying to judge all of these things...in really slow time since the weapons are heavy. I know other games do similar things to this, but once agian the apparent weight of the weapons makes this feel like it is going on forever. 2) The second big issue for me was the weapon leveling system (and really the whole leveling system in general). The only way to improve a weapon in this game is to add a ruin to it, and hope that the weapon you want to add the ruin to is one that you can add a ruin to. See why this is annoying yet? What makes it worse is that the ruins only add special effects, and don't really do much to the damamge base damage of the weapon. My problem with this, other than it being anoying, is that it doesn't really allow you any good or even decent way to grind, work, or attempt to make personal approvements to gear up for a boss or tough enemy. The leveling system doesn't help either as the complex load out and multitude of essentialy useless options means there are plenty of places to put skill points but very few that seem to help. 3) The story. Its just bland and at times can be a bit hard to follow. I know I didn't get terrebly far into the game, but after three bosses, you would think one would at least have a vegue idea as to why one is trying to fight these bosses. Or at least why one fought the bosses I did fight. I watched the cut scenes and all I know is that nobody likes monks and demons are bad. The story just bores me.Despite the beauty and great graphics of this game I just can't recomend it. I should also not that I never experianced any of the technical issues many other users have, but I'm using an MSI GT72 Dominator Pro so...that may be something to think about. Anyway, I just don't think its worth the hassle.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												Completely misses the point of the Souls series.- Combat is unfair, tedious, badly designed.- Enemies are uninspired and have gimpy attacks. Example: Fat enemy with crossbow/traps/fire grenades with 1 inch long legs moves faster and hits harder in melee than your ironclad knight character. He also seems to have no problem leaping 20 meters back the moment you start to swing your weapon (which takes 5 hours to complete). He can also do this consecutively without getting tired. Ever. And then he smashes your face in while you're recovering. Twice.- Backstabbing mechanic is clunky and rarely works when it should.- Objectives are unclear.- You have no idea where you need to go (mapping isn't done well).- You can't distinguish anything, everything looks too similar, too much of the same debris everywhere.- Side quests are vague and simply badly designed.- Voice acting seems robotic. Pre-recorded text and slapped here and there, no 'emotion' or 'reactive' dialogue whatsoever.- Characters are bland and one dimensional.- Skills are uninspiring.- Casting skills takes a ridiculous amount of time.- Casting a skill and getting hit during bugs things out. You sometimes get the benefit of the skill without triggering it's Cooldown or using Mana. Unintended bug, but is actually really useful for the player when it happens.- Fighting the simplest enemy can take 5 minutes because of the way combat is designed.- Company intro cinematics take a very long time.- In fact, everything takes a ridiculous amount of time.- Company intro cinematics cannot be skipped nor disabled.- Weapons / gear seem bland. They feel very similar to eachother, no real variety.- Difficulty curve is all over the place. Sometimes you get roflstomped by the simplest mobs, but the boss's heaviest attack does only 10 damage against you.About the controller:- Cannot disable controller vibration.- Control schemes are unintuitive.- Cannot set your own control scheme, and there are only 2 to choose from.- Made me spent my time to write a negative review.On to the good things:+ Looks quite good graphically.+ Another contestor for Souls like gameplay.+ Greatly displays how much Dark Souls could have sucked, but didn't.+ Makes you appreciate the Souls series even more.+ They tried. Did they? With a few changes in design this game could already have been so much better than it is now, so I'm not even entirely sure.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												If you are a fan of dark/demons souls then you might enjoy this game. Visually appealing with a gothic theme. The combat is slower than that of the Souls series', however, it is enjoyable. In some aspects the atmosphere is better than in the souls games. The armor and weapon design is artistic, definetely not bland or simple for most. The sound design and voice acting is quite good and plays a very large part in setting the tone of the game and it's environments. The spells are interesting, but lacking. When you pick a spell class (ie mage rogue or warrior) you are stuck with those spells and cannot get the others, I could be mistaken, but I havent been able to do this. The upgrade system through the use of runes is pretty basic. No fast travel capabilities despite having many instances in the game where you are tasked to backtrack a long distance to a previous area. Overall this game is pretty good and is worth a buy in my opinion.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Alot of the combat in this game is waiting, as nearly everything has a sheild that you cant break past. The first 2 bosses are examples of long fights that are only long because of their sheilds; and this can create the illusion of difficulty but its just waiting. Where as Darksouls always have a way for speeding this process up, with increased understanding of boss mechanics. But in this game it is alot of attack baiting (And not the fun kind, Prepare for epic side stepping action!)As the games combat is similar to Darksouls, people will create comparisons between the two. But for darksouls fans I dont think you will like this game, not that it is trying to BE Darksouls and I am not criticising the game for that. But alot of this game seems very sloppy (As an example there is no camera reset button, meaning you always trying to center your character in the screen after walking around corners. Which gets very annoying.) As a recommendation I would wait for a steam sale before picking this game up. Not a bad game just not worth the current asking price.6/10.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Quite average with quite a few quirks already (and I am not much more than an hour in). If you were planning to buy this, I do recommend it, but not for the current price. It may be more worthwhile for about €15.00.I'm recommending it as a "no", not because I think it's worthy of a no, but because it is not worthy of a yes. This game does a lot of things wrong in my eyes, and is not all that interesting. I find the story and controls difficult to grasp. and the tutorials are awfully average. The enemy positioning and aggro ranges are odd and the "stealth" system is silly. The game doesn't hold you by the hand, and as result ends up explaining a lot of elements very, very poorly.But in the end I am still not having a bad time - just not a great one either. There are a few comical elements to this game and it doesn't feel particularily bad to walk around in cool armour. But that seems to be the key selling point of the game - that everything looks cool. I can't add much to the story yet, but it doesn't seem all that impressive either.With the footage that I have seen, the playtime that I've put into this game, and the research I have done, I am fairly confident in my judgment that this game (for now) is better left in the shelves until it gets seriously cheaper.In the end, you may have more fun watching someone else play through this than play through it yourself. I definitely recommend you do research when you are considering buying this game, and if you do, buy it on a discount.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Dark Souls is my favorite game. This game is pretty bad. The combat may look similar, but it really isn't. It feels slow mo, not "heavy". The moves are nonsensically slow. There is no waiting for an opportune moment to strike or countering an enemy attack. There is only stunlocking, and back stabbing. Bossfights are too easy unless they are just broken. The magic is complete trash. All of it, and every aspect of it should be removed entirely. I played through Demon Souls, Dark Souls, and Dark Souls 2 multiple times. I got through 3 bosses in this game (much faster I might add) and am labeling this game as garbage.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												Pretty decent dark souls copy. The biggest plus is the weapon system, it might seem really slow at first but once you get the hang of it, it actually makes a lot of sense. The weight of armor and weapons is shown in the characters behavior. What I really liked about that is that some weapons have to be double handed to be able to use, so no double wielding giants hammers in this one, or even double wielding anything bigger than a short sword for that matter.Voice acting and animations are not to good but do the job just fine. Story is very forgettable and doesn't make to much sense, and the lenght of the game is just not enough. Took me 15 hours to complete which is not by far enough for a SP rpg with quiet a bit of backtracking. Graphics look really nice but the environment is so similar in all areas it loses it's appeal a bit later on. Armor and weapons on the other hand look great!The Boss fights are where the game shines, they are challenging and different from one another.I enjoyed it.7.5/10.
