number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												After completeing the game in only 15 hours, it appears obvious just how much of a rush job this game really was. Poor quality through out the entire game. Lack of enemy variety, clunky combat system and awful sound effects make this game a real bore to play. I pretty much forced myself to playthrough this just to see where it would lead.I have nothing positive to say about this game, it has no redeeming values. Even if you buy this for $5 you aren't going to have a good time. Not even an okay time. This isn't just mediocre, it's poorly executed and riddled with bad design.I can't say I experienced any moment of fun. Everything this game tries to do, other games have done better. You might think "well it looks pretty good at least" it really doesn't. To get this game to run at around 45 fps i had to turn off EVERY graphical option and set textures to Medium at 720p. It runs horribly on a brand new gaming PC that runs other current gen games at 60+ fps on 1080p. So needless to say, it looked pretty bad for me.Sound effects are terrible as well. There's about 3 weapon sounds in the game and you will hear them a million times. They don't sound powerful or realistic at all. Many missing sounds for a lot of enemies and environmental things. Cutscenes often feel like they are lacking sounds or the sounds are too quiet or just don't match what you are seeing. I turned the music off because I thought it was pretty awful too. Some of the boss music sounds like a parody of symphonic music and doesn't feel intense at all. The tracks that aren't completely awful are generic at best.It's not a very difficult game either and that's coming from someone who created the worst build possible. I put all my points into HP, MP, stamina and equip load. (I did this because I was under the impression that there would be plenty of faith-scaling weapons since i had one very early in the game) This meant that I couldn't use 90% of the weapons and shields. While I had good defense, probably too much considering I barely took damage in the later half of the game, I couldn't use any weapons or block effectively. I two-handed a weak staff for the first half of the game which took forever to kill anything. Than I finally got a good faith-scaling weapon, grinded super easily and eventually found a super low strength requiring sword that dealt way more damage than the 3 faith weapons i found in the entire game. So i used that for the end game areas.With that, you can get an idea of how poorly balanced the game is. Later weapons in the game completely replace early game weapons as the scaling is completely useless for most weapons. There is no upgrade system either, just a rune slot system for weapons, shields and armor and only the higher strength and agility weapons have slots so none of the weapons i used through out my playthrough had any slots. a completely useless system that i never even got to experience outside of giving my armor extra defense.Bosses are so bad in both design and gameplay. Some are completely broken such as getting stuck in walls or in one case I had a boss completely stand still the whole time as I slowly chipped away at his massive health pool. Most of the bosses have a ton of health so it can take ages to kill them but luckily they are very slow and predictable doing the same moves over and over again. Rolling is mostly useless in this game so you can't roll through most boss attacks so it's a waiting game, you just have to wait for that split second after they perform a combo to get a hit or two in, back away and repeat. This "technique" will work on every boss in the game even though it is extremely tedious and with the final boss, there's barely any oppertunities to safely get a hit in. Most of the bosses will ALWAYS knock you down when they hit you, even with heavy armor and really high poise. Ground pounds are very common and will knock you down from a good 15 feet away from the boss.Another example of poor quality is the overabundance of glitches and bugs. It almost seems like nothing really works as fully intended. Hitboxes can be really messed up, getting hit from attacks that don't make physical contact with you or in some luckier cases, boss attacks going right through you but you recieve no damage. If you are casting a spell (which you only get 4 in the whole game) and you get hit towards the end of the long animation, you will recieve the effect of the spell but lose no MP. This made healing during boss fights really easy so I didn't have to rely on potions too much. Slidy collision detection makes walking on stairs really weird. The lock on system is bogus, barely functional. You have about a 10% chance of being able to change target when locked on. Sometimes the camera won't even face the enemy you are locked on to but you still walk toward the enemy, this killed me in quite a few areas involving pitfalls.Level design. It's there and it involves lots of switches, back tracking and locked doors. Early areas aren't so bad, they seem pretty average at first but then you get to the middle of the game and it just gets worse from there. Narrow cooridors, enemy ambushes, floating blocks and jumping across gaps as well as pitfalls galore. Many times I had to look up a guide to find out where to go because progressing through the later game is so convoluted. You need to pull several levers to open one door sometimes, or to move some blocks around to progress. This isn't exactly obvious when you will see a switch next to a gate and expect that switch to do something. You pull the lever, nothing happens. What?!Despite all these problems, I still didn't die too much. Most of the time it felt pretty cheap when I did die. Enemies like the mages can drain your HP really quickly, shoot really fast magic that deals huge damage and knocks you down, cast a buff that drains your stamina and every time you hit them, it deals equal damage to you, these guys can end you very quickly. There are checkpoint crystals in rooms with 3 enemies sometimes so as soon as you die and respawn you are getting attacked. Getting cornered by 2 enemies with greatshields and repeatedly attacks results in no posibilities of survival. Speaking of greatshields, you can't kick through them, attack through them or do ANYTHING to counter them. If you do stagger them, you won't even have enough time to get a SINGLE hit in with how slow these weapons are. Only way I could kill them is with magic which seem to go right through their shields making them easy. Otherwise you would be screwed.The story, ha. It's run of the mill and has poor voice acting and writing. Some of the worst stuff I've seen. Awkward animations that keep repeating when npc's are talking combined with non-existent personalities makes none of the characters appealing or relatable. Even after seeing the ending of this game, I didn't have a clue what I had really done in the game plotwise. I don't even know who the final boss was, just kinda there. I assume it was a certain character but it's never explained why there's a big demon beastie as the final boss. Also plotholes as you can expect. How do the [end game enemies] know I supposedly betrayed them? Nothing here really makes much sense and the world is so generic and boring you won't really care.I think that just about covers everything. The TL;DR version is: don't buy the game. It's garbage. No, really. Don't even think about it. I don't care if it's on sale, it's bad. Really bad, probably much worse than you can imagine. You like Dark Souls? That's cool and all but this is nothing like it. Not even a low budget version of it, it's more like if you had taken Dark Souls and shattered it on the ground and tried to reassemble it but you have several large chunks missing and it just looks hideous. That's Lords of the Fallen.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												It`s like Dark souls Butt.After reading a couple of reviews of this in the steam comments and on the interwebz a singular frase seemed to pop out in every discussion about Lords Of The Fallen.It`s like Dark souls but..........So far i am not impressed with this game.So it tought i would recap som things using the new It`s like Dark souls but meme:Fighting mechanics is like dark souls but worse. Slower reaction from input, less advanced moveset etc.Enemy AI and moveset is like dark souls but, more predictable and less varied.Difficulty is like dark souls but not because its hard to master but because bosses have high HP and do a lot of damage. Thank god the AI is a predictable retard.Controls are like Dark souls but, no they are actually almost identical(360 gamepad).Atmosfere is like dark souls but it`s not, it`s just not really there at all.Story is like Dark souls but, its a lot of the same only with constant narration.Game mechanics and number of bugs in general is like Dark souls except its worse and has more bugs.Overall this game IS a lot like Dark Soul, but it isn`t a new better more advanced version of dark souls. It actually playes worse than Demon soul`s  and that`s 5 years old now,In summary i would like to quote something i read in another online review."Its like Darks Souls, but it is its own game"This pretty much sums up my opinion of this game, It is its own game, but it is by far a worse game than any of the dark Souls series.So if you are a fan of Dark souls like me you probably won`t like this game, however if you have never played dark souls and or did not like it. This game might be more to your taste. Not worth full prise tough so try and get it on sale.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												Always disliked blatantly comparing with another game but Lord of the Fallen shows no restraint in trying to say: "Hey! I can be like Dark Souls! Look how much recoil is in our melee strikes and position of enemies give an unfair advantage!"I can overlook that because if the game is enjoyable then great. What I can't overlook is poorly optimized engines that struggle to stay above 60 when there is no reason why it should break a sweat. The deliberate clunkiness of your character is almost to the point of insulting. When I swung my weapon for the first time I almost laughed that this hulking guy takes almost 3 full seconds to attack, You know...attack, that thing that is expected of you to do THE ENTIRE TIME. Mind you this was a one-handed mace...not a 2 handed hammer with an anvil attached.Story...I don't know I had no interest as the characters are plain and boring. There are audio logs to find but it just gets in the way with the game's only reprieve...being exploration. That's probably the reason I kept with the game for as long as I did. It is rewarding to search through sections and revisit areas for newly opened paths. This almost always leads to new items and what player doesn't like new stuff?The visuals are nice, I'll give it that...using some stupid Nvidia exclusive software crap that makes windy wind look more windy or something.I dislike to bandwagon but yeah...this game is desperately trying to use the Dark Souls formula to net sales. It had potential but falls flat on it's slowly moving clunky♥♥♥♥♥♥Can't recommend.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
General GameplayLords Of The Fallen is a third-person action RPG where we play as Harkyn a convicted criminal to save the world from the Rhogar threat.Both the character and weapons feel extremelly heavy in the beginning, but with proper gear and weight management this is easielly fixed.We are limited in terms of classes (warrior, cleric and rogue), but makes total sense considering the narrative of the game.Much like Dark Souls, this is a game that requires patiente to study the enemies and exploit their weaknessesGameplay Rating: 3/5EngineFledgeGraphics OptionsThe game has all the options we could have asked for.Graphics QualityOne of the first next-gen games that hit the market, and lives up to it.PerformanceIt's cursed with performance problems due to NVidia (Gameworks), the game forces PhysX that cripples performance on both AMD (specially) and NVidia builds.Even though it was stated by the developers you can disable PhysX, this is a lie. PhysX is coded deep into the game engine, and even with PhysX disabled the particles show traces of PhysX rendering.Engine Rating: 3/5Overall Rating: 6/10NotesOverall rating is a combination of the gameplay (mechanics and story) and engine (how the game looks and runs). If you disagree with my take on the game or if something is factually incorrect, please leave a comment below!

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. It looked so awesome.I really expected the characters to have some hulking power behind them. Expected to feel like every swing of my sword had an awesome force, and my shield would feel heavy, yet responsive.But alas. Whilst the atmosphere is really great, everything else is a miss. The controls are clunky, and your shield does very(!) little to block incoming blows. seems like half the time i would block, and the enemy would still hit "around" my tower shield somehow.The enemy targeting is cumbersome and unresponsive, and it is very difficult to switch targets during lock - a HUGE problem when multiple enemies spawn.Finally, the enemies. Granted, i've only played a few hours, but i've only seen 4 or 5 enemy types. Same, same, same, all the time. Makes the game feel slow and just not worth it.I REALLY hope they make a Lords of the Fallen 2, and fix all these issues.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												I was told this game is "Dark Souls done wrong". I had no problem with that, I wanted to like it for what it offers on it's own. I didn't think it was fair to make the comparsion, despite the game clearly wanting to aim for the solid 2nd best position, trying to ride the fame and hype of a genre another game bringed back, lives and profits from in a quite dominant position. And I said, I'm okay with that, it can be a great game because what's inside is what matters the most, not the franchise name burnt on it's box. And still, Lords of the Fallen is just B- in everything on it's own, compared to no other game. You just feel in every moment of it. I picked it up for 3,99 so no regrets here, mainly because I wanted a taste of what Dark Souls games are like and honestly it's only good for that. I haven't played any DS games, but I'm certain they must be better than this. It is a game that is never going to be finished (by me, it's a complete game tho), so overall I still consider it a waste if you buy this game for itself. I bought it for a taste of the DS experience, and it lasted 7 hours, and I feel like this isn't the way to make that work right. With no experience about the DS titles, I know THIS isn't the way to do it right.For this reason I cannot honestly recommend it.The game known as "poor man's dark souls". And I bought it to be that, so can't say I was disappointed with what I got, but the "poor man's dark souls" title speaks for itself. It wants to be something, but fails so, and has nothing else on it's own.1. The combat is incredibly boring. You could say it is supposed to be tactical, but reality is that you have to use a few spells you get with every class, and it's almost always the solution. Or you can look at each other with both shields up and everyone bunkering down for 5 to 10 minutes. With a random filler enemy. Shielded opponent? Whatever class you pick you can either go a) invisible to backstab b) slow down time and walk around c) just send a firey clone of yourself in it's face to explode. You can do workarounds, try interesting special moves with all the weapons, but it gets repetitive incredibly fast due to..2. the lack of cretivity. And this applies to EVERY aspect of the game. I think I have met about 4 types of opponents in the 6,6 hours I spent in Lords of the Fallen. Random "ork guy" with a shield, without a shield, jumping dog type that can breathe unblockable stuff, and crossbow guy. And variations of these, smaller, bigger, sometimes poison, sometimes fire, sometimes thin wizardey sometimes fat guardey, sometimes 4 legs sometimes none. But mechanically there is barely any difference between them and when a game is built like this, with the "less is more" in mind, so you have to fight a really small number of enemies compared to other similar games, the lack of creativity really shows. Same goes for the enviroment, it wants to be Dark Souls gothic so desperately, has a great looking engine to do so, but it just ends up being Darksiders with more blur. With the exception of the very few vistas (I think I've came across 2 under this ~7ish hours) and more unique rooms such as the temple hall at the first boss, it's always the same. Fortress, garden, cave, prison, royality rooms, even a different dimension,  battle hardened or brand new,  ALL looks the same. Not just the atmosphere, but the structural layouts, construction style, even the size of the bricks walls are mostly made of, everything is the same everywhere, and it gets boring. It wants to be Dark Souls, but every new room here is just like the one you came from instead of being something exciting, and outside areas are the same with the exception of not having a ceiling. And the bosses, oh the bosses. As interesting as they seem to be on first sight, you'll realize there is barely any challange there because they are SO BASIC mechanically that only your lack of patience can get you killed. All of them are like they exist in slow motion only, and just a bigger variant of some basic enemy with one or two extra spells and a really boring looks. Have you seen the first DS3 boss, the knight transforming to that darkness-snake thing? That alone has more creative design than everything and anything added together in this game.If you are still interested, you should know that it is a solid PC version, no fps, crash or anything else issues happend. It's not particularly demanding, you should be fine somewhat above the minimum requirements to play it on nearly maxed out settings with good speed.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												I bought this game hoping for something to do before dark souls 3 released. I walked away from this game after only and hour becuase I could not believe how unbelievably bad it was. Sloppy controls mixed with frustrating button layouts. the first two bosses were (if you can even call them that) stupidly easy, and then a bit later on I happen across a spider that kills me in two hits from across the room, through my shield. That was so jarring and I felt♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and annoyed. I tried to fight this spider a few more times and just couldnt kill it and I figured I wasnt supposed to be there. So I moved on from that disaster onto the next area were I find this giant knight with a tower shield who I spend a solid 2 minutes trying to circle around to get an opening and I couldnt, the area was to narrow or he was to ....fast....a tower shield heavy armor wielding knight was to fast to get behind. I decide since I am also a tank class I will try to trade blows, this gets me one shotted. This is a problem, one minute I am recking everything and the next I get one shot. There doesnt seem to be much of a difficulty curve because at least in the first 2 hours was everywere. This game is seriously boring with bad design choices, horrible enemy placement and lackluster animations. I hear it has nice graphics but it has O.K graphics even on ultra. The frames for it being ultra are lower then it should be signaling bad optimization but Im not an expert on that so I wont go further with that complaint. Over all I cant recommend this game to a real souls fan. Its been described as chunky souls but its more then that, its soulless souls too. Get it to try for yourself if you have to get it out of your system but otherwise just wait for DS3. Watch a Lets Play :P I here dsp is halariously fun to watch due to his horrible gameplay. So go watch that instead.
